access_notes: From Woss head south 12km on Highway 19 to the Mt.Cain turnoff and proceed onto the Nimpkish Main south. Travel south 27km on the Nimpkish Main past the Vernon Camp turnoff continuing on the Nimpkish Main until you reach the next left which is the Sutton Road turnoff. Go aproximately 1km on the Sutton Main until you will see the top of the tree above the advanced regen on the south low side of the road.
tree_site_notes:
Tree is showing sings of crown die back due to extreme age. It is growing on flat ground on high bench flood plain above the Nimpkish River near the junction of Sutton Creek and the Kla-anch wetlands. The area has high Elk useage.  The stand is very unique upper valley, CWHmm1 Amabilis dominant stand with multiple Amabalis well over 65m in height and we believed at least 2 may be taller than this nomination, but it is difficult to get the height of the others due to the heavy understory and brush.

The tallest tree previously measured adjacent to these, but now logged, was 248 ft tall. Because of this previously biggest trees loss, Chris Bowden-Green approached John Deal of Canfor to protect the remaining large Balsam within a proposed Elk Winter Range, due to its uniqueness as one of the last remaining old growth valley bottom Amabalis stands.
Coordinates estimated

access_notes: Drive west from Port Alberni. Turn left on Maggie Lake/Toquart Forest Service Road. Turn left after crossing over Toquart River. Continue past Ellswick Lake. Turn left and cross over Lucky Creek and follow road up west side of Black Peaks. Hike/bushwack up main drainage on west side of mountain.

Take Hiway 4 west from Port Alberni. Drive approximately 80km to the Maggie Lake FSR. Turn left and follow Maggie FSR for 11km to Macoah Villagfe turn-off. Keep left on Maggie FSR and drive another 4km to the end of Maggie FSR. Keep left and you are now on Toquaht FSR. Drive 9km to the junction with Lucky FSR. Turn right onto Lucky FSR and drive 2.5km to the junction with Black Peaks FSR. Keep left and follow Lucky FSR for another 2.4km. You will pass two lakes on your right. The second (and larger lake is Kite Lake). Once past Kite Lake, you will come to a major junction. Keep right and continue along Lucky FSR for another 1.4km. there will be a deactivated and brushed in spur road on your right. This is the start of teh rough trail up to Block F004C4DT. Hike up the spur for 700m to a very overgorwn junction. Keep to the left and hike a further 450 m. You will come across some yellow flagging that indicates a rough trail up to F004C4DT. The trail heads upslope from the spur road and is heavy going through an advanced plantation for approximately 150m. Once you reach the Old-growth it is easy but steep hiking. From the end of the flagged trail, continue up slope heading directly south for approximately 170m until you reach the upper falling boundary. The Amabilis fir (5 trees) will be visible both ahead of you and slightly to the right. To reach Cypress, continue angling upslope in a southeasterly direction along the base of the steep rock outcops. You will find C4DT-002 after hiking/climbing for 350m. Tree C4DT is approximately 145m above the first Cypress. Follow the rock bluff uphill (keeping the gully to your left). C4DT-001 is approximately 150m upslope and is situated on a rock knob in a nice open area of timber.
tree_site_notes: C4DT-006 is located in the CWHvm2(01) and is situated mid-slope. The slope (50%) has a N aspect.

access_notes: From Port Alice, follow forest service roads to Gooding Cove. Park as close as you can to Rowley Reefs Recreation Site and bushwack/hike to tree. This is a remote setting and requires routefinding.

Follow the upper creek trail towards the three sisters. It is a prominent, single-stemmed tree visible from the trail and approximately 50m off the left-hand side of the trail, a few minutes before the trail cuts through a giant fallen tree.
tree_site_notes: Straight and healthy, closed-grown tree on rolling valley bottom. Tree is at the edge of an small drop-off, and as such shows some minor butt sweep. First few meters of tree blanketed in moss.

access_notes: Take Hiway 4 west from Port Alberni. Drive approximately 80km to the Maggie Lake FSR. Turn left and follow Maggie FSR for 11km to Macoah Villagfe turn-off. Keep left on Maggie FSR and drive another 4km to the end of Maggie FSR. Keep left and you are now on Toquaht FSR. Drive 9km to the junction with Lucky FSR. C4DT-001 is approximately 150m upslope and is situated on a rock knob in a nice open area of timber.
tree_site_notes: C4DT-007 is located in the CWHvm2(03) and is situated on the upper slope (55%) with a N aspect. This is an area of medium to large colluvium originated on the near-vertical rock face 20m upslope.

access_notes: From the Carmanah Walbran parking lot (access from Rosander Main), follow signs for the Valley Mist trail. Where this trail hits a tee, go right following signs for the heaven tree/Stoltmann grove. Where the trail ends (at the large Sitka spruce with a prominent trailside burl), it tees into a dry creekbed running ~parallel to the active river system (NE - SW). The tree is ~75m heading left down the creekbed, on the right hand side. It can be viewed from points near the end of the trail, and from atop a fallen amabilis fir off to the right of the trail which goes over the creekbed.
tree_site_notes: Near the edge of a dry creekbed. Very narrow and straight, with a pronounced forked crown starting approximately 2/3 up the tree. Both tops are similar in height. Bark covered in moss for several meters. Much of the stem is visible from the vantage points.

access_notes: The tree is located in a large OGMA on the east side of Loup Creek. Park on Gordon River Main just past the Loup Creek bridge and hike along the slopes until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Beautiful, dominant fir with a tight crown growing in a mixed hemlock, Abies, and cedar stand. Gentle E aspect. Sparse blueberry and sword fern understory.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive east on Highway 28 for 7 km to Saunders Main. Turn left onto Saunders Main and drive for 4.9 km. Road has several tight manauvers requiring a narrower vehicle with four wheel drive. Hike uphill into forest navigating to tree.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock and amabilis fir dominated forest. Forest is sloping towards Saunders Creek. Understory contains deer fern, step moss, five-leaved bramble, and red huckleberry.

tree_site_notes: C4DT-005 is located in the CWHvm2(01) and is situated on a small bench mid-slope with a NE aspect.

access_notes: Hike northward along Upper Valley Trail to gps location. The tree is inconspciously in a dense grove about 30m west of trail. - likely not possible to find without gps coordinates.
tree_site_notes: Dense forest and adjacent to trail.

tree_site_notes: C4DT-004 is located in the CWHvm2(01) and is situated on a small bench mid-slope with a NE aspect.

access_notes: Hike Northward along Upper Valley Trail to gps location. The tree is highly visible from the trail, at a point roughly 60m to the south. It is located only about 10m from the trail at the top of an eroding cut bank.
tree_site_notes: Grows on upper bench with other Amabilis fir and some Sitka Spruce. Is located near to a cut bank being eroded by Carmanah River

tree_site_notes: C4DT-003 is located in the CWHvm2(07) and is situated midslope on a small colluvial fan with a near-vertical rock wall approximately 25m to the East. The slope is approximately one of 75% with a N aspect.

access_notes: From Lake Cowichan drive on North or South Shore Roads to Nitnat Main, follow signage for Carmanah PP, follow Rosander Main to 19 km marker
Involves a bushwhack in from the forest service road running along Loop Creek.
Nanoose Transmitter Site, Woodlot #13.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: The tree is near the intersection of Hillgrove Rd. and Sumac Dr. in North Saanich, approximately 150m west of Sumac and 50m north of Hillgrove.  The property is sign posted private property but public access is permitted by Strata #804.
tree_site_notes: The tree branches into three vertical columns at approximately 1.5 meters.  It is in good health.  The terrain is gentle to moderate slope (3-12%) with numerous gaps and openings.   A couple of fir trees are growing up with in its canopy.

access_notes: Right off footpath that runs parallel to East Saanich Road. Easily accessible.
tree_site_notes: Height to dead top 26.2, height to live top 21.2

access_notes: Marina Way
tree_site_notes: This tree has five stems.  Growing almost at tide level, this sprawling tree dominates the beach, and is easily accessed via a short, well maintained trail. Washrooms are available at the trailhead.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  The tree is at 1077 North End Rd.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.

From Thetis Island ferry terminal at Preedy Harbour, follow Foster Point Rd. south for 850 m. Tree is on west side of Rd., 650 m south of Telegraph Harbour turnoff, approximately 30 m north of Highways works yard.
tree_site_notes: Beside roadway; possible damage from vehicles. Crown has been prunned back.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Savory Shores subdivision.  Owner has fenced the tree to protect it.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy.

access_notes: From Mount Parke parking lot, follow main trial until "Giant Arbutus" signs.
tree_site_notes: Large, conspicuous arbutus in older second growth with some remnant primary forest. Tree is leaning heavily but generally healthy. Large basal scar suggests there may have been a second stem at one point that fell off and has since decomposed. Elevated rocky outcropping with low salal and moss understory with Doug-fir, redcedar, and arbutus around.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful healthy arbutus on a flat farm close the ocean.  The tree shades an old cottage believed to have been used by Emily Carr.

access_notes: From the Mt Doug beach parking lot, take the paved trail at the end of the parking lot up towards Cordova Bay Rd. The tree is on the east side of the road between the road and trail just before the crosswalk. Impossible to miss when driving through the park.
tree_site_notes: On the side of the road with a big scar facing the pavement. Hollow in the base but nice full crown and very healthy looking.

access_notes: Metchosin Road to Beach Trail access
To north of trail immediately after entering through Regional Park main entrance.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with minor defects.

access_notes: On unnamed trail 150m from Tower Point parking lot.
tree_site_notes: On bluff edge above Witty's Lagoon adjacent to open field. Crown healthy, scar on inside of fork. Large branch/fork comes off below DBH just above ground.

access_notes: Situated beside the parking lot at the Ferry Landing.
tree_site_notes: none

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  From Lantzville Road, turn right down Sebastion Road, heading for the beach. The tree will be easily visible on your right.
tree_site_notes: During recent water main construction during the last several years, a limb was removed, but this tree remains in excellent health. It’s very popular with local residents.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take accessible trail to the water and turn left onto Crekeye Point trail. Tree is located at the junction where the point trail loops around and splits off to the point.
tree_site_notes: Rotted out at the base on one side and a couple dead lower branches but top seems healthy. Mossy for an arbutus. Crown reaches towards the sea. On the side of the trail and the very edge of a seaside bluff

access_notes: Metchosin Road to Beach Trail access

tree_site_notes: On rich floodplain with cottonwood and white spruce. Understory with Calamagrostis canadensis. Rare lichen (Flavopunctelia flaventior) growing on the large Salix bebbiana.
On rich floodplain with cottonwood and white spruce. Understory with Calamagrostis canadensis.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with low forking branches, massive crown spread, and oval trunk.  The tree is 13 feet (maybe more) at its widest. The crown is wider than the tree is tall.

access_notes: Turn from highway onto Mt Sicker Rd, turn right at Westholme Rd. Look for obscure sign above the left for Eves.
tree_site_notes: Maple had recently been damaged in a winter storm, and had half of the tree spread out on the ground. There remaining tree appeared healthy and ready to put on some more girth.

access_notes:
Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  
Tree is near Dale Rd. and Stave Lake Rd., south west of Durieu.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, thick swollen base. Sitting beside four large firs.

access_notes: Near the San Juan Giant (ID# 175)
tree_site_notes: The most notable feature of this super shaggy maple tree is an enormously long branch the extends roughly 20m out from the trunk of the tree!!

access_notes: Follow Rawlings Trail ~200m south of Hollow Tree to large trailside maple (tree 54). Target tree is visible ~50m east. Follow 2019 gps coordinates, which should be accurate to <6m.
tree_site_notes: 2019 (DBH 3.37, Crown 22.3); 2016 (Ht 32.1, DBH 3.35). Middle slope, straight.  WSW aspect, ca. 10% slope.

access_notes: Immediately adjacent Rawlings Trail, ~200m south of Hollow Tree. Follow 2019 gps coordinates, which should be accurate to <6m.
tree_site_notes: Lots of cobbles on mid slope site. Mostly second-growth conifers believed to have regenerated following Hurricane Freda (1962).

access_notes: Off trail roughly equidistant between Lake Trail, Thompson Trail, and Meadow Trail.
tree_site_notes: Lots of cobbles on mid to upper slope site. Moslty second-growth conifers believed to have regenerated following Hurricane Freda (1962).

access_notes:
Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  
Tree is at 48670 Camp River Rd.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with some rot in center and an unusually massive single trunk.

access_notes: From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Park at the gate and walk south along Dyke Road until you find a place clear enough to enter the forest and bushwhack to the tree. Proceed with caution, as this Island is full of blackberry and bushwhacking is very difficult. Request permission from Bands before access.
This tree is pretty easy to get to from the highway. It's located pretty close to a small turnout, and is not far from the road.
tree_site_notes: There is a big fairy hole in the tree, leading to a hollow interior. The branches sweep around the hole in a way that it almost looks like the tree is dancing. The trunk is akwardly shaped, and its size will very alot with small changes in measurement height. Some lungwort can be found around the tree, indicative of a healthy forest.

access_notes: The tree is right off Lochmanetz Road, within Maple Grove Community Park. There is a fence preventing access from Lochmanetz, and extensive blackberry brambles preventing access from all other sides.
tree_site_notes: The tree is healthy with a massive, sprawling crown. The surrounding site is very rich and extremely overgrown with dense thickets of Himalayan blackberry

access_notes: The tree is located just within Maple Grove Community Park. Coming down the steps from the parking lot, the tree is visible on your right, and can be accessed via a small section of mowed grass towards the end of the park. However, approaching the base of the trees is discouraged by the park.
tree_site_notes: The tree is healthy with a massive, sprawling crown. The surrounding site is very rich and extremely overgrown with dense thickets of Himalayan blackberry

access_notes: North of Tatlow Walk.
tree_site_notes: Old, hollow on north side, large round crown.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property. Tree is located about 50 m from the owner's residence.  Persons wishing to view the tree are requested to contact the land owner at 778 557 7776. The tree is located on a property adjacent to Sayward Road, which is the access road between Highway 19 and the Village of Sayward.  Sayward is located on North-central Vancouver Island, about 80 km North-west of Campbell River. When driving from Campbell River, proceed North on Highway 19 to the intersection with Sayward Rd. (aka Sayward Junction).  Turn right onto Sayward Road and drive 2 km North to 1458 Sayward Rd.  The tree is approximately 300 m down the private driveway.  Permission must be obtained before entering the property.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be healthy.  It has four main trunks, all approximately the same size.  This past winter, a large number of medium-sized branched were broken off due to the abnormally high snowfall. The tree is located on one corner of a cleared field.  The surrounding growth is sparse mixed deciduous and conifer, with most of the Alders logged off 3 to 4 years ago.

access_notes: From South Shore Road in Lake Cowichan, turn onto Cowichan Lake Road towards Duncan. Follow for 2.2km until there is a private driveway on the right side of the road across from a solitary new home on the right side of the road (as of Dec. 2022). Keep going another 100m and there will be a short connector trail from Cowichan Lake Road to the Cowichan Valley trail. The Lumpkin is just off the far side of Cowichan Valley Trail in a small clearing.
tree_site_notes: The Lumpkin is a beautiful, limby maple with a thick, burly trunk that is completely coated in lichens and bryophytes. Standing as it does in a clearing allows a full view of the tree from the trail, even when fully leafed out.

access_notes: Take Highway 18 from Duncan towards Lake Cowichan. Pull off on the north side of the road just before the fire hazard sign. A short scramble up the roadcut leads to gentle terrain, with a 200m hike through a second growth alder and maple forest opening up into a remnant patch of old growth along a seasonal creek. Several large firs >1m in diameter are scattered within a younger cohort of firs, redcedars, and maples.
tree_site_notes: The Bushcamp Maple is a large tree standing near the edge of the old growth here, amongst some western redcedars. The large, branching crowns gives this tree a broad stem.

access_notes: Follow Gordon River Road from Lake Cowichan to Caycuse Main
tree_site_notes: Previously harvested area along Nixon Creek, where the big leaf maples were spared, and all other trees removed, creates a surreal congregation of very old deciduous trees dominating this ecosystem. Tree is estimated to be 240 years old.

access_notes: Turn left after crossing bridge over San Juan River, turn right at wye onto Lens Creek Main, then onto Bear Creek Main. The rec. site is just across the upper San Juan River bridge.
tree_site_notes: Growing near the "San Juan Spruce“, this moss and fern covered tree has been in good company for a long time. Tree is estimated to be 250 years old.

access_notes: Tree on district land south of Seymour Gold Course.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, excellent crown.

access_notes: 10m west from Avison Way, just north of intersection with a trail located about 150m south of Aquarium. Refer to gps coordinates.

From intersection of Wesbrook and Marine Drive, old-growth forest is seen around ravine bowl to the south. This tree is on the right side of the bowl and is not very notable until you see that the highest branch reaches very high.
tree_site_notes: Grows on moderate slope in old forest. Sandy soil with some erosion. Very upright stem for species - forest grown. First branch at 18.7m. Main stem broken at around 30m. Secondary leader reaches upwards into canopy gap and has thick foliage. Good vigour overall. Minor exposure.

access_notes: Drive to end of road at Smelt Bay on Cortes Island. Found in grassy field at entrance to the campground

From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 200 metres up that trail. Tree is on the east side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Growing wedged between rock outcrop, trail, and gully bottom with ephemeral creek. Big lumpy base before branching out at about 7 metres. Wide, gorgeous maple crown to dream of.

access_notes: From the town of Lake Cowichan follow Youbou Road from the junction with Highway #18 for approximately 16 km where a turn to the right is now on North Shore Road. Continue for another 5 km to Maple Grove Recreation Site. The tree is on the right side of the road, not too far from the entrance.
Walk 350 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to junction with Lower Goldstream Trail. Tree is right at the junction.
tree_site_notes: Right at the trail junction, gorgeous rich, wet stand dominated by beautiful maples. Leaning heavily to the trail. One very large branch previously cut by park service.

access_notes: Walk 400 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot towards Goldstream Nature House. Tree is 20 metres off trail on highway side 70 metres before creek bridge.
tree_site_notes: Hidden back from trail at toe slope below highway in rich, wet stand of super tall maples. Dense sword fern and snowberry understory.

access_notes: Seaside Route highway
tree_site_notes: Large arbutus is tucked into edge of forest near campsites.

access_notes: Highway 4
tree_site_notes: Situated near not too well worn, short loop trail that is intentionally leading to the Canoe Creek Cedar beside the Kennedy River.

access_notes: Highway 28
tree_site_notes: On escarpment above the falls. This easily accessible site is only a short walk from the parking lot, where this mist cloaked, mossy beauty awaits.

access_notes: Walk 500 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot towards the Goldstream Nature House. Tree is on the east edge of the trail 50 metres after bridge.
tree_site_notes: Right along the trail in gorgeous rich, wet stand dominated by super tall maples, cedar and fir interspersed.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.4 kilometres along coast trail. Tree is on the left about 100 metres before the next trail junction.
tree_site_notes: Not far from sea cliffs but sheltered by band of firs. Subhygric site with red alder, salal, salmonberry, and lots of stinging nettle. Not very mossy for a maple.
A large bigleaf maple with a split trunk. Half appears to be dead but the other part is alive.

access_notes:
At the corner of Wilson and Reeve St, there is a path that leads up to the Coquitlam River Trail. The tree is right next to the trail 
and clearly visible.
tree_site_notes: Tree is relatively healthy with so much traffic. Grew tall among its fellow trees. Multiple stem tree.

access_notes: From Columbia Valley Hwy., turn west onto Lakeshore Dr., park in Parking Lot A. Cross street to Lake Trail, go to junction with Endo trail fork, tree is 30m to the west.

From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail, then 200 metres up the Copper Mine Trail. Tree is on the west side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Along the ditch edge of trail (old mining road) in wide gully. Broken second leader at two metres, shockingly tall and straight. Seems perfectly healthy.

access_notes:
Park anywhere along the Pitt River Greenway Park trail and follow the path west. The tree is along the river towards the end of 
the trail. Two large Cottonwoods are also close by accompanied by many other cherry, birch, alder and cedar trees
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy leaning out over the Fraser River.

access_notes: Along the trail on the north side of the creek.
tree_site_notes: Two separate trees. The diameter of the largest stem was measured.

access_notes: Tree located just 10m south of the Spirit trail in Moodyville park, City of North Vancouver
tree_site_notes: A healthy tree.

access_notes:
Access is from the trail to Maplehurst Park at the end of Willow Road.
The tree is visible from the trail, but does not have a recognizable trail leading to it yet.
tree_site_notes:
The bitter cherry tree has a fork in log one and a sweep in log two, and some scars.  The big cherry is joined to  a smaller cherry tree above the germination point.  The tree has healthy foliage and good vigor.  Slope: 0-2%,  Aspect: flat.  Thick sword fern, vanilla leaf, Oregon grape, three-leaved foam flower, and red huckleberry.  Mosses: Step moss, Lanky moss, and Oregon beaked moss.  Also maple, alder, Douglas-fir and red cedar.
Ecology:  CWHXM site series 04(80%) 05 (20%)
Moisture and nutrients 2-4/D-E
CWHXM, Costal Western Hemlock, Very Dry Maritime, CWH subzone
Site index is estimated @ 28-30 for this nutrient-rich site.  Windthrow and plellinus root rot.

access_notes: Tree is 200 metres north of the Coast trail on the Parkheights Trail. The shortest/easiest access is from Parkheights Dr.
tree_site_notes: Just off trail in mesic to subhygric salal and sword fern on lower slope receiving water from above. Also possible on edge of old road grade. Appears healthy.

access_notes: Tree is 150 metres north of the Coast trail on the Parkheights Trail. The shortest/easiest access is from Parkheights Dr.
tree_site_notes: On a short hillslope (possibly the formerly scraped edge of a road grade) just above a subhygric bench above creek, mixed salal, goats beard, and sword fern. Seems healthy though several large cherry have fallen nearby

access_notes: The tree is located on the side of Whisky Creek opposite to the fish hatchery. It can be found at the top of the hill on that side of the creek, about 50 meters from the road. Scaling the steep overgrown berm is the fastest way to get to it, although there might be longer, easier ways.
tree_site_notes: Two trees grown together at the edge of a twice-logged bench. Site is moderately productive (CDFmm01) with scattered sword fern and oregon-grape throughout a sparse and dark understory. Abundant recreation trails throughout the area.

access_notes: Drive North on Highway 37A approximately 8 km from Kitimat's City Centre. Turn on first left old logging road just past the major powerline crossing of the highway. Park just off road and walk on quad trail East about 20 minutes to the Kitimat River bearing right at each trail crossing. Walk upriver for 5 minutes and you will see a stand of several old growth spruce trees at a point on a side channel where you will see the tree to the North along the bank.
tree_site_notes: The tree looks like two trees from a distance but there is one clearly defined main trunk well above the DBH. It is in a very small stand of old growth spruce in a floodplain area along the East side of the Kitimat River at a side channel. Recent flooding has left many uprooted trees in a logjam upstream of the tree with some debris from flooding at the base of the tree on the North side. Since we first measured  the tree in April 2024 there have been several major flood events in October and November 2024 and when we returned to see if the tree was still standing about half of the land and trees between the cottonwood and the Kitimat River had been cut away and covered with a large log jam. It now stands about 5 meters from the cut bank at the confluence of a side channel of the Kitimat River. There was sand and debris evidence of floodwaters above the base of the tree trunk. The site is across from the confluence of the Wedeene River on the West side of the Kitimat River. There is a thick layer of humus soil with sand underneath. The foliage around the tree consists of devil's club, willow and various berry bushes. Wolf and bear prints were seen in April 2024 in the sand on the bank of the side channel. There is a very large eagle's nest in the spruce tree beside the black cottonwood and when we first saw the tree there was an eagle in the cottonwood at the height of the nest. The name given to the tree is from this first sighting, Eagle's Edge.

access_notes: Charlaine Boat Ramp is on Nanaimo’s Hammond Bay Road, not far from Pipers Lagoon Park. The tree is visible as soon as you enter the parking lot, and it also overlooks Shack Island (aka Three Lagoon Islands Park)
tree_site_notes: This tree, located at Charlaine Boat Ramp near Pipers Lagoon Park, is a fairly robust specimen. It has three substantial leaders rising from a single stem. Recent maintenance by city crews has included the removal of several limbs in the upper crown for safety reasons and cutting of ivy roots around its base.

access_notes: Turn off HWY 1 in Chilliwack onto Industrial Way, turning West shortly afterwards onto Dyke Crest Road. Park along this road and bushwhack in. Proceed with caution, the area is thick with blackberry.
tree_site_notes: Cottonwood with a huge hollow

access_notes: Near the Sumas River and CNR railway trachs and bridge on Defense (DND) land, west of Chilliwack.
tree_site_notes: Very old and damaged, but living with new leaders.  Tree lost one of five trunks, looks like a multi-trunked giant maple, broken top. CWHdm.

access_notes: From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Park at the gate and walk south along Dyke Road until you find a place clear enough to enter the forest and bushwhack to the tree. Proceed with caution, as this Island is full of blackberry and bushwhacking is very difficult. Request permission from Bands before access.
tree_site_notes: Since last measurement in 1992 this tree has changed by -7.3 m in height, +3 cm in dbh and +80 cm in crownspread.

From Hwy 7, follow Malcom Rd. east, turn right over bridge into Skumalasph Island. At sharp left turn approx. 1.5 km beyond bridge, follow spur road to right. Hike northwest along slough from end of spur. Tree is in grove east of slough.
tree_site_notes: CWHdm

access_notes: Near the Sumas River and CNR railway trachs and bridge on Defense (DND) land, west of Chilliwack.
tree_site_notes: Massive single trunk to broken top with big new leader. CWHdm.

access_notes: From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Tree is located on the righthand side of Dyke Road 500m from the last turn. Request permission from Bands before access.

First Nation Reserve - please contact First Nations for permission.  
From Highway 7, 200 m south of Nicomen Slough bridge, turn east on road for 1 km to dike at Zaitscullachan Slough, turn left and then right across slough. Follow bushy track east for approximately 500 m to big trees. This tree is south of track (10U 5692 54490).
tree_site_notes: River floodplain site.

access_notes: Tree is located just south of the old KVR rail line, the line can be accessed from Highway 7 or from the trail at the end of Landstrom Road (see the trail and topographic access maps).  Near Hope - NTS92 H/6 west side.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Boat access only. Drive up the Nahatlatch River and park near the first lake (Frances Lake). Paddle to a flat of land on the opposite side of the lake and hike to the tree, as per coordinates.

From the Skutz Falls parking lot, follow the Cowichan Valley trail west for about 375m. The tree is about 40m south of the trail. You will need to scramble down a steep slope and cross a small westland to access the tree, so it is best accessed in the summer.
tree_site_notes: A large cottonwood on a slightly raised bench within an old oxbow of the Cowichan River. The tree has several large and broken limbs, but is still very tall and broad, dominating the canopy of the area. The site is rich with abundant moisture, with characteristic CDF/CWHxm floodplain vegetation. Cottonwood, alder, maple, and willow are common throughout, with stink-currant, snowberry, and salmonberry making up much of the shrub layer.
Tree was reported dead and gone in 1999, and alive by Shaun Muc in 2020.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location should be hidden to protect the area.
tree_site_notes: Gorgeous big tree with super heavy moss on one side. Small pile of debris piled on uphill side as evidence of flooding. Edge of forested side and high-bench flood plain, mixed with maple and cedar and some cedar regeneration.

access_notes: Starting at the Furlong Bay Campsite beach, the Twin Spruce (sadly one of the twins has fallen) Trail leads trhough wetlands, a salmon bearing stream and a mature forest for about 2 km in behind the campground.  It is suitable for all ages.  Walk about 30 minutes up the trail toward the highway and on the right you will see Rajas.
tree_site_notes: This large black cottonwood stands right beside a well maintaned gravel trail through an old growth forest of western cedar, western hemlock and Sitka spruce trees.

access_notes: Exiting off of Highway 19A onto Terrain Road, take your first right onto Regent Road. Continue on Regent Road, until you pass over the bridge going over the Oyster River. Once over the bridge, the trail you want to be on is direclty to the left. It is wide and easily seen from the road. There is a small pull out that can be parked on. Across from the streeet (by the telephone pole) there is an older trail sign. You do not want to go down this trail, but that is an indication you are in the correct area. Starting down the trail (on the left), walk for a mere 1-2 minutes and this large black cottonwood will be on your left hand side.
tree_site_notes: The overall health of the tree is excellent with crown and stem intact. Lots of shrubbery below the tree, and it has a very even, continuous, tall stem. It is very noticiable, and stands out amongst other, smaller trees nearby. The ground is very flat.

access_notes: Walk 600 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to Goldstream Nature House. Tree is the tall, shaggy tree just NE of nature house on estuary edge. Sit in a circle on at the benches with friends and enjoy it as another friend towering above.
tree_site_notes: Extremely shaggy, branches and leaves almost all the way to the base. Across from the Goldstream Nature House on the very edge of the estuary on a site with a fluctating water table and fine floodpain soils. Dense osoberry, maple, and salmonberry, as well as some invasives moving in from the developed trail area.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location is hidden to protect the area.
tree_site_notes: Hollow base! Situated where mid-bench floodplain transitions to low-bench floodpain and ground cover transitions from sparse vegetation and litter covered soil to exposed gravels. Tree base is heavily fluted with some evidence that soils have washed away in previous floods; measured point of germination above the high side due to this.

access_notes: Follow trail from parking lot. Tree is on your right.
tree_site_notes: Large cottonwood just off trail at a historic coal processing plant. Tree shows a tangle of younger roots at the base of the tree, suggesting active soil erosion. Several other large cottonwoods are down at the end of the trail near the river, with several others further off trail to the south. Area is a mix of productive, mature second growth and portions in various states of restoration following industrial activity.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location should be hidden to protect the area.
tree_site_notes: Edge of forested side and high-bench flood plain, mixed with maple and cedar and some cedar regeneration. Fluted base and evidence of lost soil around base. Point of germination measured above high side to account for this.

access_notes: Starting at the Furlong Bay Campsite beach, the Twin Spruce (sadly one of the twins has fallen) Trail leads trhough wetlands, a salmon bearing stream and a mature forest for about 2 km in behind the campground.  It is suitable for all ages.  Walk about 32 minutes up the trail toward the highway and on the right you will see Sattva.
tree_site_notes: This large black cottonwood stands right beside a well maintaned gravel trail through an old growth forest of western cedar, western hemlock and Sitka spruce trees.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location should be hidden to protect the area.
tree_site_notes: Interesting microsite with false-lily of the valley, salmon berry, and snowberry growing on the uphill side, transitioning immediatley to high bench flood plain with dense salmonberry on low side, except that low side has experienced conisistent recent flooding and ground has been eroded to gravel. Heavily fluted based and evidence of lost soil around base. Point of germination measured above high side to account for this.

access_notes: Exiting off of Highway 19A onto Terrain Road, take your first right onto Regent Road. Continue on Regent Road, until you pass over the bridge going over the Oyster River. Once over the bridge, the trail you want to be on is direclty to the left. It is wide and easily seen from the road. There is a small pull out that can be parked on. Across from the streeet (by the telephone pole) there is an older trail sign. You do not want to go down this trail, but that is an indication you are in the correct area. Starting down the trail (on the left), walk for 1-2 minutes and the first large black cottonwood will be on your left hand side (tree # 1174). This tree is just a little further, also on the left. It is a bit further off the trail than the first, but its crown is very visible and it does stick out quite a bit amongst the other trees!
tree_site_notes: Overall, the tree seems to be in good health. It is quite tall, and has a huge canopy. The slope is completely flat.

access_notes: From Highway 19A turn onto Glenmore Road. Continue on Glenmore until you reach the Oyster River Nature Park parking lot. The tree is located only a few metres from the trail as you enter the Oyster River Nature Park from the bottom parking lot near the old Fishermens Lodge Pub. It is on the left hand side of the trail and is very noticable.
tree_site_notes: The tree has an extremely columnar trunk with no noticeable taper until the first branching at approxumately 25-30m. The tree appears to be in good health with a nearly symmetrical radial crown. There is what appears to be a small 15-20cm diameter secondary trunk originating near the base of the tree that has self-grafted to the vastly larger main trunk. It has been completely incorporated intomthe main stem and cannot be differentiated beyind the 8-10m height on the mainstem. I would consider it to be an integral part of the tree. The tree appears to be in very good health with no broken limbs or apparent cavities in the main stem.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location should be hidden to protect the area.
tree_site_notes: Interesting microsite with false-lily of the valley, salmon berry, and snowberry growing on the uphill side, transitioning immediatley to high bench flood plain with dense salmonberry on low side, except that low side has experienced conisistent recent flooding and ground has been eroded to gravel. Heavily fluted base and evidence of lost soil around base. Point of germination measured above high side to account for this. Dense ivy with 4 inch diameter vines on creek side of the trunk.

access_notes: Can be accessed from east and west via the Rotary trail. Nearest parking at the Greta Blue Heron Reserve. Walk south on the trail through the reserve, then turn left onto Rotary trail. Tree is on the right side of the trail, just after a wooden bridge over a creek. It's about halfay between the Heron Reserve and the junction of the trail with Dyke Crest Road.
tree_site_notes: Healthy cottonwood beside trail, near a creek that runs into north side of Vedder river. Abdundant foliage.

access_notes: Walk 600 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to Goldstream Nature House. 10 metres off trail to the right just before the nature house at the junction with the gravel road.
tree_site_notes: On edge of site where high-bench floodplain transitions to mid-bench floodplain, cedars to the west and cottonwoods to the east. 100 metres from main Goldstream channel. Sparse understory.

access_notes: Growing in a sensetive floodplain ecosystem with evidence of past soil damage. Location should be hidden to protect the area.

access_notes: The ecological reserve is in Skagit Valley Provincial Park on the Whatcom Trail.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, narrow crown.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road, head North on Hwy 37 approximately 6 km, turn left (west side) on a narrow old logging road. There is a good place to park about 100 meters down the logging road. Follow old logging road, across a wooden bridge until you see a quad trail on the left.  Follow this quad trail til you come to an ancient fallen tree, and after crossing it, continue a couple of minutes until you come to a Y in the trail, take the righwalk about 3 minutes until you see an open area with several large black cottonwoods.  This will take about 25 minutes in total.
tree_site_notes: Members of the public who participated in an old growth forest tour, sponsored by the Kitimat Valley Naturalists, measured this tree at the end of their tour.  The underbrush in this area is very dense and difficult to walk in.  It consists of devl's club, willow, ferns, red ozier dogwood, prickly rose.  The area is prone to seasonal flooding and is near a creek close to the flood pain of the Kitimat River

access_notes: Follow signage to Bella Coola Regional Airport, continue as far as the access road will take you. Tree is visible on the left. At the west end of the airport runway.
tree_site_notes: Many large trees were cut down to provide clearance for airplanes accessing the runway. This tree has a broken top.

access_notes: From the trailhead for in the parking lot of Saanich Municipal Hall, walk 200m north on the Swan Lake Loop trail. Tree is on the west side of the trail, right along the trail.
tree_site_notes: Lots of galls and new sprouting at base, really impressive stump. A few big lower branches have been removed but the crown seems healthy. Growing at the base of built up slope in the flat marsh land of swan lake, high water table with evidence of recurrent flooding.

access_notes: Walk 600 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to Goldstream Nature House. Immediatley above small estuary side shelter just past the nature house.
tree_site_notes: Across from the Goldstream Nature House on the very edge of the estuary on a site with a fluctating water table and fine floodpain soils. Dense osoberry, maple, and salmonberry, as well as some invasives moving in from the developed trail area.

Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance. From HWY 7, turn South onto Nicomen Island Trunk Road. Turn South on an unnamed gravel road when nearing the tree's coordinates. It is situated in a grove of large cottonwood in the middle of a field by a pond.

After taking the ferry to Barnston Island, turn East onto Dyke Crest Road. The tree is right beside the road (North side), just past where it joins Centre Road, on the Eastern end of the Island. It is right on the boundary of the powerline RoW.
Matsqui Island is boat access only. Request permission from Matsqui First Nation prior to visiting.
Matsqui Island is boat access only. Request permission from Matsqui First Nation prior to visiting.
Turn off HWY 1 in Chilliwack onto Industrial Way, turning West shortly afterwards onto Dyke Crest Road. Park along this road and bushwhack in. Proceed with caution, the area is thick with blackberry.

Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Drive to the Horseshoe Slough Trail trailhead in Richmond, at the South end of Shell Road. Hike South, stopping when the trail bends East. The tree will be visible from here. Bushwhack, minding the blackberry, South towards the tree and the slough. Cross the slough and arrive at the tree.
tree_site_notes: Twin-stem cottonwood, possibly at one point two separate trees, now fused together, splitting about 2.5m from the base. Massive English ivy infestation, covering virtually 100% of the tree, likely contributing to recent loss of limbs. Large bird nest.

access_notes: From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Park at the gate and walk south along Dyke Road until you find a place clear enough to enter the forest and bushwhack to the tree. Proceed with caution, as this Island is full of blackberry and bushwhacking is very difficult. Request permission from Bands before access.

From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Park at the gate and walk south along Dyke Road until you find a place clear enough to enter the forest and bushwhack to the tree. Proceed with caution, as this Island is full of blackberry and bushwhacking is very difficult. Request permission from Bands before access.

Located in Prentice Park, within the Eco Garden grounds. Accessed from Highway #3, turn East at the 13th Street traffic lights, turn left onto 5th Ave. The huge cottonwood is visible on your right, just beside the ball diamond fence.
Km 39 on Pass Lake FSR. There is an old, very brushed in road to near the tree.
tree_site_notes: Flat, SBSvk, surrounded by Sx and other cottonwoods. Has a few arm like candlebra branches 50-75cm diameter. Bottom trunk fluted, no obvious cracks, holes, burls. Within 20m of year round creek.

access_notes: Located on the “Fitzen Farm” and accessed from Highway #3 just to the east of the Morrissey intersection.
Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road, turn right on Robinson Rd, cross railway tracks, turn left on Hill road to end at gate, walk towards river. Tree is downstream.
tree_site_notes: Substantial grove of veteran black cottonwoods along the edge of the Elk River. Tree estimated to be 400 years old (Terry Nelson).  A total of 0.20m was subtracted from the DBH to account for the small cedar tree captured by the DBH tape.

access_notes: The City sewage treatment lagoons is your interim destination. Follow Cokato south out of Fernie, until reaching Thompson Rd., turn right, cross railway tracks, continue until end of the road. This is sometimes a closed gate. If open, drive to lagoons chainlink fence, and follow it west toward the river. The Cokato “Forgotten Forest” is all along the Elk River.
tree_site_notes: A very interesting forest composition with some very old +400 year old trees intermixed with the 120 year old fire gen. trees.

access_notes: Park at northwest corner of the park and walk towards where Vernon Creek crosses Highway 97.  There are three giant cottonwoods; this is the closest to the creek.
Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road. Turn left onto Thompson Road, follow to end, then walk down beside lagoon chainlink fence into forest.
tree_site_notes: Large ancient cottonwoods spaced widely in a regenerating forest of cedar, spruce, and birch. Tree has a broken top with new branches.

access_notes: The River Rd. FSR follows along the east side of the Elk River opposite side from highway 3. The area between the CPR tracks and the river has many hidden cottonwoods to be discovered.
tree_site_notes: The famed Morrissey Ancient Cottonwood site has many fine trees, so it is only to be expected that some other big cottonwoods are present in other Elk river locations. This big old age beaten tree has many broken limbs all strewn about at its base, but otherwise seems healthy.

access_notes: Approx, 25 km down Red Lake road past the Kamloops airport. Pullout located on right and left side of road, once in the now closed Tranquille Meadows  Rec Site, follow the Tranquille River south through some dense brush, an open spruce grove and eventually opening up to this cottonwood. If you back in or park in the pull out on the right hand side up river, walk directly down hill until you get to the water, the tree will be visible along waters edge.
tree_site_notes: Tree growing on stream edge of Tranquille River on mid-bench flood plain (FM01) site series. Tree surrounded by heavy coarse woody debris both from flooding and shedding of its own branches.

access_notes: Cranbrook Hill Road to Broughton Road then to the end of Peardon Road. The big tree is in the forest to the right.

From Valemount, drive south towards Blue River for 46 km. Take exit to Gosnell Road, then turn left onto North Thompson FSR. Tree is on the side of the mainline about 3.5 km up from Gosnell Road. In winter, a snowmobile is required to access the tree.
tree_site_notes: Site is roadside in ICH forest. Tree appears healthy.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 1.6 km. Just after crossing a creek, bushwack about 150m off the trail to reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy. In wet forest surrounded by red cedar, white spruce, and devils club.

access_notes: Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road. Turn left onto Thompson Road, follow to end, then walk down beside lagoon chainlink fence into forest.
tree_site_notes: Large ancient cottonwoods spaced widely in a regenerating forest of cedar, spruce, and birch. Tree has new growth on top.

access_notes: Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road, turn right on Robinson Rd, cross railway tracks, turn left on Hill road to end at gate, walk towards river. Tree is downstream.
tree_site_notes: Substantial grove of veteran black cottonwoods along the edge of the Elk River. Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: Turn off of Highway 3 at Morrissey junction, follow River Rd. downstream after crossing Elk River bridge. Road to right just before Morrissey Creek leads to CPR tracks. Area on opposite side of tracks is an old-growth forest.
tree_site_notes: Many large cottonwoods occupy this area.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 2 km. Just before reaching the lake, bushwack about 100m off the trail to reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top but is in good health. Surrounding vegetation includes douglas maple, black cottonwood, elderberry, paper birch. Tree is close to shoreline of Little Lost Lake and is on flat ground.

access_notes: From downtown Kimberley drive up to the townsite area, past the Kimberley Medical Clinic.  Access the Lois Cr. Trails from the 8th and Elko trailhead.  Take Bart's out to P Junction (2.1 km).  Then follow A Frame north for about 1.2 km.  The Big Tree is located just past another cotttonwood which is right on the trail.   The tree is about 50m before a long boardwalk and 15m in from the trail, near a fallen spruce.
tree_site_notes: Large burl and fungus shown on photo. This tree is located within a wet meadow with spruce and cedar in an uncut reserve  between logged areas.  The meadow forms an unusual shape as it runs just north and east of a very sharp, forested ridge. The lower few branches are dead, live above 13m, and the main trunk starts to branch at 16m+.

access_notes: Turn off of Highway 3 at Morrissey junction, follow River Rd. downstream after crossing Elk River bridge. Road to right just before Morrissey Creek leads to CPR tracks. Area on opposite side of tracks is an old-growth forest.
tree_site_notes: Many large cottonwoods occupy this area. Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: From Highway 3, turn off onto Burton Lake Road continue past lake turn-off, take right turn onto gravel before the subdivision access. Walk up creek ravine.
tree_site_notes: One individual cottonwood had managed to root itself right in the middle of the creek.

access_notes: The tree is located on the western shore of Esquimalt Lagoon.  Follow the foot track SE along stream from Royal Roads road system.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a rounded crown and multiple stems.

access_notes: South end of Shell Rd., Richmond.
South of historic railway tracks near station at Granville Island.

Park anywhere along the Pitt River Greenway Park trail and follow the path west. The tree is along the river towards the middle 
of the trail. Two large cottonwoods, and the large cherry are further west.  Also close by arey many other cherry, 
birch, alder and cedar trees. The tree is on the north side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy.

access_notes: 1422 10th Avenue
tree_site_notes: A remnant native shrub that has managed to survive the area development

access_notes: When nominated the tree was located in the Lannan Forest. Current tree and landownership status is unknown.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Near base of road from Lakeview Heights.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: For excellent driving directions from Victoria BC, see https://www.ancientforestalliance.org/directions-red-creek-fir.php.   The tree is located off Red Creek Mainline and is accessed along a trail approximately 1/2 km from the road.  The trail head GPS is -124.22668 by 48.57998. The actual tree location is -124.220905 by 48.579422.
tree_site_notes: It is one of largest known of its species and of the pine family. It is the only known tree on earth (except coast redwoods and giant sequoias) to be 7 feet thick, 144 feet off the ground.  The tree has a large, healthy crown, huge branches and a broken top. It is on a reserve.  Mid slope, toe mesoslope, aspect north.

access_notes: No public access
tree_site_notes: Healthy with broken top and a high wood volume.  Base covered in debris.

access_notes:
Driving Directions from Port Renfrew to Big Lonely Doug
1. km 0.0 - start at the Port Renfrew Community Center/Fire
Station and drive down Deering Rd 0.2 km
2. km 0.2 - continue over single lane bridge 1.1 km
3. km 1.4 - turn right at fork and continue for 1.4 km
4. km 2.7 - cross Deering Bridge and turn left onto the Gordon River Main (right goes to Lake Cowichan)
5. Stay on the mostly-paved Gordon River Main and after
approximately 5 km it will become gravel and you
will hit a “Y” where you go LEFT and cross a high bridge
over the beautiful Gordon River.
6. After crossing the bridge keep on the Gordon River Main
for about 1.5 km, staying to the RIGHT at the next “Y”.
7. Shortly after you will cross a small bridge over a creek
(Baird Creek). This is the Avatar Grove, the newly popular old-growth forest hiking area!
8. Continue past the Avatar Grove on the Gordon River Main
for approximately 4.5 km and take your FIRST RIGHT onto
Edinburgh Main road. (Note: it’s a smaller looking road)
9. You will soon cross over a bridge above a very tall canyon
on the Gordon River. *Note: From here on 4x4 vehicles with
good clearance are recommended!
10. Follow the rough road as it veers uphill and then right. Continue
on the main road for approximately 5 minutes.
11. A giant clearcut from 2012 will appear on your right hand
side. In that clearcut you will see two big Douglas-firs left
standing - the second one is Big Lonely Doug.
*NOTE: The hike into Big Lonely Doug is through a difficult
clearcut and should ONLY be attempted by those with good
balance.
tree_site_notes: The tree stands alone in a clearcut from 2012 and is hard to miss. It has a straight trunk, a broken top, and still has most of it's branches but did recently lose one of it's biggest in a wind storm. The hike into Big Lonely Doug is through difficult logging slash and should only be attempted by those with good balance.

access_notes: Follow Hiway 4 west through Port Alberni. After crossing the 'Orange' bridge over the Somass River, drive 0.6km and then turn left on to McCoy Lake Road. Follow McCoy Lake Road to the junction with Stirling Arm Drive. Follow Stirling Arm Drive to the intersection with Ash Main. Turn left onto Ash Main and drive 1km to the junction with Stirling Main. turn right onto Stirling Main and follow it for 12km to the junction with Gracie Main. Turn left onto Gracie Main and follow it for 6km to the junction with Gracie Hook-up. Keep right onto the Gracie Hook-up and follow it for 2km to the junction with Nahmint Main. Turn right onto Nahmint Main and drive 1.2km to the bridge crossing the Nahmint River. Once across the one-lane bridge, drive 0.2km to the junction with Riverside Main. Turn left onto Riverside Main and drive 1.7km to Block 1513 located on the west side of the road. If you drive past a small weedy lake to your right, you have driven past Block 1513 and the tree. There is a small road on your right just past the lake which makes a convenient turnaround. The tree is very visible along the skyline beyond the southern boundary of Block 1513. There is a rough trail from the road (approximately 20m past the southern falling boundary of the block that leads up to 1513-002. You will pass a large Western Redcedar (Legacy Tree 1513-001, 3.15m in diameter or 9.9m in circumference) as you climb the slope up to 1513-002. There is another large Western Redcedar (Legacy Tree 1513-003, 3.11m in diameter or 9.8m in circumference) located approximately 25m up slope of 1513-002. All trees are marked with bright yellow BCTS Legacy Tree plaques. Use caution when traveling on gravel Forest Service roads. These are active industrial roads and expect to meet large vehicles at any time!
tree_site_notes: 1513-002 is a Douglas-fir in good health. There are no apparent signs of rot present upon a visual inspection of the tree. The tree is largely intact with only a few small broken limbs present in the upper portion of the canopy. there are several moderate-sized burls (approximately 1m across and flattened) on the up-slope side of the tree. It is located within the CWH vm1 and is situated on a small bench located on the lower slope with a NE aspect. The tree can be considered to be windfirm as it is sheltered within a 12.1 hectare Old Growth Management Area. This OGMA contains several other Legacy Trees (two Western Redcedar; 1513-001 and 1513-003).There is minimal evidence of historic windthrow in the vicinity of 1513-002 or throughout the OGMA.

access_notes: Temples of Time Grove.  5 km west of mainline.
tree_site_notes: Big healthy crown with a  high wood volume.  This tree was found with a wind damaged top at 280’.  It is estimated to have been over 300' tall.  Steep slope.

access_notes: No public access
tree_site_notes: The tree has a broken top.  Northwest aspect, 85% slope, mid-slope, straight. Montane.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Very good health. Windfirm. Located in large OGMA.

access_notes: West Antler Main. Steep rough road.
tree_site_notes: Very good health. Intact top

access_notes: Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park at a pullout and hike uphill through the cutblock to access Pipe Dream! Enter the cutblock at the large fir on the edge of the cutblock, just past several large stumps. Hike south through the old growth 220m until you come to an open area with many large firs. Hike southwest about 280m until the aspect changes from E to SE. The Laminar fir is just around the bend when the aspect changes.
tree_site_notes: The Laminar Fir is an absolutely massive pillar of wood, nearly perfectly cylindrical for dozens of meters, with one large branch mid-way up and a somewhat flattened top. Situated at the edge of an open patch of forest, the entire tree is visible from both upslope and downslope, with many other large firs nearby.

This tree was once the tallest in Cathedral Grove and one of BC's largest Douglas-fir on record. In 1990, it stood 70.1 m (230 ft) tall with a score of 645 points.  A major windstorm in January 1997 swept through the area and reduced this tree to a little over 100ft in height.  Those surviving the storm, which are now the tallest in the grove, have yet to be nominated.

access_notes: West side of Elk Creek, Chilliwack District watershed.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy with broken top and big crown.

access_notes: Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park at a pullout and hike uphill through the cutblock to access Pipe Dream! The Wye fir is near the northern end of Pipe Dream. The most direct route is to continue driving along the road until the end of the next regenerating cutblock (logged 2006). You can park around 48.935442, -124.587609. Hike up through the regen along the seasonal creek 60m until you reach the old growth. Follow the lip of the ravine uphill for another 90m until you reach the Wye fir.
tree_site_notes: A very healthy tree, showing vigourous apical growth and a dense crown that can be seen from the road. It has a high, narrow fork with two co-dominant leaders, giving it a truly remarkable crown spread. The tree is situated on a moderate slope near the edge of a seasonal creek ravine. In a stand of exceptional trees, it still stands out from 50 meters away in all directions as remarkable.

access_notes: Notes current to Dec. 2024. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park where the road bends heading away from the tree and hike upslope slightly to an old overgrown access road. You can follow this road for about 200m before you will need to descend down and back up a steep draw to access the tree.
tree_site_notes: This extremely tall fir is located mid-slope within a steep ravine (CWHmm1-01). Although the protection of the ravine has given rise to a fair number of tall and slender firs, this one stands well above the rest in both height and diameter. According to lidar data, this is the tallest tree in Pipe Dream or any surrounding forest. The height could not be reliably verified via hyposometer due to the dense forest and steep terrain, but the tree is very straight, with the top situated slightly upslope of the stem, suggesting that the lidar-derived height may be a slight underestimate and the tree might actually exceed 90m in height.

access_notes: No public access

Heading north, turn right at the Sayward junction down Sayward road. After 550m, turn right onto Hern road. Merge left onto Salmon River Main and follow the road for 5.1km. Slight right onto C Branch FSR. Follow the road for 2km. The tree is across the creek just before the bridge. There is a nice log bridge to cross, then a steep scramble to get to the tree.
tree_site_notes: The tree is in very good health, situated at the top of a bluff. There is a small helilogged patch just above it, which may threaten the long-term windfirmness of the tree. The surrounding forest is all of exceptional height, though this fir and a few others dominate the skyline.

access_notes: No public access

Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). This tree is on the far side of a fairly large ravine from the rest of the stand. Suggest hiking in through the third growth/riparian corridor. Some sections are very steep and loose, so use extreme caution.
tree_site_notes: This extremely tall fir is located at the edge of a very small bench within a steep ravine near the edge of an old clearcut. Although the protection of the ravine hasgiven rise to a fair number of tall firs, this one stands well above the rest in both height and diameter. The top of the tree appears to have blown off some time ago, suggesting this tree was once possibly taller than 90m.

access_notes: No public access

From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road,
continuing all the way past the lake on Cowichan Main and eventually following the Nitinat River.
Turn right at T-Intersection ( 48.8627379, -124.6438995 ) over the bridge which crosses Nitinat River, following
Carmanah Main. A visit to the waterfalls on the Little Nitinat Falls is recommended for a quick break (unmarked pull
off near 48.871476, -124.687404 ).
Follow Carmanah Main until a bridge on your left crosses the Little Nitinat River onto Flora Main ( 48.8994754,
-124.6887141 ).
Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left.
Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits. Take the left spur
K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ). After some time, along the South side
of K-265 there are a couple of small lakes accessed via a short spur (approx 48.8274633, -1248130282 ), where one
can visit the Fairy Bell Cedar at Dorothy Lake (at the head of the second lake, 48.825688, -124.822826 ).
Coming to another T-Intersection ( 48.8307925, -124.8372049 ), turn left and continue straight past another
intersection and follow it until you reach the spruce flats and recently logged areas at the bottom of the valley (approx
48.7969942, -124.8668236 ). This is where the Main and East Forks of the Klanawa River meet. This new road
bends East and becomes very coarse. It is advised that one parks in a safe location and walks to the Bumblebee
Tree from the road (starting at 48.801119, -124.832387 ).
*Alternatively the Hummingbird and adjacent forest stands can be reached by crossing one of the numerous log-jams
on the Klanawa River East Fork. Park on Newstead Main , and find a log-jam that you can cross safely ( 48.799488,
-124.817626 ) or ( 48.802287, -124.808875 ) for example. Be sensible, do not attempt when the river is flowing high,
and no I am not responsible if your shoe soles are slippery and your iphone goes for a swim ;) Keep your electronics
safe in a ziplock or wet bag. Personally, we prefer using Newstead Main, the road is in better condition and it is a
more straightforward route.
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes:
CWHvh1 07.  The top of the crown is bare and the canopy has classic spiralling form. On the uphill side of the tree the trunk has large columnar veins and a distinctive scar bare of bark (Approx. AM525 x 0.75m). Bumblebee stands at a lower slope position, at the edge of cut-block along a small and steep drainage populated by western redcedar.  The Bumblebee Tree stands on a cutblock above the Hummingbird Spruce Grove. For more detailed information about the trees of this region visit
the Vancouver Island Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com.

access_notes: Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park at a pullout and hike uphill through the cutblock to access Pipe Dream! Enter the cutblock at the large fir on the northern edge of the cutblock, just past several large stumps. Hike south through the old growth 220m until you come to an open area with many large firs. Hike uphill about 190m until you reach the Conduit Fir. This is the largest tree within a cluster of about 5 large firs, very near the edge of the old growth, where it abuts a 50-year-old second growth stand.
tree_site_notes: The Conduit Fir is an especially girthy tree, even by the standards of this stand. It is situated on a moderate slope, in an area with several other firs >250cm in diameter.

access_notes: West Antler Main. Steep rough road.
tree_site_notes: Good health. Broken top. No scarring or sign of rot on main stem.

access_notes: No public access

From the small town of Youbou, head Westward on the North Shore Road, following along the shore of Cowichan
Lake. Arrive at a signposted split between Bamfield and Nitinat and head left towards Nitinat. Driving past the head
of the Lake, you eventually enter the Nitinat River Valley. At the entrance of Nitinat River Ecological Preserve
(Eastern Portion 48.901189, -124.545689 ) you will encounter old-growth Douglas fir forest and some roadside
CMT’s. Have a look at the impressive Nitinat Fir (just below the road, 48.893787, -124.556285 ).
It is also worth checking out the canyon section of the Nitinat river ( 48.895723, -124.558131 ).
A couple of hundred meters past the turnoff for Granite Main, find a safe place to park. On foot, follow an old spur on
the north side of the road ( 48.876268, -124.587473 ) briefly. When the spur becomes overgrown, head left
( 48.878611, -124.585422 ) through the bush. Heading slightly downhill, start contouring to your right along the hillside
until you encounter an impressive stand of Fir and Hemlock on the slope above the river. Here you will encounter the
Cauliflower Mushroom Fir. Follow the lower slope around a corner (northward and upstream) for 50m or so, staying
above the dense brush along the river edge. Once you can easily cross onto the river flats, find your way to the river
edge and safely fjord across the river, just above the bend. You should be able to see a large spruce and you may be
able to see 3PP’s double leaders a little further back from the shore. The tree is located on the flats about 60m from
shore amongst sword ferns.
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote region without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you
leave home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a
full sized spare tire along for this trip. There are some basic amenities available in the Village of Nitinat. Only cross
the river when the flow is low, it is recommended to have your electronics in watertight bags and please be careful.
tree_site_notes:
Gradually tapering and with a distinctive burl, the trunk splits into two healthy looking upward facing
leaders at approximately the 40m mark.
Located on a flat and sandy riparian floodplain, 3PP is a fine Douglas fir standing amidst Bigleaf
Maple, Hemlock and Sitka spruce about 60m from the bank of the Nitinat River.
This floodplain is part of a series of high quality, intact riverside patches of old growth standing
between the Eastern and Western portions of the Nitinat River Ecological Reserves. Sitka Spruce begin to
Reach full potential in the floodplains and Douglas fir become less abundant at river level. Here and across
the river in Macoola Grove, one will find the Red Listed Tooth- leaved Monkey flowers and Blue Listed
Scouler’s corydalis carpeting the floor during the late spring and summer.
For more detailed information about the trees of the Central Nitinat River and the Macoola Grove region
visit the Vancouver Island Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

access_notes: No public access
tree_site_notes: Broken top, big healthy crown, one giant branch, and a very high wood volume.
CWHvm1 04
CWHmm1 07

access_notes: Upper Klaklakama Rec Site.  Turn from Highway 19 at the Schoen Lake PP access (Davies Road), turn onto Nimpkish Main FSR.
tree_site_notes: CWHmm1 07

access_notes: See the Caycuse Fir, page 158  in “Hiking Guide to the Big Trees of Southwestern British Columbia (2nd Edition)” by Randy Stoltmann 1991.
Royal Roads. Take old road from gravel pit downhill to the SE. At intersection with N-S road, backtrack up about 35 m to find tree about 10 m from old road on left.
tree_site_notes: Vigorous.  A few small top branches are dead.

access_notes: Upper Klaklakama Rec Site.  Turn from Highway 19 at the Schoen Lake PP access (Davies Road), turn onto Nimpkish Main FSR.
tree_site_notes: CWHmm1 07

access_notes: Access is via a steep bushwhack up from Carmanah Mainline
tree_site_notes: A towering Douglas-fir with an enromous crown that really stands out on aerial images. The tree grows on a bench adjacent to a steep canyon. In the surrounding area are other beautiful old-growth redcedar and Douglas-fir trees that somehow survived the logging that wiped clean the entire surrounding hillsides, providing a glimpse into what once was.

access_notes: The tree is located just to the east of Highway 1. Park in the parking lot and take the trail to the Goldstream Nature House. Just before the house, the road switchbacks up to a small employee parking lot. Follow the improvised trail alongside the highway until just above the tree and then carefully travel down the slope to access the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located on a steep slope just above Goldstream estuary, along with several other large Doug-firs. Slightly further north on this slope are a few other large Doug-firs and an enormous dead grand fir.

access_notes: West Antler Main. Steep rough road.
tree_site_notes: Very good health. Top intact. Windfirm

access_notes: Drive West from Campbell River. Hike in from Gold River Highway up Kings Peak trail or drive down BC Hydro access road from Elk River viewpoint and then hike up Kings Peak Trail.
Adjacent to small unofficall campsite at mouth of Nahmint River. Riverside Main. Access via Nahmint Main
tree_site_notes: Good health. Lake/creek side embankments becoming undercut and eroded. Windfirm.

The tree is located in a large intact stand of old growth on a tributary of McBride Creek. It is growing on a broad bench that sits about 2 meters above the tributary. this bench sits at the base of a low mountain (650 meters) on the north side. Local knowledge tells of snow remaining in the area until early July most years. The stand is comprised of predominantly Pacific Silver Fir (Abies amabalis) with large Douglas-fir veterans scattered throughout. The tree displays little taper up to the height where the upper portion has been broken off. The tree displays good health and appears to be growing vigourously with no outward signs of rot or decay.
Core sampling of this tree produced an age of 1551 years, which could be one of the oldest known living Douglas-fir. The tree was discovered by long-time Port Alberni logging brothers Alvin and Gunny Brown. As family stories tell, the two bothers could not bring themselves to fall this giant as it was so much larger than any trees they had ever come across. Both are now deceased and their great-nephew, Rob Cole, wished to nominate this tree in their names.

access_notes: Tree is visible from Caycuse Main about 400m from the start (off Mainline Carmanah). Bushwhack through steep, unpleasant regen.
tree_site_notes: One of two similarly large trees at the base of a small, steep retention patch in a cutblock (CWHvm1/04). Base shows substantial damage from where it was used as a cable anchor during logging.

access_notes: The tree is located directly to the west of Highway 1, just across from where Finlayson Arm Road tees into the highway. After pushing through the brush on the side of the road, the tree is immediately visible on the south side of the gully.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located on a moderately steep slope just at the edge of a small gully. The bark is deeply furrowed with an incredible, almost geometric appearance. The crown, visible from across the road, is prominent and healthy.

access_notes: Heading north, turn right at the Sayward junction down Sayward road. After 550m, turn right onto Hern road. Merge left onto Salmon River Main and follow the road for 5.1km. Slight right onto C Branch FSR. Follow the road for 2km. The tree is across the creek just before the bridge. There is a nice log bridge to cross, then follow the creek downstream until you are below the tree. Push up through the brush to get there.
