tree_site_notes: The tree is in very good health, at lower slope position just above the creek and with plenty of surrounding forest to protect it somewhat from the wind. The surrounding forest is all of exceptional height, though this fir and a few others dominate the skyline.
CWHvm1 04

access_notes: Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park at a pullout and hike uphill through the cutblock to access Pipe Dream! Enter the cutblock at the large fir on the northern edge of the cutblock, just past several large stumps. Hike north along the slope for 120m until you reach a steep ravine. Traverse the ravine, and continue along the slope for another 160m until you reach the Tensile Fir!
tree_site_notes: The Tensile Fir is the tallest tree in a stand full of towering trees. Although its girth is far from exceptional for Pipe Dream, it grows in an open area when you can get a good view of much of its length from a distance. Like several trees in the stand, it has two distinct types of bark occuring on the upslope and downslope sides of the tree. The tree is situated on a gentle slope, with a cluster of three large firs just 30m north and uphill.

access_notes: From the Glenora Trails parking lot, take the connector onto the Trans Canada Trail and turn right, towards the Holt Creek Trestle. After about 2.5km on this trail, you can see the Memory Tree and two other large, old firs sticking out above the second growth canopy by looking west through a cutblock (logged 2013) on the south side of the trail. After another 300m (2.8km total), enter into the second growth stand to the south of the trail and bushwhack 160m to the Memory Tree. Try to stay close to the edge of the forest, as there are a couple wet areas with devil's club further in.
tree_site_notes: The Memory Tree is possibly the tallest tree remaining in the Cowichan Valley, based on the publicly-available LiDAR data. It is situated at the base of a moderate slope above a bench with several good sized redcedars, in a dark and spacious stand. There are two other large (>2m DBH) firs just above the Memory Tree as well. This tree supports a large forked crown, giving it a very ovoid stem that, from the broad side, looks even larger than its 2.35m DBH would suggest.

access_notes: Tree is visible from Caycuse Main about 400m from the start (off Mainline Carmanah). Bushwhack through steep, unpleasant regen.
tree_site_notes: One of two similarly large trees at the base of a small, steep retention patch in a cutblock (CWHvm1/04).

access_notes: From Heriot Bay head north on Hyacinth Bay Road for about 9 km. Turn left onto Granite Bay Road and continue for about 7 km. Turn right at junction at 50.217626, -125.284947 and continue straight. Follow forestry roads as close as you can get to the waypoint then park and hike. There is a rough flagged route starting around 50.219282, -125.260201. Head east into the forest and into Main Lake PP. Follow the flags as the route drops down a steep slope into a valley. Once at the valley bottom, follow it downstream until reaching the trees.
tree_site_notes: Valley bottom, close to creek. Trees have survived a large fire in the past based on scarring. Forest is predominantly western hemlock, Douglas-fir, and western redcedar. Understory includes salal, swordfern, and small hemlocks. The very top of this tree is dead, otherwise it is in good health.

access_notes: Near the San Juan Giant (ID# 175)

From the Old Island Highway, turn onto Baylis Road, then turn left onto Dorman Road, and right onto Corcan Road. Continue on Corcan Road until the intersection just before the overpass under Highway 19 and turn left onto Nahmit Road, then take the next left onto Ohiat Road and continue to the end where you will find a gate. Start hiking Down the logging road past the gate until you reach the top of a big hill that overlooks a clearcut and the river valley. From here, there are two ways to go, both of which are equally difficult for different reasons. You can either head down the steep, thorny ATV trail to the left, then make your way through the thorny clearcut, or backtrack a little bit and head through the forest by the river.
tree_site_notes: The tree is located on the edge of a clearcut at the bottom of a steep hill. It has a burl near its base. The trunk has a gradual taper, and the diameter at the bottom of the crown is significantly less than at the base. There is another very large Douglas-fir a bit over 100 meters to the west which is only a little smaller than this one.

access_notes: Follow North Shore onto Nitinat Main, then turn left onto NT2. Follow and park at the turnoff for NT2F. Hike down the road and turn right uphill. Follow til end of road then short hike into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: A big Douglas-fir with a fire scarred trunk. Other larger firs in the vacinity though this appeared to be the biggest. Nice open grove!

access_notes: From Heriot Bay head north on Hyacinth Bay Road for about 9 km. Turn left onto Granite Bay Road and continue for about 7 km. Turn right at junction at 50.217626, -125.284947 and continue straight. Follow forestry roads as close as you can get to the waypoint then park and hike. There is a rough flagged route starting around 50.219282, -125.260201. Head east into the forest and into Main Lake PP. Follow the flags as the route drops down a steep slope into a valley. Once at the valley bottom, follow it downstream until reaching the trees.
tree_site_notes: Valley bottom, close to creek. Trees have survived a large fire in the past based on scarring. Forest is predominantly western hemlock, Douglas-fir, and western redcedar. Understory includes salal, swordfern, and small hemlocks. Tree is in good health and is a bit flared at the base.

access_notes: Follow North Shore onto Nitinat Main, then turn left onto NT2. Follow and park at the turnoff for NT2F. Hike down the road and turn right uphill. Follow til end of road then short hike into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Large Doug-fir in an open grove with a few other large firs and some smaller hemlock. Sparse understory of sword fern and mosses.

access_notes: From the Old Island Highway, turn onto Baylis Road, then turn left onto Dorman Road, and right onto Corcan Road. Continue on Corcan Road until the intersection just before the overpass under Highway 19 and turn left onto Nahmit Road, then take the next left onto Ohiat Road and continue to the end where you will find a gate. Start hiking down the logging road past the gate for about 100 meters, then start bushwhacking off to the left and make your way to the tree.
tree_site_notes: The tree sticks out from the surrounding trees significantly. It can easily be made out on satellite pictures, but it is too far into the woods to be seen from any roads.

access_notes: Park on Nitinat Fronting just west of the intersection with Mainline Carmanah. Buchwhack through the second-growth bench upslope to a bench of old growth. The tree is at the far end of this bench at the base of another slope.
tree_site_notes: A massive fir that dominates the canopy and is visible from the cedar just upslope (CWHvm1/01). Several similarly large firs appear to have been in the same stand but one is an old snag and one fell recently. Broad, healthy top and a beautiful straight stem only just showing signs of slowing growth.

access_notes: Tree is visible from Caycuse Main at about 1.6km, the dominant feature of a small retention patch. Lots of blowdown on the way up to the tree, so it is easier to bushwhack through the surrounding cutblock and enter in near the tree.
tree_site_notes: Large fir near a seasonal draw in a small retention patch. The top is very jagged, giving it a bit of a wizard's staff appearance. Tree seems healthy despite lots of blowdown around it.

access_notes: Head down Claymore Rd W from Laburnum Road, and continue until you hit the powerlines, then head left on Melrose Rd. Continue on Melrose Rd until you pass under highway 19. Just as the road starts to level off again, there is a small logging road on the right blocked off with dirt piles. I would recomend parking at the bottom of the hill just after you pass under the highway, because the small road is easy to miss. Make your way down the old logging road for about 100 meters, then head off to the right and find your way to the tree.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be very good health, with a pretty basic shape. It can be seen from the highway, but is quite unasuming from afar. The ecosystem also appears to be healthy. There are two other sizable Douglas-firs closeby. Marking tape can be found throughout the forest reading "felling boundary", and some of the trees (including this one) have a big "L" painted on them.

access_notes: From parking lot take trail down past former picnic ground, then take first trail on right marked “closed” ca. 28 m. Largest diameter tree on path, next to medium cedar.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. Tree bent to the SW.

access_notes: 43 km south of Campbell River along Island Highway 19A an obscure sign directs you to this Class C Park
tree_site_notes: Tree has its own interpretive sign, and is located at the south end of the campground. With a creek and an ocean near by it is well situated to put on some more girth. Except for the trampling at the root base, and the wood-peckered bark, it appears quite healthy. Tree is estiamated to be 600 to 800 years old.   The scars are from use in logging operation years ago.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive east on Highway 28 for 7 km to Saunders Main. Turn left onto Saunders Main and drive for 4.9 km. Road has several tight manauvers requiring a narrower vehicle with four wheel drive. Hike uphill into forest navigating to tree.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock and amabilis fir dominated forest. Forest is sloping towards Saunders Creek. Understory contains deer fern, step moss, five-leaved bramble, and red huckleberry. Tree is one of a small grove of large Douglas-firs growing next to a creek.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive north on Gold River Road then onto East Main into Gold-Muchalat Provincial Park. Park on side of road and bushwhack to tree.

Turn onto Evans Road off Errington Road. About 100 meters down the road, there is a gated logging road. Hike down this road until you find yourself at a nice little area by a creek with a pretty bridge made of logs and branches, benches made of split logs, and firepits. Although you can't see it, this is actually very close to the tree. Without crossing the bridge, bushwhack upstream, and you will find the tree.
tree_site_notes: Gentle sweep to base and second very slight sweep at 1/2 height. Tree is 5m from edge of small swampy creek, on the edge of flat sub-mesic to mesic douglas-fir plantation (20 years old). Slightly higher (1-2m elevation) than the depressed wet site on a small rise.The tree's base is tilted, causing the base of the trunk to be much wider. It can be seen across a field from Errington Road.

access_notes: Heritage Grove Trail accessed from the Nature Centre on Munn Road.
tree_site_notes: Grove of 500 year old Douglas-firs tower over the surrounding forest, with sword fern, salal, and Oregon grape.

access_notes: In campground by site

Follow North Shore onto Nitinat Main, then turn left onto NT2. Follow and park at the turnoff for NT2F. Hike down the road and turn right uphill. Follow til end of road then short hike into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Large, leaning fir in a pocket of other large fir near the edge of an old cutblock. Some adjacent firs are larger by DBH (one upslope is 240cm), but this seems to be the largest in the area by volume. Sparse understory of sword fern and mosses.

access_notes: The tree is an 8.5 km drive from the Fulford Ferry terminal and is adjacent to the intersection of Forest Ridge Rd. and Stevens Rd. on Salt Spring Island. To visit from the Fulford Ferry terminal, head northwest on FulfordGanges Rd towards Beaver Point Rd. After 40m, turn slight right onto Beaver Point Rd. Follow Beaver Rd for 2.5 km and then turn right to stay on Beaver Rd. After another 5.3 km turn right onto Forest Ridge Rd. The tree is 650m down Forest Ridge Rd on the right.
tree_site_notes: This tree, the Grandmother's Tree, appears healthy and its crown spread has benefited from nominal competition on a sub/wet mesic site in the CDF region. The tree is readily accessible on largely flat terrain and is directly adjacent to a well maintained trail (old roadbed) in a park reserve with no access restrictions. Soils on Salt Spring Island are generally shallow and at least one old-growth Douglas-fir just up-slope from this tree has been uprooted within the last ten years.

access_notes: Tahsis Highway
tree_site_notes: Tree was being strangled by an hemlock juvenile.

access_notes: Take South Shore Road from Lake Cowichan to Mesachie Lake. Turn right on Forestry Road and follow to the gate for Cowichan Lake Research Station. Park in the large gravel area before the gate. Enter through the gap in the foliage, through which a large redcedar is visible. Follow the rough trail to the cluster of large Doug-firs.
tree_site_notes: Large fir in a small grove of 3 other firs >1.5m diameter, two of which have low broken tops. This tree has a lovely columnar stem and a large ramicorn branch.

access_notes: Turn onto Mines Road from Riverside Road. Follow for 1.5km until there is a blocked forest road on your right. There is a small sign affixed to a tree near the start of the trail that says "King's Trail". Follow the trail for about 200m, King's Crown will be visible on the left.
tree_site_notes: King's Crown is massive, with a large broken top that has recovered into several healthy and vigorous new iterations. The tree is near a small seepage, with some other old-growth trees nearby and further down the trail.

access_notes: Hike up RS004 off Riverside Main. Access via Nahmint Main
tree_site_notes: Very good health. Large frost crack on NW face. Large burls @5m on N side of trunk

access_notes: Take North Shore Road from Lake Cowichan towards Youbou. The Widowed Fir will be just off the left (south) side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Large Douglas-fir with a stout, broken top sitting on a narrow bench just off the side of the road. Another fir of similar size on the opposite side of the road was recently cleared for development, giving this tree its widowed status.

access_notes: Turn onto Caycuse Mainline from Carmanah Mainline. Follow until just below the tree and hike up the west side of the creek.
tree_site_notes: Large fir on a small bench above a steep ravine. Sparse understory of salal. Nice waterfall behind the tree. Slightly ragged top. Likely within riparian buffer of adjacent creek.

access_notes: Kapor FSR
tree_site_notes: Well marked, and trodden trail follows old mining pack horse route to the Kokisilah River, where a small grove of giant fir Douglas- fir and western hemlock reside.

access_notes: Immediately adjacent Lees Trail, 40m east of intersection with Bridle Path.
tree_site_notes: Trailside.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack in from the forest service road running along Loop Creek.
tree_site_notes: Tree likely falls just within an Old-Growth Management Area

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Tree is immediatley adjacent to trail junction marker.
tree_site_notes: Beautiful trunk and crown, healthy, lots of fire char on lower bark. Mesic site.

access_notes: Take Highway 18 from Duncan towards Lake Cowichan. Pull off on the north side of the road just before the fire hazard sign. A short scramble up the roadcut leads to gentle terrain, with a 200m hike through a second growth alder and maple forest opening up into a remnant patch of old growth along a seasonal creek. Several large firs >1m in diameter are scattered within a younger cohort of firs, redcedars, and maples.
tree_site_notes: The Bushcamp Fir is the undisputed king of this stand, towering well above everything else in the area with deep, furrowed bark and an immense canopy. A visible collar near the base of the tree shows where the ground level would've been for a long period.

access_notes: Riverside Main, 300m north of junction with RS038 (road to Blackie's Beach Forest Service campsite.  Access via Nahmint Main
tree_site_notes: Poor health. Broken/dead top with severe rot apparent above major limb at 24m.

access_notes: Drive West from Sayward up White River Valley on White River Main. Tree is less than 100 m from road.

Head down Claymore Rd W from Laburnum Road, and continue until you hit the powerlines, then head left on Melrose Rd. Continue on Melrose Rd until you pass under highway 19. I would recomend parking at the bottom of the hill just after you pass under the highway. Head up the hill on foot, there is a small logging road on the right at the top of the hill blocked off with dirt piles. Make your way down the old logging road for about 100 meters, then head off to the right and make your way to the Little Big Fir (BC Big Tree #1332). Then continue bushwhacking through the woods towards this tree.
tree_site_notes: The tree is located on a very steep slope. There are many other large Douglas-firs in the area, many of which are marked with an "L". The bark on the main trunk looks like it belongs on a smaller fir. Feathers can be found littered around the tree, suggesting that there might be an eagle's nest in it.

access_notes: Follow the Columbia Valley Highway to the Clear Creek Campground.  The tree is 1km from the parking lot on the Giant Douglas-fir Trail, an easy but steep trail. This tree has many visitors and no fence protecting its roots from the heavy foot traffic.  Please view from a distance.
tree_site_notes: Healthy tree with a broken top.

access_notes: Head northbound on Highway 19. Continue 4 km past the Qualicum Beach exit, and there should be a turnout where you can park. The tree is located about 150 down from this turnout, and about 100 meters into the bush. (Note: there is an ATV trail leading away from the turnout. Don't go down it. It leads to private property).
tree_site_notes: Tree is located at the edge of a small, rich bench just above a steep ravine (CDFmm04). This tree has a ragged and broken top but appears otherwise healthy and vigourous. On the east side of the tree there is a large cavity excavated beneath that appears to be a bear den or similar habitat.  A few other large firs were spared from logging along the edge of the ravine, though one has recently collapsed. The understory of the bench is dominated by sword fern, with a mix of mature cedar and fir naturally regenerated after most of the bench was logged.

access_notes: Follow North Shore Road west through Youbou. Turn right on Cedar Drive (last right turn before the pavement ends). Follow until the road bends to the east and park at the pullout for the Christopher Rock Trail. Follow the trail for approximately 90m until the Youbou Creek Fir is visible on the left, about 50m off the trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is situated on a bench near the outflow of Youbou Creek with a few other large firs.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until coming to a creek. Tree is just before creek on the left.
tree_site_notes: Huge branches in a deep crown, also growing right along creek. Broken leader but still 60 metres tall! Broken top explains lost height from 2002 measurement.

access_notes: About 80 m SE of glacial kettle hole which is located 300 m SW of racetrack/ playing field and 600 m WNW of castle.
tree_site_notes: Vigorous. Tree has bend in lower bole.
CWHvm1 07

access_notes: Take South Shore Road from Lake Cowichan to Mesachie Lake. Turn right on Forestry Road and follow to the gate for Cowichan Lake Research Station. Park in the large gravel area before the gate. Enter through the gap in the foliage, through which a large redcedar is visible. Follow the rough trail to the cluster of large Doug-firs. Take the trail to the left of the first large fir (look for the boardwalk), and follow until there is a very large Doug-fir to the right of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Large fir standing in a small clearing at the edge of a grand fir and maple grove. Very gnarly lower stem and large upper branches.

access_notes: From the highway turn on Cedar road and follow signs until reaching Hemer Park. From the parking lot use the trail through the field up above. Turn left on trail at Morland road following the trail until you reach small Hemer Park sign. From the top of the slope the tree will be visible with nest near the top. Follow trail until the bottom and the tree is to the left.
tree_site_notes: The tree has an eagle nest in it, and the top 7 m is a snag (dead). The height to the last live branch is 57.7 m.

access_notes: Turn off Klanawa Main onto KM1411.1. Follow road uphill until you see tree just off road to the right.
tree_site_notes: Massive, ancient fir retained as a single stem after harvest in 2010. Broken top and only a handful of living branches. Twisting stem and flaky bark indicative of old, senescent fir. Generally poor site with low salal understory.

access_notes: Access is via a steep bushwhack up from Carmanah Mainline
tree_site_notes: A giant Douglas-fir in the remnant grove of giants!

access_notes: At 21km on Woss Road from Gold River, south side of road.
tree_site_notes: A small tract of substantial old growth has been left above the Muchalat River.

access_notes: Canoe from Willemar Lake to head of Forbush Lake, follow trail for approximately 1.5 km. tree in grove above trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a grove of exceptional Douglas-fir 60 to 80 m tall, approximately 25 ha in extent along north side of Puntledge River. Aspect south southwest, 40-45% slope, mid-lower slope, lower - toe mesoslope, concave, alluvial fan.  CWHmm1.
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: From Cedar, begin at the parking area at the end of Nicola Road. Hike the Cable Bay Trail to Cable Bay, then continue on toward Joan Point and Dodds Narrows. About 5 to ten minutes later look for a spur that turns right off the main trail (marked by a stump, see photo).  Follow this path uphill for another 5 to 10 minutes, using the waypoint provided to guide you to the tree, which will appear on the left side of the trail. The tree is situated on private land, 40 metres uphill on the spur trail.  The landowner currently allows public access.  Watch out for people riding horses as the trail is also used by equestrians.
tree_site_notes: This fire scarred veteran remains in exceptionally good health, with a very robust, distinctive crown. It may be the largest firs in the Nanaimo area.

access_notes:
Drive from Woss 10km south on highway 19 to the Mt.Cain turnoff going onto the Nimpkish Main south, following to the Sebalhal Main. Drive the Sebalhal Main to the McIver Main.
Drive the McIver main to across the McIver river bridge and then turn right onto first spur right off the McIver Main. Drive 600m to end of spur and walk into the timber to tree.
tree_site_notes: McIver #8 is in good health. It is largest diameter tree amongst a number of scattered Douglas fir vets in the 60m to 71m tall range within a natural fire induced second growth. The fire was recorded as 1930, and is verbally recognized to be originating from a seasonal fish smoking site, belonging to "the river people" within the greater traditional territory of the Namgis First Nation, at the mouth of McIver Creek & Sebalhal Creek on Vernon Lake.
CWHdm0 06
CWHvm1 05

access_notes: From the Fulford - Ganges Road turn onto Beaver Point Road follow as per coordinates
tree_site_notes: Located in Trinity Western University - Crowsnest Ecological Research Area

The tree appears to be relatively healthy. It has a distinctive crooked top that makes it appear to be leaning from afar. The sourrounding area is rual developments, but there is some deciduous forest nearby. There are also some other Douglas firs on the property of similar size that are a bit smaller, but still quite large.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Tree is right on creek edge to the right of trail.
tree_site_notes: Right on creek edge slope break, lots of fire charring and a gorgeous full crown with big branches.

access_notes: From highway 101, Sunshine Coast, signage to Big Tree Rec. Site near Trout Lake leads 3 km along Crowston Rd. (unsigned) to parking lot. Follow wheelchair accessible gravel trail to tree.

From Columbia Valley Hwy., turn west onto Lakeshore Dr., park in Parking Lot A. Cross street to Lake Trail, go to junction with Endo trail fork, continue to the east for ~ 30m, tree is 20m to the south-east.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Highway 4 to Crescent Road
tree_site_notes: Tree is estimated to be 800 + years old, located along trail in municipal park "Qualicum Heritage Forest", with its own interpretive sign.  See heritageforest.ca.

access_notes: Gracie Main to Nahmint Main
tree_site_notes: A plump healthy Douglas-fir growing on a steep slope above the Nahmint River.

access_notes: On the western end of an “island” of tall conifers located ca. 400 m NE of the gravel pit. Island is surrounded by alder swamps and pastures.
tree_site_notes: The top 8m of the tree is dead.

access_notes: From #2 tree go uphill short distance in direction of parking lot. Tree has large wound on NW side.
tree_site_notes: Some dead top branches.

access_notes: Sensitive area - exact location is hidden.
Hike up RS004 off Riverside Main. Access via Nahmint Main
tree_site_notes: Good health. Broken top. Windfirm in large leave area

access_notes: Kapoor FSR
tree_site_notes: Well marked, and trodden trail follows old mining pack horse route to the Kokisilah River, where a small grove of giant fir Douglas- fir and western hemlock reside.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Turning west off of Highway 19, directly across from the Sayward exit, you will find yourself on the Salmon River Main. Accessing the park is not that straight forward, as there is no signage, and the White River FSR is somewhat off direction from the paved Salmon River Main, which lured me off course for about 6 km before realizing that the river was on the wrong road I was supposed to be on. Backtracking, I found where I missed the turn-off at the junction. The rough gravel road rises steeply from the Salmon River valley, where at the 17 km marker a junction where the road goes down to a bridge crossing the White River, is not the right direction, stay left on the Victoria Main for a further 6 km, where the Park Boundary sign is your first indication that you are getting close to your destination. A short distance further, and an obscure (facing in the wrong direction of travel) sign directs you towards a short trail that leads you through the big Douglas-fir trees towards the river.
tree_site_notes: Touted as the "Cathedral Grove of the North“.  The tree is within the protected area of the White River Provincial Park, which is a narrow linear strip of preserved old-growth, with extensive harvesting visual all around it. The Douglas-fir, tree #1292, is right beside this short trail, before you get to the river. The western redcedar, tree #1293, is upstream, off trail, through some flat, but deadfall barriered ground.  The Sitka spruce, tree #1294, is very close to the western redcedar.
CWHdm0 06

access_notes: At top of 162 stairs on the Prospector Trail from the Day-use area
tree_site_notes: Broken Top

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be in very good health with no rot or conk apparent. The leader appears to be dead but has live foliage visible 3-4 meters down from the tip. It has lost a very large lower lateral limb (approximately 1.2m in diameter and 2m from the base of the tree) leaving a large scar on the tree (approximately 1.5m x 1.6m in size) that has calloused over nicely on the margins.

access_notes: Take Cowichan 700 spur off of Cowichan Main. Then take first right. Old road can be driven for a short distance before a washout. Walk along the old road before hiking up the steep hillside.
tree_site_notes: A leaning tower of a fir tree growing on a flat plateau perfect for a bushwackers picnic.

access_notes: From parking lot take trail down to former picnic ground, growing somewhat of an opening.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.
CWHmm1 01 Gnarly

access_notes: If you are driving north on Hwy 19, park just past the Kinkade Creek bridge and choose your path to this giant, which is near the east side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Anyone who had driven over the Kinkade Creek bridge on Inland Island Highway #19 has probably spotted this conspicuous fir towering over the highway.

access_notes: Follow trail south from upper parking lot at Chek Recreation Site for about 700m to gps points. The tree has a large talus field to its east and is highly visible from the talus field and from further down the canyon to the south. Many other impressive firs are visible around this talus slope.
tree_site_notes: Lower slope position along the bottom of a mossy talus slope.

access_notes: From Highway 19, turn onto Eve River Main FSR, and follow to the Junction Pool Rec. site. Located about 3 km before the Rec. Site access road. Located on a steep slope below the Eve River FSR Main.
tree_site_notes: A group of 3 very large Douglas-fir cling to the steep slope below the road, and are visible from the road. Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: Along Highway 1 north of Yale and south of Spuzzum.
From Gillies Bay drive south on Harwood Point Road. Park and walk down Shelter Point Nature Trail.

From the Chattelle Road parking area, make your way down to the river on the downstream side of the bridge (do not cross it). Continue along the left bank for about 100 meters, then head into the forest and make your way to the tree. This route can only be used when the river is low enough.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located at the edge of a raised microsite in a large riparian bowl (CDFmm06/11), flanked by abundant sword fern and horsetail just below. This tree has a ragged and broken top but appears otherwise healthy and vigourous. The majority of the surrounding forest is younger alder/willow wetland, with cedar-grand fir forest on elevated sites. The area appears to have been high-graded long ago, but this and several other large firs are still present in pockets. There is a taller and more slender fir directly adjacent to this one.

access_notes: From parking lot take trail down to former picnic ground. Closest large tree to the north of picnic ground.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Tree is located at the exit gate to the Cultus Lake Park campground off of Columbia Valley Hwy. Parking available alongside highway just before campground entrance. Walking distance ~ 200m east.
tree_site_notes: Veteran Douglas-fir with fire scar in the first third of the tree, large broken branches and conk in 2 third, and a flattened top. Tree is located on a flat slope position in the CWHdm. Indicator plants: Sword fern, vine maple, red huckleberry, vanilla leaf and kindbergia moss.

access_notes: From Highway 19, turn into parking lot for Ripple Rock Trail. The tree is above the trail, about half way in.
tree_site_notes: Situated where an obvious seepage discharges out of the bank.
CWHvm2 08

access_notes: At top of 162 stairs on the Prospector Trail from the Day-use area
South of Gartley Point Rd on Highway 19A. Please respect private property and view from a distance. Three is beside the driveway.

From Coombs, drive to Little Qualicum Falls Provincial Park, via Highway 4. Park in the day use area, and make your way down to the bridge that crosses the river just above the Upper Falls. Cross the bridge, and turn left, following the river on the opposite side to reach this tree
tree_site_notes: This is a tree in excellent health growing alongside the Little Qualicum River. A storm in 2019 devastated the park, destroying many old growth Coastal Douglas firs.
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: Drive north on the Lund Road 11.6 km from Powell River bridge crossing. Trailhead is marked with a 6X6 post on opposite side of highway from Atrevida Rd.
tree_site_notes: Heavily scarred trunk. Tree has many tops.

access_notes: West side of Elk / Beaver Lake Regional Park (off trail at end of Linnet Lane).
tree_site_notes: Healthy and supporting a leaning dead tree.

access_notes: From #3 tree towards pond. The northerly of two firs standing close to each other with intertwined crowns.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: From intersection of old road coming down from gravel pit with N-S road follow foot of slope to the SE. Tallest tree, about 20 m from edge of alder swamp.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Follow signage for Porpoise Bay PP, from Sechelt on Sechelt Inlet Rd. continue for 3 km past PP to Hidden Grove Trailhead at the Sechelt Heritage Forest.
tree_site_notes: Follow Monty's Way to Purple Trail, then Pink Trail to this tree. Many other large veteran Douglas-fir in this otherwise 2nd growth forest.

access_notes: Follow Conn Road from False Bay
tree_site_notes: Unassuming ancient fire scarred Douglas-fir, growing above a marsh, and behind the outhouse.

access_notes: Highway 28 - Campbell River to Gold River
tree_site_notes: Located at the edge of a clear-cut, and visible from the highway soon after crossing the bridge over Miller Creek. Growing in riparian leave strip beside marsh.

access_notes: Off trail. But visible from Tunnel Trail.  Best located using 2016 gps coordiantes, which should be accurate to 6m.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 04
CWHvm2 08

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot turning left at first junction and continue 100 m. Tree is on the right side of trail opposite junction with unnamed trail heading south.
tree_site_notes: Healthy beautiful crown with large branches, small animal den on north side at base but no sign of use. Dark, mesic site.

Large veteran Douglas-fir growing at the edge of a cliff above the Chemainus River. Tree is straight and growing vigourously. Hemlock growing alongside the base. Adjacent stand is old, naturally-regenerated second growth of primarily Douglas-fir and redcedar, with occassional biglead maple and black cottonwood (CDFmm01).

access_notes: From Heriot Bay, drive North on Hyacinthe Bay Road. Turn left on Granite Bay Road. Turn right on road just before Luoma Creek. Follow roads towards Main Lake Park - Clear Lake. Hike to tree.

From the Gabriola ferry terminal at Descanso Bay, drive down North Road for 3.5 km, then turn left on Barrett Road and follow for 1.1 km. Follow signs to Sandwell Provincial Park. Park in the small parking lot and take the trail into the forest. The tree is near the end of the trail when it reaches the beach about 1km from the parking lot. The tree is located about 30 metres off the trail to the left.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located on top of a boulder field of sandstone in relatively steep terrain very close to the ocean. There is a large fire scar on the uphill side of the tree. The tree appears healthy with a large crown. Surrounding vegetaion includes swordfern and oregon grape. Surrounding tree species include Douglas-fir, western redcedar, and grand fir.

access_notes: Turn from highway onto Mt Sicker Rd, turn right at Westholme Rd. Look for obscure sign above the left for Eves.

tree_site_notes: Has a broken top, about 2 feet of dead bleached wood, with a full healthly crown below.

access_notes: Stramberg Lake / Vic Marsh Trail. Drive north on Hyacinthe Drive to Open Bay FSR. Park at 1st bridge, enter into Big Tree Woodlot following logging road for 2 km, look for flagged trailhead on north side of road. Hike 5 km to east side of Stramberg Lake.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: From trailhead of Tisdall Walk, continue north along Pipeline road for 30m, and tree is visible roughly 30m east from Pipeline Road. Not possible to access tree base, but great view from Pipeline Road.
tree_site_notes: Just south of Eagle Tree, and still live practcally right up to its top.

access_notes: From Chilliwack head south to Cultus Lake on Vedder Road, make a left turn at the round-about onto Cultus Lake Road. Road shortly becomes Columbia Valley Rd., continue on and turn right on to Parmenter Rd, crossover hatchery creek culvert (approximately 200m from Columbia Valley Rd. junction) and park on either side of road. Watch for gravel trucks. Trailhead is on the south side. Broke Back trail branches to the right (west), carry on up the trail for about 100m, tree is on the lower slope.
tree_site_notes: This particular tree was originally dubbed the Boss by Alfie Brenner, locally known as the unofficial Mayor of Cultus Lake, in his memory, the Cultus Lake Stewardship Society group has decided to officially name the tree "Alfie". Veteran Douglas fir tree located lower-slope in the CWHdm. Indicator plants: sword fern, mahonia, kinbergia moss, indian plum, bleeding heart and vanilla leaf. Pathological indicators: basal fire scar, heart rot conk lower third, top broken in upper third.

access_notes:
From Squamish (junction of Cleveland avenue and Highway 99) drive 24.5 km north on Highway 99 to the Conroy Creek FSR
entrance.
- Drive about 500m up the FSR to a large parking area and campground. This is the Chek Canyon rec site.
- A climbers' access trail leads horizontally south from here. Hike this trail for about 5 mnutes until its end at a cluster of very
large talus boulders under steep cliffs equipped for rock climbing.
- continue bushwhacking south for about 600m along the base of the canyon. Progress is difficult because of numerous fallen
trees, the creek and talus/ scree slopes.
tree_site_notes:
Visibility of crown is limited. But top is dead (at least several meters in height) and broken. Top is >40cm where broken.  The tree is located on flattish ground next to a small creek in the base of a deep canyon. The tree is the
largest so far discovered in an area of undisturbed old growth which is approximately 700m long and extends for several
hundred metres up both side of the canyon. In the area there are approximately one hundred firs of one meter diameter or
bigger and at least five trees around two meter diameter. I believe the area has never been logged due to very large talus
boulders and other physical barriers created by the canyon topography.

access_notes: From Hammond Bay Road in Nanaimo, turn uphill onto Malaspina Way, then left onto Laguna Way, then left at the stop sign,  following Laguna Way to its end
tree_site_notes: This tree is in deteriorating health, having lost most of its crown in a storm about a decade ago. I am nominating it because very few old growth Douglas-firs remain in the Nanaimo area. The region once boasted numerous mature firs, but almost all older specimens have been logged.

access_notes: From parking lot take trail down past former picnic ground, then take first trail on road marked “closed” down almost to culvert. Free standing tree in draw on right.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: In lawn immediately east of Stanley Park Malkin Bowl.
tree_site_notes: Just to the south-east of Stanley Park Pavillion with lawn at base.
CWHvm1 07

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail until the junction with Anderson Cove Trail. Tree is on the right about 250 metres up the trail.
tree_site_notes: Growing on slope break five metres above small creek, mesic to sub-hygric site, dark, dense successional forest with sparse understory of ferns. Very burly with impressible multi-leader crown that leans and reaches to the south.

access_notes: Highway 28
tree_site_notes: Old Growth Loop Trail growing beside trail, above Campbell River canyon. Eagle or osprey nest on top of tree.

access_notes: Turn from highway onto Mt Sicker Rd, turn right at Westholme Rd. Look for obscure sign above the left for Eves.

From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot turning left at first junction and continue 100 m. Tree is on the right side of trail opposite junction with unnamed trail heading south.
tree_site_notes: Burly and flared base with fire scars and a very deep crown. Appears open grown.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail. Tree is about 20 metres south of trail junction.
tree_site_notes: Broken/flat top, fire char at the base. Lots of nice flat branches with heavy moss in the crown, great habitat tree. Shady mesic site forty metres from flowing creek in the bottom of valley.

access_notes: Tree is located in Linely Valley Regional Park managed by the Regional District of Nanaimo. From Hammond Bay Road in Nanaimo, turn onto Malaspina Way, then left onto Laguna Way, then right onto Lost Lake Road, and finally left again on Burma Road. Park at the end of Burma Road.  From here, you will have to rely on your navigational skills and the waypoint provided, as the tree is a short distance off a well tracked but unmarked trail. Take the second major fork on your left  off the main trail (you should soon cross over a tiny stone bridge) and begin navigating from there. Enjoy the adventure!
tree_site_notes: This tree is one of the healthier specimens I’ve located in the Nanaimo area, with a robust crown! The park it resides in was once privately owned and nearly all the forest there was logged long ago, but a handful of old growth trees remain.

access_notes: Growing along Girlfriend Trail in Mt Maxwell Provincial Park between junctions with Sunshine and Little View Trails. Shortest access via Mt Maxwell summit parking lot
tree_site_notes: Growing immediately next to trail slightly above gully bottom.

access_notes: From the Gabriola ferry terminal at Descanso Bay, drive down North Road for 8.3 km. The Elder Cedar Nature Reserve is located on the left (North) side of the road. Park in the small parking lot and take the trail into the forest.  At the first juncion, go left without crossing the creek. The tree is about 500m down the trail from the parking lot on the right side.
tree_site_notes: Tree appears very healthy with a large spreading crown. It is located beside a creek in a forest dominated by western redcedar, Douglas-fir, bigleaf maple, and grand fir. The understory includes swordfern, salmonberry, oregon grape, and salal.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is immediatley on the right.
tree_site_notes: Sweeping base with heavy fire charring. Deep, robust crown.
On the banks of the Puntledge River

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Tree is the smaller of the two immediatley adjacent to trail junction marker.
tree_site_notes: Fire char at base, deep and very branchy crown.

access_notes: Roughly 50m SEE from southeast corner of Stanley's Bar and Grill.
Highway 4 west of Coombs
tree_site_notes: Heavily used trail. Evidence of root trampling from visitors taking photos. Please stand at a distance when taking photos of this tree.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left and follow west side of creek gully, tree is the second large tree.
tree_site_notes: Gorgeous crown, lots of big branches, nice straight trunk. Could be a model for a douglas-fir calendar. Seems totally healthy but I was harrased by two brown creepers while measuring it, likely because of a nest and not food.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left and follow west side of creek gully, tree is the first large tree.
tree_site_notes: Deep branches and full crown.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 350 metres and the tree is on the right, before you get to the junction.
tree_site_notes: Mesic site below rock outcropping not far from creek in gully bottom. Dead top 10 metres. Very burly base and healthy crown (besides the top).

access_notes: Growing along Girlfriend Trail in Mt Maxwell Provincial Park between junctions with Sunshine and Little View Trails. Shortest access via Mt Maxwell summit parking lot
tree_site_notes: Big and very wolfy. Growing on moderate SW facing slope in stand of exclusively smaller (<40cm) douglas fir, fire scaring at base. A hundred metres in elevation above open garry oak woodlands. Based on form and stand characteristics likely open grown in more open habitat. As big or bigger than most stumps in the provincial park.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, head SW on unnamed trail towards Beechy Head. Turn right at first trail, an unnamed trail that cuts through to the interior trail. Tree is trailside 350 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Well charred trunk with cavities in the base. Slightly mounded in sparse dark understory in the bottom of a gully. A shockingly clear and straight trunk with a small, tight canopy, relative to most other douglas-firs in the area.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until coming to a creek. Turn left and follow left edge of creek for 30 metres.
tree_site_notes: Lots of fire charring and some pitch at base. Skinny crown.
CWHmm1 06

access_notes: Growing along Girlfriend Trail in Mt Maxwell Provincial Park between junctions with Armand and Little View Trails. Shortest access via Mt Maxwell summit parking lot
tree_site_notes: Growing on mesic flatbottom of dark gully, mixed stand with large (50cm+) redcedar, western hemlock, and big leaf maple. Beautiful full crown, faint but interesting zigzag shape to mid-trunk.

access_notes: From Highway 19, turn onto Eve River Main FSR, and follow to the Junction Pool Rec Site. Beside trail upstream of the Eve and Adam River confluence.
tree_site_notes: Located in a stand of trees that has not been cut, like many of the others within this valley.

access_notes: From Chilliwack head south to Cultus Lake on Vedder road, make a left turn at the round about onto Cultus lake Road. Road shortly becomes Columbia Valley Rd., continue on and turn right on to Lakeshore Drive, public pay parking on the left. Walk through the park or south on Columbia Valley Rd. to the Cultus Lake Parks Board Office. Follow Sweltzer Cr. Trail across from the Cultus Lake Parks Board Office for approximately 300m. Tree is on the high-side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Veteran Douglas-fir tree located mid-slope in the CWHdm. Indicator plants: sword fern, vine maple, mahonia, kinbergia and step moss, spinywood fern and vanilla leaf. Pathological indicators: Phaelolus schweinitzii conk present adjacent to trunk, basal scar, large broken branches in the 2nd third of tree and broken top in 3rd of the tree. Phaeolus schweinitzii is a common butt and root rot pathogen in old growth Douglas fir. This brown cubical rot is quite destructive to the roots and first 3m of the heartwood in the trunk of the tree.  Fruiting bodies are usually found on the forest floor at the base of the tree or above the roots. The fruiting body is easily identified by a brown velvety topped fungus. The pathogen commonly enters the host through a fire, logging, or an abrasion scar. This pathogen has most likely entered the Sweltzer tree through the fire scar currently visible at the base of the tree.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail. Take eastern trail that heads back towards coast trail. Tree is about 250 metres ahead on right.
tree_site_notes: Growing in shallow gully a few metres above creek on mesic to subhygric salal site with sparse/piney rock above to the south. Flat top, lots of fire char, super branchy crown that's greater than half the height of the tree.

access_notes: East of Hagensborg on Highway 20. Turn off to left at Saloompt Road. At 2.6 km, turn left at the wye, then 1.4 km further to signed parking area. Tree is in a small forest reserve beside the Saloompt River.
tree_site_notes: Wedged between the confluence of two rivers. Comprised primarily of giant Douglas-fir with an understory of cedar, Sitka, hemlock, cottonwood and bigleaf maples. Tree has a sheaved top.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is immediatley on the left.
tree_site_notes: Deep crown, dark mesic site.

access_notes: Beaver Creek Road
tree_site_notes: This tree has a significant lean. Located beside the river on the Stamp River Long Trail at approx. 1.5 km from the south trailhead.

access_notes: From the bus stop at the very north end of PKOLS park, take the Whittaker trail 500 metres south. Tree is right on the trail.
tree_site_notes: Tagged previously with a silver tag #0503. Beautiful deep crown with clear, straight trunk. Extensive coverage of powdery lichen gives it a ghostly appearance. Toe slope and rich/sub-hygric site of dense sword fern, mixed grand-fir and maple with surrounding douglas-firs.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.4 kilometres along coast trail. Tree is on the left about 150 metres before the next trail junction. Very easy to miss when coming from the west and basically completely hidden when coming from the east. Tree is about 50 metres back off the trail in a tangle of salal and blackberry. It is a serious challenge to cross those 50 metres in anything less than five minutes.
tree_site_notes: Super dense salal mesic site with oceanspray, nootka rose, and blackberry. Tree is alone in a opening sheltered from sea by band of firs and below a pine-rock knob. Very easy to miss from the trail. Don't recommend trying to walk to the base of it.

access_notes: East of Hagensborg on Highway 20. Turn off to left at Saloompt Road. At 2.6 km, turn left at the wye, then 1.4 km further to signed parking area.  Tree is in a small forest reserve beside the Saloompt River.
tree_site_notes: Wedged between the confluence of two rivers. Comprised primarily of giant Douglas-fir with an understory of cedar, Sitka, hemlock, cottonwood and bigleaf maples.

access_notes: Elkington Forest is a conservation community with 97 residential and 15 commerical lots nestled in 1000 ares of protected forest. The tree is located near Trailhead Hamlet with access from Lot 11 on the Big Tree Trail.
tree_site_notes: Healthy Douglas-fir with broken top.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn left at first junction. Tree is on the left 15 metres from gully slope break
tree_site_notes: Slight lean and a short crown, appears closed grown despite height. Large scar at base.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn right at first junction. Tree is on the left 30 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Little bit of fire char at base. Healthy crown.

access_notes: Drive North of Campbell River. Turn right on Browns Bay Road then left on Discovery Creek Forest Service Road.

Rathtrevor Provincial Park is located in Parksville, just to the south of town. Upon entering the main gate into the campground, the one way road leads to the right, follow the road for approx. 150 m, there are many big Douglas firs in this forest, with the largest tree site being our choice for the night. Site #8 is graced with this huge tree at  the driveway entrance. A rather odd looking, strange “Snouted Fir" is on the right hand side of the access road, and will act as your landmark if my site number reference is incorrect.

From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn left at first junction. Tree is on the left in a pair on immediate edge of creek gully.
tree_site_notes: Leaner with moderate fire charing. Growing right on edge of creek gully and immediatley adjacent to tree # 1807

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn right at first junction. Tree is on the left 30 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Very branch with deep crown. Very furroughed base with some fire charing. Appears growing on stump noticably larger than it is.

access_notes: Growing along Girlfriend Trail in Mt Maxwell Provincial Park between junctions with Armand and Little View Trails. Shortest access via Mt Maxwell summit parking lot
tree_site_notes: Growing on steep slope directly below rock bluff. Some faint fire scaring on base.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail. Take eastern trail that heads back towards coast trail. Tree is about 220 metres ahead on right.
tree_site_notes: Mound/stump grown. Growing in shallow gully a few metres above creek on mesic to subhygric salal site with sparse/piney rock above to the south. Amazingly the main stemm is not the tallest: candelabra comes of at twenty metres and sky rockets with smooth bark like a second growth tree would have in a plantation. Five plus candelabra tops. Crown is at least half the height!

access_notes: Growing along Girlfriend Trail in Mt Maxwell Provincial Park between junctions with Armand and Little View Trails. Shortest access via Mt Maxwell summit parking lot
tree_site_notes: Growing on mesic flatbottom of dark gully, mixed stand with large (50cm+) redcedar, western hemlock, and big leaf maple. Strong sweep to base.

access_notes: Follow signage from highway south of Nanaimo to parking lot. Walk down hiking trail for about 500 m. Tree is on crest between the two lakes.
tree_site_notes: 2nd growth forest with a few fire survivoring Douglas-fir dotting the landscape.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn left at first junction. Tree is the first big tree on the left after the junction.
tree_site_notes: Shallow crown, moderate fire charing on lower bark

access_notes: Metchosin Road to Beach Trail access
Dalrymple Creek Nature Trail. South of Sayward on Highway 19, a signed trailhead and parking lot on the east side of the highway connects to a forested loop trail.
From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot. Tree is right at start of trail on side of road. Can't miss it.
tree_site_notes: Very interesting tree. Skinny trunk from 5 metres up but huge bulging base with large scar and internal burning on the road side. Appears like it was once two trunks from one base but road-side trunk is gone.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn left at first junction. Tree is on the left 15 metres from gully slope break
tree_site_notes: Deep crown with fire charing at base.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn left at first junction. Tree is on the left in a pair on immediate edge of creek gully.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance. Head north from Ganges, turn right on Upper Ganges road. Then turn left onto Leisure Lane. Leisure lane turns into Howell Lane.  As you approach the intersection with Howell Lane, look back over the meadow, you can see Father Fir on the left side of the meadow. It towers over the rest of the trees.
From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot. Tree is straight ahead at the first junction.
tree_site_notes: Nice full crown, minimal fire charring.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is 40 metres down trail, slightly into the bush on the left towards creek.
tree_site_notes: Funny spindly top but nice branch crown lower down. Fire charring and some flaking bark at base. Fungal fruiting bodies at base sadly.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 250 metres up that trail. Tree is on the east side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: In a shallow, dark gully with open salal dominated outcrops on both sides. Super straight and clear trunk.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot turning left at first junction and continue 100 m. Tree is on the right side of trail opposite junction with unnamed trail heading south.
tree_site_notes: Broken top and short flat crown. Heavy fire char and large scar on south side to heartwood with some woodpecker damage, but otherwise healthy. Big bulging base like many of the Douglas-fir in the area.

access_notes: From main Mt Doug parking lot at the base of Chruchill Dr, take Churchill Drive up to the switchback, then right down onto the Merriam Trail. Turn left at the first junction, tree is on the left.
tree_site_notes: Wolfy, with a deep crown. Previosuly broken top and a couple new tops forming via turns towards candelabra. A few well healed scars at the base. Convex but mesic site with extremely dence oceanspray overtopping dull oregon grape, sparse salal, and incredible stair step moss.

access_notes: From the ferry terminal follow North Cove Road to signed parking area. Tree is approx. 0.5 km along the trail.
tree_site_notes: Bark thickness was nearing 30 cm.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is 40 metres down trail, slightly into the bush on the left towards creek.
tree_site_notes: Heavy lean with fire scaring at base. Broken top.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is immediatley on the right, next to the sweeper. Easy to miss among the bigger trees..
tree_site_notes: Some fire scaring, branches very low on trunk. Beautiful tree overshadowed by neighbours.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take Interior Trail 2500 metres. Tree is hidden about 100 metres north of the trail, behind thick salal and down a short cliff. Be careful not to wander off the cliff while salal surfing.
tree_site_notes: Gorgeous tree hidden off the trail below a short cliff. In a sparsely covered salal site with ferns and cedars, water recieving. Super mounded, had to crawl several way up to measure DBH. Growing on very old, very large stump over 1.5 from ground. Beautiful straight trunk and nice full crown.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until crossing a creek. Turn left towards open sky and deciduous trees and tree is 40 metres down trail on left.
tree_site_notes: Big sweep to base, growing on a mound.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, head SW on unnamed trail towards Beechy Head. Turn right at first trail, an unnamed trail that cuts through to the interior trail. Tree is trailside 400 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Fire charred stem is leaning hard with a huge wolfy crown with several candleabra tops coming off the high side. Growing from the bottom of deep dark gully with high rock on both side. With cedar and hemlock and sparse understory

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Centennial Trail west for short distance, tree is on the right.
tree_site_notes: Branchy almost to the base with some flaking bark at base. Broken top. Growing on a mound.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.4 kilometres along coast trail. Tree is on the left about 100 metres before the next trail junction.
tree_site_notes: Interesting open mesic to subhygric site with salal, salmonberry, and stinging nettle, canopy of red alder, maple, and grand fir with occasional dominant douglas-fir and western hemlock succession below.

access_notes: Off S Creek Trail roughly 8m to NE at a point roughly 50m SE of intersection with Wren Trail.
tree_site_notes: Very tall and skinny fir. Has a moderate-sized canopy gap to the north.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot and turn right at first junction. Tree is on the right 30 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Appears grown from stump larger than itself. Some woodpecker cavities in base and flaking bark. Broken and flat top.

access_notes: Tree is located at the junction of the Coast Trail and Parkheights Trail. The shortest/easiest access is from Parkheights Dr.
tree_site_notes: Beautiful tree hidden below trail in salal on the edge of high oceanside cliff. Stem curves towards cliff at the top and all of the canopy hangs free out over the water.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, head SW on unnamed trail towards Beechy Head. Turn right at first trail, an unnamed trail that cuts through to the interior trail. Tree is trailside 400 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Super mounded on old stump. Wood of the stump is still evident even after hundreds of years. Tree is leaning hard with evidence of several broken tops. Growing from the bottom of deep dark gully with high rock on both sides. Small ephemeral stream nearby but little understory.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot. Tree is in the middle of first trail junction.
tree_site_notes: Appears grown from stump or nurse log. Broken top.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Centennial Trail west for short distance, tree is on the right.
tree_site_notes: Growing on a mound. Broken top.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, head SW on unnamed trail towards Beechy Head. Turn right at first trail, an unnamed trail that cuts through to the interior trail. Tree is trailside 300 metres ahead.
tree_site_notes: Mild sweep but clear wood with simple crown, unlike most douglas-firs in the area. Growing in the bottom of very dark gully with little understory.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres along coast trail (past the two junctions towards the Copper Mine Trail). Tree is on the left just past the second junction and just before a creek and small bridge.
tree_site_notes: Trailside above sea cliffs in dense salal. Thick branches in a beautiful, reaching coastal crown with a flat top. Leaning heavily.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 200 metres up that trail until coming to a giant redcedar and a very big maple. Just north of the maple, turn right up a tight, dark gully. Tree is at the top where it flattens out, about 50 metres off the trail.
tree_site_notes: Submesic slope below rock outcrop. Impressive crown for dense forest. Supporting a ratsnest of blowdown that leans against it and likely broke the top.

access_notes: Tree is located at the junction of the Coast Trail and Parkheights Trail. The shortest/easiest access is from Parkheights Dr.
tree_site_notes: Sweeping base that leans out over trail, heavily offset crown that hangs towards the west. Healthy and gorgeous.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail. Take eastern trail that heads back towards coast trail. Tree is about 200 metres ahead on right.
tree_site_notes: Growing in shallow gully a few metres above creek on mesic to subhygric salal site with sparse/piney rock above to the south. Lots of fire char on a lumpy, fluted base. Nice branchy crown with a flat top.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.7 kilometres along coast trail (past the two junctions towards the Copper Mine Trail). Tree is on the left (uphill side), right on the trail.
tree_site_notes: Trailside above sea cliffs surrounded by alternating rock outcroppings and dense salal. Fire charred at base and a flat, broken, wind blown crown.

access_notes: Bushwhack through blackberry, and rose shrubs.
tree_site_notes: Please respect private property and view from a distance. The tree is beside the railway tracks on private property and is visible from Church Road at the railway track crossing. Tree has "wildlife tree“ badge attached to trunk.

access_notes: Growing on Coast Trail one kilometre west of junction of Coast Trail and Park Height Trail East Sooke Regional Park. Access via either trail.
tree_site_notes: Not a particularly big tree but maybe the most impressive crown I've ever seen. Extremely gnarly, eight to ten thirty centimetre branches and at least 3 broken leaders. Lowest branch reaches 15 metres towards the water and is nearly completely buried in soil build up at one point. Heavy fire scaring and several woodpecker cavities on lower bark. Crown needles are spare but green and lower branches robust with new growth. Growing on cliff edge along trail above a gully 50 metres from the water.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take Interior Trail 2500 metres. Tree about 20 metres north of the trail, well visible from the trail.
tree_site_notes: On a extremely salal-y plateau, several broken tops.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take trail to Beechy Head, then turn west onto Coast Trail. Take trail 1.3 km from Beechy Head. Tree is located just off the trail after reentering forest after passing piney bluff.
tree_site_notes: Incredible crown, huge double stem splits about 10 metres up. One top is broken but still robust. Close to sea shore in dense salal. Huge fire char on one side. Crown reaches toward sea. Growing on rock outcropping with lots of debris built up on uphill side.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take Interior Trail 2500 metres. Tree just below the trail below a short rock bluff.
tree_site_notes: Another funny tree. Heavily burnt out hollowed base, flaky bark is charred up the stem. Several broken tops, cedar-like candelabra is taking over. Crown stretches enormously east-west but is broken off and short in the other direction. Just below a short cliff, growing with sparse salal, sword fern, and cedars

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take Interior Trail 2500 metres. Tree is trailside.
tree_site_notes: Funny tree. Growing on solid rock surrounded by salal right on the edge of trail. Broken top that looks like it's been broken a few times. Cool cavities in the bark. Large branches reach off canopy but are borken themselves.

access_notes: Off trail. But visible from Tunnel Trail.  Best located using 2016 gps coordinates, which should be accurate to 6m.
Off trail 20m west of Pipeline Road, roughly 50m north of Tisdall Walk.
Off trail 15m west of Pipeline Road, roughly 70m north of Tisdall Walk.
Off trail 15m west of Pipeline Road, roughly 100m north of Tisdall Walk.
tree_site_notes: Prominently visible from road uphill and across the Pipeline Road from the Eagle tree. Leans quite a bit southward. Is right beside a large western hemlock. Somewhat open grown compared to other large Douglas-fir nearby to south.
A large Douglas-fir growing somewhat on its own. Nice thick bark!

access_notes: Take BR 60 off of Carmanah Mainline. Buswhack to GPS point through beautiful forest.
tree_site_notes: A large Douglas-fir with a hemlock growing off the side. Nice and open around the tree. Other big Doug-firs nearby.

access_notes: Take Gordon River Mainline to Edinburgh Main and drive nearly to the end. A spur road goes up hill and on the left where recent logging took place. This fir is in a small leave strip adjacent to cutblock.
tree_site_notes: A enormous Douglas-fir tree now growing on the edge of a cutblock. Windthrow has taken away from the asthetic of the area. Still an impressive sight to see. Remains unprotected.

access_notes: Take Gordon River Mainline to Edinburgh Main and drive nearly to the end. A spur road goes up hill and on the left where recent logging took place. This fir is on the right hand edge of a small leave strip adjacent to cutblock.
tree_site_notes: A gigantic Douglas-fir growing on the edge of a cutblock among smaller hemlock trees.

access_notes: A short bushwhack off Gordon Mainline a few minutes past Avatar Grove down towards the river.
tree_site_notes: A nice looking straight Douglas-fir with a broken top. Had a mountain bike ramp constructed beside it in the past as well.
