access_notes: Take Gordon Main to Hemmingson Main then TR11 to the top of the mountain. This road is steep and sketchy. Alternatively, hike from the base of the mountain from Edinburgh Mainline before you get to Big Lonely Doug. This is a trek but doable.
tree_site_notes: A nice Douglas-fir within an approved cutblock on the backside of Edinburgh Moutain.

access_notes: Tree is located at 782 Smith Road, Bowen Island, BC V0N-1G2. Take the ferry to Bowen Island. Continue onto Bowen Island Trunk Road. Turn right onto Mt. Gardner Road, continuing straight onto Woods Road. Turn right onto Smith Road. Continue onto the publicly accessible portion of the Xenia Centre's property. Signage will indicate where the Opa tree is (lefthand side of road). Beyond the Opa tree on this road is not open to the public. Please respect the Centre's instructions.
tree_site_notes: Tree is publicly accessible and in a viewing area with a couple benches immediatley beside the road. It appears to be healthy. The top broke off at some point in the past, but new leaders have taken its place.

access_notes: Tahsis Highway
tree_site_notes: Loop Trail around lake has an assembly of some very fine Douglas-fir, hemlock and cedar.

access_notes: Follow Valley Mist Trail to Skippers Path.
tree_site_notes: Fire scarred protective bark, and an electric green canopy catching the sunlight from far above the surrounding trees. This is a survivor.

access_notes: Travel about 9km down Hemmingsen FSR, until you see a discarded culvert on the left. Tree is just off the road.
tree_site_notes: Large fir visible from the road, on a slope with some remnant old growth. Several bark-stripped cedars are nearby. Appears to be just inside a legal old-growth management area.

access_notes: From Port Renfrew, travel north towards Lake Cowichan. After crossing the Deering bridge, turn left to start down Gordon Main and proceed for 23km. Turn left onto Truck Road 10 and proceed for 5.2km. Turn left and cross the bridge over Loup Creek. Immediately turn left and follow the road until it ends after approximately 150m. Walk down the old FSR for about 2km, then bushwhack to the tree. Be aware that there are several seasonal and perennial streams that you will need to wade across while following the old FSR.
tree_site_notes: Loup Trident is ancient and decrepit, and seems extremely unstable. The crown is generally healthy, with incredible spiral grain and two large forks flanking a dead top that give it a trident appearance. Most of the centre of the tree is rotted out with very soft and hollow wood, and one side has only a strip of living bark tissue supporting it, which is completely separated from the wood. It is on a low slope near a couple other large firs just above the creek.

access_notes: From Port Renfrew, travel north towards Lake Cowichan. After crossing the Deering bridge, turn left to start down Gordon Main and proceed for 23km. Turn left onto Truck Road 10 and proceed for 5.2km. Turn left and cross the bridge over Loup Creek. Immediately turn left and follow the road until it ends after approximately 150m. Walk down the old FSR for about 2km, then bushwhack to the tree. Be aware that there are several seasonal and perennial streams that you will need to wade across while following the old FSR.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be extremely old, with only a single living branch. The bark has an incredible appearance and texture, more reminiscent of ponderosa pine than Douglas-fir. The surrounding forest appears generally younger than much of the surrounding area, perhaps indicating that this tree is a veteran of a somewhat more recent disturbance.

access_notes: From Nanaimo, take ferry to Gabriola Island. Drive across Gabriola to Degnen Bay and launch a boat at the public boat launch. Paddle or boat across Gabriola Passage to Wakes Cove public dock.
tree_site_notes: Tree looks relatively healthy. Top appears to be broken off long ago. Some woodpecker holes present.

access_notes: Access is via a steep bushwhack up from Carmanah Mainline
tree_site_notes: A stately Douglas-fir that was left when the area was originally logged. Super tall and stands out from the rest of the surrounding second-growth.

access_notes: Take Cowichan 700 spur off of Cowichan Main. Then take first right. Old road can be driven for a short distance before a washout. Walk along the old road before hiking up the steep hillside.
tree_site_notes: A Douglas-fir with grizzled bark growing at the base of a fern-laden slope. A dense grove of similar sized Doug-firs can be found on the hillside above. An impressive sight to see these surivors!!

access_notes: Take Cowichan 700 spur off of Cowichan Main. Then take first right. Old road can be driven for a short distance before a washout. Walk along the old road before hiking up the steep hillside.
tree_site_notes: A hillside of proud Douglas firs that survived the widespread logging of the Nitinat Valley

access_notes: Lakelse Lake PP near site 21.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Lakelse Lake PP, near site 21.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: South of Rose Valley Lake.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy. There is another big tree right beside this one.

access_notes: North of Joffre Creek. From Duffey Lake Rd. follow North Joffre Creek logging road for approx. 2.5 km. Cross creek and contour through forest to slide path. Tree is isolated in slide path/avalanche chute surrounded by slide alder. Tree visible from North Joffre logging road.
tree_site_notes: This tree appears to be very healthy, some burls observed. Historic grown-over bole scars likely from boulders (slide). One fungi fruiting body located inside an old scar. No insect bore holes noted. Needles green and abundant to the tree top. Only one small cone located on ground, tree does not appear to be stressed. Tree dominated by Alder and surrounded by devils club, huckleberry, salmonberry, bracken fern, ribes and thimbleberry. (FG 2019) This tree is a perfectly formed sentinel with sprawling roots clinging to a huge boulder in the path of winter snow slides. The base swells to over 8 feet thick before expanding still further into massive, flaring roots.  ESE aspect, 40-45% slope, mid-slope, concave, (upper mesoslope, convex), avalanche deposition zone.  CWHds1, montane (RVP 1999)

access_notes: Headwaters of the Shuswap River.
tree_site_notes: Excellent health. ICHvk1

access_notes: Public access is permitted, but summer vehicular access is controlled at a gate. Trail access is open all summer. Winter access is restricted to clients.  From Fernie, on Highway #3 turn onto Mount Fernie Park Road, proceed through campground to the Island Lake parking lot (gate is sometimes closed so inquire about vehicle accessibility). If able to drive to the lodge, drive the 8 km through spectacular old growth cedar forest, then follow the Fir Trail and look for the large western larch on the crest. From this vantage point, peering down into the deep gully this very stately tree is visible, but very difficult to access. Alternatively, book yourself a cat skiing adventure, and ask to be taken to Hunter Bowl, where the snowcat pick up zone is located very close to the tree.
tree_site_notes:
This remarkable tree stands alone in an alder slide path, where evidence of seepage on the adjacent southerly facing slope was observed, as there was no snow on this slope. There are many very large trees on the crest above this Engelmann spruce, including western larch, Douglas fir, and some other mature spruce.
The tree appears to be in good health, as a 400 mm increment bore core sample was extracted with no signs of internal decay. The tree supports a healthy crown, and given its sheltered location, will hopefully extend its longevity for a while yet. Age is estimated at 550 years old.
Summer access would be very difficult as a waterfall is directly below, an alder choked gully above, and very thick vegetation surrounding the tree. Access at the time of measurement was via snowmobile. The Fir Trail is located above the tree, so further summer site access investigation is warranted.

access_notes: From Island Lake Lodge follow trail signage to Spineback Trail. In the lower meadows, before the trail begins its descent into the Three Bears peaks, a display of mature Engelmann spruce line the corridor. The noted tree is right beside the trail, and is an outstanding sight.
tree_site_notes: Having measured up quite a few Engelmann Spruce, I would have to sy this is the showiest of the bunch.

access_notes: This trees is 100m from BCBT #1177.  The directions to 1177 are: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1, as you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the now closed Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the very overgrown spur follows the drainage to where the road is obstructed by a small landslide. We had to back down from here, so best to just park at the junction and walk up to the tree. It is only about 850 m until this massive tree shows up on the left side of the road. You can’t miss it!
tree_site_notes: Healthy tree with 2 scars on trunk and some burls, located beside large western hemlock and western redcedar within grove of large, old trees and giant devil's club.

access_notes: From Kelowna travel north on Westside Road and turn left onto Bear FSR. Travel approximately 44km on Bear FSR then turn right onto Nicola River FSR. Travel approximately 13km on Nicola River FSR.  Tree is located approximately 35m into the woods on the west side of the road beside a small water receiving site.
tree_site_notes:
Tree is in good health overall, some frost crack and advanced rot visible on roots. No visible conk.

Tree is located on the base of small, historic alluvial fan just below the edge of the Pennask plateau and about 800m upslope of the Nicola River in the MSxk.

access_notes: From Hurley Road between Gold Bridge and Railroad Pass, turn west on to Upper Hurley River logging road. Drive approximately 5.5 km. Tree is below road, about 15 m from road in fire break. (Another large specimen is north of road, about 150 m east.)
tree_site_notes: South aspect, 0-5% slope, toe of slope, concave. ESSFmw, montane.

access_notes: Pass through Ainsworth Hot Springs on highway 31. Going north, before you get to the "Jones Boys" marine, turn left onto Western Rd. Follow this road for approximately 4 km as it zigs zags up the mountain. About the third sign pointing to Cody cave turn right towards Lendrum Creek. There is a logging company using marking tape that shows the clear cuts that they are going to log this summer. The machines are already in there. Go past the first two cat tracks heading down, but take the third road down towards Lendrum Creek that is currently untouched. Follow this old mining road for another 4 km through a patch of old growth Forrest. As you approach the last clear cut that looks over the valley, the road gets really narrow, steep, and rough. You will come to a small creek crossing the road. Cross the creek and right there is the tree. The total distance from the parking lot of Western Rd is 10.8 km. Your max elevation at the tree is around 1444 meters.
tree_site_notes: This tree is just beautiful! It is very healthy with no dead branches, and is alive from bottom to top. The top is bushy. There is a small fork about 20 feet from the top. There are other very healthy trees close by, but they are less than a meter in diameter. It is growing on a very steep slope next to a creek. We found this tree many years ago while backpacking into Wheeler Lake at the end of the mining road. There are also huge cedars before reaching this spruce tree in the area. One of the trees measured is 27 feet in circumference that you can stand up inside and the another at 29 feet that is very healthy.  The nominator named his tree "Allan Hirst Tree" after his grandmothers brother who served with the moose squadron "19" bomber group with the R.C.A.F. in WW2. He flew the Lancaster bombers over Germany and didn't come back after his 27th mission.

access_notes: This trees is 100m from BCBT #1177.  The directions to 1177 are: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1, as you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the now closed Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the very overgrown spur follows the drainage to where the road is obstructed by a small landslide. We had to back down from here, so best to just park at the junction and walk up to the tree. It is only about 850 m until this massive tree shows up on the left side of the road. You can’t miss it!
tree_site_notes: Healthy tree located beside old logging road, ~17m from road.  Surrounded by devil's club and vine maples in a grove of very large western redcedars, with some western hemlock and Engleman spruce.  Northeast side of tree has bark chewed, possibly from an animal, with lots of sap drips.

access_notes: This tree is 150 m east from the tree with the ID# of 100.
tree_site_notes: South aspect, 0-5% slope, toe of slope, concave.  ESSFmw, montane.

access_notes: Skiing is the easiest way to find this tree as signs and ski area maps will direct you there. If accessing in the summer, a good approach is to come up the Gorby Trail from Mt. Fernie Provincial Park and keep on following the summer access roads into Cedar Bowl. This big spruce is up in this bowl.
tree_site_notes: Tree does not have much remaining stature, as the top has been annihilated by either avalanches, lightning or a combination of both. Diameter is very significant.

access_notes: Near Clendinning Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Located above the ski out to the Glory Basin Chair, somewhere in the Kneedeep Glades.
Very remote, requiring long and difficult journey.
tree_site_notes: Tree is relatively healthy, though the very top is dead. Most of the crown looks good. Largest spruce in immediate area. Tree is likely a hybrid Engelmann x white spruce, but location suggests Engelmann.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Open grown, very branchy.Fascinating site: small Sx pocket at toe of gentle east slope, interspersed with Douglas-fir, pine and apsen. Tree is thought to be white x Englemann hybrid.

access_notes: 3371 Auchinachie Rd.  Please respect private property and view tree from the road side.
tree_site_notes: In 1903, six-year-old Robina Evans would bring lunch to her father and crew who were clearing the land of trees to start a farm. Robina enjoyed her time under the oak tree playing with her dolls and asked her father to save the tree.  In 1922, Robina and her husband Harold Truesdale purchased two acres of the Willow Park Farm for $500 dollars and built a home beside the oak. Robina passed away in 1984. The original house, now known as Westie Manor, and the oak tree remain standing and are both well loved and cared for. Robina’s oak is very healthy with a wide, flat-topped crown.

access_notes: Go east on Cedar Road from Hwy. 1, south of Nanaimo; cross the Nanaimo River and turn left (north) onto Raines Road; follow the road, which parallels the river's east bank, for about 2 km to the parking lot at the end (you will pass through the Snuneymuxw First Nation reserve, Nanaimo River #2); there is a sign and gate on the gravel road that heads ~north from the parking lot to the tree (about 120 m walk); the tree is easily visible from the lot
Located on Grant Street, immediatley opposite the apartment block at 1750 Chambers.
tree_site_notes: The trunk is much wider in one direction than the other. Located behind a wooden fence with danger tape on it, on the edge of an abandoned property. Beautiful round canopy that reaches around power lines. Seems pretty healthy.

access_notes: Located in Kings Park, 1150 Caledonia Ave, Victoria

tree_site_notes: The Snuneymuxw Harbour Landing Oak tree is a cultural feature supporting oral history of this location being very near to the historic Snuneymuxw Village site, on Unceded Coast Salish Land. Low and wide canopies on Garry oaks that were mature prior to colonization are important cultural features.

access_notes: Totem Park Ravine in Pacific Spirit Regional Park.
tree_site_notes: Highest leaders died in 2018, but other leaders about 50cm below remain living, but thinning somewhat. No major storm damages noted in recent years.

access_notes: Take Meades Creek Road to the south side of the south fork of the creek (just north of the mobile home parks). Park on the side of the road and hike down to the tree.
tree_site_notes: This grand fir stands on the edge of a bench just above a seasonal drainage into Meades Creek. The tree can also be seen from within or across the creek channel, as it stands well proud of its surroundings. It appears generally healthy, with a living, vigourous top. The surrounding forest is old second-growth (~120+ years old), with large grand firs and Douglas-fir scattered throughout the rich, flat delta. Old burned cedar snags are all that remain of the old growth here.

access_notes: Bottom (near the beach) of Totem Park Ravine in Pacific Spirit Regional Park, located below tree #318
tree_site_notes: Tree has a severe lean, crown has thinned 10-15%  in past several years.

access_notes: North of trail #7 at Wreck Beach, located in Pacific Spirit Regional Park.
Approximately 6 km east of Hope in the East bound rest area on Hwy 3 after Nicolum Creek.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, branches low on trunk, strong leader.

access_notes: Start up Prospector's Trail from Finlayson Arm Road. Follow the trail for about 350m. The tree is visible from the trail, about 30m to the north
tree_site_notes: The tree is situated at the edge of a small bench, along a seasonal stream. The tree is extremely tall, with a healthy and vigorous crown, unlike many other grand firs in the area.

access_notes: The tree is located in a large riparian bowl with steep walls on all sides. The bowl can be accessed via Top Bridge parking lot, or by parking along Kaye road and hiking through the devlopments. If accessing from Top Bridge, you may need to navigate some wetland areas.
tree_site_notes: This grand fir stands on a slightly elevated section of a large riparian bowl contained within an old oxbow of the Englishman River. This particular section is very flat and with an open canopy of grand fir, redcedar, and bigleaf maple, with no trees appearing to be more than a couple hundred years old. The understory is a dense carpet of sword fern, with riparian forbs occupying seasonal watercourses that snake through the area.

access_notes: Immediately uphill from intersection between road coming down from gravel pit and N-S road.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: From the Burnt Bridge parking lot, drive approx. 3.9km west, until you reach a pullout and trail leading down to the river. The tree is about 100m down the trail, right at the edge of a small bench above the river. There are several other large grand firs in the area, although this is the largest living.
tree_site_notes: The tree is in declining health, with much of the top dead, although the existing foliage seems healthy.

access_notes: Take South Shore Road from Lake Cowichan to Mesachie Lake. Turn right on Forestry Road and follow to the gate for Cowichan Lake Research Station. Park in the large gravel area before the gate. Enter through the gap in the foliage, through which a large redcedar is visible. Follow the rough trail to the cluster of large Doug-firs. Take the trail to the left of the first large fir (look for the boardwalk), and follow until you see this tree off of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Grand fir in a patch of remnant old growth with large Douglas-firs and bigleaf maples. Has a hemlock growing off its side.

access_notes: Take South Shore Road from Lake Cowichan to Mesachie Lake. Turn right on Forestry Road and follow to the gate for Cowichan Lake Research Station. Park in the large gravel area before the gate. Enter through the gap in the foliage, through which a large redcedar is visible. Follow the rough trail to the cluster of large Doug-firs. Take the trail to the left of the first large fir (look for the boardwalk), and follow until there is another trail branching off to the left at an orange survey marker. Follow this trail until there you see a large grand fir off to the left of the trail beyond a pile of downed trees.
tree_site_notes: Moss-covered grand fir off the side of a rough trail. Very staight, branchless stem up to a narrow crown.

access_notes: From Columbia Valley Hwy., turn west onto Lakeshore Dr., proceed for 40m, tree is on the right (north) at edge of grass.
Edge of parking lot in day-use area.
Walk 350 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to junction with Lower Goldstream Trail. Turn right and go 40 metres. Tree is 20 metres off the trail to the north.
tree_site_notes: Strongly mounded on floodplain site with extensive evidence of flooding (runnels to mineral soil common, debris piled on uphill side of trees). Immediatley adjacent to ephemeral channel. Right next to an even bigger cut grand fir stump (~1.4m wide). Top 7 metres dead.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 50 metres up that trail. Tree is on the east side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Beautiful mesic to subhygric grove of large grand fir grading up from seaside cliffs, super dense salal throughout with pockets of salmonberry, red elderberry, and sword fern. Very branchy tree, almost right to the base.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot cross Munn Rd and take unnamed trail that parallels road north from Centennial Trail. Tree is in the bush on the left in grove of grand fir.
tree_site_notes: Growing below the road in an open site with maple and forb cover, likely overgrown meadow. Slight lean, biggest of three in a tight clump. Overshadowed by 1m douglas-fir. Split top.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot cross Munn Rd and take unnamed trail that parallels road north from Centennial Trail. Tree is in the bush on the left in grove of grand fir.
tree_site_notes: Growing below the road in an open site with maple and forb cover, likely overgrown meadow. Leaning slightly with a healthy, deep crown.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 200 metres up that trail until coming to a giant redcedar and a very big maple. Just north of the maple, turn right up a tight, dark gully. Tree is at the top where it flattens out, about 50 metres off the trail.
tree_site_notes: On a dark, flat submesic to mesic site above a gully with sparse ferns and salal. Big scar with burn marks at base, split top.

access_notes: Walk 350 metres from main Goldstream Provincial Park parking lot to junction with Lower Goldstream Trail. Tree is just past the junction on the right.
tree_site_notes: Rich, wet, forested site with beautiful stand dominated by large maples and interspersed cedars and firs. 50 metres from cottonwood dominated floodplain. Broken top with wide, flat top of the trunk. Possibly previously topped by the park service. For reference surrounding stand is 50m tall.

access_notes: From Nanaimo, take ferry to Gabriola Island. Drive across Gabriola to Degnen Bay and launch a boat at the public boat launch. Paddle or boat across Gabriola Passage to Wakes Cove public dock.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy.

access_notes: The grand fir is located in the forest adjacent to the Selkirk College Silver King Campus, on the campus’s south side. From Nelson, BC, drive to the Selkirk College Silver King Campus and park in the lot. Walk to the back corner of the lot and enter the forest there. Look for a well-worn footpath leading up from the parking lot and into the trees. The grand fir is about a 1-minute walk.
tree_site_notes: The grand fir tree is located in a small, well-loved inland temperate rainforest in the back corner of the Selkirk College Silver King Campus. Neighbors walk their dogs through this forest, kids from the Silver King Childcare Centre go on outings in this forest (and have built a tree fort in it), and local mountain bikers have created a rudimentary pump track of berms, rollers, and jumps through it. There is very little understory due to the heavy human presence, but the cedar, hemlock, grand fir trees, and other trees appear to be thriving. There is an abundance of lichen hanging from tree boughs, and moss on the rocks. The grand fir we call Grandalf the Fir appears to have been part of a former art intallation, as there is faded red and green graffiti on his trunk, and the trunks of a pair of nearby cedars have been painted with the faces of ghoulish forest sprites. Grandalf has also been climbed, at least his lower section, as someone inserted a wooden seating platform in his boughs, approximately 5 metres off the ground. There is also evidence that someone used his lowest bough as a pull-up bar, as there’s grippy athletic tape wrapped around it. Another of Grandalf’s distinguishing features is a small forked trunk, at about 2 metres, which is dead and apparently died some time ago based on its short stature compared to Grandalf’s soaring height.
Co-nominator 2: Selkirk College Forest Technology Program Class of 2024

access_notes: Please respect private  property and view from a distance. Tree is located beside the house on Lakeview Heights Road. This road is on the North Shore of the West Arm of Kootenay Lake.
tree_site_notes: This tree has achieved an exceptional growth rate, and is just under 100 years old. Apparantely a leaking septic pipe provided enriched nutrients for a large part of its life. The yard is covered in this trees progeny, with trees ranging in size from 200 mm dbh to just seedlings.

access_notes: Porto Rico Road for 800 m. Small pull-out just after bridge crossing the Salmo River. Exceptional gathering of big cedars, hemlocks, cottonwoods, and a couple grand firs, squeezed between the road and the river.
tree_site_notes: Very old tree with heavy crenelated bark, that could be mistaken for a cottonwood or hemlock. Beautiful very tall tree, with widely spreading branches.

access_notes: The locally celebrated Corn Creek Cedar is right beside this tree. Turn south from Highway 3 into West Creston, and carry on through the Creston Wildlife Management Area, until the first bridge crossing, Corn Creek has a small parking area, a short walk upstream and the Cedar and Grand Fir are hanging out together here.
tree_site_notes: Not being that familiar with grand fir trees where I live, it is a real treat to see their shiny glossy wide spread needles on display in the forest.

access_notes: Ask the Kanaka Bar Band for permission, tree is in an extremely sensitive archaeological site.
tree_site_notes: Exception specimen, valley-bottom Fraser River, perched on a rock outcrop above the river. In an extremely archaeologically sensitive area.

access_notes: Mt Broadwood Hertitage Conservancy.  If interested in visiting this site, drive on Highway #3,  16 km. west from Fernie, and turn left onto the Morrissey Road. The road crosses over the Elk River, then the CPR tracks, where you take the road to the right. Stay on the main road (River Road) where you will come to the Morrissey Creek bridge. Just before the bridge, a road to the right (the TransCanada Great Trail) leads down towards the Elk River. Stay to the left all the way down the road,  as there are many rights, until you reach a yellow gate at the CPR tracks. Park here and walk down the tracks a short distance to your right (north), where you will come into a large opening that is the hydro transmission powerline right of way. To your left, towards the Elk River, and through a cattle gate (close after passing through), you will begin to notice enormous cedar stumps, and dark forests lining either side of the right of way clearing. The “Jeffy Dougy” fir is located in the forest on the left. If you follow a small drainage channel upstream, keeping your eyes up, the top of this gnarly “flowertop” tree can be seen above the canopy.
tree_site_notes: Tree is the lone interior Douglas-fir observed in this small protected stand of western redcedar, hemlock, black cottonwood, and Englemann spruce. Definitely predates the surrounding trees. Located on the Elk River floodplain.

access_notes: Boat access only - hike to coordinates from river, up a steep hill to a flat plateau, gold rush era cabin and trails nearby.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in decline and near the end of its life, significant foliage loss, yet it remains an imposing specimen.

access_notes: Upstream of Highway #16 beside the Dore River.
This tree is situated in mature forest north of the Slim Creek Rest Stop, located 123km east of Prince George
tree_site_notes: South aspect slope, 20%. Stand is mostly even-aged hemlock and cedar, with scattered large Douglas-fir veterans.

tree_site_notes: Some root rot but otherwise healthy

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Tree is on Kane Valley Road, 11 km east of Kingsvale off the Coquihalla Hwy, 400m off the road on the south side.

access_notes: Drive up Stanley Street to the top of the hill, where upon entering the Cemetery gates the tree is immediately visible.
From Horsefly turn right across bridge, turn left onto Z road in 1km, turn right at 26km, follow signs to Elysia resort, stop at Keno Lake Rec Site, 75m from 34km sign on decent trail.

From Peachland take Princeton Ave. to McDougald Rd. which turns into Munro Lake FSR.  Follow Munro FSR for 6.7km and turn left onto the new Finlay FSR. There is a wide spot for parking on the new Finlay FSR at the 7Km sign.  Park there and walk ahead to Finlay Creek.  Hike up the creek a few hundred meters to the tree.  An access map is available (see the "Tree images and location maps" tab). 
PLEASE NOTE: The Munro FSR reconstruction project is mostly complete.  The road is much improved but will still be muddy in spots.  Note that it is a ONE LANE ROAD with pull-outs.  During active logging you must be prepared to back up to a wide spot in the road if you meet a truck.
tree_site_notes: Fairly healthy.  Appears to have a broken top at about 8" diameter (guess).  Small stand of very large trees in the shallow valley of Finlay Creek.  Devil's Club.  This tree is within 20 feet of the creek.  Area logged to within a few hundred meters about 100 years ago.  A new logging road (Finlay FSR) was constructed about 200 meters south of the tree.

access_notes: This tree is situated in mature forest north of the Slim Creek Rest Stop, located 123km east of Prince George.
tree_site_notes: Flat slope, 5%. Stand is mostly even-aged hemlock and cedar, with scattered large Douglas-fir veterans.  Tree is healthy.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 12km then turn right onto Spokin lake road. In 850m turn right onto Dewar Lake FSR, continue for 7km, then turn right. In 1050m park and tree is 20m from cutblock edge. Note: tree 1218 is right beside 1217, and 1219 is 38m east.
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy, slight dead top. Tree was submitted as BC Special Tree Nov. 2022, ID unknown.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, hike up trail, and then descend to Lizard Creek, serious bushwhack up Hunter's Ridge.
tree_site_notes: Douglas-fir are very uncommon in the ICH zone of the Lizard Range.

access_notes: Turn from Highway 16 onto Walker Creek FSR. After crossing bridge over the Fraser River turn right onto POB FSR - Grove begins at approx. 8 km.
Sensitive area - exact location is hidden.
tree_site_notes: This tree is on a dry, open, west facing gentle hill with other vetran Douglas-firs. Top third of the crown is dying back. Age estimated to be 650 years old.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with massive branches and crown.

access_notes: At 5.5 km from the Crescent Spur trailhead. Right beside the trail
tree_site_notes: Healthy, but with several fungal fruiting bodies on forest floor around base, believed to be Polyporus schweinitzii. No broken tops, burls, or stem conks. Ground generally level. Mixed ICH moist forest.

access_notes: Hembrie Ridge is well known for its well established Douglas-fir and ponderosa pines. The Hembrie Mountain Road, accessed off of the Princeton / Summerland Road at approx. 9 km from town, is a good starting point to explore these expansive big tree strewn hillsides.
tree_site_notes: In search of the fabled Hembrie Ridge Fir referenced in the BC Big Tree Registry, it quickly became revealed that there were lots of Douglas fir and Ponderosas scattered throughout this expansive ridgeline. The tree was a very nice find, on a warmed up southwest facing slope.

access_notes: From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning onto Highway 5A to Princeton.  After 8km turn right onto Coalmont Rd. After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd and drive 5km to Davis Lake Recreation Site. From the Rec Site, hike 500m northeast straight up the steep hill above the lake. Grove of trees is on the top of the hill.
tree_site_notes: Growing on edge of dense Douglas-fir stand and open aspen stand. Gentle slope, slight sweep to tree. Double stemmed Douglas-fir with two 80cm+ stems immediatley adjacent. Submesic to mesic hilltop site with thick, dominant douglas-fir forest with veterant trees interspersed. Considerable mortality to large trees throughout area though no rot or beetle evidence, possible due to drought or damage from significant wind event in late 2000s.

access_notes: Beside Hwy#3, 15 km west of Princeton, clinging to hillside beside highway.
tree_site_notes: This tree report dead in 2019 (struck by lightening). Previous site notes from 2000: Healthy, ancient full tree clinging to hillside. Bark is scorched.

access_notes: Ask the Kanaka Bar Band for permission.
tree_site_notes: Fair-sized Douglas-fir with an intact crown

access_notes: North of Princeton.
tree_site_notes: This ancient tree has a broken top.

access_notes: Tree is behind the Boothroyd Airstrip, visible from highway.
tree_site_notes: Dead crown

access_notes: 1. Drive to Dome Creek Road (approximately 90km west of McBride).  Travel north on this road for approximately 900m. 2. Turn west on a gravel road.  This road is rough in places and a 4WD high-clearance vehicle is recommended. 3. As of 2020, the road was passable to approximately 7km.  4. Hike remainder of road to tree's location (located on the north side of old cutblock).
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and appears to be healthy.  No forest health conditions noted.  Tree is growing on south aspect slope with 20% grade.  The stand has evidence of old selective harvesting.

access_notes: Travel 18 km on Scotch Creek Forest Service Rd. (670 Rd), then 5.6 km on 673 Road. Tree is about 50 m below road on steep slope.
tree_site_notes: On steep-mid-slope, west aspect. Tree in leave strip between old clearcut blocks.

access_notes: Drive south from Ashcroft along Highway 1. Turn right on to Venables Valley Road. Turn right on to Twaal Lake FSR. Turn right on to Murray-Blue Earth FSR and then follow to tree's coordinates. Park at pull out and scramble down to the tree. It is very obvious from the road (look for the huge crown on the lefthand side of the road).
tree_site_notes: Large Douglas-fir growing off the side of a steep hill at the edge of a clear cut. The tree has an amazing upper crown

tree_site_notes: tree is alive and healthy but has some root rot

access_notes: Approximately 8 km on the Oyama Lake Rd.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: From the junction of Kal Lake Road and Hwy #6, drive east on Hwy #6 approximately 15.5km then turn left onto Noble Canyon Rd.Continue approximate 400m onto Coldstream Creek FSR (dirt road begins). Continue to 4.5km then turn left onto Becker FSR. Continue on Becker FSR to 13km then turn left onto John Park FSR. Continue on John Park to 16.5km and turn left onto Waneck Way FSR. Continue approx 1050m on Waneck Way through block K8UK and the Big Tree is located on the low side of the road
tree_site_notes: The "Father tree" has a large fire scar at the base. It has a broken top with several forks. The BEC Zone is the ICH xm1 (LMH75), on a mesic 101 site. It has a flat, SW aspect on gentle slope (22%). The soils were classified as a Silt Loam. Surrounding vegetation includes Utah honeysuckle, saskatoon, rose, Douglas-maple, clematis, Oregon grape, and pinegrass. The stand is predominantly Douglas-fir with smaller amounts of western redcedar, western larch, paper birch and white spruce.

access_notes: Please respect private property and view from a distance. Tree is located on 3058 Highway 31.

From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 1.6 km. Just after crossing a creek, bushwack about 100m off the trail to reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in good health and is the largest Douglas-fir in the recreation site. Surrounding trees and vegetation include western red-cedar, white spruce, black cottonwood, paper birch, devil's club, red elderberry, queens cup. Tree has a few woodpecker holes at the base. Tree is near a creek and on relatively flat ground.

access_notes: North of Princeton.
tree_site_notes: An old, full and healthy tree.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy with forked top. Evidence of charring on lower bark near ground. Some larger lower branches have broken. Slope 31%, Aspect 162 degrees SSE.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 12km then turn right onto Spokin lake road. In 850m turn right onto Dewar Lake FSR, continue for 3km, then turn right. Follow for .5km and follow fence line down for 950m. tree is 300m off trail to left
tree_site_notes: Tree has conk and broken top but is healthy

access_notes: From Williams lake head north on Hwy 97N for 31km, turn right on Blue Lake road for 7km, tree is on left 200m off road on top of ridge
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: From Likely head east for 500m then turn left onto Quesnel Forks (Rosette Lake road), turn left in 8.5km, follow spur for 1km and it is 150m to the right, flagged trail in yellow ribbon
tree_site_notes: Tree has broken top

access_notes: Highway 20 at base of Heckman Pass
tree_site_notes: none

access_notes: Approximately 3 km on Potts Farm ATV Trail from highway 24 where trail begins at McCarthy Corner.
tree_site_notes: Tree is generally healthy with multiple tops, fire charring (but no scars) on north-east side.  Crown is very lifted with first live branch at greater than 10 m height.  Salt block placed at the base of the tree so the area immediately around the tree is highly disturbed.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 12km then turn right onto Spokin lake road. In 200m turn right into Dewar Lake Rec site, follow lake edge around to east for 150m
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: Drive south on Blackwater Rd. from Prince George for 45 minutes and make a right on Punchaw Rd. at approximately 24 km past Baldy Hughes.  Drive down Punchaw Rd. for 6 km. You will wo be near the top of a high area, locally called Rosebud Mountain.  Just before the road takes a sharp hook to the right and enters a thick, old-growth forest, look at the tree tops to your left.  You will be able to see this tree at the edge of the forest on the southwest edge of the clearing with a twisted, old top.  It is approximately 300 m from the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a robust crown that is fairly consistent around the whole tree.  The top has broken off some time ago.  This tree is in the proposed Rosebud Mountain Reserve (for more information see http://savingrosebud.com/).

access_notes: From Williams Lake head north for 16km on Hwy 97N, turn left onto Bull Mtn rd, 1.9km turn right, follow for 3.3km and it is 40m off road to the left beside creek
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 12km then turn right onto Spokin lake road. In 850m turn right onto Dewar Lake FSR, continue for 7km, then turn right. In 1050m park and tree is 20m from cutblock edge. Note: tree 1218 is right beside 1217, and 1219 is 38m east.
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy, slight dead top. Tree was submitted as BC Special Tree Nov. 2022, ID unknown.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 12km then turn right onto Spokin Lake road. In 850m turn right onto Dewar Lake FSR, continue for 3km, then turn right. Follow for 3km and tree is on left below lower switch back 60m off road
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Pitch on one side. Adjacent to old ranch trail.

access_notes: From Williams lake head south on Hwy 97 for 30km, turn left onto Knife creek road , follow for 12km and tree is 50m from road
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: Daladon Road accesses a new subdivision development above the Logan Lake townsite. The grouping of these veteran trees is  located by finding the only opening between some houses (utility /park access corridor) on this road, and head downhill, where a small pond with a bit of a trail network winds about some old boy Dougs.
tree_site_notes: Introduced to this site by long-time environmental advocate Bert Parkes, the trees he had tagged with dimensions 20 years previous had long since faded, but Bert and the trees haven’t.

access_notes: Kane Valley Cross Country Ski Trails Provincial Rec Site. From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning right onto Kane Valley Rd. Drive approx. 4km until turning left at the signs for Kane Valley cross country ski trails. Trails are driveable in 4x4 vehicle in the summer. Grove is at the top of the hill where the trails loop back down.
tree_site_notes: Along edge of cross country ski trail. Noticable top die back.

access_notes: Take Ord road out of Kamloops past the airport. Continue on Ord road until it turns into Red Lake Road going over the bridge next to the rail road bridge. Stay on the road for approximatly 21 km until crossing Tranquille River again. Once on the east side of the river you will come up a bit and watch for pull outs on the left side of the road one small place to park on right side of road. Ditch has been dug along should to prevent vehicle traffic. You can go in where the no motorized access sign is on left hand/ river side. It is  in an open meadow area next to Tranquille River. Head northwards and you will approach the tree just beyond the last campground that has a notable built up fire pit.
tree_site_notes: Closed canopy growth form. Tree growing on edge of high-bench flood plain (IDFhx2 112 site series) and built up (but closed) campground site. Tree obviously predates campground construction. Tree appears healthy and robust. There is some cutting damage and woodpecker holes.

access_notes: Larch Hills Nordic area is accessed from the Grandview Bench Road, and then follow signage up gravel roads for 8 km to the day lodge. The big trees are a further 5 km up the Larch Hills FSR, on the aptly named Big Tree Alley.
tree_site_notes: This giant Douglas-fir is right at the edge of a big logging block, and right beside the road. Appears lonely with all of its brethren having been sacrificed to the saw.

access_notes: Highway 16 from McBride to Prince George is devoid of settlements, unless you travel a few km down to the Fraser River, then there are a few hardy souls eeking a living. Dome Creek is the only settlement in the vicinity of this tree. Spied right from the highway to the northeast of the Ptarmigan Creek bridge.
tree_site_notes: Another one of the amazing trees hiding out in this frontier. This Douglas-fir has been visited by timber cruisers in the past, as the paint marks on the tree indicate. But the recent Provincial Park designation should keep it safe for a while.

access_notes: From Dunster, head northwest on Dunster-Croydon Road for 1.4 km. Turn right onto Dunster Station Road and continue for 3.7 km. Turn right onto BC Highway 16 East and drive for 10.8 km. Turn left onto Croydon Road North and continue onto Horsey Creek Road for 3.4 km from the highway. Park on side of road and walk into forest for less than 100m.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy and has a slight bend at the base. Largest fir in area. Surrounded by smaller trees.

access_notes: Across Mountainview Road from the Paradise trailhead.

From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 5km then turn right onto Dugan lake road. Drive 1.5 km to rec site.  From here ATV trail goes south for 2km and then turn left onto road and head east for 3.2km, turn left onto trail at landing for 640m, tree is on right side of trail
tree_site_notes: tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: Signage on Highway #3. Tree is beside parking lot in the day-use area. Visible from highway.

From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning onto Highway 5A to Princeton.  After 8km turn right onto Coalmont Rd. After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd and drive 5km to Davis Lake Recreation Site. From the Rec Site, hike 500m northeast straight up the steep hill above the lake. Grove of trees is on the top of the hill.
tree_site_notes: Fire scarred, healthy. Claw marks on bark. Considerable mortality to large trees throughout area though no rot or beetle evidence, possible due to drought or damage from significant wind event in late 2000s.

access_notes: The GPS co-ordinates are approximate, follow directions to find this tree. Drive through Logan Lake when coming from Kamloops. Turn LEFT at the Esso station and continue to the Black Bull pub where you can park. Walk the service road SOUTH behind the pub, continue past Duck Lake and follow the power line road to its high point.  Go LEFT down the hill until it flattens out. Follow the trail to the NORTH and you will immediately see a dozen old firs that are between 3-4m in circumference.
tree_site_notes: On an eastern slope below the hydro line. Perhaps 400 years with a slight lean and 10cm of bark.  No nests but plenty of woodpecker holes. 20+cm branches, none are dead.  There are at least a dozen old vets in a 500 m stretch along the gulley between the hydro line and gulley bottom.

access_notes: The GPS co-ordinates are approximate, follow directions to find this tree. Drive through Logan Lake when coming from Kamloops. Turn LEFT at the Esso station and continue to the Black Bull pub where you can park. Walk the service road SOUTH behind the pub, continue past Duck Lake and follow the power line road to its high point.  Go LEFT down the hill until it flattens out. Follow the trail to the NORTH and you will immediately see a dozen old firs that are between 3-4m in circumference.
tree_site_notes: On an eastern slope below the hydro line. Perhaps 400 years with a slight lean and 10cm of bark.  No nests but plenty of woodpecker holes. 20+cm branches, none are dead.  There are at least a dozen old vets in a 500 m stretch along the gulley between the hydro line and gulley bottom.

access_notes: Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road. Turn left onto Thompson Road, follow to end, then walk down beside lagoon chainlink the backwater channel is parallel.
tree_site_notes: A lone Douglas-fir, amongst some big cedar trees residing beside a good water source.

access_notes: From Williams lake head south on Hwy 97 for 30km, turn left onto Knife creek road , follow for 13km and tree is on right side beside road
tree_site_notes: Tree has a recent broken top

access_notes: Access is restricted.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a broken top with evidence of some heart rot occurring where the break is. Otherwise, it has a healthy quality. There is use by small mammals, specifically squirrels and mise and evidence of woodpecker excavations in the bark. There was no evidence of past or present Douglas-fir bark beetle activity. The tree is located on a small knoll, surrounded by multi-aged Douglas-fir forest, with a minor component of spruce. SBSdw2-01. The supporting tree structure buffer on the east side is less than 56 meters due to proximal private land.

access_notes: From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning onto Highway 5A to Princeton.  After 8km turn right onto Coalmont Rd. After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd and drive 5km to Davis Lake Recreation Site. From the Rec Site, hike 500m northeast straight up the steep hill above the lake. Grove of trees is on the top of the hill.
tree_site_notes: Adjacent to two large dead douglas-fir. Top 3 feet dead, potentially drought affected. Considerable mortality to large trees throughout area though no rot or beetle evidence, possible due to drought or damage from significant wind event in late 2000s.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Tree appears healthy, 30 cm hole in base with fire scaring within, possible culturally modified tree. Tree growing on edge of opening along bench on gentle east facing slope. Despite slope area is moisture recieving from steeper slope above to the east and covered in dense prickly rose and snowberry. Veteran trees interspersed among earlier seral site associations with aspen and dense shrubs. Tolko cutblock layed out approx 50 m away to SW.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Tree growing near bottom of small gully below gentle slope. Surrounded by by snowberry and Douglas maple brush.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.
tree_site_notes: On bench below steeper slope but above another steeper slope. Mesic site, recently logged. Tree was cruised as part of cutblock. Healthy. 2 very large fallen firs 20 m to south, both have evidence of butt rot.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive south on Highway 97 for 15km, turn left onto Likely road, 4.6km turn right onto Horsefly road for 5km then turn right onto Dugan lake road. Drive 1.5 km to rec site. It is across from site 18, 150m to the south.
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: Highway 31 between Nelson and Balfour
tree_site_notes: Tree has a dead top.

tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy

access_notes: Lundbom Rd., off of highway 97C, east of Merritt.

From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning onto Highway 5A to Princeton.  After 8km turn right onto Coalmont Rd. After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd and drive 5km to Davis Lake Recreation Site. From the Rec Site, hike 500m northeast straight up the steep hill above the lake. Grove of trees is on the top of the hill.
tree_site_notes: In a group with three dead standing and one dead fallen Douglas-fir all greater than 1.5m DBH.  Considerable mortality to large trees throughout area though no rot or beetle evidence, possible due to drought or damage from significant wind event in late 2000s.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune, drive north on Highway 16 towards McBride for 16.7 km. Turn off onto the Small River FSR and continue. Pull off to side of road below slope and hike up to tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy and largest in area. Can be seen from the road. On a south facing slope. Looks to be in an area slated for forestry.

access_notes: From Williams Lake head south on Hwy 97 to 150 Mile then turn left on pigeon road, turn right onto redeau lake road in 1km, follow for 29km and turn right on 108 road for 1km, then turn left on Tillicum lake road, in 850m turn right on tillicum south FSR for 500m and it is 75m off road to right in middle of a cutblock
tree_site_notes: Broken top

access_notes: Savory Ridge Ungulate Winter Range/North shore of Francois Lake. Approximately 100 km due west of Vanderhoof.  The co-ordinates for this tree are approximate.  The tree is growing in the middle of a large opening with only scattered smaller Fdi and At.
tree_site_notes: No obvious pathogens, however the crown is thinning substantially.

access_notes: Located above Nemaiah Valley Road near the Vedan Road and Nemaiah Valley Lodge access road.
tree_site_notes: Stunted tree, resulting from windy conditions, forest fires, and higher latitude climatic effects.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.

tree_site_notes: On bench below steeper slope but above another steeper slope. Mesic site, recently logged. Tree was cruised as part of cutblock. Heavy pitch on one side.

After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd and drive 5km to Davis Lake Recreation Site. From the Rec Site, hike 500m northeast straight up the steep hill above the lake. Grove of trees is on the top of the hill.
tree_site_notes: Fire scarred. Open grown and branchy. Considerable mortality to large trees throughout area though no rot or beetle evidence, possible due to drought or damage from significant wind event in late 2000s.

access_notes: From Kamloops head east on Highway 1. Turn right on Dallas Drive, signs for Barnhartvale. Follow Barnhartvale Rd for 8.4 km and turn right on Robbins Range Rd. Follow for 3.6 km, keeping right (straight) onto Campbell Range Rd. Park at the junction with Scuitto Lake FSR. Tree is a few hundred metres east of road in the bush.
tree_site_notes: Growing on N facing slope in young Douglas-fir forest, likely predates incursion of stand into previous grasslands. Growing along grassland edge and near very old over grown ranch road.

access_notes: A short trail north of the campground leads up onto the plateau above the lake.
tree_site_notes: Windswept plateau has left many of the trees stunted, but very old.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Growing in moisture receiving area below cutblock slope and just along open bench above another cutblocks. Branches right to base.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Growing in moisture receiving area below cutblock slope and just along open bench above another cutblocks. Heavy cattle useage through the site.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.
tree_site_notes: On bench above cutblock. Beautiful interior Douglas-fir growth form with round shape and leader. Bench site open and well-used by cattle.

access_notes: Take Ord Road out of Kamloops past the airport. Continue on Ord road until it turns into Red Lake Road going over the bridge next to the rail road bridge. Stay on the road for approximatly 21 km until crossing Tranquille River again. Once on the east side of the river you will come up a bit and watch for pull outs on the left side of the road one small place to park on right side of road. Ditch has been dug along should to prevent vehicle traffic. You can go in where the no motorized access sign is on left hand/ river side. It is in an open meadow area next to Tranquille River. Head northwards and you will approach the tree just beyond the last campground that has a notable built up fire pit.
tree_site_notes: Tree growing halfway up a 4 metre tall esker above high-bench flood plain site immediatley adjacent to BC BigTree # 1531, a 1.29m interior Douglas-fir nominated by Brayden Stephenson. Bark lost on uphill side to bare wood with fire scaring. Possible culturally modified tree.

access_notes: From Kamloops head east on Highway 1. Turn right on Dallas Drive, signs for Barnhartvale. Follow Barnhartvale Rd for 8.4 km and turn right on Robbins Range Rd. Follow for 3.6 km, keeping right (straight) onto Campbell Range Rd. Park at the junction with Scuitto Lake FSR. Tree is a few hundred metres east of road in the bush.
tree_site_notes: Growing on N facing slope in young Douglas-fir forest, likely predates incursion of stand into previous grasslands. Adjacent to second large vet, in small brushy fir forest. Leaning downslope. Other vets in area mostly leaning down slope

access_notes: From Kamloops head east on Highway 1. Turn right on Dallas Drive, signs for Barnhartvale. Follow Barnhartvale Rd for 8.4 km and turn right on Robbins Range Rd. Follow for 3.6 km, keeping right (straight) onto Campbell Range Rd. Park at the junction with Scuitto Lake FSR. Tree is a few hundred metres east of road in the bush.
tree_site_notes: Growing on N facing slope in young Douglas-fir forest, likely predates incursion of stand into previous grasslands. Area features grove of about 10 to15, 80cm Douglas-fir vets. Fire scarred on base.

access_notes: From Elko, drive onto River Road, drive 5 km to  the Silver Springs parking area. Climb up trail. Tree is above the path along the 1st lake.
tree_site_notes: Southwest facing slope. Tree is at base of a well drained, moss covered scree slope, with birch trees.

access_notes: Above the lake, and near the private residence.
Above highway 3, where the Swansea vehicle bridge crosses over Moyie River. Cross railway tracks, climb to ridgeline.

Follow Tranquille Road through Kamloops travelling west to where the road crosses the CNR tracks and the pavement ends, continue as the road climbs up above Kamloops Lake. Tree is below the Tranquille / Kriss FSR
tree_site_notes: Located in a sagebrush, juniper ecosystem, where some fire resistant Douglas-firs continue to thrive.

access_notes: Drive on south Highway 93 towards Grasmere, at top of Elk River Bridge hill, turn right to parking lot
tree_site_notes: Common fire survivor Douglas fir in the South Country grasslands.

access_notes: Drive on south Highway 93 towards Grasmere, at top of Elk River Bridge hill, turn right to parking lot
tree_site_notes: Common fire survivor Douglas-fir in the South Country grasslands. Tree has a spire top.

access_notes: From Williams Lake drive south to 150 mile house, turn left towards Horsefly/Likely, turn left towards Likely, drive past Big lake, turn left onto Beaver Lakes Road, turn right onto 8300 (ridge road), turn right onto side road at 4km, turn left in 825m, turn left in 250m, turn right in 200m, turn right in 350m. Drive to end and park. Navigate to tree. Approximately 300m east down 45% slope.
tree_site_notes: A healthy tree on a flat wet shady site, protected by steep ridge above, estimated height of 45m.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive North on highway 97 for 23km, turn right on Lyne creek road. Drive 7.9km, turn right for 2.6km  to Forest Lake Rec Site. Walk around west/north side of lake for 850m on trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy but has a dead fork above DBH. CAUTION: the dead fork is quite dangerous so try not to touch it. Tree was submitted as BC Special Tree ID S26991.

access_notes: From WIlliams Lake drive west on Highway 20 for 2km, turn left onto Dog Creek Road, follow for 25km. Turn right onto Tuckers Road (through field), follow for 4km. Quad may be required as road is rough and at the time there was no road connection to that section, just quad trail. Old road goes through Linde Bros mill site, but permission is required.
tree_site_notes: Tree is alive and healthy. It is right beside an existing road and adjacent to a proposed permit CP 20. A 2 tree length (84m) reserve (WTP) has been established around it to retain all supporting trees. Tree was submitted as BC Special Ttree Nov. 2020, ID unknown.

access_notes: Turn from Highway 16 onto Walker Creek FSR. After crossing bridge over the Fraser River turn right onto POB FSR - Grove begins at approx. 8 km.

Tree is located on one of the trails that loops around in the hills behind Peterson Creek Nature Park in Kamloops. Multiple ways to access but safest is starting from the main parking lot for Peterson Creek located above the provincial land off of Columbia and 5 th street. Once on the trail follow main trail until east tod moore trail sign taking you up the left/east side of the canyon. Follow all the way up until you reach the bench and viewpoint above the named "Falls Viewpoint". From here there are two options:  # 1 - follow the double track towards the fence and powerlines. At the fence there is a sign down with a phone number. Cross the stairs or close cattle gate behind you and continue on double track as it leads up under the power lines. There is a single track spur going up hill where you will exit right climbing a bit more and veering west before reaching the large tree from below,  OR # 2 - follow canyon side single track from this location until it goes up and veers left away from the canyon. Continue until you come to an old logging slash pile left and take single track that leads below it, you will shortly come up to the big tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a large intact dead top. Massive limbs, larger than most of the trees around it. Chipmunk observed in tree on multiple visits. A very old and rare Quinine Conk located on trunk (noted on Inaturalist ID:220767603). I am sure many others have rested under its shade and admired its girth and presence.

access_notes: Hike in from Robbins Range Road pull off for Buse Lake Park cliffside. Tree can be seen when approaching Upper Buse Pond. From Kamloops follow Hwy#1 to Dallas Drive exit. Follow to Barnhartvale rd, when it curves right off Dallas Drive exit. Follow to Robbins Range Road to Robbins Creek Road, parking is on left side of road by popular winter tobbogan hill.
tree_site_notes: Large and Healthy looking. doug-fir, root rot appears to be in greater area near cliffs and may pose hazard in future. generally undisturbed land evidenced by propensity of wildflower varieties.

access_notes: Petitot R/Stanislaus Cr.
tree_site_notes: Extensive stand of trees to 23m (75') tall.

access_notes: Clearwater Rd to Wells Gray Park - Edgewood Retreat.  Tree is in regenerated mixed forest from historical 1926 fire.
tree_site_notes: Tree estimated to be 90 years old (Terry elson)..

access_notes: Tree located approximately 10 m north of Tyaughton Creek Trail, approximately 500 m WNW of Deer Pass trail junction.
tree_site_notes: Southwest aspect, level valley bottom at toe of slope. ESSFxc.

access_notes: Located above Fairy Creek Trail.
tree_site_notes: On open grassy, south facing slope with small seepage.

access_notes: There is a trail called Old Stumpy that is part of the Elk Valley / Transcanada Trail. It heads north out of Fernie, and about 1 km along a lone Lodgepole Pine stands beside the BC Hydro right of way.
tree_site_notes: This Lodgepole Pine likely regenerated after the 1908 Fernie fire, and has managed to put on some extra growth as a result of its southern exposure, spring fed water source, and generally nice view.

access_notes: Located beside the lower Montane Trail near Coal Creek
tree_site_notes: A remnant tree from an area that was otherwise heavily impacted by industrial activity in the early 1900's. Tree has 4 tops.

access_notes: From Ashcroft, head south on the Transcanada Highway. Turn right (West) onto Hat Creek Road. Follow this road for 22km; it will eventually end at the fire lookout at Cornwall Hills Provincial Park. Walk to the tree’s coordinates from here. The road is rough, and 4 wheel drive with high clearance is necessary.
tree_site_notes: Twisted old lodgepole pine. The original leader has died, but a new leader has taken its place, giving this tree an odd candelabra crown.
ESSFmw, montane.

access_notes: From Cypress Bowl ski area, follow Baden Powell Trail east, cross tributary of Cypress Creek, then follow rough trail up east side of creek to Old Strachan Trail. Tree is above trail about 100 m and slightly west, near base of clearing below bluffs.
tree_site_notes: Middle mesoslope below bluffy area. Aspect west. MHmm1

access_notes: From old Sunset Creek Trail, hike cross-country south to base of large talus slope. Tree is in talus, near top, below cliffs (visible from Bowen Island Lookout-Howe Sound Crest Trail).
tree_site_notes: Aspect west, slope approximately 60-65%, middle slope, concave, avalanche deposition zone. MHmm1, montane.

access_notes: No public access
tree_site_notes: Aspect NNW, slope 60-70%, middle slope, concave. CWHvm1.

access_notes: Drive North from Campbell River. Turn right on Big Tree Main. Turn left on Venus Main. Turn right on roads that bring you up ridge running south from Big Tree Peak. Drive as far as you can then bushwhack along ridge.

From the Sayward junction, head south onto Dyer Rd. Merge right onto Salmon River Mainline, then take the first left onto White River Road/A Branch/Canyon Main. Turn right to head up A branch, and proceed for 5.2k. Stay straight to merge onto Tlowils Lake Main. After 550m, turn right onto TL100. Follow for 4.7k until you see a patch of retained old growth on the right. Hike up through the patch, passing Tree #297 (Yellow-cedar; Sir Daniel Sampson). The tree is near the top of the retention patch.
tree_site_notes: The tree sits near the top of a retention patch of very productive high-elevation old growth, containing an exceptionally large yellow-cedar (Tree #297). The top has been blown off, but the lower branches are vigorous and the tree appears to be in good health.

access_notes: South end of Shell Rd. in Richmond.
When nominated the tree was located in the Lannan Forest. Current tree and landownership status is unknown.
tree_site_notes: Some rotten branches, otherwise healthy.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: Massive, sprawling tree with many stems surrounding a hollow cavity. As evidenced by historical photographs, the appearance has changed little in the past 60 years. The tree may have once had a large central stem that died and was regenerated by many stump sprouts which have since fused. The largest of these individual stems was measured at 36cm DBH. Several of the stems are dead but the tree is, overall, very healthy and vigourous. The tree sits on a gentle and well-shaded NW slope (CDFmm04) blanked in Galanthus which erupt in a spectacular winter bloom.
Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Healthy.  Trunk forms 3 stems above 1.37 m; main leader broken off; 2 remaining stems are vigorous.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Tree is in front garden on 2513 Kings Avenue, West Vancouver, B.C.
tree_site_notes: Designated a West Vancouver Heritage Tree.  Level upland site. CWHxm1

access_notes: The tree is located next to driveway on 598 Martindale Road in Parksville.  Please respect private property and view the tree from the road.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears healthy; likely some decay in the lower trunk from a few small cavities from cut off branches.  The tree is forked into 5 main branches.  Tree is open grown in the middle of a grassy yard, the crown touches some conifers on the one side at the fence.  The site is flat.  It is believed that the tree was dug up from its natural location near Horne Lake and planted in the yard in the mid- to late-1960's.

access_notes: About 2.5 km north of Quatse Lake.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with forked top.

access_notes: From Sechelt, head north on Sechelt Inlet Road towards the park Hidden Grove / Sechelt Heritage Forest Recreation Site. Park between these 2 areas on the right beside an old, chained off logging road. Walk this road until you reach the powerlines and then head south along the powerlines. Watch for a little hidden trail that will appear on the left (east) side of the powerlines. Follow this trail which leads to another old logging road. Follow this final logging road up the small hill (east) and Yewlanda will be sitting on the left (north) side of this road.
tree_site_notes: This is definitely the largest Pacific yew any of our party had seen before, and it is exceptionally healthy. The fact that it grows beside a small creek at a nutrient rich site bodes well for its future. The tree is also growing in well shaded conditions, below a canopy of larger deciduous trees and taller conifers, so it’s well protected. Tree is likely several meters taller (28 to 30m tall)  as the uppermost limb could not be properly sighted when measuring tree height.

From Coombs, drive on Highway 4 to Little Qualicum Falls Provincial Park. From the parking lot, make your way to the trail that leads downhill to the river between the Upper Campground and the Lower Campground. Before reaching the Lower Campground, you will find the tree on the left hand side of the trail
tree_site_notes: This specimen is in vigorous health, growing in a semi shaded area alongside the Little Qualicum River. The crown is full, and the tree is moss covered, as is typical for Pacific yews

access_notes: East Side Road 13K of Lower Seymour Conservation Reserve.
Hydraulic Creek south side of Lower Seymour Conservation Reserve.

tree_site_notes: Healthy, 3 ft of dead top, 2 large limbs recently broken off on one side.

The tree is facing east and located in a partially shaded clearing alongside a trail. It is in excellent condition and grows in a reasonable good soil medium. It is well protected from winds by a nearby bluff and other trees. It is the landowner’s intention to do everything possible to ensure the future health of the tree.

This tree is situated on the side of shaded hilly terrain, and it is both well protected from the elements and enjoys excellent health. From a tree core, its age is estimated to be 355 years. The surrounding forest is mostly twisted and ornate old growth cedar which perhaps escaped harvest under previous ownership because easier timber to harvest was readily available nearby.

access_notes: On swampy ground at extreme south end of Shawnigan Lake (see access map).
tree_site_notes: Healthy. On swampy ground. CWHxm1
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: On swampy ground at extreme south end of Shawnigan Lake (see access map).
tree_site_notes: Healthy. Unidentified fungal conk on bole indicating advanced heart rot, but this is normal for trees of this age and it maintains a vigorous crown. On swampy ground. CWHxm1

access_notes: Tree is on the Buckbrush Swamp Trail, about 164 feet from Liberty Drive and 180 feet from Eagle Tree Place.

From Youbou… Follow the North Shore Road 29.4 kms to Cowichan Main, then turn left onto Mainline South Carmanah Road at 42.2 kms. At 48.4 kms, turn slightly left at Mainline Carmanah/Nitinat Fronting, and finally, at 52.2 kms, turn right onto Rosander Main. Now follow Rosander Main, paying close attention to the waypoint given for the tree when finding the right place to park, as the tree is a very short distance from the road.
tree_site_notes: This yew appears to be in excellent health and is growing in ideal conditions! There is another of comparable size(0.60m diameter and 15m height) growing nearby that we are not nominating just yet, mostly because obtaining accurate crown spread data will be quite hazardous due to the terrain.

access_notes: On swampy ground at extreme south end of Shawnigan Lake (see access map).
tree_site_notes: Healthy. On swampy ground. CWHxm1

access_notes: From Coombs, drive to Little Qualicum Falls Provincial Park, via Highway 4. Park in the day use area, and make your way down to the bridge that crosses the river just above the Upper Falls. Cross the bridge, and turn left, following the river on the opposite side to reach this tree.
tree_site_notes: This robust Pacific yew is one of several noteworthy specimens growing alongside the Little Qualicum River. The trunk is distinctly angled in the direction of the river, but the tree appears to be quite securely rooted. The crown is full and healthy.

access_notes: From Sechelt head east on the Sunshine Coast Highway towards Wilson Creek. At the intersection with Field Road, head north on Field Road. Turn east (right) onto Sechelt Wilson Creek FSR. Drive up to almost km 7 and turn left onto a small spur that has a concrete block with a sign that says "Entering Chapman Creek Watershed". Park here if the spur is too tight or messy for your vehicle. Just over 300m up the spur is a clearing on the right side with some pink flagging tape. You can park here and enter the forest here as well. There is no official trail but a bit of a game trail that heads north following Wilson Creek. The tree will be on the west side of the creek and on the east side of an old skidder road.
tree_site_notes: This tree seems to be in very good condition. It’s protected by a strong forest canopy.

access_notes: Metchosin Road to Beach Trail access
From Woss drive south. Turn right on Mount Cain Road. Turn right on Davie River Road and drive to Schoen Lake. Paddle to the end of Schoen Lake then buswhack to the tree.

tree_site_notes: Tall yew growing at the edge of a sandy bank along a side channel of the Chemainus River. Tree has a single stem and a large, healthy canopy, growing in the partial shade of old second-growth. Tree has a substantial lean, but does not appear to be at risk of falling. Adjacent vegetation is typical rich riparian indicative of moderate disturbance, with abundant large, early-seral species and abundant fern understory (CDFmm06).

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.
tree_site_notes: Good condition, several significant limbs improperly removed from the NE side leaving some unsightly stubs.

access_notes: From Sechelt head east on the Sunshine Coast Highway towards Wilson Creek. At the intersection with Field Road, head north on Field Road. tree_site_notes: Generally speaking, the tree is in good health. It did suffer the loss of a significant lower limb due to a nearby fallen tree, but is otherwise quite vigorous.

access_notes: 4330 Island Highway South
tree_site_notes: Located in the parking lot of the Kingfisher Oceanside Resort and Spa

access_notes: From Halfmoon Bay head west on the Sunshine Coast Highway towards Homesite Creek. Turn north (right) onto Homesite Creek FSR. Drive up past the campground and park at the trailhead for Cabin Fever. Walk up the trail a bit until you reach around 270m in elevation. From there head south off trail towards the unnamed creek. Tree is on the north side of this creek.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in excellent health, and is well situated in a secondgrowth stand alongside a seasonal creek bed, just outside the boundaries of an Old Growth Management Area. Judging by the recovery of the surrounding forest, I would expect that soil conditions are quite good. Nearby, there are a couple more yews that may reach similar size in the next several decades. Conditions are ideal for future growth, as soils are good and it is sheltered from winds by a small rock outcropping and a vigorous forest canopy. Additionally, due to the proximity of a popular nearby recreational trail, it is thought unlikely that the forest here will be harvested again.

access_notes: From Holberg Main FSR at 7km from highway,  turn onto Georgie Main, follow signs 5.5km  to Rec site. Trail is located at last campsite (not marked). About 1 km along rough trail.
tree_site_notes: Mix of stunted shore pine, western hemlock, yellow-cedar and Pacific yew in abundance.

First Nation Reserve - please contact First Nations for permission.  Tree is on the west side of Chatham Island, off Oak Bay. At edge of beach, in full sun in open field. Easily visible from a boat.

"Big Mike" had some heart rot but appeared healthy overall. The tree is facing in a south-southeast direction and is growing approx 4 feet from the highwater mark of O'Connell Lake under a large Western Red Cedar. The surrounding forest is a second growth Western Hemlock stand and the site is located in the CWHvm1.
