This small enclave of Pacific yew appears to have a shallow sub-surface groundwater regime throughout. The forest floor was dotted with oak fern and some twisted stalk, but otherwise quite devoid of vegetation. Some smaller diameter western redcedar and Englemann spruce were the primary species in this location. Based on ring count of an adjacent, recently cut 0.15 m. radius stump (solid to the core), the age of the nominated tree is estimated at 257 years old.
ICHmw2. Multiple Forks and crooks present. East aspect.

access_notes: Private land - access is restricted.
tree_site_notes: One of the native species located in a private arboretum, that contains many exotic species throughout the forest.

access_notes: From Highway 7 near Deroche, turn East on to Malcom Road, turning right a short ways after onto Dyke Road. Park at the gate and walk south along Dyke Road until you find a place clear enough to enter the forest and bushwhack to the tree. Proceed with caution, as this Island is full of blackberry and bushwhacking is very difficult. Request permission from Bands before access.

tree_site_notes: This paper birch was measured at the smallest diameter below where the two stems merge. Serval forks were also observed in the mid to upper crown.  Overall the tree was in good health, surrounded by cedar trees & adjacent large burnt out stumps.  The terrain sloped 5-10% towards the south.  It was a very rich subhygric site with dense ferns and alder.  Old bear claw marks were observed on the lower 1/3 of the tree.

access_notes: Clearwater Rd to Wells Gray Park - Edgewood Retreat. Tree is beside driveway.
tree_site_notes: Tree estimated to be 90 years old (Terry Nelson).

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Tree is at 314 Hunter Street in Silverton.
tree_site_notes: Urban tree, unknown whether it was planted or perhaps preserved from native site clearing when the property was developed.

access_notes: Little Lost Lake trail is accessed off of Highway 16, where a precariously approached pull-out is the parking area. A few km’s east of Tete Jaune Cache you will see a signed trailhead and pull-out on the right. The trail climbs steeply until you get closer to the lake. There is a loop walk around the lake. This is where this impressive birch tree was found.
tree_site_notes: Looking around and measuring up some of the big Douglas-fir trees that are growing around the lake, we stumbled upon one of the largest and most beautiful paper birches I have ever seen. Very tall, very healthy, and with a spectacular peeling bark show.

access_notes: The path to the tree can be found by starting at the Visitor Information Centre trailhead, and by following the Mt. Proctor Trails signage. The trail signage now directs you away from this area, however once you come out into the meadow opening, go up the hill towards the cow fence that is visible above. When you cross through the turnstile in the barb wire fence turn right, where the old trail passes through above the meadow area, and then comes to a 3 way junction, where you will take the left arm. As the trail has been recently re-routed, it does not see as much traffic, and will quickly become overgrown, so keep your senses heightened. Not too far up from the junction,  the “Big Birch” holds its place of reverence right beside the trail.
From Highway 3, turn off onto Burton Lake Road continue past lake turn-off, take right turn onto gravel before the subdivision access. Walk up creek ravine.
tree_site_notes: Many old birch occupied the incised ravine of Burton Creek.

access_notes: From Casltegar head east on Highway 3 (Crowsnest Hwy) towards Salmo for approximately 3.3km. On the right you will see a sandy pull out, park here and cross the highway on foot heading up the runaway lane. Go up the runaway lane for 150m and then take a right on the quad trail. Walk the quad trail for approximately 1.7km and then leave the trail and head north, bushwack to the tree at a bearing of 349 degrees for approximately 550m.
tree_site_notes: Bear claw marks on bark, Fd/Cw Stand, southwest facing aspect, approx 15% slope

access_notes: At the 2 km marker of Kokanee Creek Rd access to Old Growth Trail (signed at Highway 3B)

tree_site_notes: Unbelievable pine. Has a tire swing and a ladder, as well as a skull, nailed into its bark, yet it remains thriving. No die off in crown.

access_notes: This tree is 2 kilometers south of Allison Lake Park on Highway 5A. It is on the west side of the highway when you are driving north.

access_notes: The Three Blind Mice trail network can be accessed by driving from Penticton north along Naramata Road.  Turn right (about 6 to 7 km from downtown Penticton) onto Riddle Road and drive to the top of the road where roadside parking is available.  The walk or ride to the tree is about 5 to 5.5 km one way.  Enter the attached URL into your browser to access the trail map:  look for the intersection of Pinecone and Ponderosa trails, located near the middle of the trail network.  https://www.trailforks.com/region/three-blind-mice/map/?activitytype=1&z=12.0&lat=49.56396&lon=-119.55505
tree_site_notes: The tree is located at the base of a moderate west facing slope in a relatively flat area.  The tree is in good health and does not appear to have a broken top.  A good view of the top of the tree is difficult due to the surrounding Ponderosa pine and Douglas-fir trees, which partially block the view. The area is used by mountain bike and hiking enthusiasts.  In general, the area is characterized by steep rocky bluffs and flat benches.  The larger trees tend to grow on the benches or in ravines where moisture is more plentiful.  The area is used by whitetail deer, elk, black bear and coyote, as well as numerous species of birds.

access_notes: Lundbom Rd., off of highway 97C, east of Merritt.
tree_site_notes: Old gnarly giant with 3 massive limbs and dead top. IDFdk1

Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Moisture receiving despite Ponderosa pine presence. Area covered in dense snowberry, prickly rose, and dogwood. Pine presence counter to other site associations indicating potential changes over time to since tree germinated. Adjacent to old ranch trail. Healthy

access_notes: From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning onto Highway 5A to Princeton.  After 8km turn right onto Coalmont Rd. After 11km turn right onto Voght Valley Rd. Grove of trees is along the road.
tree_site_notes: Significant fire scarring at base. Submesic to mesic area of aspen groves, grassland, and fifteen year old pine plantation. The area surrounding this grove of trees features dozens, if not hundreds, of very large Ponderosa pine worth measuring and nominating to the Big Tree Registry.

access_notes: Tree is on private land and access is restricted.
tree_site_notes: Upon visual inspection the tree seems in good health. It rises straight up and at approximately 3.5 meters deviates to the southeast and then resumes a straight upwards growth. It is located near the shoreline of the Granby River surrounded by cottonwood trees and alder. The tree lies on a level gradient, primarily south facing aspect.  To the north exists a rising face of a south facing mountain slope.
Dead top, otherwise healthy.

access_notes: Drive northeast on 3/95 to 30th Avenue North. Turn right, then left on Stahl Road. Follow Stahl Road into the community forest, where it is called Sylvan Lake Road, all the way to the Larch parking lot, about 2 km. Park and hike east to the Fence Line Trail [~100 m]. Turn left and hike north on Fence Line ~ 400 m to Windy Bluff Trail. Turn right and hike east on Windy Bluff ~500 m, where there is a trail leading to the Big Tree Trail [~250 m]. Turn right and hike on the Big Tree Trail ~600 m to the Big Tree.
tree_site_notes: Dry site. Climbing spikes in trunk, platform aloft [on west side] and dead top.

access_notes: The Princeton Kamloops Highway 5A climbs up from Merritt towards Princeton. On the right about  5 km from town is the Kane Valley Road. Follow this gravel road until reaching the Harmon Lake Rec site. The big Ponderosa Pine is not too much further along and is visible from the road.
tree_site_notes: With its candelabra of branches spreading out in all directions, this tree seems like it should have a pride of lions hanging out with it.

Open fire damaged wood on both sides and ellipsoid shape to base, almost twice as wide in one dimension as the other: in one direction it would appear to be 1.40m wide, while in the other only 80cm wide. Submesic to mesic area of aspen groves, grassland, and fifteen year old pine plantation.  The area surrounding this grove of trees features dozens, if not hundreds, of very large Ponderosa pine worth measuring and nominating to the Big Tree Registry.

Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Grove of trees is approximatley 500 metres down hill (east) from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Open grown, branchy, healthy. Adjacent to old ranch trail.

access_notes: Located, and visible from the Highway 95A when passing through Marysville.
tree_site_notes: Growing in the front grounds of the Jehovah Church.  Many ponderosa pine can be viewed in this general area, but for some reason this appears to be the largest.

access_notes: Turn onto Blackwater Lake Road from Pemberton Portage Road. Follow for 500m then turn right onto the dirt road. Proceed for about 150m. The tree will be on the left about 75 off the road, just outside the fence.
tree_site_notes: This tree, along with several other large ponderosa pines, was left after the area was logged in 2005. The site is a flat and dry bench, with low ground cover.

access_notes: Kane Valley Cross Country Ski Trails Provincial Rec Site. From Merritt take Highway 97C (Okanagan Connector) towards Kelowna before turning right onto Kane Valley Rd. Drive approx. 4km until turning left at the signs for Kane Valley cross country ski trails. Trails are driveable in 4x4 vehicle in the summer. Grove is at the top of the hill where the trails loop back down.
tree_site_notes: Growing on north facing slope at high elevation, incredibly odd for a Ponderosa, likely reflecting huge differences in fire behaviour and disturbance history in the era that it germinated. No evident Ponderosa regenerating at this elevation/aspect. Fire scarring and exposed wood around cat face on down hill side. Along edge of cross country ski trail/road. Despite being on the rec site, there is Tolko logging layout in the area. Tree is outside cutblock boundary.

access_notes: Kalamalka Provincial Park in Coldstream is well signed, so follow signage to the last parking lot. From here head up the Corral Trail to Cougar Cairn junction and then continue up the Lookout Trail. The tree is on the escarpment overlooking the lake.
tree_site_notes: This tree seems to be taking advantage of its promentory above Kalamalka Lake. One of the lower branches extended out over 5 m.

access_notes: Coldstream, east end of Community Park.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top  but otherwise healthy. IDFxh1a

access_notes: Cai Creek ATV Trail from Highway 3 east of Castlegar.
tree_site_notes: Signs of fire damage; piece of bark removed to measure; exceptionally cool layered bark.

access_notes: Take Midday Valley Rd from Merritt to kilometre 11.5 and turn right onto Lindley FSR. Take to KM 2.5 then turn on to Lindley Spur 1. Take for 1.5 km keeping right and park in the landing at the end of the road ( 50.082621, -120.895236). Tree is 150 metres uphill from the landing.
tree_site_notes: Incredible tree. No less than 6 leaders, maybe as many as 10, each more than 30cm circumference. Moisture receiving despite Ponderosa presence. Area covered in dense snowberry, prickly rose, and dogwood. Pine presence counter to other site associations indicating potential changes over time to since tree germinated.

access_notes: In Kimberley, starting at the Higgins Street nature park entrance, hike or bike the Eimers road to the three corners. Take a left onto the lower army road to the four corners junction. Take the Duck Pond Trail to the height of land as it starts to fall away into the St. Mary’s valley.  Tree is about 700m S on Duck Pond from junction with Keiver Way. The tree is unmistakably the largest tree in the area, somehow missed in the decades earlier logging.
tree_site_notes: Classic ponderosa, tall straight, branches start 1/2-3/4 the way up. Small fire scar at the base on south side. Situated on a gentle south facing slope.

The area surrounding this grove of trees features dozens, if not hundreds, of very large Ponderosa pine worth measuring and nominating to the Big Tree Registry.

access_notes: Drive south from Silverton on Highway #6, turn left onto Red Mountain Road, turn right onto Lower Galena Farm Rd. Road ends at washout bridge crossing Hasty Creek, continue on foot up old overgrown road. Tree is in middle of road.
tree_site_notes: Tree has two tops. This is a rare ponderosa pine for this area. When the original Red Mountain Road was constructed in the 1920s, the tree was left in place and the road was routed around both sides of the tree.

access_notes: From Highway 3, turn off onto Burton Lake Road continue past lake turn-off, take right turn onto gravel before the subdivision access. On slope above cut-block.

Despite growing on east facing slope, area is moisture recieving from steeper slope above to the east and covered in dense prickly rose and snowberry. Veteran trees interspersed among earlier seral site associations with aspen and dense shrubs.

access_notes: From Kamloops head east on Highway 1. Turn right on Dallas Drive, signs for Barnhartvale. Follow Barnhartvale Rd for 8.4 km and turn right on Robbins Range Rd. Follow for 3.6 km, keeping right (straight) onto Campbell Range Rd. Park at the junction with Scuitto Lake FSR. Tree is a few hundred metres east of road in the bush.
tree_site_notes: Growing on N facing slope in young Douglas-fir forest, likely predates incursion of stand into previous grasslands. No burn marks. Covered in claw marks, daybed at base, on crest at top of short steep slope in young Douglas-fir forest.

access_notes: Above highway 3, where the Swansea vehicle bridge crosses over Moyie River. Cross railway tracks, climb to ridgeline.
Wycliffe Road to Moose Lake Road
From Elko, drive onto River Road, pass the Silver Springs parking area. Park in next pull-out, and start up the slope above.
tree_site_notes: Southwest facing slope. Tree is in a mixture of juvenile Douglas-fir and aspen.

access_notes: From Highway 3, turn off onto Burton Lake Road continue past lake turn-off, take right turn onto gravel before the subdivision access. On slope above cut-block.
tree_site_notes: Southwest facing slope. Well drained scree slope, with juvenile Douglas-fir and aspen.

access_notes: From Highway 3, turn off onto Burton Lake Road continue past lake turn-off, take right turn onto gravel before the subdivision access. On slope above cut-block.
tree_site_notes: Southwest facing slope. Well drained scree slope, with juvenile Douglas-fir and aspen. Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: Enderby Bluffs Trail is well signed, directing you to a trailhead parking area. The trail climbs up through a mixed juvenile forest before alighting onto a rocky boulder strewn bench. There were quite a few veteran trees (larch, spruce, cedar) and a surprise showing of this ponderosa pine very close to the trail.
tree_site_notes: The big Ponderosa seems to be one of the very few trees of this species. Showing signs of fire scarred bark this veteran just outlasted the rest of the forest.

access_notes: Cai Creek ATV Trail from Highway 3 east of Castlegar.
This cutblock is difficult to get to without crossing private property. It is straight uphill to the East from downtown Slocan Park.
tree_site_notes: Tree appears healthy. There is a heavily used Elk trail at it's base. Three Elk literally led me to this tree - I first noticed them just 300' to the North of where this tree was, and walking towards them after seeing them, they took me right to the tree. I knew this tree was there by reading timber cruise data publicly available for this proposed BCTS cutblock. We know they will log it because it is included in the overall volume estimate for this cutblock. It is slated to be logged November 2025. I have walked over 30 BCTS pending cutblocks this year and started "Save What's Left Conservation Society" (www.savewhatsleft.com).  This tree has been named after Lt. Col. James Stone, after the Canadian officer who, facing horrific odds, famously ordered his battalion: "No retreat, no surrender," and emerged victorious (Battle of Kapyong, 1951). It feels like we’re facing similarly grim odds in the fight to save what’s left of our forests, yet we must persevere.

access_notes: In Kamloops take Rose Hill Road off of Valley View Drive. There will be a yellow gate blocking access for vehicles, park here taking care not to block the gate for emergency access or bc hydro. Follow path for about 1.35 km, turning right when you see abandoned concrete barriers on path.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. Large fire scare. Fallen branch remains.

access_notes: Ikeda Cove
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: From road along north side of Lost Lagoon, follow Tatlow Walk for approximately 100m. Tree is approximately 6m east of trail.
tree_site_notes: Level upland site. CWHdm.

access_notes: The tree is located on Moon Road. The Strathcona Regional District has a right of way over this unbuilt road allowance. The tree is located on the trail approximately halfway down and at the top of the bank before you descend to the beach. The tree is adjacent to the top of the staircase. Moon Road is located by driving southerly on Sutil Point Road from Mansons Landing for approximately 3 kms until you come to Highfield Road, at which point you follow Highfield Road south for approximately 600 metres until you come to the trailhead sign marking Moon Road Trail.
tree_site_notes: The tree is currently healthy although nearby surrounding alders are in decay, both young and old. The tree is at the top of a slope approximately 50 metres from the beach. A few years ago I became aware of the Big Tree Registry and this tree caught my attention as to being a noteworthy tree. This tree originally resided on land owned by my grandfather, John Manson, for whom Mansons Landing was named after (and his brother Michael). My grandfather pre-empted the land in 1888 and it has remained in our family since. Moon Road was dedicated as road allowance in 1984. A large house is currently under construction on a neighbour's adjoining property, within 30 metres of the tree.

access_notes: Park on Chemainus road and follow the train tracks southward. After about 275m, the tree will be about 25m to your left in a small bench at the edge of the rail right-of-way.
tree_site_notes: This alder stands at the edge of a small seasonal depression near the edge of an old rail right-of-way. The surrounding forest is more mature than most adjacent forest, populated by cedar and grand fir. The tree is leaning, but tall and healthy, with the stem blanketed in moss.

access_notes: Jedway Townsite is in Harriet Harbour, Skincuttle Inlet, Gwaii Haanas NP.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road, head North on Hwy 37 approximately 6.4 km, turn left (west side)and park at the pull out for the Snowflake Community Fairgrounds. Before the gate to the fairgrouns there is a trail leading to the right which parallels the highway heading north.  Follow this trail to the end of the fairgrounds where it continues into the forest and past the Kitimat River Park Boundary sign.  Down a short hill take the excellent trail to the left and follow above a backwater of the Kitimat River about 100 meters.  You will see the alder just above the backwater below your trail about 10 meters.
tree_site_notes: This large heavily leaning tree is growing on a flood prone clay bank just above a backwater of the Kitimat River.  It is leaning over the river with 2 extra long sets of moss covered branches growing over the backwater.  Interestingly it has a small spruce tree growing in the place on the alder where the moss covered branches diverge.  The terrain is soft and dense, full of small alders, devil's club, willow, berries and rotting logs.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take Coast Trail or Interior trail to the unnamed trail that leads to Cabin Point. Tree is located on edge of trail just  down the hill from where the unnamed trail meets the coast trail, on the edge of the beautiful, sheltered bay just east of Cabin Point. Maybe the best place in the park for a swim.
tree_site_notes: Creekside just above the high tide in a beautiful sheltered bay alond the coast trail. Crown reaches out to the sea, gorgeous full elm-like crown for an alder. Surrounded by nettles on a wet site.

access_notes: Turn north off of Highway 20 into the Rip-Rap RV and Campground. In a forest trail loop beside the Bella Coola River. Tree is upstream from the campground.
tree_site_notes: Many old trees of a varied species can be seen along this trail.

access_notes: From Holberg, drive to San Josef River boat launch and paddle or boat to Sea Otter Cove. Otherwise, can hike from San Josef Bay Trailhead over Mount Saint Patrick and down to Sea Otter Cove.
tree_site_notes: Healthy red alder with large crown. The tree splits into many forks at about 2m in height. Two large alders grow side by side on what appears to be the site of an old structure. This is the larger of the two. Evidence of past logging nearby.

access_notes: Ask the Kanaka Bar Band for permission, tree is in an extremely sensitive archaeological site.
tree_site_notes: This unusally tall and thick juniper is in a grove of similar specimen, right along the Fraser River. Tree is declining. Much of the crown is dead. Part of the bark was culturally modified, with significant regrowth suggesting this occured centuries ago. It is adjacent to the remains of an old cabin.

access_notes: Ask the Kanaka Bar Band for permission.
tree_site_notes: This is an exceptional juniper located on a grass flat beside the Fraser. The tree extends over 20m along the Fraser River, very healthy.

access_notes: Cranbrook Community Forest. From Cranbrook, take Highway 3/95 northeast about 12 km to Mission/Ft. Steele Road. Turn left and follow this road towards the rifle range. At about 0.4 km turn left on an old logging road and follow it southwest and west about 2.3 km, where it turns south and then continues west, passing three ponds to the south of the road. The third of these ponds is called Double Duck Lake. Continue past it for about 500 m. There is a meadow on the south side of the road with a big tree at the midpoint of its edge along the road. Park. Hike northeast up a gully between two hills about 600 m to the big juniper, which is growing at the base of a rock face on the west side of the gully. Alternatively, from Double Duck Lake, hike due north and follow a ridge about 500 m. Turn west and walk down into a gully, where the juniper grows at the base of that east-facing rock face.
tree_site_notes: Rock face to west, growing on slope [~20º],  trunk slants ~20º to northeast, several large branches, trunk concave to northeast [old fire scar?], cross-section of trunk is not circular - estimate 22" x 27" diameter.

access_notes: Enderby Bluffs Trail is well signed, directing you to a trailhead parking area. The trail ascends for about 8 km, then daylights onto the crest of the imposing bluffs. There are a few Rocky Mountain Junipers along this ridgeline, with a couple of the larger ones growing very close to the edge and right near the end of the trail
tree_site_notes: When someone tells you about a special tree, and even shows you a photo, it is time to venture out to find it. Curious how this tree compared to the champion in the Standard Hills, I had to see for myself. A long hike on a very hot day, almost had us turning around prematurely, luckily we mustered up some extra gusto, and not too much further on reside these unique, full sized junipers. It would be interesting to know how old they are?

access_notes: Drive on south Highway 93 towards Grasmere, at top of Elk River Bridge hill, turn right to parking lot
Follow Jocelyn Hill Trail from Emma Dickson Drive, Highlands Municipality about half an hour. Tree is located within shouting distance E of Trail. (Use GPS coordinates.)
tree_site_notes: Second growth Douglas-fir <100 yr old, shore pine, Scouler’s willow, ocean spray and salal. Closest stump of harvested Douglas-fir ca. 20 m away from willow tree (cut looks like nearly 100 yrs old).

access_notes: Follow Johel Rd until road ends. Continue through lot onto old forest road. Tree is on right side of road.
tree_site_notes: Large willow growing directly adjacent to a second-growth Douglas-fir. Single stem splits into many tops, some dead. Open forest with some larger Douglas-fir, but primarily younger alder, white, and lodgepole pine.

access_notes: Point Grey, North of Aberthau Community Centre.
Follow Main Road south to end of Island at Squitty Bay
tree_site_notes: Rocky headland supporting large arbutus, shore pine, Douglas-ir, and many seaside junipers tucked into the sheltered crevasses that extend to the ocean.

access_notes:
Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance. 
Tree in on the SW end of Coal Island.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes:
Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.   
The tree is on a short, steep bank above beach just north of public beach access at end of Madrona Drive.  If you visit this tree, please use the public beach access and view the tree from the beach.
tree_site_notes: A healthy and much improved tree over past 10 years according to property owner.  Minor defects. Ocean front above beach on short, steep bank.

access_notes: From Sidney, drive north to Swartz Bay and take ferry to Saturna Island, or take a private vessel directly from Sidney or Point Roberts. Once on Saturna Island, can launch a kayak or other water craft and travel across Tumbo Channel to Cabbage Island. Cabbage Island is small and the tree is located on the other side of the marsh from the campground on the southeast side of the island.
tree_site_notes: Healthy seaside juniper. Close to a marsh on Cabbage Island. The island contains other tree species such as trembling aspen, western redcedar, Douglas-fir, and primarily salal, grasses, and sedge understory.

access_notes: Pine Point Recreation Site
tree_site_notes: CWHxm2

access_notes: Point Grey, North of Aberthau Community Centre.
Adams Bird Sanctuary is in lower Summerland near the bottom of Peach Orchard Drive, just up hill from the Switchback/Cemetery Rd. junction.
tree_site_notes: This tree has four branches which join at the bottom, and are fused up to 1.6m. The branches themselves are huge and form a crown which is truly impressive. From the Adams Bird Sanctuary entrance/sign, the short trail goes right to this tree and does a loop around it, crossing a stream under the canopy.

access_notes: Bishop Wild Bird Sanctuary.
tree_site_notes: Dead top.

access_notes: East Yak Mainline from Port Clements, past Ferguson Bay Main, to Ferguson Bay triangle connector. Park there (west end of triangle, on East Yak Main). Old unsigned road heads south at west end of triangle. Can drive in. Pine patch on left (east) side of road, 50 meters from road in leave patch in 10 yr old block. (200 meters before old Haida canoe). Trees very visible from newer portion of the old road (road passes through 40+yr plantation, then opens up into swamp logging, tiny patch of leave trees east of road, large pines very visible. Road beccomes impassable 200m beyond - right fork to Haida canoe parking (trail up past huge cedar to west), left fork just overgrown.NOTE: at least one more potentially larger pine farther East (in view above Cy canopy).
tree_site_notes: healthy, vigorous; super-canopy; detected 3 old frost cracks on bole, but quite faint; self pruning.  CWHwh1 04 (LMH28); CWHwh1 110 (LMH68) – CwHw-Salal-Deer Fern. Tree is in leave patch. Older (30-40 yr) plantation around, recent cuts adjacent.

access_notes: Tree is 50 metres south of junction of Anderson Cove and Copper Mine Trails.
tree_site_notes: Mesic to subhygric salal dominated site not far from swamp/marsh wetland below slopes of Mount Maguire above. Quadruple split top!

access_notes: Tree is beside the trail on way into San Josef Bay Beach. Easy walk on well graded trail from parking lot leads through many quality old growth cedars.
tree_site_notes: A small isolated patch of shorepine can be seen above the trail.

access_notes: Tree is located in a field on the north side of Koksilah Road approximate 1.3 km east of Hwy 1. Please respect private property and view the tree from the road side.
tree_site_notes: Healthy and straight pine residing at the edge of a small irrigation pond within a farm field (CDFmm08). Tree is very conspicuous as the only conifer for some distance and much taller than any surrounding vegetation. Tree once hosted a large lateral branch that recently fell during a storm. Surrounding vegetation characteristic of a fluctuating water table, with alder, rose, dogwood, and honeysuckle being common.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance.  Tree is located at 611 Constance Ave, Esquimalt.
Kokish main > Branch 250 > East Main > Branch 209-2A-4, see photo/map
tree_site_notes: Located on the edge of the road right-of-way. Slight lean away from road. Stem forked about 5 meters down from tree height. Root system slightly exposed due to road construction and natural erosion of soil and thick duff layer.

access_notes: From Ayland Farm parking lot, take coast trail about 300 metres past petroglyphs. Tree is tucked into the salal 5 metres off tree, just before the trail takes a sharp turn south on top a steep cliff.
tree_site_notes: Triple top. Growing close to sea shore in sparse pine/fir stand with dense salal understory.

access_notes: Growing on unnamed trail south of of the junction of Endurance Ridge and Interior Trails in East Sooke Regional Park. Access via either trail or the Coast Trail
tree_site_notes: Trail side with a nice forked top (it seems all the big pines in the area have double tops). Flat site, mesic to subhygric, a few metres from ephemeral standing water.

access_notes: Private land - exact location is withheld.
tree_site_notes: Incredible canopy! Wild cumber at base and an enomrous china rose growing up in the canopy about 3 metres of the ground. One giant branch comes off at 80cm. Diameter measured at narrowest point below branch (at 45cm off ground) is 90.8cm.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.4 kilometres along coast trail. Tree is on the left about 150 metres before the next trail junction. At the last open salal patch before coming to the big maple, turn left and whack through salal towards the open rocky cladina covered knob. Tree is at the top.
tree_site_notes: Four topped multi-stem growing on xeric rock knob with cladina lichens. Great spot for a picnic if you can put up with the bushwack to get there.

access_notes: Growing a hundred metres north of the junction of Endurance Ridge and Interior Trails in a gully in East Sooke Regional Park. Access via either trail.
tree_site_notes: Beautiful candelabra top. Growing on old stump mound surrounded by salal but only a couple metres above standing water swamp.

access_notes: Growing at the junction of Endurance Ridge and Interior Trails in East Sooke Regional Park. Access via either trail.
tree_site_notes: Heavy lean and split top but healthy, growing at trail junction. Likely pioneer post-logging/broadcast burning. Mesic sight at lower slope, thus pine and salal indicate coastal douglas fir BEC zone

access_notes: From Woss head north on highway 19 aproximately 12km to the Siding 4 crossing on the Markusen road. Travel 1km down the Markusen Road to the marked Siding 4 interpretive Trail.The group of shore pine are at the north end of the trail near the old railgrade.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy and growing on flat ground on high bench above the Nimpkish River. It is an old growth Douglas fir fire history stand with the last fire being aproximately 170 years ago based on ring counts of adjacent subdominant hemlock below the fir vets. There are half a dozen shore pine of the same 33m height in this spot, ranging from 32 to 43 cm in diameter.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.7 kilometres along coast trail (past the two junctions towards the Copper Mine Trail). Tree is on the right, base is hidden a little bit in shrubs 5 metres off trail.
tree_site_notes: Just off the cliff edge above the sea. Leaning super heavily so that crown doesn't overtop the base of the tree. Healthy and well rooted despite the lean.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail until the junction with Anderson Cove Trail. Tree is right on the trail about a kilometre up the trail.
tree_site_notes: Another split top crown like almost all of the big pines in East Sooke. Growing on submesic to mesic salal and cherry dominated site with open succesional forests grading into xeric rocky outcroppings above.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 400 metres along coast trail. A faint junction takes a trail down to a small islet. Tree is on the shore right above tidal rock flats.
tree_site_notes: A funny, squat tree. As many as ten leaders depending on how you count it. Definitley a "shore" pine, only 5 metres from shore, but not very "contorta." Looks more like the trees that grow in ranchers' fields in the interior than the average shore pine. For such a seaside site trunks are all very straight and mostly undamaged. Protected from the open sea wind by a small islet.

access_notes: Growing on Coast Trail one kilometre west of junction of Coast Trail and Park Height Trail East Sooke Regional Park. Access via either trail.
tree_site_notes: Forked top, healthy crown. Growing trail side 50 metres from the sea.

access_notes: Ponderosa Annex, near Lower Mall, UBC. East of Lower Mall, west of South Ponderosa Annex.
Heading out of Holberg - North on San Jo Main, Left on Raft Main, 13 Kms down on your right
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 06
healthy tree with healthy top

access_notes: Located in Carmanah Walbran Forest. From MacMillan Bloedel Road H-1000, follow West Walbran Trail south, past Anderson Lake, to a point approximately 800 m south of Anderson Lake on east bank of creek. Tree is near trail at forest edge.
tree_site_notes: This is beautiful healthy and straight tree is a "veteran" in a younger stand.  It is found growing deep in unlogged coastal rain forest valley. West southwest aspect, 5-10% slope, lower slope.  Tree Score was calculated using a hybrid approach.  It is based on the 1999 measurements of height and crown spread made by Van Pelt, and the 2020 measurement of diameter by TJ Watt. This approach was taken as the previous diameter estimate was found to be overestimated.  A full remeasure of this tree is planned and tree score will be recalculated.  The wood volume estimate of 266 cubic meters by R. VanPelt is based his diameter estimate of 4.07m.

This spruce is absolutely phenominal and perhaps now the largest known overall in the Carmanah Valley. I boasts a thick, towering trunk that puts it in a league and likely age class of its own compared to other large spruce trees in the area. It also has one of the most dynamic and sprawling canopies. The main trunk breaks into two main stems which then also have multiple iterations of their own. From a top down perspective, the canopy of this one tree appears to be of 3-4 individual trees. This is one of the most rewarding and noteworthy big tree finds in a long time.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Yakoun River floodplain flats.  Approx 30 kms north of Queen Charlotte City off Q.C. mainline logging road.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Located within Gwaii Haanas National Park Reserve and Haida Heritage Site is the ancient village, and now current watchmen of Windy Bay, or Hlk'yah GaawGa. Windy Bay is on the western side of Lyell Island, and is home to a moderately sized salmon bearing stream and estuary.  From the watchmen cabin (south side of river), there is a well marked and maintained trail that follows the estuary up to the foot of the river, and crosses the river to the north side. From this point the trail winds into the woods, where you will walk for about ten minutes, before encountering the spruce tree right on the trail.
tree_site_notes:
This tree is estimated to be in the 800-900 year range according to the local Haida. It is characterized by a very large trunk that diminishes little in circumference with height. Relatively healthy with broken top, CWHwh1. 
Diameter at branch appears to be about 2 m.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see tree BC BigTree # 411"San Jo's Smiley" on your right. Park here and admire that tree before hiking into the woods behind it and bushwhacking on an angle towards your left through some tricky log jams. This tree is on the edge of the next clearing you arrive at.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 06 This is an incredibly impressive Sitka spruce tree with a gigantic columnar trunk that towers into the sky. The sheer volume is staggering. The tree has a broken top but seems to be healthy otherwise. The forest for the most part around it was logged in 2012, exposing one side to the elements. Other giants exist nearby. Certainly not a cheater tree, this one earns all it's wow factor on honest terms. A must see!!

access_notes: The tree is located on the east bank of Carmanah Creek, 1.3 km upstream from mouth of creek.
tree_site_notes: This tree is one of the tallest known trees in Canada. West southwest aspect, 75% slope, lower slope, straight (seepage site, lower mesoslope, concave).

access_notes: Drive from Lake Cowichan to Nitinat Lake and then towards Carmanah Valley. Cross the bridge over the Caycuse River and head up hill. Keep your eye open for a big spruce sticking out above the surrounding trees on the right hand side of the road. Park here, check out that spruce, then carry on downhill and into the flats to find the tree.
tree_site_notes: Has broken top. Grows on the edge of a creek bank. Nice maples around as well and lots of elk sign. A second big spruce is just beyond through the woods.

access_notes: Yakoun River floodplain flats.  Approx 30 kms north of Queen Charlotte City off Q.C. mainline logging road.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: This tree is easy to get to (2 hour drive from Victoria) and is located very close to the road.  For excellent driving instructions see the Ancient Forest Alliance's Hiking Guide (http://www.ancientforestguide.com/big-trees.php?ID=4).
tree_site_notes:
This tree has a volume of 333 cubic meters.  One cubic meter representing the amount of wood found in a single telephone pole. 
River floodplain site.

access_notes: Many kms south of Pt  Clements on the Q.C. logging mainline, east side along Yakoun River.......about 1 km off road.....vigorous hike.
tree_site_notes: Many small scares and swellings, top intact.

access_notes: The tree is in a remote part of the San Juan River that is very difficult to access without a watercraft. You could bushwhack in from about 4km down the road just west of the Lower Harris bridge on the Pacific Marine Road. This would require about 1400m of bushwhacking through dense riparian and I have not tried it but it would not be for the faint of heart. The other access option is to paddle in from Fairy Lake and land on a gravel bar south of the stand. The bush is still fierce, but we found abundant elk trails throughout which make it easier to navigate. You are unlikely to be able to access from the north channel as this water course is not easily navigable.
tree_site_notes: Tree sits on a small bench just above a fen. Top is dead but tree is otherwise very healthy. Extremely productive floodplain with dense salmonberry, red elderberry, and stinkcurrant forming nearly impenetrable shrub layers in some areas. Some rare instances of vine maple can be found nearby.

access_notes: South of Pt Clements off the Q. Charlotte mainline to the east.....significant walk in the forest to reach this tree.
tree_site_notes: Live top, healthy tree

access_notes: From Holberg, take SE Main to Koprino Main to Hathaway Main. This tree is just off the side of the road and not very hard to get to.
tree_site_notes: A big, muscly Sitka spruce with rough bark that looks like Godzilla. One of the most impressive trees in this region! Easy to get to off the road.

access_notes: From the Carmanah parking lot at the end of Rosander Main descend the Valley Mist Trail to the junction. Turn right (downstream) and continue to the Randy Stoltmann Grove.  Once in the Grove, keep right. The largest tree on the right is The Party Tree, just opposite The Needle.
tree_site_notes:
This is the largest tree in the Stoltmann Grove both in height and in girth. The Party Tree is named after the famous tree in the Lord of the Rings that is the site of Bilbo's birthday party. There is another tall tree just to the left of The Party Tree (between The Needle and The Party Tree) that is roughly 82 meters tall, or more.  

This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time

access_notes: About 20 kilometres (12 mi) from Port Renfrew, or 8 kilometres (5.0 mi) from Lizard lake when driving toward Honeymoon Bay. There is a small sign for the tree on the right-hand side of the road, when driving northeast. There is a substantial dirt parking area, and a short, flat path leads to the tree roughly 70m to the east.

Turn left after crossing bridge over San Juan River, turn right at wye onto Lens Creek Main, then onto Bear Creek Main. The rec. site is just across the upper San Juan River bridge.
tree_site_notes: This is the number two sitka at this site, being eclipsed by tree #175, the "San Juan Spruce“, but having held its crown, and with a towering trunk poking right out of your campsite. It is now is the healthy substitute, and potential future replacement for crown wearer. Tree is estimated to be 450 years old.

access_notes: The tree is on the Rainey Creek Trail, about 1/3 of the way in from the Tennis Court Entrance on the trail. For information on the trail see http://districtofstewart.com/parks-recreation/parks-sport-fields-and-trails/  or http://www.trailpeak.com/trail-Rainey-Creek-Trail-near-Stewart-BC-10202
tree_site_notes: Tree appears healthy with no visible marks or blemishes.

access_notes: Extremely open and easy-walking fern-filled glade just below Caycuse Main. Tree is visible from the road at about 800m from the start of Caycuse Main (off Mainline Carmanah). Adjacent to another beautiful spruce that is slightly smaller with a flaired base.
tree_site_notes: A spectacular spruce with a massive forked crown and a large burl. Its upper branches are covered in licorice fern and several dens have been excavated under the roots on all sides of it. Located in a gorgeously open and lush elevated bench above the Caycuse River (CWHvm1/07). A few spruces dominate the scenery, giving a cathedralesque appeareance to the stand, with smaller hemlocks throughout and occassionaly bigleaf maple. Understory is almost entirely a carpet of sword fern and small herbs with very few other shrubs.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Very good health
Another giant spruce growing along the Koprino River (there are a few if you look!) surrounded by a jungle of plants. And mosquitoes.

access_notes: Park on Hwy 14 just south of the Loss Creek bridge. Bushwhack through a bit of salmonberry. Recommended during dry months.
tree_site_notes: Productive floodplain bench above Loss Creek, with a steep cliff to the south, leading the trees here to grow to exceptional heights. Site formerly hosted some large cedars which likely died during the last major flood event. The tree grows in a dense, swampy portion with abundant salmonberry and red elderberry.
CWHvh1 07

access_notes: Extremely open and easy-walking fern-filled glade just below Caycuse Main.  Tree is visible from the road at about 800m from the start of Caycuse Main (off Mainline Carmanah). Adjacent to another beautiful spruce that is slightly larger with a neat burl and a massive forked canopy.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful tall and straight spruce with a symmetrical fluted base. Its upper branches are covered in licorice fern. Located in a gorgeously open and lush elevated bench above the Caycuse River (CWHvm1/07). A few spruces dominate the scenery, giving a cathedralesque appeareance to the stand, with smaller hemlocks throughout and occassionaly bigleaf maple. Understory is almost entirely a carpet of sword fern and small herbs with very few other shrubs.
I'd hope to find some nice big spruce here not far from Hecht Beach and Hecht Yeah we did!
CWHvm1 10

access_notes:
From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road, continuing all the way past the lake on Cowichan Main and eventually following the Nitinat River.Turn right at T-Intersection ( 48.8627379, -124.6438995 ) over the bridge which crosses Nitinat River, following
Carmanah Main. A visit to the waterfalls on the Little Nitinat Falls is recommended for a quick break (unmarked pull off near 48.871476, -124.687404 ). Follow Carmanah Main until a bridge on your left crosses the Little Nitinat River onto Flora Main ( 48.8994754, -124.6887141 ). Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left. Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits. Take the left spur K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ). After some time, along the South side of K-265 there are a couple of small lakes accessed via a short spur (approx 48.8274633, -1248130282 ), where one can visit the Fairy Bell Cedar at Dorothy Lake (at the head of the second lake, 48.825688, -124.822826 ).
Coming to another T-Intersection ( 48.8307925, -124.8372049 ), turn left and continue straight past another
intersection and follow it until you reach the spruce flats and recently logged areas at the bottom of the valley (approx
48.7969942, -124.8668236 ). This is where the Main and East Forks of the Klanawa River meet. This new road
bends East and becomes very coarse. It is advised that one parks in a safe location and walks into Hummingbird
Grove (starting at 48.801119, -124.832387 ).
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 07. Hummingbird Tree has large buttressing roots, numerous large burls, a bare crown and a healthy canopy. The Tree is located on a toe slope, in a recent cutblock, situated near the edge of a riparian plain. It stands on the North Bank of the East Fork of the Klanawa River. Ther are numerous fine and large specimens of Sitka spruce, western redcear and even occasional Douglas fir still stands in the Klanawa River Valley System. Hummingbird Grove is one of the two outstanding spruce groves of this beautiful area. For more detailed information about the trees of this region visit the Vancouver Island Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

access_notes: Starting from the Carmanah Walbran parking lot at the end of Rosander Main, walk down the Valley Mist Trail to the junction. Turn right (downstream) towards the Stoltmann Grove, and after passing the Heaven Tree, stay right at any forks in the trail. When the trail dead-ends in the Stoltmann Grove at a gully or creekbed filled with logs and vegetation, The Needle is the large spruce with a prominent burl on the left (downstream) side of the trail.
tree_site_notes:
The Needle has an obvious burl near the base. It has a slight lean, and it is situated on the edge of the creekbed or gully that bounds the Stoltmann Grove on one side. It is near the obvious largest tree in the grove (circumference 8.48 m), but it is not immediately adjacent to it.

This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: From Holberg, take SE Main to Koprino Main to Hathaway Main. The trees are a short walk off the road. Use GPS point for locating.
tree_site_notes: Two very tall and impressive Sitka spruce trees growing close together, appearing to be joined at the base. They sit just a short hop of the road in a nice fern glade beside a creek. Currently unprotected.

A picture-perfect spruce covered with golden moss standing like a beacon in the ferny forest drawing you ever further in.

tree_site_notes: A tall sitka spruce growing on the edge of a recent cutblock in the Klanawa Valley. Stark contrast in spring between the lush, green plants around the tree and grey slash in the clearcut.

access_notes: Outside of Holberg, leave Northest Main onto NE 40 spur. Take this road as close as you can get to the GPS point. Bushwhacking down into the riverside grove was very challenging in places with steep hillsides and windthrow. Only for experienced hikers.
tree_site_notes: One of three Sitka spruce trees that act as a time capsule of how the region of the San Jospeh River near Holberg would have once looked. When standing in this location, one can for a moment imagine when vast river valleys would have once looked like this. I truly powerful spot. Tree measured was furthest left of the trio (away from the river).

A towering spruce pillar that makes a great roadside attraction for the wayward traveller. A short jaunt through a bit of bush takes you to this incredible tree which is stands out among the more even-aged hemlock forest surrounding it. A large gash near the base points to some troubled past that you'd have to ask its neighbours about to find out.

access_notes: From the Carmanah Walbran PP parking lot at the end of Rosander Main, descend the Valley Mist trail to the Coast Tower (the large spruce snag that is cordoned off). Turn left (upstream, or north) off the trail, and walk for a few minutes into the clearing. The first large spruce in the clearing is Major Tom; the next large spruce in the same direction is Ground Control.
tree_site_notes:
The site is located in a wet shrubby clearing (mostly large salmonberry, with some blueberry and huckleberry). There is a small hemlock growing out of the base of Major Tom. 

This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: Starting from the Carmanah parking lot at the end of Rosander Main, descend the Valley Mist trail and turn right (downstream) at the junction, towards the Randy Stoltmann Grove. In the Stoltmann Grove, turn left and walk through a dense patch of salmonberry on an overgrown trail leading downstream. The first large tree on the right is Dunsinane
tree_site_notes:
Has a forked top, although it is not very obvious from the ground. Quite bushy low down, with adventitious branches. Situated opposite a 'walking hemlock' with exposed roots. 

This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: From the Carmanah-Walbran PP parking lot at the end of Rosander Main, follow the Valley Mist Trail down to the junction. Turn upstream towards the Three Sisters. After a few minutes walking the trail descends a staircase to a low flat terrace.  Walking along the trail from the bottom of the staircase for a minute or two brings you to the Goose. It is on the right side of the trail (facing upstream). If you make it to the wooden bridge (across a dry creekbed) you've gone too far.
tree_site_notes: Wide mossy monumental trunk. This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main then Q Main line nearly to the end. This is a massive journey. Only worth it if you're already down this far.
tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 10. A large Sitka spruce growing tall and straight like a Roman pillar.

access_notes: From the Carmanah Walbran PP main trailhead, hike down the Valley Mist trail to the junction. Turn left towards the three sisters, and continue until you reach the creek. The stand of trees containing the Diver is just past a small wooden bridge over a dry creekbed. After the bridge there is a washout, and the trail divides in two, with a bypass around the washout. Facing upstream where the bypass rejoins the main trail, the Diver is on the side of the trail to the left. Carmanah Creek is visible from it's base. It is the most upstream (north-easterly) of the stand in which it is situated.
tree_site_notes:
The tallest of a stand of tall Sitka spruce on the NW side of Carmanah Creek. 
This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: From the Carmanah Walbran PP parking lot at the end of Rosander Main, descend the Valley Mist trail to the Coast Tower (the large spruce snag that is cordoned off). Turn left (upstream, or north) off the trail, and walk for a few minutes into the clearing. The first large spruce in the clearing is Major Tom; the next large spruce in the same direction is Ground Control.
tree_site_notes:
Ground Control is on the far edge of the same clearing as Major Tom. Both have a small hemlock growing out of the base. A tree has recently fallen across the base of the trunk of Ground Control, so there are broken branches and a trunk at the base. There is also a large scar low down on the trunk of Ground Control from the impact. 

This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.

access_notes: From the Riverlodge Recreation Centre parking lot  turn left and drive 100 meters to the Dyke Road and turn left.  Drive 150 meters and turn left off the dyke road and drive a short distance where you'll see a sign on the left and a parking lot for the Giant Spruce Park.  Walk a minute down a wide trail and you will find the large tree on your right.
tree_site_notes: This tree has an impressive base with many conks. This tree has a broken top that has been damaged over the years: 2025 ht= 25.9 m, 2000 ht= 42.4 m, 1983 ht= 50.3.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Starting at the Coho Flats trail, hike approximately 45 minutes to the junction of Fisherman's Trail.   Turn left (or south) and follow trail along the Kitimat River for appxoimately 40 minutes.  Just before a wide backwater with a high bridge over it you will find the Maiden about 30 meters to the right of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry.  The Maiden Sitka spruce is located in a small but  magnificent stand of ancient western red cedar, amabalis fir, western hemlock and Sitka spruce trees.  Lots of nurse logs and fallen giants litter the ground with some young trees growing  under the dense canopy.  This high flood bank is at the bottom of a slope with wetlands paralling the trail.  In the vicinty of the Maiden there are sparce devil's club, red alder, elderberry and maple in the shrub layer with ferns and foam flowers in the herb layer.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 10

CWHvm1 10
A big lonely spruce left in a cutblock near Quatsino Sound. A stark reminder of the giants that were once found here.
CWHvh1 10

access_notes: From the Riverlodge Recreation Centre parking lot turn left and drive 100 meters to the Dyke Road and turn left. Drive 150 meters and turn left off the dyke road and drive a short distance where you'll see a sign on the left and a parking lot for the Giant Spruce Park.   This tree is on the right side of the trail and has the sign in front of it saying it is a younger sibling to the Giant Spruce.
tree_site_notes: Surrounded by a few lone cedar and spruce giants, this tree is growing in a previously logged site.  Its surrounded by thick devil's club and berry bushes.

access_notes: From Holberg, take SE Main to Koprino Main to Hathaway Main. These two trees are difficult to get to, involving a steep bushwhack and then crossing a sketchy & steep ravine. Not recommonded for most people.
tree_site_notes: An exceptional pair of unprotected spruce trees guarded by a towering rock wall, a steep and trecherous gully, and spiny devil's club. These tall, straight pillars soar skyward, their great height owed to the shelter of the cliff behind them.

access_notes: From the Carmanah PP parking lot, hike down the valley mist trail to the first junction. Turn left, towards the Three Sisters. A few minutes of walking, past a gully containing an eighty-meter giant, leads to low riparian terrace. Gatekeeper is on the right side of the trail (facing upstream) at the bottom of a staircase which is the second descending staircase after the junction.
tree_site_notes:
Smooth mossy trunk without much buttressing. Situated on a low riparian terrace.
This tree was one of ten nominated by a UBC research team in the Carmanah Valley in July 2016. The team consisted of Matthew Beatty, Jon Degner, Vincent Hanlon, James Luce, and Ryan Murphy, as well as Sally Aitken, James Frystak, and TJ Watt, who were present part of the time.
CWHvh1 10
CWHvm2 06
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: From the Riverlodge Recreation Centre parking lot turn left and drive 100 meters to the Dyke Road and turn left. Drive 150 meters and turn left off the dyke road and drive a short distance where you'll see a sign on the left and a parking lot for the Giant Spruce Park.  Paralleling the parking lot on the north side you will see a connection to a quad trail paralling the parking lot and heading west.  Walk 1 minute along this trail and you will see Blue's tree on the left.
tree_site_notes: Surrounded by a few lone cedar and spruce giants, this tree is growing in a previously logged site.  Its surrounded by thick devil's club and berry bushes.

access_notes: Sombrio Beach parking area, short trail to beach. Tree is located by the toilets.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 01 Gnarly

access_notes: Turning west off of Highway 19, directly across from the Sayward exit, you will find yourself on the Salmon River Main. Accessing the park is not that straight forward, as there is no signage, and the White River FSR is somewhat off direction from the paved Salmon River Main, which lured me off course for about 6 km before realizing that the river was on the wrong road I was supposed to be on. Backtracking, I found where I missed the turn-off at the junction. The rough gravel road rises steeply from the Salmon River valley, where at the 17 km marker a junction where the road goes down to a bridge crossing the White River, is not the right direction, stay left on the Victoria Main for a further 6 km, where the Park Boundary sign is your first indication that you are getting close to your destination. A short distance further, and an obscure (facing in the wrong direction of travel) sign directs you towards a short trail that leads you through the big Douglas-fir trees towards the river.
tree_site_notes: Touted as the "Cathedral Grove of the North“.  The tree is within the protected area of the White River Provincial Park, which is a narrow linear strip of preserved old-growth, with extensive harvesting visual all around it. The Douglas-fir, tree #1292, is right beside this short trail, before you get to the river. The western redcedar, tree #1293, is upstream, off trail, through some flat, but deadfall barriered ground.  The Sitka spruce, tree #1294, is very close to the western redcedar.

access_notes: Little Qualicum River floodplain is on District lot 76, lot 6, Newcastle Land District of BC.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy. The height to circumference ratio indicates the possibility of superior genetics. There is a spruce grove on this property and adjoining properties of up to 300 trees of all ages, all very tall indicating the possibility of resistance to the spruce leader weevil. There is no indication of leader weevil damage.  Small circumference for a Sitka spruce, likely due to it being in a dry subzone of the CDF zone.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvh1 08

access_notes: From Port Alice, follow forest service roads to Gooding Cove. Park as close as you can to Rowley Reefs Recreation Site and bushwack/hike to tree. This is a remote setting and requires routefinding.
Tree is about 50 metres south west of Pike Road parking lot by the creek. Exit the outhouse and look striaght ahead.
tree_site_notes: Mounded on creek banks. POG (point of germination) ~ 40cm above high side. Super straight and healthy looking. Creek valley from parking lot to Iron Mine Bay has several moderate sized sitka spruce as well, though surrounding hillsides have lots of arbutus.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Drive to Bere Point Regional Park. The Beautiful Bay Trailhead is at west end of campground. Tree is on the Beautiful Bay Trail about 1.5 km from the trailhead.
From Highway 19, turn onto Rock Bay Road FSR, take the left turn right before the Rock Bay Resort. Tree is between the access road to the fish hatchery and the waters edge
tree_site_notes: Well positioned in a small island of trees very near the shoreline
CWHvm1 10
One of six big spruce left standing after logging. There is now five after one blew down. Will have to see if it survives as well…
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 04

access_notes: Starting at the Kitimat River Pumphouses, walk downstream along Joe's Trail for about 16 minutes.  This Sitka spruce is on the left along the edge of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Students in the Outdoor Education class at Kitimat City High measured this tree at the end of an Old Growth forest tour.  The dense undergrowth of this tree is mainly devil's club, ferns, salmon berries, elderberries, and young evergreen trees of various ages.  This area is regularly flooded and the ground is covered in sandy sediment so the trail looks manicured.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: From Port Alice, follow forest service roads to Gooding Cove. Park as close as you can to Rowley Reefs Recreation Site and bushwack/hike to tree. This is a remote setting and requires routefinding.
Water Taxi
tree_site_notes: Big Tree Trail follows boardwalks for about 1 km, then the remaining loop is a quagmire of boot sucking mud, but the primeval forest is spectacular. The spruce was not too far off of the trail

access_notes: Turn north off of Highway 20 into the Rip-Rap RV and Campground. In a forest trail loop beside the Bella Coola River. Tree is upstream from the campground.
tree_site_notes: Many old trees of a varied species can be seen along this trail.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 04

access_notes: From Ridge Road in Campbell River walk down past Ecole des Deux Mondes to grass field. Pick up trail in SE corner of field and follow it to this tree.
From Port Alice drive west on forest service roads to Side Bay and beyond. Tree was accessed from a difficult hike along the coastline in Lawn Point Provincial Park.

Drive North on Highway 37A for approximately 7 km and turning on the first left after the Snowflake Community Fairgrounds. There is a place to park about 100 meters from the highway. A 10 minute walk on an old road, through a second growth forest down a gentle hill brings you to the Sitka Spruce, The Motivator, on the left. If you cross a wooden bridge you've gone too far.
tree_site_notes: The Motivator is in good health on a flood plain near a small creek dammed by beavers. The wetland area is regularly flooded although now a few hundred meters from one of the branches of the Kitimat River. The umbrella nature of the tree makes it easy to walk around and view. Most of the main branches are covered in a thick layer of moss so the upward view is amazing. A perfect half circle of large mushrooms grows along the crown edge on the north side. Plants around the tree are devil's club, willow and berry bushes. The soil is a thick layer of humus on a sandy base. This Sitka spruce tree is at the bottom of a hill logged in the past and the first of many giant untouched trees acting as sentinels to this intact pocket of magnificent old growth. Few people know about this amazing ancient pocket forest and so last year I took a group, as part of an educational push by the Kitimat Watershed Stewardship Group, on a one-day hike to learn about old growth forests. The group all wanted to continue this process of discovery for other trees in the area. We called it the Motivator as now we are motivated to promote our wonderful old growth by tree identification into the future.

access_notes: From the Riverlodge Recreation Centre parking lot turn left and drive 100 meters to the Dyke Road and turn left. Drive 150 meters and turn left off the dyke road and drive a short distance where you'll see a sign on the left and a parking lot for the Giant Spruce Park.  Right past the' Giant Spruce Park' sign as you head toward the Giant Spruce you will find this tree on the left hand side off the trail about 4 meters.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top and has lost some of its height since 2000 when it was recorded as 74 m tall and has grown in diameter about 12 cm.  Surrounded by a few lone cedar and spruce giants, this tree is growing in a previously logged site.  Its surrounded by thick devil's club and berry bushes.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy. 37 and Kitamaat Village Road, drive north on Hwy 37 for 5 minutes, turn left on Oolichan, left on Coho Ave, right on Rainbow Blvd and right on Chinook Ave.  Park on left near playground.  Walk about 250 m towards the Kitimat River down a hill and along the dyke road.  Turn left and walk on quad trail until you can see the Kitimat River.  The tree is about 20 meters off the trail through thick brush and devils club.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry. This is just one of many large spruce trees in this little pocket of old growth. Tree has a large snapped top. The Kitimat River is cutting away the high bank nearby.  Neighbouring old growth trees include Western red cedar, red alder and willows.  Surrounded by devil's club, salmonberry, willow, young western red cedar and Sitka spruce this tree is best viewed in early spring or late fall.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Sitka Spruce has a forked, dead top, but overall is healthy. Tree is located near an S6 stream, approximately 100m from the Zymagotitz River to the east. Understorey vegetation includes devil's club and fern.

access_notes: On trail from campground down to the beach.

Starting at the Kitimat River Pumphouses, walk downstream along Joe's Trail for about 15 minutes.  This Sitka spruce is right along the edge of the trail above a flood prone watercourse.  It is on a mound of silty soil.
tree_site_notes: Students in the Outdoor Education class at Kitimat City High measured this tree at the end of an Old Growth forest tour.  The dense undergrowth of this tree is mainly devil's club, ferns, salmon berries, elderberries, and young evergreen trees of various ages.  This area is regularly flooded and the ground is covered in sandy sediment so the trail looks manicured.

access_notes: From the Riverlodge Recreation Centre parking lot turn left and drive up the slight hill to the Dyke Road.  Turn right and take first left at large sign "Notice of Protected Area."  Walk to the left downstream along the Kitimat River, along Joe's Trail for 12 minutes and when you arrive at a wooden bridge the tree is across the bridge straight ahead on the right side of the trail.  The tree is in a tightly spaced group of 5 trees.  The spruce observed is the first and largest in the group.
tree_site_notes: Members of the public who participated in an old growth forest tour, sponsored by the Kitimat Valley Naturalists, measured this tree at the end of their tour.  This is one large spruce in a group of 2 more spruce and 2 western hemlock surrounded by a sandy base.  False solomon's seal and devil's club surround the base which also has a quad trail on both sides of the group of trees.

access_notes: This tree towers in an open space over campsite #2 at the Hirsch Creek Municipal Park.
tree_site_notes: Members of the T'simotsa Girl Guides group in Kitimat measured this tree after a tour of the old growth forest in Hirsch Creek Municipal Park.  The ground around this tree is packed dirt that has seen a lot of campers playing beneath its canopy.  It has seen occasional flood sediments deposited but stands tall on the edge of an ancient forest that has seen some leaners and dead standing trees controversially cut down due to safety concerns.  The crown branches are very high up on the stem and there's a large human made scar the the bottom of the tree.

access_notes: From Highway 19, turn onto Eve River Main FSR, and follow to the Junction Pool Rec. site. Tree is beside trail upstream of the Eve and Adam River confluence.
tree_site_notes: Located in a stand of trees that has fortunately not been cut down, like many of the others within this valley.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy. 37 and Kitamaat Village Road, drive north on Hwy 37 for 5 minutes, turn left on Oolichan, left on Coho Ave, right on Rainbow Blvd and right on Chinook Ave.  Park on left near playground.  Walk about 250 m towards the Kitimat River down a hill and along the dyke road.  The Grand Entrance Sitka spruce is on the left.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry. This single tree, growing out of the side of the dyke,  was spared when the Cablecar dyke road was built. Its on a floodplain but protected by the dyke.  The tree is in good health, straight and tall surrounded by red alder and young amabilis fir and black cottonwood trees and shrubs including elderberry, red osier dogwood, thimbleberry, and Nootka rose.

access_notes: From the start of the Hirsch Creek Trail, just past campsite #2, walk about 4 minutes along the wide gravel trail toward Hirsch Creek.  You will see Tree Dino on the left off the trail about 20 meters.  It sits along a recently created frisbee golf course in the forest.
tree_site_notes: This sitka spruce tree sits between the hiking trail and a frisbee golf course.  It is surrounded by dead standing trees as well as logs of varying degree of decay.  There are trees of various ages growing in the area including cedar, spruce and hemlock.  Devil's club is the predominant bush around the tree.

access_notes: Drive from Port Hardy, following signs to Winter Harbour, turn right onto Topknot Main  and signed Grant's Bay Rec. Site. Tree is near access trail to Grant's Bay
tree_site_notes: Located in a very isolated grove of primarily Sitka spruce.  Most of the surrounding primary forest has been harvested.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road, head North on Hwy 37 approximately 6 km, turn left (west side) on a narrow old logging road. There is a good place to park about 100 meters down the logging road. Follow old logging road, across a wooden bridge until you see a quad trail on the left.  Follow this quad trail til you come to an ancient fallen tree, and after crossing it, continue a couple of minutes til you come to a Y in the trail, take the right trail and bushwack about 25 meters towardsthe  Kitimat River.  This will take about 20 minutes in total.
tree_site_notes: Members of the public who participated in an old growth forest tour, sponsored by the Kitimat Valley Naturalists, measured this tree at the end of their tour.  This tree is healthy and doesn't apprear to have a broken top.  No obvious evidence of wildlife use.  The surrounding ecosystem contains false lily, devils club, salmonberry and dead fallen trees laying on the ground nearby.  This tree is growing on a nurse log.

access_notes: Water access only.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh2

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests to the bottom end of the lake.
tree_site_notes: A sizable spruce amongst a grove of a dozen more. Difficult to access but beautiful forest at the south end of the lake.

access_notes: Bushwack in from NF 1400 along North Fork Main.
tree_site_notes: A truly impressive spruce that comes by its size honestly. Grows amongst a few other giants not far from the riverbank of the Klanawa River. Just outside the edge of a Wildlife Habitat Area.

access_notes: Take Klanawa Main to KM 1200 spur road then KM 1107. Bushwhack downslope and into the flats.
tree_site_notes: A tall, cylindrical spruce that catches your eye from afar. Protected within  a Wildlife Habitat Area. Recent logging encroaching close by.

access_notes: Take Klanawa Main to KM 1200 spur road then KM 1107. Bushwhack downslope and into the flats.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful spruce  growing in the lush valley bottom of the Klanawa River festooned with redwood sorrel at its base. Hard to get to but an impressive tree. Protected in a Wildlife Habitat Area.

access_notes: Take Klanawa Main to KM 1200 spur road then KM 1107. Bushwhack downslope and into the flats.
tree_site_notes: A big, burly, boss-like spruce growing in dense forest along the Klanawa River. Protected in a Wildlife Habitat Area.

access_notes: Take Nitinat Main to the Nitinat Junction. Bushwhack to the GPS location.
tree_site_notes: A wide base spruce that stands in an impressive grove of other sitkas as well. Currently protected in an Old-Growth Management Area.

access_notes: Take Cowichan Main to the Nitinat Junction. Turn right onto Carmanah Mainline and cross the bridge over Nitinat River. Bushwhack into Nitinat River Provincial Park. Tree is close to rivers edge a distance in.
tree_site_notes: A colossul Sitka spruce growing within the provincial park. A stunning sight to see with other giants right nearby.

access_notes: Bushwhack through second-growth off of Red Creek Mainline down towards the San Juan River. You will have to navigate a steep slope adjacent to a beautiful waterfall. Tree is down on the flats amongst a few other big ones too.
tree_site_notes: A very impressive Sitka spruce tree growing on the flood plain of the San Juan River

access_notes: Hellish bushwhack through exteremely dense stink currant, salmon berry, and swamps  from Red Creek Main. Might be easier to approach from river. Not for the faint of heart!
tree_site_notes: A tower of a spruce with big reiterating branches and a deep 'v' split between the dual trunks part way up. Might split down the middle one day! Another big spruce right beside it as well.

access_notes: Hellish bushwhack through exteremely dense stink currant, salmon berry, and swamps  from Red Creek Main. Easier to approach from river. Not for the faint of heart!
tree_site_notes: A big spruce. There are others nearby.

access_notes: Bushwhack in from spru road off of Harris Creek Main.
tree_site_notes: A big spruce with strong arms like Gaston
A nice spruce growing near the banks of the river.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before heading into the forest on the opposite side of the road (choose your own adventure as to how to get in there). Use GPS coordinates to track down the tree. An alternate route would be to bushwhack in off of Palmerston Main.
tree_site_notes: This spruce is truly out of this world! It must have grown over top of something a long time ago, creating this massive, burly, rootball base that if you measure it there, would be 4.7m wide. We measured it around the narrower trunk above. There is a noteable 'knuckle' window that sticks out off the side and reconnects with the tree creating a window. So strange!! Really one of the coolest trees either of us had ever seen before.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right.
