Park here and admire that tree before heading into the forest on the opposite side of the road (choose your own adventure as to how to get in there). Use GPS coordinates to track down the tree.
tree_site_notes: An amazing spruce tree growing on the dividing line of dark, dreary second-growth and lush, epic old-growth. The tree's base and trunk have unique spiral shape and there is a hobbit hole on oneside providing space for an intrepid tree traveller to sit and ponder life's big questions. Well worth a visit!
A big beautiful spruce that was spared logging in the 90's but now within an approved cutblock

access_notes: This place is out there! Hike down off of Side Bay Main through second-growth and find a way to cross the Keith River  then bushwhack through the epic and beautiful old-growth using the GPS point as a guide.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful Sitka spruce tree growing in a Wildlife Habitat Area along the Keith River near Side Bay. Legend has it loggers refused to cut down this patch of forest given it's impressive nature while the entire surrounding areas were clearcut in the 1980's. Today an island of old-growth exists here. Impressive Sitka spruce trees abound in this grove, which is braided by a network of clear streams and wildlife trails. Still more to explore!

access_notes: This place is out there! Hike down off of Side Bay Main through second-growth and find a way to cross the Keith River  then bushwhack through the epic and beautiful old-growth using the GPS point as a guide.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful Sitka spruce tree growing in a Wildlife Habitat Area along the Keith River near Side Bay. Legend has it loggers refused to cut down this patch of forest given it's impressive nature while the entire surrounding areas were clearcut in the 1980's. Today an island of old-growth exists here. Impressive Sitka spruce trees abound in this grove, which is braided by a network of clear streams and wildlife trails. Still more to explore!

access_notes: Hike the Spruce Bay Recreation Trail from the camping area. This tree is slightly off trail towards the back end of the loop.
tree_site_notes: A towering Sitka spruce that is one among many along the Spruce Bay Trail. This trail is like a slice of Carmanah on the north island. The stumps in the second-growth nearby tell a heartbreaking story of trees of almost unimanginable proportions and densities, sadly gone forever. The Spruce Bay Trail is a glimpse into that lost world.

access_notes: A short bushwhack off of San Joseph Main through some wet and bushy terrain.
tree_site_notes: A towering Sitka spruce with two branches shooting upwards off its side like someone putting there arms up in the air!

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main towards the coast. Turn left onto Raft Main. Take your first right onto a small side road (semi-over grown with alders). A short ways down you will see the current #1 Sitka spruce tree on your right. Park here and admire that tree before walking further down the road. You will see a ribbon of trees on the left combing close to the road, parallel this towards the back edge of the clearing where you will find this tree.
tree_site_notes: CWHvh1 06 A big ole' Sitka with some junk in its trunk! Big Girtha is just one of many massive spruce trees found in this exceptional zone - possibly the highest concentrations of giant Sitka's that we know of, largely (we think) due to the limestone substrate they grow on.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A beast of a spruce tree with a big burl at the base. This tree has a commanding presence when standing before it! Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There are other large spruce trees in the area. Worth more exploring in the dry season.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg get to NE Main and start travelling down Quatsino Sound. Carry onto SE Koprino Main then onto Hathaway Main then Michelson Main. Use GPS points to park close to the tree which will be on the left side of the road through a bit of a swampy section. Not super far but gumboots might help. You can see the big top from the road.
tree_site_notes: A nice big spruce in a nice forest. Thankfully it's protected by an OGMA and WHA. There is an amazing double-headed spruce across the road growing unprotected and well worth a look!
A nice spruce growing on a steep slope that leads down to the ocean in a far away forest. The hillside is home to additional spruce groves as well. Bit of a trek to get here.
A big and beautiful spruce in a grove of other giants along the riverside. A trip back in time to see this stand. Thankfully it's protected within a Wildlife Habitat Area.

A noteable spruce with a flared base growing in a spectacular yet threatened grove. A beautiful creek flows through the middle of the forest here. Coastal temperate rainforest at its finest, but for how long…

access_notes: Victoria Main
tree_site_notes: Base of tree was very fluted, making Point of Germination determinations difficult.

access_notes: From Holberg, drive to San Josef River boat launch and paddle or boat to Sea Otter Cove. Otherwise, can hike from San Josef Bay Trailhead over Mount Saint Patrick and down to Sea Otter Cove. Long and challenging access.
tree_site_notes: Large veteran spruce that likley escaped logging due to its broken top. The tree is hollow at the base and appears to be used as a bear den. The top half of the tree is broken off. The tree still contains vigourous green branches despite this. A large branch forks off from the main stem about 4 metres up the tree.

access_notes: This tree is accessed via the trail to Chin Beach off of Highway 14. Take the trail down through second-growth forest for about 5 minutes until you reach a large cedar tree on the path. Trailhead is 1.3 km west of Lines Creek Bridge on Highway 14. A small pull-out with a traffic cone attached to a hydro pole is the trailhead marker.
Take Cowichan 700 spur off of Cowichan Main. Then take first right. Old road can be driven for a short distance before a washout. Walk along the old road before hiking up the steep hillside.
tree_site_notes: A lovely spruce growing near a beautiful bigleaf maple tree

access_notes: From Port Alberni take Ash Main to Stirling Arm Main to Canal Main to Lake Main then left on Danylon Main. Watch for another small spur on your left at 49.074536, -124.910083 that takes you down towards the river. The tree is just off the side of that small dirt access road.
tree_site_notes: A big beautiful spruce growing in lush old-growth forest. Other large spruce and bigleaf maples are found nearby. Beautiful spot, especially in the spring.

access_notes: Along Hanna and Tintina Creeks, just east of Meziadin Lake. Tintina Creek is next to Bear Glacier Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: This tree is named after chief Wii Litsxw (Big Blue Grouse) - Txawoxkw (Half a sleep, snoring). The tree is located within the Hanna Tintina Conservancy.  The land was protected through the Gitanyow Recognition and Reconciliation Agreement and through the Gitanyow Lax'yip Land Use Plan (www.gitanyowchiefs.com).   In 1987 this tree was 210 years old and healthy.

access_notes: Along Hanna and Tintina Creeks, just east of Meziadin Lake. Tintina Creek is next to Bear Glacier Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: This tree is named after Neil J Sterritt, a dear friend of Gitanyow and Chief Wii Litsxw-Txawoxkw.  The tree is located within the Hanna Tintina Conservancy.  The land was protected through the Gitanyow Recognition and Reconciliation Agreement and through the Gitanyow Lax'yip Land Use Plan (www.gitanyowchiefs.com). In 1987 this tree was 150+ years old with heart rot.

access_notes: Tree located approximately 100 m east of Dad's Run Ski Trail, approximately 100 m up slope from  Mom's Run Ski Trail.
tree_site_notes: Broken top. Tree has decay in trunk and is in poor condition although living.  Site aspect north, slope approximately 35-40%, middle slope, concave.

access_notes: Located at Fernie Alpine Resort, a person could ride the Elk Chair up (summer or winter) then walk up the summer road into the Lizard Bowl, where it wraps around to the top of the Ballet Run. Hidden in the alder behind a big larch tree is the subalpine fir.
tree_site_notes: There are many vey old subalpine fir growing in the Lizard Range. This particular tree has the benefit of being on a knob that is not subject to the many avalanches that course down either side. Also the big larch seems to have also afforded some protection. This tree is well hidden, and it is not until you climb underneath its branches to you gain the appreciation for how massive it is.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 1.8 km. Before reaching the lake, bushwack about 100m off the trail to reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is an outlier in a forest dominated by black cottonwood, white spruce, western red cedar, douglas fir and paper birch. Tree appears healthy with a large crown almost reaching the ground.

access_notes: The Olivia Creek Trail can be accessed by travelling up the Hartley Lake Rd. from Dicken Road. Hartley Lake Road is a narrow winding dirt road, but is passable under most conditions with a 2WD vehicle. Once you have passed the lake, below to the left, you are at the Hartley/Sulphur Creek Pass. Olivia Creek access is the second old road to the left, just before the road begins descending towards the Bull River. The old road can be quite overgrown, and will have large puddles to navigate around. This 4 km. road section can be driven in a 4WD if you are not worried about your paint job, and want to earn some more “Kootenay Pinstripes”. If you get lured into driving up this road, there are no good turn arounds until it can be too late. Using a bike, or hiking is recommended to get to the old sawdust pile, from where 1 km. further, on a less friendly road, connects you to the trailhead.
tree_site_notes:
The tree is a bit inconspicuous as a subalpine fir, as most of the surrounding trees are large Englemann spruce. The bark on this old tree was not easily distinguishable as a subalpine fir, but the branches swept right down close to the ground, allowing for tree species identification. Located on edge of an avalanche meadow, where a profusion of alpine flowers were in bloom, including: Sitka valerian, Forget-Me-Nots, stinging nettle, blue elderberry, clasping twisted stalk, yellow columbine, and silky phacelia. 
An adjacent 1.54 m. DBH Englemann Spruce was aged at 502 years old.

access_notes: Takla Lake is next to Mt. Blanchet Provincial Park. Km 85.5 driftwood FSR connector.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, conical form.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow trail.
tree_site_notes: Easily accessible.

access_notes: Follow signage from Slocan City to Valhalla Provincial Park, turn right on Bannock Burn FSR, stay right at first wye, follow signage to Gimli Peak Trail. Nice specimen of Sub-Alpine fir rich beside trail.

Drive from the Argenta/Duncan Lake junction north up the Duncan FSR until arriving at the Glacier Creek FSR to the right. 29 km drive up the Glacier Creek FSR to trailhead parking area. 8.4 km trail with 653 m elevation gain. The tree is on a slope above the trail soon after you cross over a small bridge the big trees become visible up to the left.
tree_site_notes: Broken top with a rotted/unconstituted center, but appeared otherwise to be healthy. This is a gnarly tree.

access_notes: EC Manning Provincial Park. From Mount Frosty trail, descend talus to east of saddle before final climb to peak. Tree is located in open grove of larch below talus slopes, on bluffy terrain.
tree_site_notes: Aspect east, slope approx. 40-45%, middle slope, convex. Alpine Tundra zone.

access_notes: The 8.4 km access trail climbs 653 m vertical gain to a maximum elevation of 2830 m. You will be glad to get your legs stretched out after the long 29 km drive up the Glacier Creek FSR. Following the Duncan FSR from Argenta to the well signed right turn onto Glacier FSR is where the bone rattling begins, but once you become surrounded by the massive glaciated peaks, all discomfort disappears. Once at the parking lot, the trail switchbacks up steeply through ESSF forest, where at about 6 km you emerge into the larch studded, namesake meadows.  The tree can be seen above, to the left after you cross a bridge over a small creek. Following up through the gully you will see two large, ancient sentinels on the rocky ground above, the tree to the right #1327, and the larger more scraggy tree is # 977 "Grand Daddy Subby". There appear to be quite a few of these very old sub-alpine larches dotting the exposed ground in the meadow, so further big tree exploration of this beautiful sub-alpine area is warranted.

tree_site_notes: ESSFdk, montane.

access_notes: On the East side of Ladyslipper Trail, half way between Ladyslipper Lake and Pyramid Lake in Cathedral Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. A very large branch comes off the trunk 4 meters above the ground.

access_notes: On the East side of Ladyslipper Trail, half way between Ladyslipper Lake and Pyramid Lake in Cathedral Provincial Park.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with broken top.

access_notes: 75 km SE of Vanderhoof.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.

access_notes: Private land - please respect private property and view from a distance. Tree is on Ashworth Point, southeast tip of Hernando Island.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, vital, top live. CDFmm.  In 2002 this tree was found to be healthy but with multiple broken tops and branches from wind and evidence of butt rot.

access_notes: When nominated the tree was located in the Lannan Forest.  Current tree and landownership status is unknown.
tree_site_notes: Lost large 20+ branch that reduced crown spread.

access_notes: When nominated the tree was located in the Lannan Forest. Current tree and landownership status is unknown.
tree_site_notes: Bracket fungus on trunk at 1.2 m height.
Healthy.

access_notes: It is located next to Hwy 97, 50 km west of Chetwynd and approximately 0.5 km west of Fred Nelson Creek.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. Tree has a lean to the north and is quite old with butt rot and ant activity evident. It is in a stand of 7 large aspen trees (5 standing and 2 down). The measurements for the other 4 healthy trees (in meters) are: cir 2.9, ht 33, crown 4; cir 2.07, ht 34.6, crown 4; cir 2.01, ht 34.6, crown 3; cir 2.49, ht 28.5, crown 4.

access_notes: From Tete Jaune Cache, drive east on Highway 5 / 16 for 3 kilometers towards Mount Robson. Park at pullout on south side of the highway just past truck weigh scale pullout. Cross the highway and find the trailhead for Little Lost Lake Recreation Site about 100m west of the pullout. There is a sign marking the trail. Hike up Little Lost Lake trail for about 1km. Tree is off to the right side less than 100m from the trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in poor health, but still alive. Nearby trees are similar size and healthy.

access_notes: Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road. At south end the tree can be seen beside the railway tracks.
tree_site_notes: A group of old aspens within a sea of black hawthorn.

access_notes: 15 km east of Okanagan Falls.

Take Highway 95A South from Kimberley's downtown for 5.7 kms, then turn right onto St. Mary Lake Road.  Park at Campground trailhead on North side of St. Mary Lake Road at approximately 3km. 500m hike or bike to Hoodoo View Trail junction and 100m to creek crossing.
tree_site_notes: One of more large limbs have broken off near the top, affecting canopy size and shape. Live crown is quite small, and one branch and gap in the crown are visible on the City airphoto.  This tree is one of two aspen trees growing right on a creek.  The creek goes underground just past a footbridge, then comes out in a small channel right under this tree.

access_notes: Private land - access is restricted.
tree_site_notes: Growing on a residential property, where the septic system likely nourishes the tree.

access_notes: This tree is in a very remote location. Access is approximately 23 km SSW of Hwy 20 by rough ATV track starting at the Kleena Kleene landfill site.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be in good health with no distinguishing characteristics other than its size. This tree is shorter than nearby trees but has a larger diameter.

access_notes: From Enderby Cliffs Provincial Park parking lot, take the main trail.  From the Larch viewpoint at 3Km continue along the trail about 400m to the third switchback/wood baricade, where the trail makes a hard right (see * on the map).  The tree is off the trail and very tricky to get to.  Turn left off the trail and very carefully proceed down the ridge about 50 m to a saddle and turn right into the crater or bowl.  The aspen is on the opposite side of the crater.
tree_site_notes: This is a unique spot, requires some interpretation from a geologist!  It is a wetter site than most of the hillside, and besides the cedar and deciduous trees there now, there are remnants (stumps and fallen snags) of old Douglas-firs 80+ cm.  Slightly unusual: Cedar with fire scars.  An unusually massive Lodgepole pine fell across the trail just before the barricade spot. The aspen trees are covered in moss and a few kinds of lichen - white and leaf which seems pretty unusual.  There is another impressive aspen 60m NE of this tree (or 45m directly north of the trail at the wood barricade) with ht=35.5, dbh= 0.62, crownspread=8.7, score= 199

access_notes: Located on Fernie Alpine Resort property on the edge of a logging block known locally as “Charlies’ clearcut”. Park at Lot 4 where the x-country ski trailhead is located, take the left trail going downhill. When you come to the first fork, head south into the cut-block. Roaming around in here you might find the tree.
tree_site_notes: A trembling aspen of this size loses its identity somewhat, as the bark on the lower trunk begins to resemble that of a cottonwood. Unmistakable are the shiny white branches above, and the characteristic branch configuration of the aspen.

access_notes: This tree is in a remote location. Access is by rough ATV track starting at the Kleena Kleene landfill site along Hwy. 20. The tree is situated approximately 23 km ssw from there.
tree_site_notes: The tree was generally in good health.

access_notes: From Bricker's Road, hike up above residential area where many large aspen reside. Tree is on the flank of Mount Proctor
tree_site_notes: Southwest facing slope with many springs resurging throughout.

access_notes: South of tennis courts in Central Park, Burnaby.
Enter woods off Southwest Marine Drive along vague track. Tree is approximately 30-40 m from road on left-hand (west) side of track.
tree_site_notes: Level upland site, two trees at this site. CWHxm1.

access_notes: SW corner of Woodhaven Swamp in Belcarra Regional Park (see access map).
tree_site_notes: Tree runs up hill in an arc, large crown branching in all directions. Tree is in a grove of 4, all over 2 feet circumference. CWHdm.

access_notes: Musqueum Park, Vancouver.
West of Brockton Oval in Stanley Park.
Enter woods off Southwest Marine Drive along vague track. Tree is approximately 30-40 m from road on left-hand (west) side of track.
tree_site_notes: Level upland site, two trees at this site. CWHxm1.

access_notes: South of Tatlow Trail on Lover’s Walk in Stanley Park.
Follow the Perimeter Trail and the tree is next to a rotting Fir stump at the the northwest corner of the park. There is an entrance off of Como Lake.
tree_site_notes: This Vine Maple is in very healthy condition and it leans over the trail. The height is to the tallest branch growing up. The tree itself may be longer than this but in many cases, it grows every where. It would be nice to have a tag on it or at least have the municipal government recognize the tree. Especially since many Vine Maples have bent to the recent snow storm and will be removed.

access_notes: Request access permission from the Ucluelet First Nation.  Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Healthy hemlock in a grove of similar specimens, surrounded by dense salal. Intact crown.

access_notes: Tree is on Cormorant Island on the John Anderson Big Tree Trail. Trail loop leads from campground beside ecological park.
tree_site_notes: Area is referred to locally as Gator Gardens

access_notes: From the Lynn Headwaters Regional Provincial Park parking lot, take the Lynn Headwaters Trail toward Norvan Falls (7 km). Just before the falls, turn right onto the Coliseum Mountain trail. This trail is rugged and fairly vertical. Follow the yellow blazons and orange trail-marking tape. After about an hour, the trail levels out and is in more dense brush and old-growth. Follow the trail, crossing creek beds, until you reach a stony avalanche chute. You'll see Norvan Ponds (pools and waterfall) about 40 m to your left, down the chute. Keep walking on the path, which meanders up the stony avalanche chute. Look for the pink trail-marking tape in the bush to your right and walk about 15 m off the trail to the tree. The tree is above (to the right of) the path, below The Needles. The tree is not visible from the path.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, has 6 reiterations (new leaders) and broken top at 115 feet, 5 leaders forming ‘candelabra’ top.  Tree is at bottom of large avalanche chute.

access_notes: Drive to Bere Point Regional Park. The Beautiful Bay Trailhead is at west end of campground. Tree is on the Beautiful Bay Trail about 1.5 km from the trailhead.
Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Healthy hemlock with an intact crown surrounded by salal and other healthy specimens.

access_notes: Request access permission from the Ucluelet First Nation.  Park at the Florencia Beach parking lot and then walk through the forest to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in decline having lost 20m in ht and 8m in crown spread since it was nominated in 1986.

access_notes: From saddle between Grouse Mountain and Mount Fromme, follow hiking trail north around back of Grouse Mountain into Barrier Creek Valley. From a point approximately 100 m east of Barrier Creek, descend steep, forested slopes approximately 100 m to tree.
tree_site_notes: This was once a huge tree but now has a broken top and is barely alive.  Aspect north, slope approximately 85%, middle slope, straight, avalanche deposition area. CWHvm2.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive east on Highway 28 for 7 km to Saunders Main. Turn left onto Saunders Main and drive for 4.9 km. Road has several tight manauvers requiring a narrower vehicle with four wheel drive. Hike uphill into forest navigating to tree.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock and amabilis fir dominated forest. Forest is sloping towards Saunders Creek. Understory contains deer fern, step moss, five-leaved bramble, and red huckleberry.

access_notes: From Woss head south on Highway 19, turn left onto Tsitika Main, continue to the end of Tsitika Main where it dead ends at the Lower Tsitika River Provincial Park, just before the dead end turn left onto Catherine Maine. Take the first right over Catherine Creek and continue to the end of the road near the GPS points. Bushwhack from there.
tree_site_notes: Tree is extremely healthy, the crown is intact and there is no visible rot or major damage.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive north on Gold River Road then onto East Main into Gold-Muchalat Provincial Park. Park on side of road and bushwhack to tree.

Notes current to Dec. 2022. No gates or deactivated roads. Directions from Cassy's Coffee House in Youbou. Travel 24.6km west along North Shore Road and turn right onto Nitinat Main. After 4.1km, turn left onto NT2. Cross the bridge at 1.1km and stay left at the fork at 1.3km. Stay left at the fork at 2.3km. Stay right at the fork at 7.4km. Stay left at the fork at 9.1km. At 9.7km, turn right onto the branch road. At 500m stay left at the fork. At 1.2km, stay left at the fork. At 1.9km, turn left onto the spur. Follow road until recent cutblock on both sides of the road (logged 2019). Park at a pullout and hike uphill through the cutblock to access Pipe Dream! Follow directions to Laminar Fir, tree is just downslope an across the seasonal drainage.
tree_site_notes: One of the larger hemlocks in Pipe Dream. The forest is composed almost entirely of Doug-fir and western hemlock, and the hemlock is only just starting to become dominant in portions. They have yet to reach their growth potential on this productive site.

access_notes: From the start of the Hirsch Creek Trail, just past campsite #2, walk about 10 minutes along the wide gravel trail toward Hirsch Creek.  You will find Toad on the left.
tree_site_notes: This hemlock is in a typical old growth forest with lots of dead standing cedar, spruce and hemlock, as well as decaying old logs covered with moss and lichen.  Trees of various ages are growing in the vicinity.  Devil's club is the predominant bush around tree.

access_notes: 92 km drive from Lake Cowichan along South Shore Rd. Follow signs to Park. Found along the Heaven Grove Trail
tree_site_notes: An unusually positioned western hemlock amongst the giant Sitkas.

access_notes: Follow Tahsish River to just downstream from Tahsish River/Kwois Creek confluence. (Site found in Tahsish-Kwois Provincial Park on Vancouver Island)
tree_site_notes: Level alluvial site. CWHvh1.

access_notes: On bench on steep hill north of Fairy Lake and east of Fairy Creek. Access is very poor, perhaps best option is driving to 1km on Fairy Rd, taking old forestry road to the edge of mature timber than hiking straight up hill.
tree_site_notes: Largest in a grove of 20-30 very large (1 metre plus DBH) hemlocks on the toe edge of a bench.

access_notes: Drive West from Campbell River. Hike in from Gold River Highway along Elk River Trail.
Highway 4
tree_site_notes: Situated near not too well worn, short loop trail that is intentionally leading to the Canoe Creek Cedar beside the Kennedy River.

access_notes: On bench on steep hill north of Fairy Lake and east of Fairy Creek. Access is very poor, perhaps best option is driving to 1km on Fairy Rd, taking old forestry road to the edge of mature timber than hiking straight up hill.
tree_site_notes: On steep toe concave toe slope only a few metres above a depression with seasonal non-creek drainage.

access_notes: Follow Tsitika FSR from Highway 19 to near  10.5 km marker. Tree is located below the road.
tree_site_notes: Heavily pounded elk print ground all around base of tree.

access_notes: Starting at the Coho Flats trail, hike approximately 45 minutes to the junction of Fisherman's Trail.   Turn left (or south) and follow trail along the Kitimat River for appxoimately 35 minutes.  Jonny's western hemlock is on the right about a meter from the trail.  There's trail marker nailed to the tree hence its name.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry.   Jonny's western hemlock is located near a small but  magnificent stand of ancient western red cedar, amabalis fir, western hemlock and Sitka spruce trees.  Lots of nurse logs and fallen giants litter the ground with some young trees growing  under the dense canopy.  This high flood bank is at the bottom of a slope with wetlands paralling the trail.  In the vicinty of Jonny's western hemlock there are sparce devil's club, red alder, elderberry and maple in the shrub layer with ferns and foam flowers in the herb layer.

access_notes: From Sechelt, head west towards Halfmoon Bay on highway 101. Turn north onto Halfmoon-Carlson FSR just after Trout Lake. Follow this road all the way up to Spipiyus Provincial Park and park around 49.64974, -123.89742. This requires 4x4 with clearance and good tires.  It should also be noted that accessing this forest requires both good fitness and considerable experience in negotiating/bushwhacking rough terrain.
tree_site_notes: Typical of larger western hemlocks found at elevations of over 600 metres, this is a very healthy tree and not currently affected by pathogens. The outlook for its future survival is very good.

access_notes: From Kitimat City Centre Intersection on Haisla Blvd, drive 9.6 km and turn right on Bish Creek FSR and proceed for 10 km. Turn right up rougher older FSR and drive 3.8 km up the Bish Valley. Hike about 20 meters to left, down toward Bish Creek to find the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree stands on a slope right beside the FSR in a mixed western hemlock and amabilis fir forest with a deep decaying moss level.  Widely spaced trees of mixed ages and loosely spaced shrubs including blueberry, ferns and various patches of groundcovers.

access_notes: Montizambert Creek located in Cypress Provincial Park.

Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44. Tree is within falling boundary.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a broken top that may have been subject to a recent lightning strike.

access_notes: Starting at the Coho Flats trail, hike approximately 45 minutes to the junction of Fisherman's Trail.   Turn left (or south) and follow trail along the Kitimat River for appxoimately 30 minutes.  The Marker western hemlock is on the right about a meter from the trail.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry.   The Marker western hemlock is located near a small but  magnificent stand of ancient western red cedar, amabalis fir, western hemlock and Sitka spruce trees.  Lots of nurse logs and fallen giants litter the ground with some young trees growing  under the dense canopy.  This high flood bank is at the bottom of a slope with wetlands paralling the trail.  In the vicinty of the Marker western hemlock there are sparce devil's club, red alder, elderberry and maple in the shrub layer with ferns and foam flowers in the herb layer.

access_notes: At 21km on Woss Road from Gold River, south side of road.
tree_site_notes: A small tract of substantial old growth has been left above the Muchalat River.

access_notes: Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44. Tree is near proposed logging road.
tree_site_notes: The tree is healthy, growing on a 30-40% slope in a stand of other large mountain hemlocks.

access_notes: Turn off Hwy #101 heading North on the Sechelt-Roberts FSR 7472.02. Drive to intersection with Dakota Creek FSR 7575 Br.01.  Drive to proposed BCTS TFL A79517-DK42.  Follow road center line uphill into DK44.
tree_site_notes: The tree is growing in a stand with other mountain hemlocks on top of a ridge on a North facing slope.

access_notes: Starting at the Kitimat River Pumphouses, walk downstream along Joe's Trail for about 17minutes.  This western hemlock  is right along the edge of the trail in a dark clearing with little growth around it..  It is growing on a nurse log.
tree_site_notes: This hemlock is surrounded by large Sitka spruce trees and seems diminutive in comparison.  The roots have formed large buttresses over a nurse log and so the POG is adjusted accordingly.  Very little is growing around the tree due to the shade from a large group of Sitka spruce in its vicinity.  Recent flooding has left a film of fine silt around the base of the nurse log.

access_notes: Travel towards Lake Cowichan along Pacific Marine from Port Renfrew. Go past Fairy Lake and then turn left on to the Granite Main logging road just after you cross Renfrew Creek. Drive 7 km up Granite Main, take the second left turn off of Granite Main onto Granite 6000. Continue across the creek then take the first left onto G6101, follow the road until it dead ends on a newly built logging road. From the end of the logging road head north along the ridge line towards the GPS point, the tree will be on the north slope just below the Ridgeline.
tree_site_notes: The tree is very large in diameter and has a broken top approximately 25 m up it’s trunk. The tree is living with one larger reiteration and several branches.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive east on Highway 28 for 7 km to Saunders Main. Turn left onto Saunders Main and drive for 4.9 km. Road has several tight manauvers requiring a narrower vehicle with four wheel drive. Hike uphill into forest navigating to tree.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock and amabilis fir dominated forest. Forest is sloping towards Saunders Creek. Understory contains deer fern, step moss, five-leaved bramble, and red huckleberry.

access_notes: From Gold River, drive east on Highway 28 for 7 km to Saunders Main. Turn left onto Saunders Main and drive for 4.9 km. Road has several tight manauvers requiring a narrower vehicle with four wheel drive. Hike uphill into forest navigating to tree.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock and amabilis fir dominated forest. Forest is sloping towards Saunders Creek. Understory contains deer fern, step moss, five-leaved bramble, and red huckleberry.

access_notes: The small settlement of Ferguson is accessed from Highway 31 near Trout Lake. The gravel road climbs up beside the Lardeau River where you will come to a wye, turn right onto the Alpha FSR and drive about 500 m, where on the right a myriad of trails lead down towards the river. The big hemlock is hiding down in the wetness with a bunch of spruce and cedars.
tree_site_notes: There are quite a few big hemlocks lurking in this forest. This particular tree was the largest found and over 400 years old.

access_notes: The Below the Gods Trail is accessed in the Smallwood Creek area. Turn off of Highway 3a onto Beasley Road, then make the first quick right onto Queen Victoria St. This road transitions into the Smallwood FSR. There are too many junctions to describe, so utilize Trailforks to find this trail.
tree_site_notes: Having been given a tip about the big trees along this trail, the mixture of cedar and hemlock is a common site in this region. The presence of sub-surface water where this big hemlock is growing, has obviously had a positive influence on its growth. This is a Skookum tree.

access_notes: Davis Creek Trail is accessed from Highway 31 to the north of Kaslo, near the village of Lardeau. The Provincial Park campground is a good place to park your vehicle, and then begin the steep climb up to the Rim. The forest changes to Larch, then into a cedar/hemlock as the ground flattens out a bit. Water does not seem to know where to run, and the ground is wet everywhere. The trail ends at Fishhook Lake, with big trees to be found all around.
tree_site_notes: This mighty hemlock was very close to the trail, with a lot of the trees having been given appreciative names. This guy is “Hemi”

access_notes: Travel Akokalyx FSR to 12.5 km then turn south on Crawford FSR. 4 km on south side of road at small pullout. walk in 50m. Cutblock boundary nearby.
tree_site_notes: Slanted 15%, broken top, Twisted branches looks like mistletoe. In lush bench area above near Akokalyx river N side. Many moderately large cedar approx between 1 and 1.75 m. Low growing devils club.  Very open and park like.

access_notes: From Highway 3 when travelling west from Creston, and right before the yellow avalanche closure gate is a large pull-out parking area on your left, where some unobtrusive trail signs are attached to the trees. Situated quite high up on the trees so as to not disappear as the snow pack gets deeper. A trail heads down to where it crosses Summit Creek, and then a loop configuration allows you to chose your direction on the 1.3 km route. I like to walk it both ways, as new delights are revealed every time.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlocks of this enormity are not that common, generally succumbing to old age, rot, blowdown, or casual chainsaw death. The sheltered high elevation environment seems well suited for this big tree. This is the biggest tree found in this grove, but there are likely some larger ones to be found if getting off trail is your thing.

access_notes: Drive to end of road at Clearwater Lake. Trailhead is at the very last campground and is not very well marked.

Very High Trail - Giveout Creek FSR. Drive up (way up) Giveout Creek FSR from Highway 16 for approximately 14 km to where the top of the Morning Mountain Trails come up to connect with the road. There is a parking area and trail map kiosk here. Follow the Fairly High Trail back down for about 500 m to the junction with Very High Trail. Walk up the 2.6 km trail for about 2 km. where the Dreadlock Hemlock is visible not too far off of the trail. It is the largest tree in this area, so you should know when you see it.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: From the Island Lake Road, the first road after the lower parking lot heading up towards the Hydro right of way (yellow gate) leads to where it crosses the Lazy Lizard Trail. The tree is not too far into the forest on the left, just above this crossing.
Long drive from Williams Lake past Keithley Creek / Caribou Lake to 3100 FSR.
tree_site_notes: Located above road  in an isolated area of cedar hemlock.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow signage to Cabin Trail. Venturing off trail onto a game trail overlooking Hunter Bowl.
tree_site_notes: Western hemlock make rare appearances in the East Kootenay, while not exceptionally large, it makes this discovery worthy of recognition.

access_notes:
From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak.                  the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak. 

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.
tree_site_notes: Found in a hemlock forest in the ICH BEC zone with little understory vegetation.

access_notes: From Kimberley take St. Marys Lake Road out past Riverside Campground and continue past St Marys Lake. Stay right at Redding Cr and right again at 49.5km on Dewar Cr FSR. Continue to 58km. We parked by a large pile of rocks and walked back on the road 50m. The tree is up slope from here, about 80m.
tree_site_notes: This one of a kind tree is actually two trees stuck together up to 3m. One side is broken at 35m. The taller side is dead at 35+m. It is nestled amongst 80-100cm old growth cedar/hemlock/spruce trees that look small in comparison! It is in a planned cutblock, just below a proposed road and adjacent to an old growth deferral area.  This block is currently on hold.

access_notes: Midway between Bridesville and Rock Creek on the connector.   South of Johnstone Creek PP, 1 km north of US border.
tree_site_notes: Ancient, lightning blackened top, large bole to about 100'.

access_notes: To locate this site on the Lizard Range, drive right on through the campsite on Mount Fernie Park Road, until you reach a trailhead kiosk on the left, where an obvious aluminum bridge crosses Lizard Creek. Immediately after exiting from the bridge turn left onto the signed “Gorby Trail”. This is actually an old road that leads up into the lower basin of Cedar Bowl. Upon arrival in the big basin, take the road to right, Red Tree Road, and follow it for about 500 m. where the Snakebite Trail ushers you into the forest on your right.
tree_site_notes:
Many fire survived veteran Western Larch spire up from the Western Red Cedar forest on the lower slopes of the Lizard Range. The difficulty field locating them, in the absence of a trail, is the thick alder, buckbrush, and devil's club choked underbrush that presents the challenge. The larch tree sampled was right beside the Snakebite Mountain Bike Trail, so can be located a bit more easily.
This stand of trees appears very healthy, likely, with todays fire suppression prioratization in proximity to an urban area, could live another 500 years? Age estimate from annular ring count of a "cookie" of a similar diameter tree in close proximity is 425 years.

access_notes: Wally’s Follies is an obscure ski run at Fernie Alpine Resort. It is most easily accessed in the winter when skiing. If interested in visiting this site in summer, the easiest approach would be to walk up Gorby Trail from the Mt Fernie Provincial Park to where it meets Red Tree Road. Follow the road to the right until you come to the Snakebite Trail (also many big larches) sign on the right, but turn left and head up into the bush where an assortment of very large larch and cedar trees are gathered.
tree_site_notes: A western larch tree of this height stands out above the surrounding forest canopy. I was looking for a big cedar, which I found, but was pleasantly surprised to come across this old larch, with its battle scarred base and stout trunk, it was a very nice sight.
Very healthy with small dead top.

access_notes: The Big Larch Trail is accessed from a roadside pull-out that is on the right a few km north of Hills on Highway 6. A signed trailhead directs you up a de-commissioned logging road. At the 3rd switchback an old skid trail heads off to the south, where you will cross a small creek. The big larches are just above on the edge of a fairly recently logged area.
tree_site_notes: Wow!, what a tree. A friend of mine from Rosebery sent me a photo of himself under a big larch. He said it was over 5 ‘ in diameter. While not quite making that size, this is an outstanding trees as the photos reveal.

access_notes: From Jaffray or Elko drive down to Kikomun Creek Prov. Park.  Take Teepee Cr Rd. west across Koocanusa Lake, past the campground/boat access. Then head south on Caven Cr FSR (starting at 15.5 km).  At 32.5 km turn left onto Bloom FSR, at 42.5 turn right onto Middle Bloom and park just past the 45 km sign.  It is a short hike down to the creek through ~50 yr old Lodgepole pine second growth.
tree_site_notes:
This tree has some scorch at the bottom, but is otherwise quite intact.  Remnants of a whorl of large branches is evident at about 6m up.  Two other larch trees are within 5-6m of this one, forming quite a trio!  The two largest of the three are within 5m of a tributary to Bloom Creek.  The other large larch (128cm DBH) is leaning downstream and would be close to 55m if growing straight up. The smaller (~1m) larch has a broken top, totald height is about 35m.  Another large larch lies toppled over the creek, making a natural bridge just upstream.
A proposed bridge location and road centre line is marked out about 20m upstream and upslope from the two closer trees of the trio.  
The surrounding riparian area contains a range of species - spruce, balsam, cedar, hemlock and Douglas fir but all the largest trees are western larch up and down the creek for about 100m, with large live trees, short and tall snags, and down trees. Most of these larch are in the 80cm diam range.

access_notes:
From Kimberley : Take Hwy 95A towards Cranbrook. Turn R onto St Mary's Lake Rd. Turn L onto Lakeside Rd and continue onto Hellroaring FSR. Keep R at first fork, then stay L on Hellroaring FSR (do NOT go onto Meachen FSR). You will cross Hellroaring Creek over a bridge.TThe tree is 50m back from the 9km marker and roughly 4km past the 31km marker. The boulderfield will be on your L, the last km marker I remember seeing was for 30km up. If you cross a 2nd bridge, you have gone too far (but there is a good turnaround spot there). The biggest larch is within 20m of the road. The others can be located by scrambling around the boulderfield. 
From Cranbrook: Take Hwy 95A towards Kimberley. Continue through Marysville. Turn L onto St Mary's Lake Rd; the rest is the same as above.
tree_site_notes: Minimal lower stem damage/decay, but displays signs of larger branch and top breakage characteristic of larger larches. The largest larch was located at the toe of a scree slope, NW aspect.  Growing all around the edges scree slope were similarly large larches: 26 trees measured were >3m and 4 were >4m. Many of the trees, especially those on the southeast (top of the slope) side of the scree slope bore fire scars and charring suggestive that they survived a fire decades ago.  Height to live crown 8m, ht to broken top 39m, branches ascend upward a few meters. Woodpecker holes on bottom 2 m.
Healthy, dead top, seed tree in old clearcut.

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch and Moe's Canyon Trail goes north through the patch past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and continues north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #1 is just east of the trail, about 60m north of the Magic line junction.  This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a one ha patch of old growth of western larch/Douglas-fir/spruce growing in a flat area right at the south end of Moe's Canyon.  Logging occured in 2006 to the south and east of this patch and elsewhere within the Kimberley Nordic Trails area.  The patch contains at least 13 large trees over 100 cm DBH and eight of these trees are over 50m in height.  All the largest trees are western larch but there are two Douglas-fir trees scoring over 300 points.  This is the highest ranking tree found based on height, circumference and crown size.   The smaller mature western larch trees at the periphery of this area are well over 400 years old so this tree could be in the 600 - 800 yr range.

access_notes: Gilnockie Provincial Park and Ecological Reserve are a long ways from anywhere. Located close to the US border between Grasmere and Yahk, this 100 km section of wilderness (minus all the logging blocks) is accessed from Caven Creek FSR, Bloom Creek FSR, and Ward Creek FSR. Gilnockie Creek is best accessed by driving 2.3 km west of the Yahk River bridge, and then bushwhacking down to the creek along the edge of a clearcut. Many superb larch specimens reside along the creek.
tree_site_notes: Not often a grouping of veteran western larches is encountered. This assembly of massive trees residing on a bench above Gilnockie Creek supports quite a display of greatness. The larch is an amazing 517 years old.

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch and Moe's Canyon Trail goes north through the patch past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and continues north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #1 is just east of the trail, about 60m north of the Magic line junction.  Moe's #3 is 35m further, 15m east of the trail. This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree has a small burn scar at the base, a large burl at 18m, broken top at 39m and a Y-shaped live top.  This would be the highest ranking tree in this area if not for the broken top. It does have the largest circumference and crown size, and the most majestic look overall.

access_notes: Giveout Creek FSR is located above and to the south of Nelson where a right turn just past the Waldorf School turn-off leads up and up for about 8 km. The Bear’s Den trail is best referenced on Trailforks to locate where to head up.
tree_site_notes: In awe about the big cedars and hemlocks that have man-made biking structures winding up and over some wild terrain, these big larches could go by un-noticed. The tree is over 400 years old, and it appears that it will be around for a long time yet.

access_notes: Visible from the Island Lake Road, a heavy bushwhack into the Lizard Range jungle will afford you much pleasure when arriving at this tree.
Drive north from Rossland on Highway 3B to Biathlon Trailhead. Mxi?p Xewílh (Cedar Trail) begins on opposite side of highway.

Horse Barn Valley Interpretive Forest. Driving Directions:   High-ground-clearance vehicle is recommended. From the Kimberley Riverside Campground and RV Resort it is 8.9 kilometres to the parking area. From the campground, drive west on the paved St. Mary Lake Road for 4.1 km. Turn right on the Matthew Creek Forestry Road and just before the 2km sign turn right again on a narrower, rougher gravel road marked with a HBV signpost. After about 1.5km veer left then right to keep climbing to the parking area and kiosks.   The Western Larch tree is a short walk from the kiosk in on Talus Trail. Cross a small bridge, then a board walk and 50m along the larch is on your left, at a small Queen's Cup interpretive sign.
tree_site_notes: The tree is located in the Horse Barn Valley Interpretive Forest which is managed by the Kimberley Nature Park Society. This tree has scorched bark and a scar running 8m up the top side of the tree.  It has a large fork at 16m and a broken top/fork at 40m. It is growing on a steep sidehill and is leaning almost over the trail. This tree is just North of a nice patch of old growth cedar.

access_notes: Fish L./ Caven Cr. FSR. Cross the Koocanusa Reservoir on the Kikomun Bridge, at 15.5 km marker turn left onto Caven FSR, at 37.5 km marker turn right. Set odometer to 0, 0.8 km turn left, 1.6 km turn left again. Tree is in open forest near the guiding outfitters.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top. Tree estimated to be 430 years old (Terry Nelson).

access_notes: Drive up Gerry Sorensen Way, past Kimberley Alpine Resort and continue until the road becomes North Star Drive. The Nordic Club is at the end of North Star Drive.  Take any of the fun trails around to the south end of the Centennial loop to Iker's landing.  Then take Landsem south.  About half way along Landsem look for a smaller trail marked Moe's Canyon/Magic Line.  Follow this steep up to the top of hill.  You are now looking north at the old growth larch patch.  Magic line cuts right, to the east of the patch.  Moe's Canyon Trail goes north past the largest trees and continues past the Mussers Plateau Trail junction and north into Moe's Canyon.  Moe's #2 is 20m west of the trail, about 50m NNW of the Magic line junction.  From this junction look for a tall dead top, it belongs to a mostly dead western larch, about 20m west of our tree.  This and the other tallest trees in Moes are also visible from the south end of Larch Loop Trail.  Moes #1, Moes #2 and the dead top larch are also visible from around the first switchback on Musser's trail.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a one ha patch of old growth western larch/douglas fir/spruce growing in a flat area right at the south end of Moe's Canyon.  Logging occured in 2006 to the south and east of this patch and elsewhere within the Kimberley Nordic Trails area.  This tree is easily missed since it is west of the trail by 20m, just north of the more open logged area.  This tree has a deep, 2m fire scar at the base but otherwise seems to be in great condition.

access_notes: I drove straight up Lumberton to the 3 km mark, where the road meets up with a KVR right of way.  A little farther there is a big quarry on both sides of the road and a brown BC rec site marker.  I turned right at this marker and followed the road through big piles of large rocks then stayed right about 500m along then headed uphill, past the Palmer Bar Rec Site and across a bridge.  That left turn was at about 2km from the quarry, just before a Y junction.  I didn’t drive all the way up that last road, but if you can it’s a quick 5-10 min walk along the trail/creek to the trees, just past a rocky slope on the west side of the creek.
tree_site_notes: 4m from creek. Dead top 3m. There are about 5 trees at the north end of the patch between 85 and 95cm.  And one about 110cm DBH/30m tall with a broken top uphill.

access_notes: Old Growth Trail - Strawberry Pass.  Drive north from Rossland on Highway 3B to Seven Summits trailhead. Follow signage to Alzheimer's Junction, then a further 0.5 km to Cedar Grove Junction.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top.

access_notes: I drove straight up Lumberton to the 3 km mark, where the road meets up with a KVR right of way.  A little farther there is a big quarry on both sides of the road and a brown BC rec site marker.  I turned right at this marker and followed the road through big piles of large rocks then stayed right about 500m along then headed uphill, past the Palmer Bar Rec Site and across a bridge.  That left turn was at about 2km from the quarry, just before a Y junction.  I didn’t drive all the way up that last road, but if you can it’s a quick 5-10 min walk along the trail/creek to the trees, just past a rocky slope on the west side of the creek.
tree_site_notes: Dead Top 1.5m,  leaning, small  burn scar.  There are about 5 trees at the north end of the patch between 85 and 95cm.  And one about 110cm DBH/30m tall with a broken top uphill.

access_notes: From the Kimberley Riverside Campground take the Campground Trail up to Jimmy Russel Road. Follow it up and turn right on Duck Pond Trail. Follow Duck Pond up to junction with Skid Road Trail. The western larch is about 200m N-NW from this point, about 50m up from the base of the hill.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a large fire scar and a 4m dead top. Fairly large gnarly branches and burls give it an ancient look. Needles have piled up at the base of the tree since the last fire, forming a thick layer. An 80cm/36m Douglas-fir is just 5m up the slope.  The tree in is a Williamson's Sapsucker (WISA) Wildlife Habitat Area within Kimberley Nature Park. Critical WISA habitat includes large wildlife trees like this western larch as suitable nest trees, large snags and downed wood for ant foraging and mid-sized Douglas-fir for sap wells. The WHA is being treated for fuels - small trees and ladder fuel removal will hopefully protect the WISA habitat over time.  The tree was discovered by the Wildsight Youth Climate Corps crew.

access_notes: The Mud Lake Nordic Area is accessed from Highway #3, near the Blueberry Paulson Summit. The tree is located beside the Ridge Trail which is accessed from the Old Growth Trail

From the east end of Grand Forks, B.C. proceed north on Granby Road approx. 23km to the POC of the Miller Cr. FSR on the right (east) side.  Proceed on the Miller Cr. FSR approx. 8.2km to the Cameron Cr. bridge.  Park here and walk approx 800m on the Miller Cr. FSR to the tree on the left (west) side of the road.
tree_site_notes:
Aspect - SW, slope 14%.  Tagged as a "Wildlife tree. Tree had a dead top in 2016, which has since broken off. Though bark is intact, tree shows signs of woodpecker damage near the base. Approx. 50% of remaining branches have green needles.
Tree is located at the bottom of Miller Cr. FSR fill-slope, adjacent to logged block

access_notes: Access is from the North end of Cheewhat Lake. Please be aware that this is a trail-less wilderness area. Access to this and other areas on the West side of the Lake require strong prepared parties who are experienced at navigating  very challenging forested terrain. Only recommended to those who are familiar with this particular region. Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal. This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, top up your fuel and bring a full sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes: The Darkside Cedar is a dark and robust. It is potentially comprised of two separate trees growing close together. It stands with a lean near the South West corner of Chewhat Lake. The Darkside Cedar is a dark and robust and suspected to be two separate trees growing close together. It stands with a lean near the South West corner of Cheewhat Lake.  It is located in a rather densely vegetated area, on a low angled slope, in the SW area of Cheewhat Lake.  The Cheewhat Lake area is a well known hotspot for western red cedar including some of Canada's largest known specimens.  Located near the Eastern boundary of the Pacific Rim NP and 10 km from the Pacific Coast, this wilderness area sees abundant precipitation and little natural disturbance, allowing for grand and ancient forest stands to persist. The region has been inhabited by various members of the Nuu-Chah-nulth Clan for centuries and contains many CMT's (culturally modified trees) and other archaeological sites.

access_notes: From Rossander Main, take the right hand fork at 48.721251,-124.732298, a few km before Cheewhat Lake.  After a couple of hundred metres, find a safe place to park and continue on foot on the road, across the creek and through the gate (approx. 48.7261631, -124.7408409).  Continue along the road for another couple of hundred meters until you reach a split in the road (48.7277770, -124.7464745) and head left, along the lake.  Follow for a hundred meters and find a place to break into the dense forest from the road (at approximately 48.726271, -124.747923) and head down the mild slope for another hundred meters or so.  After some tight wriggling through the forest, you will find the tree at 40.725319, -124747376.  After enjoying this broken-hearted giant, you may want to visit the beautiful cedar at 48.7242987, -124.750226.  Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and courteous to other road users.  It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.  This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly.  Input your coordinates before you leave home.  In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, top up your fuel and bring a full sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes: There are two trunks where one of the them is barely clinging on to life.  The Giants stands on a low angled slope, in a narrow margin of densely vegetated old growth forest between Doobah Lake and the logging road.  Doobah Lake is directly adjacent to the better known Cheewhat Lake area.  Although it undoubtedly hosted many grand specimens of red cedar it has been heavily logged over the last 30 years or so. Over the last four years a new logging venture has been rapidly consuming much of the remaining old growth forest on Western side of Doobah lake and along the adjoining Oyees lake.  A wonderful lakeside cedar grove and numerous CMT's (culturally modified trees) have been destroyed or degraded by these recent logging activities.

access_notes: 40 km south on pavement in the Chilliwack River Valley, then 10 km gravel along Chiliwack Lake to Depot Creek trailhead. 3 km hike into the old growth.
From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Centennial Trail west for short distance, tree is right in the middle of the trail. Can't miss it.
tree_site_notes: Really cool tree with seven leaders. Lots of dead lower branches but crown seems healthy.

access_notes:
For good access directions to this tree, see "Vancouver Island Big Trees"  http://vancouverislandbigtrees.blogspot.ca/2010/06/directions-to-cheewhat-lake-cedar-trail.html.
The GPS co-ordinates for the trail head leading to tree #89 and #84 are 48.69273, -124.73593.
tree_site_notes:
In coastal rain forest, and in dense salal-huckleberry 30' high brush, about 1 km from a mainline road, and among many other very large cedars. Aspect west, slope 40-50%, upper mesoslope, convex.  

In 2006 the tree was observed to be very healthy with cambium intact for about 90% of the circumference - even the small scar where it is absent does not extend very far up the trunk. Above 40' the trunk breaks up into multiple stems.

access_notes: North of Cheewhat Lake.  From Rosander Mainline, follow roads T23 and T23B past Doobah Lake to near Park boundary. Rough trail leads to Cheewhat Lake.  The GPS co-ordinates for the trail head are 48.70175, -124.75104.  Tree is near Park boundary, west of the trail and visible from Road T23B.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top.  South aspect, 30% slope, upper slope, convex.

access_notes: East of Cheewhat Lake. From Rosander Mainline, follow cat track and backspar trail along west side of 1987 clearcut (Park boundary). Rough trail through blowdown and forest leads to tree, 45 minutes from road. The GPS co-ordinates for the trail head leading to tree #89 and #84 are 48.69273, -124.73593.
tree_site_notes: In a coastal rain forest, in dense salal-huclkeberry 30' high brush, about 1 km from a mainline road, and among many other very large cadars. Aspect west, slope 40-50%, upper mesoslope, convex.

access_notes: Follow Great Cedar Trail clockwise from wharf near Morpheus Island to the tree marked "Hanging Garden Tree".
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy and carries a large crown. The lower trunk is festooned with burls and hemlock seedlings, and above, a massive fluted trunk supports a large head of reiterated trunks, many of which are dead, a characteristic of old red cedars.

access_notes:
From the small town of Youbou, on the Eastern end of Lake Cowichan, head Westward on the North Shore Road,
continuing all the way past the lake on Cowichan Main and eventually following the Nitinat River.
Turn right at T-Intersection ( 48.8627379, -124.6438995 ) over the bridge which crosses Nitinat River, following
Carmanah Main. A visit to the waterfalls on the Little Nitinat Falls is recommended for a quick break (unmarked pull
off near 48.871476, -124.687404 ).
Follow Carmanah Main until a bridge on your left crosses the Little Nitinat River onto Flora Main ( 48.8994754,
-124.6887141 ).
Follow Flora until you reach Upper Klanawa Main ( 48.861963, -124.739748 ) and turn left.
Not long after passing Newstead Main (do not take this road), the road starts climbing and splits.
Take the left spur K-265, up a steep pitch and around a tight bend ( 48.8267934, -124.7812745 ).
After some time, along the South side of K-265 there are a couple of small lakes accessed via a short spur (approx
48.8274633, -1248130282 ), this is where you can access the Fairy Bell Cedar at Dorothy Lake (at the head of the
more westward lake, 48.825688, -124.822826 ).
Please be advised that this is an ACTIVE logging area, follow suitably safe driving techniques and be vigilant and
courteous to other road users. It is advised to only visit this area on weekends when logging activities are minimal.
This is a remote area without cellular reception so plan your trip accordingly. Input your coordinates before you leave
home. In general the gravel road driving is reasonable for most vehicles, but fill your tank and definitely bring a full
sized spare tire along for this trip.
tree_site_notes:
- The Fairy Bell Cedar appears healthy, shows typical conical form and has two main leaders which are bare
at the tip and a smaller third leader.
-The Tree is located on a flat drainage area which flows to the head of nearby Dorothy Lake, at the edge of
a recent Cutblock between this and another small lake. These lakes drain into the Klanawa River,
1 km to the west. A fine old Sitka spruce tree stands about 50m to the South West of Fairy Bell.
-Although currently this area has been and is still being aggressively logged, numerous fine and large
specimens of Sitka spruce, Western Red cedar and even occasional Douglas fir still stand in the Klanawa
River Valley System. For more detailed information about the trees of this region visit the Vancouver Island
Prominent Tree Survey, a project hosted by the coastaltrailcollective.com

access_notes: The location is being kept private at the request of the Ahousaht First Nation.
tree_site_notes: This giant cedar is the most mind-blowing tree I’ve come across in nearly two decades of big tree hunting. Unlike most other trees, its trunk gets wider going upwards, culminating in a sprawling fortress-like crown of wooden spires akin to a massive wooden wall of an ancient castle. This giant could possibly have the largest or near largest wood volume of any tree in Canada for about the first 50 ft of its trunk - the part you see from the ground. This would make it, experientially, perhaps the most impressive tree in Canada, despite other cedars being taller or ranking higher overall. Coming across this tree has been the highlight of my life-long search for ancient giants. No logging plans exist for the area and thankfully, due to the incredible Land Use Vision from the Ahousaht First Nation, 80% of the old-growth in their territory, including where this tree is found, will be protected through a series of provincial conservancies to be legistlated by the province.

access_notes: From the Pacific Rim Highway, turn onto Alaska Pine Road, and eventually take a turn onto Kennedy River Road. Continue until you reach the coordinates 49.09218° N, 125.68949° W, where you’ll stop. From there, follow the old logging road until you near the transition to old-growth forest. After passing through the second-growth area, it’s a challenging bushwhack to a trio of exceptionally large trees. The largest of these is the "Dark Horse," and the second-largest is also a tree with a 5-meter width. The bushwhack is difficult, with dense brush, creeks to navigate, and no established trails.
tree_site_notes: The tree is exceptionally large. It grows in a grove alongside two other massive trees, one with a trunk 5 meters wide and another 4 meters wide. These giants thrive on a relatively flat bench just above the Kootowis River. The monarch of the grove appears ancient and complex, with a solid bole and doesn’t taper quickly. Its crown is especially striking, featuring a highly developed, intricate candelabra-like top. Despite its apparent age, the tree is remarkably healthy, with numerous living branches and abundant foliage. The tree retains a substantial amount of living cambium, and while it has a large scar that opens into a significant hollow extending upwards, it remains robust. Surrounding the tree is a massive detritus mound, hosting numerous epiphytes. Additionally, the base of the tree features prominent burls, further adding to its grandeur and uniqueness.

access_notes: Drive from Port Renfrew or Cowichan lake to the bridge in the central walbran valley (direction can be found on friends of Carmanah Walbran website).  From the bridge, follow signs and a walking trail to the castle giant, continue past the castle giant 50m to the fork for a loop trail, which gains 200m of elevation to a bench where the grove perches.  There are 4 massive trees in the grove, this one is the farthest east, and notably the largest.
tree_site_notes: The tree is large and gnarly, with an open fisher big enough to sit in at the base.  The tree is ancient in appearance, but it seems in good health.

access_notes: Drive to the unprotected Central Walbran Valley. From there, follow signage and trails to the Castle Grove and the Castle Giant Tree.
tree_site_notes: One of the most famous and reconizable cedars in the Walbran Valley. An absolutely giant. Used to be home to a canopy research station as well.

A castle-like cedar of epic proportions. It's wide base and multi-spired crown are a wonder to behold! It grows on a little hummock that must of provided a bit of relief from the wetter/scrubbier environment that surrounds it. Other giants can be found in this grove but this one, the biggest, grew in a place that I did not expect to find much!

access_notes: Park at 49.092207, -125.689604. From there, hike along an overgrown road towards the GPS pin for the tree. As the old road dissappears, it's best to bushwack the last stretch through the second-growth to your right. Access is best suited for those with strong hiking/route finding abilities.
tree_site_notes: A tree of epic proportions. A true goliath. Ian nearly fainted when he first saw this tree. This is one of the best cedar groves we've ever come across.
CWHvh1 10

access_notes: Park on Rosander Main and follow alder-covered road into the woods. The Doobah Giant will be on your left after about 5 minutes of walking. Can't miss it!
tree_site_notes: This is one of the grandest cedar trees I know of. It looks gigantic from all sides and has an incredible triple spire crown. I first visited this tree in 2009 with Ken Wu. About time it was entered into the registry!

access_notes: NEW Access Notes: Proceed north from Campbell River on Hwy 19 for 75 km.Turn left at the Sayward junction onto Sayward Rd, then immediately right onto Dyer Rd., for 500 m, then left onto Salmon River Main for approximately 500m, then turn right onto WR Main for approximately 20 km. Turn right and cross Victoria Bridge over the White River. Immediately turn right after bridge crossing and proceed north for 1.5 km. Then turn left onto WR307 or 0.5 km. Park at second overgrown spur road on the right past quarry and walk from here. Approximately 700m to end of spur then another 150m west to tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a candelabra top with one main stem and 4 side stems.  One of the side stems as 5 m of dead top.  The tree is on the face of a western hemlock and Douglas-fir plantation.

A massive redcedar with unique burls and branches standing in an open, almost park-like area. Not too hard to get too from the lakeshore once you've paddled over. The tree was originally pictured in some of Maywell's old film photos from around Cheewhat Lake. If you visit one tree on this side of the lake, make it this one!

access_notes: The tree is located 300 meters NW from the Henderson Lake Fish Hatchery, located at the north end of Henderson Lake (see access map).  At the Henderson Lake Lodge, you can find a new access trail to the tree (10 minute hike).
tree_site_notes: Tree is located in an old-growth forest on an old flood plain. Thick brush e.g.:  Devil Club and Alder bush, Salmon Berry makes travel awkward. The tree has a scraggly-branched top.

access_notes: From Pemberton, drive up Pemberton Meadows Road until a large gate on the Lillooet South FSR at km 2. From this gate, hike or bike up the Lillooet South FSR until you cross South Creek, and turn left onto South Creek Road which branches south off the main line immediately after the bridge. Follow South Creek Road into the South Creek valley until you come to a landslide, which has completely destroyed the road and bridge. Leave the road and hike down to the creek, and walk upriver until you come across a log crossing and the partially destroyed bridge. Use these with extreme caution and only at low water. Cross the creek to continue on South Creek Road, which now runs along the south side of the valley. Follow this road, which gets progressively more bushy, until you reach a second crossing back to the north side of the valley. This bridge is also out, but a log crossing can be found 360 metres downstream. Once you are again on the north side of South Creek, follow the road to its end. Alternatively, open areas on the last 1 kilometre of road may offer a potential helicopter landing area. Hike through clearcut and then open forest for 220 metres (170 metres from the edge of the clearcut), heading southwest, until you reach the bottom of a large avalanche path. The tree is located at the bottom of this avalanche path and its size makes it unmistakable from other large trees nearby.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears to be healthy and has long green branches and foliage which drape to the ground. There is one large burl located 182 centimetres above the ground on the southeast side of the trunk. The stem is forked once mid-height on the stem, and a second fork is present near the very top of the tree. Of these three stems, the tallest is still alive and the other two appear dead. Vertical surface-level scratches and scars in the bark on the lower trunk indicate potential wildlife use. The surrounding subalpine ecosystem is a shaded valley bottom with a southeast slope angle of 5-10 degrees and a small flattening where the tree itself stands. South Creek lies southeast of the tree, 200 metres away, and the tree itself stands at the bottom of a large avalanche path, indicated by the presence of dense slide alder and the absence of large trees. A small, seasonal creek runs near the tree. The surrounding forest has minimal understory, except for the presence of devil's club and slide alder. This forest has many other large trees of note.

Like Pokemon, 'you gotta catch em' all', and Burl'batron is a might fine specimin at that. Huge contorted burls adorn the face of this ancient cedar, a sight that only a mother, or big tree hunter, could love.
A monumental old-growth redcedar in the forest off the edge of a cutblock from 2017. Has a nice bear den on the side. A prime example of the amazing cedars this region would have once produced.

access_notes: From Highway 4, head north on Alaska Pine Road. Stay left past the plastic depot. Proceed through the quarry and park at the start of the overgrown spur (49.08005,-125.69452). Head left down the old road at 49.08175,-125.69929. Proceed through the second growth and enter into the old growth near the tree.
tree_site_notes: Typical high-productivity Kennedy Flats area. Area is noted by increasing topography and less dense vegetation. This is the largest of several large cedars in the area that populate an elevated bench above a small channel of Kootowis Creek. The understory is dominated by salal, with occassional willow and evergreen huckleberry. Area is flanked to the west and south by a meandering stretch of creek and to the north and east by lower productivity forest.

access_notes: Park at the gravel pullout at pole #237 along Highway 14 about 5 minutes before Loss Creek. From here you can see the large, candelabra top of the tree sticking out of the canopy off the road. Walk east (towards Sooke) a short distance along the road barrier before turning right into the second-growth.Follow the edge of the embankment on your right and look for a zig-zag path that takes you down to the enormous tree, which grows on the side of a steep slope.
tree_site_notes: Absolutley massive cedar with huge candelabra top that's visible from the road. I first stumbled upon it in 2009 and then later noticed that Randy Stoltmann may have noted it in one of his old books as well.

access_notes: Two options for access. Option 1: Follow Carmanah Mainline until below the tree. Gain 200m on the "Caycuse Grind" as you climb through the steep second growth into the steep old growth. Option 2: Walk approx. 2.6km along very overgrown deactivated road and pop down straight to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Exceptionally large mid-slope cedar growing well beyond anything in the surrounding old growth, which is primarily composed of ~30-50m tall hemlock and amabilis fir. Large, healthy crown and a very large and active bear den. Sparse deer fern understory. Currently in an unprotected forest and likely just below the legal threshold for protection (3.85m) as measured by industry standard high side DBH.

access_notes: Starting from Holberg, take San Joseph Main roughly 10km towards the coast where you will take a spur road on your left (no name known). Stay on the main spur and after a short while the tree will be up a small rise on your left. You can't miss it.
tree_site_notes:
This cedar is absolutely enormous. It's huge, riveted trunk looks like the chest of a humpback whale. A number of large limbs then burst skyward, creating healthy and bushy crown. Unfortunately, however, like Big Lonely Doug, it stands alone in a clearcut from 2019. It's likely that its health will suffer now that the forest is gone around it. After surviving for many, many centuries, only time will tell if it will make it to the end of the next one.

*There is a notable spiral cedar within viewing distance of this one and another impressive lone cedar a bit further up the road as well.

access_notes: Drive from Port Renfrew along Gordon Mainline past Avatar Grove and turn right onto Edinburgh Mainline. Stay on this road for 5-10 minutes, passing Big Lonely Doug.
