When forest appears along the edge of the road again you’ve reached Eden Grove. Keeping going past the trailhead at the Douglas-fir until you reach a wide section where you can park on the right hand side (48.641948, -124.442476). From here you need to bushwhack down to the tree. There are many other giants to be seen here too!
tree_site_notes: This tree is magnificent and very burly. It grows on the edge of a creek bank in a fairly flat and open section of Eden Grove. There are many other giant trees in the vicinity as well. This area is currently unprotected and has falling boundary and road location tape throughout the grove.

access_notes: Park at 49.092207, -125.689604. From there, hike along an overgrown road towards the GPS pin for the tree. As the old road dissappears, it's best to bushwack the last stretch through the second-growth to your right versus the old-growth on your left. Access is best suited for those with strong hiking/route finding abilities.
Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: A truly monumental cedar growing on a slope just up from the lake. Side on slope appears healthy, opposite side breaking apart and hollowing out. Transforms into three spires a short ways up!

access_notes: The location is being kept private at the request of the Ahousaht First Nation.
tree_site_notes: A superlative redcedar with many forking thorn-like branches. This tree grows a short distance from The Wall. No logging plans exist for the area and thankfully, due to the incredible Land Use Vision from the Ahousaht First Nation, 80% of the old-growth in their territory, including where this tree is found, will be protected through a series of provincial conservancies to be legistlated by the province.

access_notes: Drive to the unprotected Central Walbran Valley. From there, follow signage and trails to the Castle Grove and the Castle Giant Tree. Tree is hidden just off trail on the left about 3/4 the way through. Access is discouraged at this time.
tree_site_notes: A massive cedar wall looms in front of you as you approach this giant found by trail worker volunteers in recent times. Amazing tree!

access_notes: Kennedy Lake Rec Site
tree_site_notes: Note, "Tree Score" was calculated using a hybrid approach.  It is based on the 1999 measurements of height and crown spread made by Van Pelt, and the 2023 measurement of diameter by TJ Watt. This approach was taken as the previous diameter estimate of 5.91 m was found to be grossly overestimated. A full remeasure of this tree is planned and tree score will be recalculated.

The tree stands as the clear dominant feature within a beautiful open stand of large cedars near the edge of a small lake. While much of the surrounding area skews smaller and younger (even including some Douglas-fir and western white pine in places), this small stand is clearly buffered from disturbance. The tree itself is still exemplarly, both wider and taller than anything in the surrounding stand. The stem is straight and columnar, only splitting off high up the stem into three healthy and viourous apices. There are relatively few large burls skewing the measurement of diameter for a cedar of this size, making it even more impressive than the measurements suggest.
A beautiful cedar with a big burl growing on its side that resides at the base of a gentle slope covered with deer fern and trilliums. A place to visit in spring time and admire!

access_notes: The tree is located in a large OGMA on the east side of Loup Creek. Park on Gordon River Main just past the Loup Creek bridge and hike along the slopes until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Large cedar in an open area with extensive blowdown. Tree is surrounded by thick hemlock regen. Gentle east aspect slope with continuous hemlock/amabilis forest and the occasional large cedar.

access_notes: Follow Klawana Main along south side of River. Stay striaght instead of crossing river onto Darling Main (road is now K900). Park at overgrown spur KM950. Hike down old road until end. Short hike through cutblock into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Enormous cedar at the base of a north slope. Large strip of missing bark on north side lined with stair-step burls. Tall huckleberry and blueberry understory surrounding tree.

access_notes: A challenging bushwhack off spur road DR 400 access via Darling Main in the Klanawa Valley region.
tree_site_notes: A gigantic redcedar that really does impress. A key hole lets light through at the right time of day. You might just find yourself saying 'Oh my Darling!'

A twisting and whirling cedar of epic proportions. Its trunk and root base spirals upwards as if someone grabbed it from the top and wrung it out. It's a work of art and a wonder to behold. This grove of trees here, small as it is, contains some of the finest examples of redcedars.

access_notes: Take a boat to Cougar Annie's Garden in Hesquiaht. The tree grows off the main boardwalk to the cabin and garden. Can't miss it!
tree_site_notes: A truly spectacular cedar with many burls and forking arms. The tree grows just a short distance off the elevated boardwalk that leads through the forest from the beach to Cougar Annie's Garden. Well known by those who've been there. There are many other large cedars with fantastic shapes along the Walk of the Ancients trail nearby.
A huge burl has been cut off the tree.

access_notes: Drive to the Giant Cedar Trail on Highway 4 and then follow the short trail along Kennedy River to the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree is showing the effects of repeated visits from tourists; its roots are getting damaged by frequent foot traffic. Despite its crown breaking off at some point in the past, the tree remains impressive.

A wall of a cedar with a bear den at its base. Behind it is a giant nurse log that must have been an old friend. Beyond that, second-growth plantations begins, a stark contrast to the strip of old-growth left here.
This redcedar is covered with plants, has multiple spires, and a little hobbit hole in the bottom. Mother Earth approves!

access_notes: From Highway 4, head north on West Main. Turn onto the spur at 4.8km and continue for about 1.5km. Head south through the second growth until you reach the old growth. Stay on the east side of the creek and make your way to the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree stands in a small patch of productive old-growth along a shallow seasonal creek.  The tree is tall and vigourous, at the corner of a small raised elbow along the creek. This is the largest of several old cedars in the area, with a carpet of deer fern making for easy walking.

One of dozens of giant cedars that can be found in this remnant patch of old-growth. This grove is an example of the expansive tracks of world-class old-growth that would have once covered this region but were largely logged out from the 1950's onwards.

access_notes: Highway 19 north of Sayward, near the Adams River is an obscure turn off to the west. The tree is not too far along the FSR.
tree_site_notes: Tree is somewhat hidden, but many spired cedars are visible all around this area that a likely as grand as this tree.

access_notes: From Rosander Main, turn onto T23 then T23B. Park closest to the GPS point and bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A supremely sexy cedar. Super solid at the base with a tall trunk and big branching limbs up high that you can see when you step back. Part of a small remnant patch of old-growth left after miles of the surrounding old-growth was cut in the 1960's. Looks especially nice in the hieght of spring.

access_notes: From Nitniat crossed the Caycuse River on Carmanah Main and take an immediate right turn, continue for 100 m then turn left onto RM100A continue until you reach a split in the road, turn right onto RM110-1 and continue until you cross a bridge over the canyon, go uphill and take a right onto RM114-1 after a few switchbacks. Follow this road until you reach an old clear-cut then hike through the clear-cut towards the GPS point, you'll need to cross the creek which is precarious in places but is generally crossable.
tree_site_notes: The cedar is in a small leave tree area between two approved (but not cut) cut blocks. It looks healthy and has a large butress making it hard to measure.

access_notes: Travel down North Shore Road from Youbou. The tree is visible from the road.
tree_site_notes: The Shaw Creek Cedar is in a broad riparian bench composed of older spruce and maple forest. The tree has an impressive, conical form. A couple small pieces of bark have been cut away in the past, but the tree is otherwise in great condition.
A creek flows right through the base of this cedar, which also happens to be a great place to take a nap.

access_notes: Near Winter Harbour, take WH Main down to the old landing near the water. Park and bushwhack up into the old-growth grove on the hillside above.
tree_site_notes: A giant redcedar growing in a remnant patch of old-growth outside Winter Harbour. It had its burls cut off years ago when logging was active nearby. Other giants lurk in the woods around here.

access_notes: The tree is approximately 1 km north east of the east end of airport runway.
tree_site_notes: A residual tree left at the time of fairly extensive logging approximately 80 to 100 years ago. Tree has a spike top of approximately 50 feet that does not appear to be broken, and has some folds and cracks on the stem that would indicate some defect.

access_notes: Follow Carmanah Mainline until below the tree. Hike through the second growth and the tree is just at the edge of the old growth along a seasonal creek.
tree_site_notes: Imposing cedar growing along a seasonal creek. Beautiful sweeping stem surrounded by a wreath of sword fern. Currently unprotected.
CWHvm1 08
A beefy cedar growing on a slight ridgeline. It's a huff to get to this tough lookin' tree.

access_notes: From Rosander Main, turn onto T23 then T23B. Park closest to the GPS point and bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful redcedar with a long arm-like branch jutting out from its trunk. The branch is covered in moss and hosts a little garden of plants as well. Around the back of the tree you will find quite the big burl booty!

access_notes: Take Cowichan Main to the Nitinat Junction. Turn right onto Carmanah Mainline and cross the bridge over Nitinat River. Bushwhack into Nitinat River Provincial Park. Tree is close to rivers edge a distance in.
tree_site_notes: A wall-of-a-cedar that appears solid on one side but has an opening on the back that enters into a giant chamber with firescars inside. The floor is all sand due to past flooding from the river nearby. Very cool tree!

access_notes: South of Pt. Clements off the Q. Charlotte main to the east.
tree_site_notes: Several trunk scars, burls, etc.....typical O.G. cedar.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road, head North on Hwy 37 approximately 6 km, turn left (west side) on a narrow old logging road. There is a good place to park about 100 meters down the logging road.  Follow old logging road, staying on fork to left down a gentle hill.  At the bottom of the hill, and before a wooden bridge,  watch for a rough trail cut to the right,  Walk about 20 meters, through dense underbrush to find another ancient wester red cedar but continue on rough trail past this tree to find the largest western red cedar in the Kitimat Valley, so far!
tree_site_notes: Standing near an old oxbow wetland off the Kitimat River, in fertile ground thickly covered with willow, devil's club and berry bushes.  The dense understory leaves little room to admire this tree from a distance.  This tree has three crowns with living brnaches right to their tops.  It stands straight and has a heart shaped burl at eye level.  Looking up the stem, the branches are knarly and artisticly swirled and bowed.  Fiarly recently tree climbers have nailed two sets of railway spikes to be able to climb into the upper leve of the tree.

access_notes: Follow Klawana Main along south side of River. Stay striaght instead of crossing river onto Darling Main (road is now K900). Park at overgrown spur KM950. Hike down old road until end. Short hike through cutblock into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Mangled mess of an old cedar in a sprawling, low-productivity salal depression. 3-4 dominant stems each splitting into several tops, but all clearly from a single tree.
A castle-like Cedar with striking spires shooting skyward. This giant grows on the edge of an old cutblock in a patch of unprotected old-growth. Another giant cedar can be found closer to the road.
CWHvm1 08
CWHvm1 10
CWHvh1 04
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Just south of Campbell River.

tree_site_notes: A big old cedar with some heft to it. Marked as a leave tree in an unprotected forest at risk of being future logging.

access_notes: Into the forest to the east of the campground stands this mighty tree.
tree_site_notes: An ancient tree with many hemlock trees working to strangle it.
An impressive and solid redcedar with a big burl on its side. If this tree comes alive at night, watch out!
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 08
CWHvm1 04

access_notes: From Rosander Main, turn onto T23 then T23B. Park closest to the GPS point and bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A big cedar that's part of a small remnant patch of old-growth left after the surrounding forest was clearcut for miles in the 1960's. Looks especially nice in springtime.
A big and scraggly cedar along the west side of Cheewhat Lake.

access_notes: Tree is beside the trail on way into San Josef Bay Beach. Easy walk on well graded trail from parking lot leads through many quality old growth cedars.

Park on Nitinat Fronting just west of the intersection with Mainline Carmanah. Buchwhack through the second-growth bench upslope to a bench of old growth and onto another slope. Tree is near the top of this slope.
tree_site_notes: A conspicuous cedar on a slope of old growth hemlock scattered with moderately-large Doug-fir (CWHvm1/03). Notably the only large cedar anywhere around, on a small, somewhat poor bench with chest-high salal, in an area with an otherwise low understory of ferns and huckleberry. Large multi-stemmed top leading to a towering, healthy canopy  with dens excavated on two sides.

access_notes: The tree is located near a small tributary of the Goldstream River.  Due to the significance of the tree, ease of access, and sensitivity of the ecosystem, the specific location of this tree should remain hidden.
tree_site_notes: This relatively young and vigourous redcedar is growing on a rich floodplain near a small stream. Just to the northwest of the tree is a large pile of colluvial material at the base of a bluff. This sheltered and productive location has given it both the resources and need to grow to extreme height. Although this tree may be very near the height limit for the species, the top of the tree is still alive and it may continue to grow to even greater heights in the coming years.

access_notes: Tree is beside the trail on way into San Josef Bay Beach. Easy walk on well graded trail from parking lot leads through many quality old growth cedars.
Follow Hemmingsen Main until spur road on your left (48.67085,-124.27412). Follow spur into second growth, then down steep slope to bench along Hemmingsen Creek.
tree_site_notes: Large, healthy cedar growing along a riparian bench. Open hembal forest, with scattered large cedars. Dense understory of regen and salal.

access_notes: Heading west on Hwy 19 from the Sayward junction, travel for 40km and turn right onto Tsitika Main. Proceed for approximately 22km, and turn right onto Derby Main before Tsitika crosses the bridge. Follow for 1.2km, and pull off just past the bridge. Bushwhack upslope for approximately 80m until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree is a healthy and impressively columnar specimen within a spectacular bench of large cedars at the edge of a cutblock. There may be bigger ones further upstream, but we had limited time to explore. The site is relatively flat once you get above the road, although the vegetation can be thick. The creek carves a spectacular canyon at the edge of the stand.

access_notes: Finlayson Arm section of park, just off of the Malahat Highway
tree_site_notes: Paved trail beside tree, with protective fence to keep the visitors at bay. Skunk cabbage and fawn lilies at base of tree.
CWHvh1 04
CWHvh1 06

access_notes: From Port Renfrew, travel north towards Lake Cowichan. After crossing the Deering bridge, turn left to start down Gordon Main and proceed for 23km. Turn left onto Truck Road 10 and proceed for 5.2km. Turn left and cross the bridge over Loup Creek. Immediately turn left and follow the road until it ends after approximately 150m. Walk down the old FSR for about 2km, then bushwhack to the tree. Be aware that there are several seasonal and perennial streams that you will need to wade across while following the old FSR.
tree_site_notes: A massive, dominant cedar tree with good form and vigour, situated on a moderate slope.

access_notes: From Port Renfrew, travel north towards Lake Cowichan. After crossing the Deering bridge, turn left to start down Gordon Main and proceed for 23km. Turn left onto Truck Road 10 and proceed for 5.2km. Turn left and cross the bridge over Loup Creek. Immediately turn left and follow the road until it ends after approximately 150m. Walk down the old FSR for about 2km, then bushwhack to the tree. Be aware that there are several seasonal and perennial streams that you will need to wade across while following the old FSR.
tree_site_notes: A large tree with a tall, healthy crown. Situated at the base of a slope with high canopy cover and little undergrowth. There are many other large cedars in this particular stand.

access_notes: From Rosander Main, turn onto T23 then T23B. Park closest to the GPS point and bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A big cedar that's part of a small remnant patch of old-growth left after the surrounding forest was clearcut for miles in the 1960's. Looks especially nice in springtime.

access_notes: From Woss drive south. Turn right on Mount Cain Road. Turn right on Davie River Road and drive to Schoen Lake. Paddle to the end of Schoen Lake then buswhack to the tree.

Gordon River Main near Grant's Cove.  Turn left after crossing bridge over San Juan River, continue to Edinburgh bridge crossing, then a further 4.5 km, just before the Loup Creek bridge, and beside the Gordon River.
tree_site_notes: Heavily vegetated with large salal makes access difficult, although not very far off of road. Just up above the river. Beautiful tree.

access_notes: Drive West from Sayward up White River Valley. Take White River Main then turn left on Stewart Main and cross over the White River. Bushwack to tree after crossing bridge over Consort Creek.
David Farrant / Blinkhorn Trail. Follow signage to Telegraph Cove from Highway #19. Follow signage to Forest Camp. Trailhead is from Site #95. The big cedar is not too far up the trail.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 07
CWHvm1 07
CWHvm1 06

access_notes: Turn onto Andreeff Road from Laburnum Road, and continue until the road ends. Head down the trail on the right for around 200 meters, then head off the trail into the woods on the left and make your way down to the river where the tree (and its sister) are located.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a forked trunk. It is one of a pair of two massive cedars. The surrounding forest is very healthy. There are many cedars and douglas firs in the sorrounding area with diameters of 5-8 feet.

access_notes: Drive West from Sayward up White River Valley. Take White River Main then turn left on Stewart Main and cross over the White River. Bushwack to tree after crossing bridge over Consort Creek.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 08

access_notes: Near Winter Harbour, take WH Main down to the old landing near the water. Park and bushwhack up into the old-growth grove on the hillside above.
tree_site_notes: A stately cedar growing in a patch of ferns. Quite the scenic spot!
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: The tree is located in a large OGMA on the east side of Loup Creek. Park on Gordon River Main just past the Loup Creek bridge and hike along the slopes until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Vigourous cedar growing on a bench. Generally open around, with sparse blueberry and salal understory. Base is buttressed, but wuickly tapers to a remarkably tall and straight stem.
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: This tree is accessed via the trail to Chin Beach off of Highway 14. Take the trail down through second-growth forest for about 5 minutes until you reach a large cedar tree on the path. Trailhead is 1.3 km west of Lines Creek Bridge on Highway 14. A small pull-out with a traffic cone attached to a hydro pole is the trailhead marker.
tree_site_notes: A fairly well known cedar that grows on a popular surf trail. Tree is beginning to split higher up the trunk.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Take Nahmint Main to Riverside Main to View Main and then first spur on left. Tree is in strip of forest to left between the spur and the creek.
tree_site_notes: A monumental redcedar growing in the Nahmint Valley.

access_notes: Turn onto Andreeff Road from Laburnum Road, and continue until the road ends. Head down the trail on the right for around 200 meters, then head off the trail into the woods on the left and make your way down to the river where the tree (and its sister) are located.
tree_site_notes: The tree appears suprisingly healthy from afar, its highest point still has a basic cedar shape. It appears like it once had a second leder, but it's since broken off, leaving a "curly" pattern on the trunk where it was. The surrounding forest is very healthy. There are many cedars and douglas firs in the sorrounding area with diameters of 5-8 feet.

access_notes: Turn south onto Elliot FSR from Highway 14 at the Welcome to Port Renfrew sign. Tree is below road at about 1.5 km.
tree_site_notes: Quite a few candelabra topped cedars visible below road. Active logging on upside of road at time of visit.
CWHvh1 04
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 04
A phenominal cedar tree growing in an unprotected old-growth grove. Lots of cool shapes and twists to it. Some culturally modified trees can be found on the opposite side of the road from this tree.
CWHvm1 05
CWHvm1 04
CWHvm1 07

access_notes: From Woss drive south. Turn right on Mount Cain Road. Turn right on Davie River Road and drive to Schoen Lake. Paddle down Schoen Lake then buswhack to the tree.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 08
CWHvh1 10
CWHvm1 06
CWHvm1 10
A beautiful cedar currently wrapped in orange bands in preperation for falling within a recommended deferral area. The tree is just one of many giants in an extensive grove that should be protected.
CWHvm1 07

access_notes: The tree is located in a large OGMA on the east side of Loup Creek. Park on Gordon River Main just past the Loup Creek bridge and hike along the slopes until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Cedar growing at the edge of a steep slope with extensive debris accumulation on the high side. General area is a moderately steep east aspect forest. Hemlock and redecedar with minor component of amabilis fir. Understory primarily blueberry and salal.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: The tree is located in a large OGMA on the east side of Loup Creek. Park on Gordon River Main just past the Loup Creek bridge and hike along the slopes until you reach the tree.
tree_site_notes: Gorgeous silver cedar growing along a gentle E aspect slope with several other large cedars. Open stand with luscious blueberry understory. Tree has a prominent low fork, giving it an oblong stem that makes it appear much larger on two sides.
CWHvm1 10
CWHvh1 04
CWHvm1 07
CWHvm1 04

access_notes: Turn left after crossing bridge over San Juan River, next bridge crosses Gordon River. On steep bank above river.
tree_site_notes: Isolated patch of very mossy hemlock, cedar and yew trees clinging to steep unlogged strip of rainforest.

access_notes: 40 km south on pavement in the Chilliwack River Valley, then 10 km gravel along Chiliwack Lake to Depot Creek trailhead. 3 km hike into the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Sapper's Old Growth Reserve
CWHvm1 08
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: Immediately on Lovers Walk Trail 130m east of intersection with Rawlings Trail.
tree_site_notes: Trailside giant.
CWHvh1 08
CWHvm1 10
CWHvh1 05
CWHvm1 10
CWHvm1 08
CWHvm1 08
CWHvh1 04

access_notes: From the intersection of Deering Rd and Hwy 14 in Port Renfrew, travel south on Hwy 14 for 6km. Turn right onto Minute Creek FSR and drive for 1km. Tree is visible upslope on the lefthand side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located on a slope just up from Minute Creek FSR, at the edge of an old cutblock. The surrounding area is some of the last remaining old growth along this road, with a couple large cedars above the road and abundant large hemlocks and amabilis fir below the road.
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: Near Winter Harbour, take WH Main down to the old landing near the water. Park and bushwhack up into the old-growth grove on the hillside above.
tree_site_notes: An ancient cedar with a spiky top growing in a remnant grove of cedars outside of Winter Harbour.

access_notes: Use GPS coordinates to locate tree in the woods off the main road leading into the town of Winter Harbour.
tree_site_notes: A big redcedar jwith a hollow center and lots of bear claw marks. We found the skull of a black bear nearby as well.

access_notes: Follow signage to Bella Coola Regional Airport, A small trail leads from the parking area into the adjacent forest, directly to the East of the airport parking lot.
tree_site_notes: Many large trees were cut down to provide clearance for airplanes accessing the runway. This act was highly protested by local residents.

access_notes: Turn north off of Highway 20 onto Walker Park Road, 10.5 km east of Bella Coola.
tree_site_notes: An assembly of most impressive trees accessed by a flat 2km loop trail through the lowland floodplain of the Bella Coola River.
CWHvh1 04
CWHvh1 05

access_notes: From Woss drive south. Turn right on Mount Cain Road. Turn right on Davie River Road and drive to Schoen Lake. Paddle across mouth of Davie River on Schoen Lake then buswhack to the tree.

Head northbound from Qualicum Beach on the old Island Highway for aprox. 6 km. When you reach the 4-lane stretch, take the first left onto Baylis Road. At the next intersection, take a left onto Dorman Road, then take a right onto Corcan Road. Follow Corcan road until you see Highway 19, and the tree will be on the left. Park in the clearing on the left side of the road just before the underpass and make your way back to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Much of the tree is still alive. It maintains it's central leder up to its highest point, and it is unassuming at first glance. It lies along Corcan Road and Kinkade Creek, next to a tunnel where the creek passes under the road. It is also less than 100 meters from Highway 19, near the Corcan Road overpass.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road drive North until you see the Hirsch Creek Bridge and just before the bridge, about 100 meters,  you will see an old logging road on the left. Turn in here and park.  Walk along old road until you see a well trodden trail heading to the right.  Follow this trail for about 3 minutes when you'll see this Majestic Candleabra on the right.
tree_site_notes: This large cedar is about 20 meters from the edge of Hirsch Creek and is fairly bare around its base.  It stands near other old growth and younger hemlock, Sitka spruce, western red cedar and even balsam fir.  The tree  sits between a steeper slope above it with wet seasonal trenches criss crossing the flatter area nearby.  Devil's club and some berry bushes are growing in the mossy ground littered with decaying trees and fallen limbs of a large size.
CWHvh1 06
CWHvm1 10

access_notes: From Port Renfrew, travel north towards Lake Cowichan. After crossing the Deering bridge, turn left to start down Gordon Main and proceed for 23km. Turn left onto Truck Road 10 and proceed for 5.2km. Turn left and cross the bridge over Loup Creek. Immediately turn left and follow the road until it ends after approximately 150m. Walk down the old FSR for about 2km, then bushwhack to the tree. Be aware that there are several seasonal and perennial streams that you will need to wade across while following the old FSR.
tree_site_notes: This tree is far and away the dominant feature of this large bench, which is otherwise populated exclusively with middling hemlocks and a sparse understory. The tree appears vigourous and healthy, with a perfectly straight and tall bole.
CWHvh1 10
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: On Park Drive 200m south of Hollow Tree.
tree_site_notes: Very noticeable from Park Drive as the road practically goes around it; has asphalt foot path on the other side from road.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 200 metres up that trail. Tree is on the east side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Growing wedged between rock outcrop, trail, and gully bottom with ephemeral creek. Almost no butt flare (except on the low side) gives it an impressive spruce-like base.

access_notes: Turn off of Highway 20 at approx. 8 km east of Bella Coola onto the Snooka FSR. 0.5 km on rough road to parking lot. Located just off of, and below the East Loop section of this undulating trail system
tree_site_notes: A group of very large cedars luxuriate in a very wet seepage area, in an area otherwise populated primarily with second growth forest. Tree height includes a 3m dead top.
CWHvm1 05
CWHvm1 08

access_notes: From Sechelt head east on the Sunshine Coast Highway towards Wilson Creek. At the intersection with Field Road, head north on Field Road. Turn east (right) onto Sechelt Wilson Creek FSR. Drive up towards Dakota Ridge, turning north (left) onto Dakota Road. Drive just over 400m to a deactivated spur the heads north (on the left). Park here and walk up this deactivated road through an old clear cut until you enter the forest. Follow along the clear cut in the forest heading east and the tree should be just a little north of the cut block (~60m).
tree_site_notes: This tree has now begun to decline in health, but I still felt a nomination was in order simply because it represents the only large cedar surviving in this general area. Since BCTS has now stated this block will be logged again in 2027, I’m hoping the tree can be excluded and afforded a reasonable buffer so that it can live out its remaining years pleasantly.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy. 37 and Kitamaat Village Road, drive north on Hwy 37 for 5 minutes, turn left on Oolichan, left on Coho Ave, right on Rainbow Blvd and right on Chinook Ave.  Park on left near playground.  Walk about 250 m towards the Kitimat River down a hill and along the dyke road.  Turn left and walk on quad trail for about 5 minutes  The tree is very close to the quad trail on the left.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry.   This tree stands in sandy soil with some groundcover and devil's club but mainly young spruce, hemlock and cedar trees around it.  These small trees have a significant amount of moss on the branches.

access_notes: Turn north off of Highway 20 onto Walker Park Road, 10.5 km east of Bella Coola.
tree_site_notes: An assembly of most impressive trees accessed by a flat 2km loop trail through the lowland floodplain of the Bella Coola River.

access_notes: From Kitimat City Centre Intersection on Haisla Blvd, drive 9.6 km and turn right on Bish Creek FSR and proceed for 10 km.  Turn right up rougher older FSR and drive 2.3 km up the Bish Valley. Hike about 10 minutes to left, through an old growth forest down toward Bish Creek to find the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree stands in a mixed western hemlock and Amabilis fir forest with a deep decaying moss level.  Widely spaced trees of mixed ages and loosely spaced shrubs including blueberry, ferns and various patches of groundcovers.  There were many trickling water flows with the sound of ducks as well as grouse and woodpeckers echoing in the tall forest.

access_notes: Turning west off of Highway 19, directly across from the Sayward exit, you will find yourself on the Salmon River Main. Accessing the park is not that straight forward, as there is no signage, and the White River FSR is somewhat off direction from the paved Salmon River Main, which lured me off course for about 6 km before realizing that the river was on the wrong road I was supposed to be on. Backtracking, I found where I missed the turn-off at the junction. The rough gravel road rises steeply from the Salmon River valley, where at the 17 km marker a junction where the road goes down to a bridge crossing the White River, is not the right direction, stay left on the Victoria Main for a further 6 km, where the Park Boundary sign is your first indication that you are getting close to your destination. A short distance further, and an obscure (facing in the wrong direction of travel) sign directs you towards a short trail that leads you through the big Douglas-fir trees towards the river.
tree_site_notes: Touted as the "Cathedral Grove of the North“.  The tree is within the protected area of the White River Provincial Park, which is a narrow linear strip of preserved old-growth, with extensive harvesting visual all around it. The Douglas-fir, tree #1292, is right beside this short trail, before you get to the river. The western redcedar, tree #1293, is upstream, off trail, through some flat, but deadfall barriered ground.  The Sitka spruce, tree #1294, is very close to the western redcedar.

access_notes: Drive West from Campbell River. Hike in from Gold River Highway up Kings Peak trail or drive down BC Hydro access road from Elk River viewpoint and then hike up Kings Peak Trail.

tree_site_notes: CWHvm1 07
A wavy and warbled cedar growing atop a remote slope amongst some other nice cedar specimins. Unprotected

access_notes: Beaver Creek Road
tree_site_notes: Located beside the river on the Stamp River Long Trail at approx. 1.5 km from the south trailhead.

access_notes: Network of trails near Cortes Bay, where the Celebrated Cedar  can be found.
tree_site_notes: Tree was adorned with offerings of crystals, tobacco, fun figurines, and ribbons.

access_notes: Upper Adam Road
tree_site_notes: Tree is located close to the campsite with a small creek running very close to its base.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Very sound tree with fern and devil's club surrounding the tree.

access_notes: Drive West from Campbell River. Hike in from Gold River Highway along Elk River Trail.

Turn off of Highway 20 at approx. 8 km east of Bella Coola onto the Snooka FSR. 0.5 km on rough road to parking lot. Located just off of, and below the East Loop section of this undulating trail system
tree_site_notes: A group of very large cedars luxuriate in a very wet seepage area, in an area otherwise populated primarily with second growth forest.

access_notes: From the Kitimat Chamber of Commerce on Hwy 37, travel 1 km to the Hirsch Creek Bridge.  Continue 200 meters and turn right into the Hirsch Creek North Trail Parking Lot.  Walk on the wide gravel trail for about 10 minutes and turn off onto the trail to your left side.   Walk 5 minutes and look to your left side where you will see the large cedar 30 meters into the forest.
tree_site_notes: This large tree is growing in a soil mound.  A gullly is on two sides of the tree and the surrounding area is laced with ferns, false lily of the valley, several varieties of mushrooms and numerous deadfall trees on top of the composted material.

access_notes: Follow Tsitika FSR from Highway 19 to  7 km marker. Tree is right beside road.
tree_site_notes: A lone tree left at the edge of a huge clearcut logging block.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is close to clearing completed for building of a stage. Healthy vigour, but dead top.

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy 37 and the Kitamaat Village Road, head North on Hwy 37 approximately 6 km, turn left (west side) on a narrow old logging road. There is a good place to park about 100 meters down the logging road.  Follow old logging road, staying on fork to left down a gentle hill.  At the bottom of the hill, and before a wooden bridge,  watch for a rough trail cut to the right,  Walk about 20 meters, through dense underbrush to find this shaggy looking ancient tree.
tree_site_notes: Standing near an old oxbow wetland off the Kitimat River, in fertile ground thickly covered with willow, devil's club, and berry bushes.  The dense understory leaves little room to admire this tree from a distance.  The tree is hollow and has a slight list to it but otherwise has a full live crown.  It reselmbles a gnome with his shaggy bark pooping off the surface of the stem.

access_notes: Turn from Highway 19 onto Rooney Lake FSR

From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take unnamed trail immediatley across Munn Rd from Parking lot a short distance until coming to a creek. Turn left and follow left edge of creek for 60 metres.
tree_site_notes: Hollow tree. Huge cat face with fire scaring but seems healthy. Split top with one broken but alive.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is forked; suitable for habitat as the base of the tree is hollowed. Tree form has unique branching. Flat ground with minimal vegetation surrounding. Next to a fire pit on the property.

access_notes: Drive North on Highway 37A for approximately 5km from Kitimat's City Centre Mall. Turn left at the Hirsch Creek Park sign. Drive 0.5 km to the Hirsch Creek Park trail entrance and park. Walk approximately 100 meters on the trail and see the tree off trail about 10 meters to the right.
tree_site_notes: The Hirsch Creek Park Trail #1 cedar is in good health. It is near a wetland approximately 150 meters from a branch of Hirsch Creek. A very popular year-round trail goes through ancient trees and along Hirsch Creek in a well-used 30-minute loop, parts of which are susceptible to annual floods. Controversy around logging danger trees has been an issue with the public in this park. This trail has numerous specimens of old growth Sitka spruce and western redcedar, many standing but also fallen giants in many stages of decay providing nursery logs and habitat for a variety of birds, insects, mammals and plants. What is interesting is that there is a Sitka spruce tree growing on the lower side of this tree.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Lightning struck tree with a dead, forked top. Middle of trunk is hollowed, and charcoaled. Located from across the first aid cabin on the property.

access_notes: From Highway 99 turn onto the obscurely marked Cal-Cheak Recreation Area. Tree is in campground.
tree_site_notes: Tree is signed as "Danger Tree"

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is rotted out and heavily leaning to the East. Tree is loated near an S6 stream, approximately 100 m from the bank of the Zymagotitz River to the East. Heavy understorey of fern and devil's club.

Large veteran cedar growing along a side channel of the Chemainus River. Tree is open grown and appears vigourous and healthy, with a long crown and single top. The top is dead but intact. Tree is growing at a substantial angle from the side of a sandy embankment that is actively eroding, but the root system appears very soundly anchored. Adjacent stand is old, naturally-regenerated second growth of primarily Douglas-fir and redcedar. Surrounding vegetation is mesic-rich with abundant fern and huckleberry understory (CDFmm04).

access_notes: From the junction of Hwy. 37 and Kitamaat Village Road, drive north on Hwy 37 for 5 minutes, turn left on Oolichan, left on Coho Ave, right on Rainbow Blvd and right on Chinook Ave.  Park on left near playground.  Walk about 250 m towards the Kitimat River down a hill and along the dyke road.  Turn left and walk on quad trail for about 7 minutes.  The tree is in an area near a wetland and is in the open about 20 meters from the quad trail.
tree_site_notes: Members of the Kitimat Valley Naturalists learning about how to nominate and measure trees on a weekend training session measured this tree under supervision by volunteers from the UBC Big Tree Registry.   A great tree for us to practice measuring above a burl and with a high POG.  It's growing by a wetland on the floodplain and quite open considering the general thick underbrush in the area.  It towers above red alder, young Sitka spruce, hemlock trees, and fallen trees of all sizes all covered in mosses.  Ferns, skunk cabbage, elderberry and salmon berry are in the shrub and herb layer.

access_notes: Drive North of Campbell River. Turn right on Browns Bay Road then left on Discovery Creek Forest Service Road.

From the Gabriola ferry terminal at Descanso Bay, drive down North Road for 8.3 km. The Elder Cedar Nature Reserve is located on the left (North) side of the road. Park in the small parking lot and take the trail into the forest. At the first juncion, go right and cross the small creek. The tree is about 200m from the parking lot.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a hollow base and a large fire scar is present; however, appears healthy. The tree has large forking branches about 5 metres up the trunk. It is located near a creek in a forest dominated by western redcedar, Douglas-fir, bigleaf maple, and grand fir. The understory includes swordfern, salmonberry, oregon grape, and salal.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Located near an S6 stream, with vegetation including grasses and devil's club. The tree has a unique branch near the base of the tree. Located next to a building on the property.

access_notes: From Francis-King Regional Park main parking lot take Grand Fir Trail across Munn R from north end of parking lot turning left at first junction and continue 150 m. Tree is on the left side of trail at junction marker. Can't miss it.
tree_site_notes: Huge hollow tree with complete holes in several spots and fire scaring on inside. Multi-candelabra top with short crowns, but appears healthy.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail until the junction with Anderson Cove Trail. Tree is right at the junction.
tree_site_notes: Subhygric trailside site in valley bottom near creek with salmon berry and sword fern understory. Flutted and wide base but no scaring despite being immediatley adjacent to trail/old road.

access_notes: From the trailhead off Kitselas Road, travel south on the T2 trail to the junction with Hatchet Boy.  Turn left onto Hatchet Boy and almost immediately (within 10 metres) turn right onto an unofficial trail known as Ancient Ones.  Stay on the most well-trodden path from here for about 15 minutes until it traverses into a seasonal creek drainage where you will see this interesting ancient cedar below you to the right with the creek running right under it.
tree_site_notes: This tree is located over a seasonal creek.  The area has large boulder outcrops above the creek and the area has been previosly logged.  The lower roots are exposed and extend outward and the tree is fully hollow.  It has a dead top.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is leaning in the Northeast direction; dead top; healthy. Land is cleared around the tree.

access_notes: Highway 30
tree_site_notes: Tree is located near the campsite beside the Marble River.

access_notes: Nominated by the Kitimat Valley Naturalists Watershed Stewardship Group.  The tree is in an old growth stand along Hirsch Creek.  It is a mixed forest of spruce, hemlock, alder and cottonwood. Logging from 50's to 60's surrounds the perimeter of the creek. Tree is about 10 meters from the shore of Hirsch Creek at the base of a steep rock cliff. Area is subject to seasonal flooding. Soils are sandy. Ancient fallen trees surrounding this specimen.  The spot is a sandy stopping point for swimmers, hikers and cliff jumpers.
tree_site_notes: Leaving Kitimat on Highway 37A, approximately 1.7 km from the junction with Kitamaat Village Road, turn right onto gravel road and drive about 300 m to parking lot on north side of Hirsch Creek.  Follow marked trail east and travel upstream along Hirsch Creek for approximately 1 km where trail intersects an old gravel logging road.  Turn right and carefully cross old bridge.  Approximately 100 m south after bridge turn left (East) and follow hiking trail upstream along Hirsch Creek for approximately 700 m.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Significant burn on tree on an Eastern facing slope. Very little vegetation, but devil's club is present.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 3/4 of a kilometre to the first of two unnamed trails that leads to the Copper Mine trail. Hike 400 metres to junction with Copper Mine Trail, then 100 metres up the Copper Mine Trail. Tree is on the west side of the trail.
tree_site_notes: Along the edge of trail (old mining road - shocking they didn't cut it down to build it), with a big scar probably from road building. Wood in the scar is well rotten but crown looks healthy. Just above flowing creek on subhygric site.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is heavily leaning, forked with a dead top. Tree is on flat ground, with minimal vegetation.

Large veteran cedar growing in a sandy bank along the Chemainus River. Tree is open grown and appears vigourous and healthy, with a long crown and single top. The top is living, though it does not appear to be putting on substntial height increment, with abundant lateral branching near the apex. Adjacent vegetation is typical rich riparian indicative of a fluctuating water table but infrequent disturbance (CDFmm12). The tree is named "Xpey’ Siem": Xpey’ is cedar and Siem means an honoured part of nature in the Hul’q’umi’num’ language.

access_notes: Drive 2.5 km from the left turn off onto Kitselas Road and park at a pull out on the left side of the gravel road.  You will see a rough route across a log over a watercourse and then follow a flagged route to the right for about 15 minutes over rolling terrain.  When the trail meets Steinhoe Creek you will see a large cedar tree on the right touching the edge of the creek bank.
tree_site_notes: This is a lone large cedar in a previously logged forest of hemlock, spruce, cedar and cottonwood in the 40-50 year old age range.  The forest is open with some windfallen young trees littered on the forest floor.  There is a steep incline up a hill above the creek.  The creek has undercut below the cedar and a large spruce tree that once grew beside it has fallen recently into the creek.  Devil's club and some groundcover surround the cedar.

access_notes: From Kitimat City Centre Intersection on Haisla Blvd, drive south 9.6 km and turn right on Bish Creek FSR and proceed for 12.5 km.  Park on left side of gravel road and walk back about 5 minutes til you come to a draw filled with rip-rap rock on the right.  From here there is no trail and you will have to scramble down to cross a creek and then back up the slope to an elevation of about 100 meters where an easily hikable shelf of older cedar trees is located. Progress Northwest along shelf for about 20 minutes slow hiking to reach this tree.
tree_site_notes: Surrounded by a mixed western hemlock, amabilis fir and western red cedar stand of quite young trees ranging in age from a few years old to maybe 100 years old.  Spaced out along a shelf there are some very large cedars about every 100 meters including this one.  The duff layer is deep and littered with branches and young fallen logs.  There is no evidence of logging or a fire but this linear stand of old cedars begs exploration.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Very sound tree, with full top.

access_notes: From Kitimat City Centre Intersection on Haisla Blvd, drive south 9.6 km and turn right on Bish Creek FSR and proceed for 12.5 km.  Park on left side of gravel road and walk back about 5 minutes til you come to a draw filled with rip-rap rock on the right.  From here there is no trail and you will have to scramble down to cross a creek and then back up the slope to an elevation of about 100 meters where an easily hikable shelf of older cedar trees is located. Progress Northwest along shelf for about 20 minutes slow hiking to reach this tree.
tree_site_notes: Surrounded by a mixed western hemlock, amabilis fir and western red cedar stand of quite young trees ranging in age from a few years old to maybe 100 years old.  Spaced out along a shelf there are some very large cedars about every 100 meters including this one.  The duff layer is deep and littered with branches and young fallen logs.  There is no evidence of logging or a fire but this linear stand of old cedars begs exploration.

access_notes: From Pike Road parking lot take Pike Road Trail to the Coast trail, then about 1.5 kilometres to second of two unnamed trails that lead to Copper Mine Trail. Hike 200 metres up that trail until coming to a giant redcedar and a very big maple. Just north of the maple, turn right up a tight, dark gully. Tree is about 40 metres up on the south side of the ephemeral creek.
tree_site_notes: On a hump just above a creek and below a salal/pine rock outcrop in a very dark and narrow gully. Giant flared base on the downhill side.

access_notes: From Kitimat City Centre Intersection on Haisla Blvd, drive south 9.6 km and turn right on Bish Creek FSR and proceed for 12.5 km.  Park on left side of gravel road and walk back about 5 minutes til you come to a draw filled with rip-rap rock on the right.  From here there is no trail and you will have to scramble down to cross a creek and then back up the slope to an elevation of about 100 meters where an easily hikable shelf of older cedar trees is located. Progress Northwest along shelf for about 20 minutes slow hiking to reach this tree.
tree_site_notes: Surrounded by a mixed hemlock, cedar stand of quite young trees ranging in age from a few years old to maybe 100 years old.  Spaced out along a shelf there are some very large cedars about every 100 meters including this one which has about 25 percent of its bark remaining.  The duff layer is deep and littered with branches and young fallen logs.  There is no evidence of logging or a fire but this linear stand of old cedars begs exploration.  This tree is named due to the large amount of bark which has come off and is deposited aroung the base.  The tree has a candelabra with a small amount of living branches.  There are other western red cedars in the area which are dead standing giants around the size of this tree.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy. Land is cleared around the tree.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is forked; dead top. Culturally modified tree.

access_notes: From Highway 99 turn onto the obscurely marked Cal-Cheak Recreation Area. Tree is near Sea to Sky Trail after crossing over Cheakamus River on the suspension bridge.
tree_site_notes: Mostly rotten base with signs of supported greenery in the upper canopy. Beautiful tree! Tree has many spires.

access_notes: Visit www.valhallaresort.ca to book a viewing
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy. Area surrounding tree is cleared. Located behind the Ageha Stage.

access_notes: This tree is accessed via the trail to Chin Beach off of Highway 14. Take the trail down through second-growth forest for about 5 minutes until you reach a large cedar tree on the path. From there, veer left into the bush along a rough footpath for about another 2 minutes until you find the Fortress Giant!
tree_site_notes: Healthy. Large, multi-forked cown. This tree is the crown jewel of the grove!

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack in from the forest service road running along Loop Creek.
tree_site_notes: Currently unprotected

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack in from the forest service road running along Loop Creek.
tree_site_notes: Currently unprotected

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: A wide and impressive cedar that splits into two trunks a third of the way up. Other amazing cedars just down slope from this one.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: A truly gargantuan cedar that looks like a redwood. Very little taper in the trunk. Healthy with two large banches that extend outwards like flexing arms.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: A monster of a redcedar that splits into 3 twisted trunks a short ways up. Hidden amongst dense brush.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: Massive cedar with a burl on the backside. Another giant close by but appears to be dead.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: An absolutely stunning & enormous cedar growing on a slope above the lake. Bark has amazing swirly patterns and theres a big burl on the left face of the tree below a big iterating branch. Some hollowing inside.

access_notes: Involves a bushwhack through the forests on the eastern side of the lake.
tree_site_notes: Nothing super notable other than it's huge!

access_notes: Take Nitinat Main to Nitinat Falls Provincial Park. Bushwhack down steep slope into the flats. Tree is hidden amongst dense foliage near the river.
tree_site_notes: An enormous redcedar growing in the flood plains of the Nitinat River. Decorated with lots of low, sweeping branches. Quite the sight!

access_notes: Bushwhack in from Rosander Mainline
tree_site_notes: A big redcedar standing alone amongst a forest of smaller hemlock trees.

access_notes: Take spur road off of Rosander Mainline towards Doobah Lake.
tree_site_notes: A giant, twirling redcedar tree growing at Doobah Lake. This area was previously potected as an Old-Growth Management Area but was later privatized for the Ditidaht First Nation as part of the their ITA and who have now logged much of the old-growth along the lake. The area is home to some of the very biggest ancient cedars and amazing CMTs - where they still remain.

access_notes: Bushwhack in off of Rosander Main or from the trail to the Cheewhat Giant.
tree_site_notes: A behemoth of a cedar. Splits into two trunks halfway up. This lake grows the most amazing trees!

access_notes: Bushwhack in off of Rosander Main or from the trail to the Cheewhat Giant.
tree_site_notes: Trunk splits into another enormous arm part ways up and bark has incredible swirling patterns on it. Big hemlock roots growing off the side. Grows in a beautiful deer fern glade with a number of other massive cedars around it. One of the most beautiful spots around the lake.

access_notes: Take Nahmint Main to View Main and bushwhack downslope, across creek, and up the hill.
tree_site_notes: A nice cedar on the slope. GPS coordinates may be slightly off.

access_notes: A bushwhack off Gordon Mainline a few minutes past Avatar Grove and down towards the river. Starts in second growth then enters into beautiful old-growth on a flat bench overlooking another bench.
tree_site_notes: This huge cedar grows right on the edge of a flat bench overlooking another bench below. A truly impressive spot to just stop and take it all in. A second giant cedar grows just a short distance away downslope. This area is unprotected and may be logged at any time.

access_notes: Starting from Lake Cowichan take South Shore Main to Caycuse Main until you can drop down onto Haddon Main. Follow that to the end of the road where you see a new cutblock where my before & after photos were taken. Drive through the cutblock until you can access a spur road that takes you down across a creek and up the adjacent hillside. Halfway up this road park. The tree is up hill on the left above the road cut. Use GPS for final way-finding.
tree_site_notes: This tree is an absolute giant. It has a massive, burly base and a super thick trunk that towers skyward to a multi-forked top. It appears to be within a retention patch but only 50ft away from the falling boundary tape of a planned cutblock nearby. Other giants exists in the forest around it as well. A true wonder to behold.

A big, beautiful cedar with lovely coloured bark that swirls around. The tree has a hole that you can crawl right through at the base!
A giant cedar with whiteish bark. Looks like it's been around for awhile. Will probably be around for a long time still!
A cedar covered in small burls. Looks like a witches nose!
A massive cedar with a bear den.
A solid cedar growing in a lush patch of ferns.
A solid cedar growing in a lush patch of ferns.
Monumental redcedar with an active bear den. A really special tree and spot.
An towering cedar that soars skyward. Standing here feels like you're in the redwoods of California. This might be where all the fairys live.
A twisted redcedar that looks like a piece of red licorice!

A super giant cedar that makes you stop and say 'WOW'! This one really stands out and with the other big trees around it, makes for an amazing experience. A full sized Hemlock is also growing out of the trunk.
A super hefty cedar growing in a small creek ravine. A wall of wood!

access_notes: Take a boat to Vernon Bay in Barkley Sound, find a beach to land on, bushwhack into the forest. Dense terrain!!
Boat access to the shore then bushwhack in.
tree_site_notes: A beast of a cedar growing on a bench at the top of a rise.

access_notes: Take Gordon Main to Ediburgh Main then walk ED39 spur road on left (old). Bushwhack up through overgrown clearcut (this sucks) until you get into a patch of old-growth with a few scattered giants.
tree_site_notes: A beautiful cedar in a remnant patch of old-growth on Edinburgh Moutain. A great place to have a nap after climbing down the mountain.
A scragly old cedar within an approved cutblock.
A giant solid cedar that is now within an approved cutblock.

access_notes: Take FSR's from Powell River to point closest to GPS and hike in through the second-growth.
tree_site_notes: The largest cedar in a stunning pocket of old-growth at the base of a towering cliff in the Eldred River Valley.
A giant redcedar tree with some big burls on the trunk. May now be in a retention patch.
A massive redcedar with a warbly trunk that has the appearance of an old wax candle. Very cool and impressive tree
A stately cedar in an area with a number of other large trees. Another larger cedar is found further on but had died.
From a distance I thought this was one tree, and the biggest ever at that. Turns out its clearly two trees once you view it from the side. Still an incredible sight to see nonetheless!
This one's a big guy!
A big old cedar growing next to a multi-spired cedar that looks like Medusa! A fun place to find yourself in along the lakeshore.
A wall of wood that eventually splits into two. Stands out in this zone!
A giant hollow cedar that you can stand inside growing just up the hill from a small creek.
A dry den in this ancient, castle-like cedar provides a great shelter for hobbits trying to avoid the dangers lurking in these regions. You may be sharing it with a black bear though.

access_notes: Highway 4
tree_site_notes: Situated near not too well worn, short loop trail that is intentionally leading to the Canoe Creek Giant beside the Kennedy River.

access_notes: A short walk from a well signed trailhead pull-out on the side of Highway 4
tree_site_notes: Located right beside the trail, tree sees a little too much attention with evidence of trampling.  Please view and photograph from a distance.

access_notes: Follow Loss Creek FSR for approximately 4.5km, then bushwhack up through the steep second growth until you reach the old growth above. Sideslope across the gullies until you reach the tree. May also be accessible from above via West 90 FSR.
tree_site_notes: Tree is located at the edge of a gully.

access_notes: Near the Tofino/Ucluelt junction on Pacific Rim Highway #4, take West Road until is crosses a bridge over Staghorn Creek. Park on the right after the bridge. The old San River Road is now deactivated. The Clayoquot Arm Beach Rec Site (now closed) is on the right handside. Along the boardwalk trail, this tree can be found off trail on the right hand side. There are other incredible cedars along this path that is now sadly in dissrepair.
tree_site_notes: A colossal redcedar commands your attention from afar. It has a wide, flat trunk and enormous bass. Looks impressive from all angles. A true king of the woods!

access_notes: Take a boat to the big tree trail, then bushwhack your way to the GPS point. Bit of a trek through rugged terrain!
tree_site_notes: A massive redcedar with a wall-like face growing at the edge of a pretty creek. This tree really stands out and has lost of beautiful patterns and shapes in its bark

access_notes: A steep bushwhack off of Highway 4 leads to a pocket of scattered old-growth cedars that were left during earlier logging.
tree_site_notes: A pair of old-growth cedars growing side by side. The aerial imagery for this region appears to show impressive crowns, however, the overal tree sizes were not enormous.

access_notes: Bushwhack through the old-growth just off of Highway 4 to the GPS point. Other big cedars can be found throughout this slope!
tree_site_notes: A beautiful cedar with hues of purple and green in its trunk. Part of a grove of cedars growing along the highway.

access_notes: From Nanaimo, take ferry to Gabriola Island. Drive across Gabriola to Degnen Bay and launch a boat at the public boat launch. Paddle or boat across Gabriola Passage to Wakes Cove public dock.
tree_site_notes: Healthy single stemmed tree. Largest in stand. On the side of an old road surrounded by salal.

access_notes: Park at 49.092207, -125.689604. From there, hike along an overgrown road towards the GPS pin for the tree. As the old road dissappears, it's best to bushwack the last stretch through the second-growth to your right. Access is best suited for those with strong hiking/route finding abilities.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in a grove of other mid-sized cedars. The crowns in this area look enticing on the  aerial imagery, however, after searching, no major record breakers were found here. This tree gives a good impression of what's found in this zone.

access_notes: Take Cowichan 700 spur off of Cowichan Main. Then take first right. Old road can be driven for a short distance before a washout. Walk along the old road before hiking up the steep hillside.
tree_site_notes: An impressive redcedar growin on the edge of an embankment. A bear den entrance is on the backside of the tree.

access_notes: Taking Little Slocan FSR north from Passmore turn up Russell Creek FSR approx 13 km up. Travel 11 km up Russell FSR. Trees are 30 m down the bank on a small flagged rail. Please respect tape to prevent root damage.
tree_site_notes: Amazing grounping of 8 trees with individuals trees ranging from 0.75 to 2 m in diameter. Irregular circumference due to 8 stems, 2 stems visibly hollow but trees otherwise healthy with lush crown and alive tops.  On moderate, rocky, NW slope, 35 m below logging road. Devil's club, hemlock, fern, western yew, deciduous. Near small rockslide area. Less than 5 m from creek.

access_notes: Located below the road and just above the creek amongst a very large grove of big cedar trees.
Located along boardwalk with identification signage.
tree_site_notes: Estimated to be 1800 years old, “The Big Tree” as the name suggests is just that. One of, if not the chubbiest cedars in B.C.’s Interior.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: The tree is the largest in a grove of very large interior western red cedar.

access_notes: Up and to the left of the Treebeard tree after some serious alder bashing.
Located along boardwalk with identification signage.
tree_site_notes: This tree is named after Dave Radies. In 2005, while studying lichen biodiversity, he learned of the logging plans for the area and quickly spread the word. A year later with the help of many people in the area, the Ancient Forest Trail was built.  Thanks to the combined efforts of folks like Hugh Perkins, Dave Connell, Darwin Coxson, members of the Caledonia Ramblers and the local First Nations, this magnificent forest is now preserved for future generations to enjoy and cherish.  The Radius Tree has been heavily trafficked, and now has a protective fence around it to protect its roots. The buttressed base of this tree is amazing.

access_notes: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1, as you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the now closed Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the very overgrown spur follows the drainage to where the road is obstructed by a small landslide. We had to back down from here, so best to just park at the junction and walk up to the tree. It is only about 850 m until this massive tree shows up on the left side of the road. You can’t miss it!
tree_site_notes: The tree is somewhat solitary, and appears to have been graciously left behind. With huge limbs spreading out above as cedars. We circumnavigated around its girth, where the Interior sized D-Tape couldn’t wrap the entire circumference. Our explorations down below towards the creek turned up some considerable sized western red cedars, western hemlocks, and a notable Engelmann spruce. This region is worthy of further explorations, where myth’s of even larger cedars are whispered by the locals.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Tree has flare at base, is hollow and has a bear den inside and bear rubbings outside.

access_notes: Up and to the left of the Treebeard tree after some serious alder bashing.

The Kokanee Creek Old Growth Trail is found by following the Kokanee Glacier access road off of Highway #3A for 12 km. on a 2 wd suitable gravel road that climbs steeply up the drainage. B.C. Recreation Sites and Trails has a well positioned sign on the highway directing you to this preserve. The trailhead is well signed, and a few pullouts are available for parking.
tree_site_notes: The Old Growth forest occupying the flanks of Kokanee Creek appears to be thriving in this wet belt environment. Only threat is perhaps over visitation. Evidence of past logging and mining activity have fortunately not compromised this otherwise sensitive site.

access_notes: The Staubert Lake Cedars are tucked away beside the Trout Lake highway, and are easily accessed. A stylish wood  carved sign alerts you to the trailhead, where a small pull-out beside the road provides parking for a few vehicles.
tree_site_notes: This is the first tree encountered as you enter this enchanting grove. Spread out on the Beaton River /Poulman Creek floodplain, there are many spectacular trees, however the entry sentinel, with its own viewing chair is outstanding.

access_notes: Up and to the left of the Treebeard tree after some serious alder bashing.

Boat access only traveling west across Revelstoke Lake. Good launch point at Carnes Creek Recreation Site accessed via Hwy 23 north of Revelstoke. Tree is located approximately 2 to 2.5 km up a flagging marked trail . Trail is accessed from a small flagged drainage approx 500 m north of the mouth of Frisby Creek. Accessing area through Frisby Creek not recommended.
tree_site_notes:
Tree has significant graduated multidirectional lean. Tree is on edge of landslide area and has some mechanical damage and is surrounded by avalanche debris. This area is prone to avalanche due to steep slopes above.

The tree is located in a spectacular contiguous old growth area in the Frisby Creek drainage that has not been significantly impacted by logging. There has been some shake bolting and selective logging lower in the valley. The valley is towered over by steep slopes and the tree is on a bench situated above a lower bench along Frisby Creek and below steep slopes leading into the alpine. Moist and lush area. Lots of Devil's club and moss, abundant mushrooms. Lots of moose activity and bear dens in the area.

access_notes: Up and to the left of the Treebeard tree after some serious alder bashing.

The turn off to the Cedar Grove Trail is 10 km from Highway 23.  A well signed forestry road to the left is followed for 5.5 km to the trailhead. The gravel road is quite rough and rocky, but is navigable with a 2 wheel drive vehicle. On the way up, there is a wye that is un-signed, so attention should be paid here to get where you want to go. The right branch is your direction.
tree_site_notes: This triple trunked cedar is a very solid looking tree. With black gooseberry trailing around at its base, it seemed well accompanied to put on a few more years growth.

access_notes: Please respect private property and view from a distance. An isolated grove of cedars, located between the Ranch's cleared fields and the Salmo River. Beside highway #3, and the Salmo River, in the "Groovy Grove".
Following Mt. Fernie Park Rd. from Highway 3 to Island Lakes 2nd parking lot is where the trailhead to the Od Growth Trail begins.
tree_site_notes: Venturing off of the trail to a floodplain bench above Lizard Creek this massive tree stands in a meadow environment of Cow Parsnip and Devil’s club

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Tree has partial defoliated castled top and is at slight angle approx 5-10%.

access_notes: Accessed from the Mount Fernie Park road off of Highway 3 near Fernie, you drive through the campground, and follow the gravel Island Lake access road until you arrive at their first parking area and gate. If the Lodge is open for summer guests the gate will be open. Otherwise you can walk / ski or ride your bike up the road or provided trails. About 4 km up the road a second trailhead parking area for the Old Growth trail is on the right. You can park here, and walk up the road about another 50 m and an old spur to the right (the winter road) leads up another 50 m where the "Mammoth" is hiding in the bushes on the left.
tree_site_notes: Included in the trees height is a 4.0 m. dead spire top. The tree is surrounded with heavy underbrush, making accessibility somewhat difficult. The bulbous base of the tree is typical of the many old cedars growing in this area.

access_notes: The Staubert Lake Cedars are tucked away beside the Trout Lake highway, and are easily accessed. A stylish wood  carved sign alerts you to the trailhead, where a small pull-out beside the road provides parking for a few vehicles.
tree_site_notes: The #29 tree is located near the old homestead, and has a 29 tag on it. I think this might indicate 29 ft in circumference before it put on a bit more girth?

access_notes: Highway 16 on opposite side of the road from Ancient Forest parking lot and across from gated rock quarry to the west.

Boat access only traveling west across Revelstoke Lake. Good launch point at Carnes Creek Recreation Site accessed via Hwy 23 north of Revelstoke. Tree is located approximately 2 to 2.5 km up a flagging marked trail . Trail is accessed from a small flagged drainage approx 500 m north of the mouth of Frisby Creek. Accessing area through Frisby Creek not recommended.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in lush area near creek in flattish area and moist depression. Tree has enlarged lower branch turret and small burl lower down. Tree has slight lean and is in windfall area. Three large trees are leaning on it. The tree is located in a spectacular contiguous old growth area in the Frisby Creek drainage that has not been significantly impacted by logging. There has been some shake bolting and selective logging lower in the valley. The valley is towered over by steep slopes and the tree is on a bench situated above a lower bench along Frisby Creek and below steep slopes leading into the alpine. Moist and lush area. Lots of Devil's club and moss, abundant mushrooms. Lots of moose activity and bear dens in the area.
ICHmw2. Tree sits on valley bottom with multiple wildlife cavities. FC’s with >10% diameter change. Located 80m from S1 stream.

access_notes: The Eagle River Nature Park is located on the opposite side of Highway 1 from  the Yard Creek Provincial Park campground in Malakwa (12 km east of Sicamous). This is a section of divided highway, so turning onto the Malakwa north frontage road is a bit challenging. Once on the north frontage road head to the west end where the trailhead parking lot is located. The 6 km loop trail has a few cedar groves, with the Grandmother of the Eagle tree being at the furthest out on the loop trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is luxuriating in the riparian area of the Eagle River, and enjoys lots of space allowing for the impressive spread of the branches. The flat, floodplain, and watersoaked surroundings provide ideal growing conditions for these big cedar trees.

access_notes: To access the tree: 1) Drive from Prince George to the Hungary Creek FSR, approximately 80km east along Highway 16, 2) Drive approximately 2.8km along the Hungary Creek FSR, following resource road radio protocols.  Park at an appropriate location, 3) Tree is located approximately 100m south of the Hungary Creek FSR.
tree_site_notes: Tree condition and health: dead top, tree appears healthy. Ht to live crown is 31.1, ht to dead top is 34.0. Site conditions: located on 5% slope with NW aspect, mid-slope position. There was a fire in this stand ~100 years ago.  Many larger cedar in the stand were burned.

access_notes: Just past Downie FSR turnoff across from pullout at 63 km up Hwy 23 north of Revelstoke. Walk approx 1 kn up new trail.
tree_site_notes:
Largest tree found in area of large trees (many over 2 m). Lush gently N sloped bench area 150 m above Downie Creek. 35 m below logging road. Devils club, fern, hemlock, yew. 
Turreted low (15-20m up) and also 3 upper turrets. A medium size burl 4 m up tree.

access_notes: Drive north up the Duncan FSR to the top of the lake. Cross Duncan River bridge, and look for road to left. Gate is sometimes closed, but walking in a couple of km will land you in this great forest collection on both sides of the road. The further you go, the bigger the trees get.
tree_site_notes: Sampled tree was on the west side of the road, standing amongst some grizzly bear chewed skunk baggage, and thick alder.

access_notes: Easily accessible, this tree can be found by driving on West Creston Road, just off Highway 3. At approximately 4.7 km you will come to a bridge that crosses Corn Creek. A small pullout just before the bridge, is the parking spot.
tree_site_notes: Standing alone beside Corn Creek this tree is very visible, and the area around the tree has been heavily visited. A view from the other side of the creek is worthwhile.

access_notes: Located along boardwalk with identification signage.
tree_site_notes: Treebeard, from the famed Tolkien Ents, has long pendulous branches reaching almost to the forest floor. Seemingly looking to get another anchor onto the ground.

access_notes: Located on the south side of Lizard Creek, where a ski touring bridge provides a crossing to an old road that traverses through amazing cedars.
tree_site_notes: Very difficult measurement due to trees position on steep slope below the road.

access_notes: The Island Lake lodge access road winds up through spectacular old-growth. Just find a place to park and explore.
tree_site_notes: With its buttressed roots dipping into the small stream at its base, it has a big foot look. Tree has a 6m dead spire.

access_notes: The trail is accessed from the 2nd Island Lake parking lot in summer. Follow the Old Growth Trail to the Cabin Ridge junction (signed). Trail descends down to Lizard Creek, where a sometimes tenuous crossing is required. This big Cedar is just up the trail aways, but not right beside the trail.
tree_site_notes: A handsome twin trunk dominates this trees appearance. Whether it has inosculated, or just grew this way will never be known.

access_notes: Davis Creek/Fishhook Lake trail is a steep hike, that starts at the Davis Creek Provincial Park campground in Lardeau.
tree_site_notes: Located close to Fishhook Lake this is one of many very large cedars and hemlocks that line the trail.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow signage to Cabin Trail. Venturing off trail onto a game trail overlooking Hunter Bowl.
tree_site_notes: Evidence of many animals (elk, moose, bears) bedding down at base of tree.

access_notes: From Highway 16, a  high bridge crosses over the Goat River. A rest area on the west side of the bridge is the parking area. The rough trail is on the south side of the highway, and continues for 8 km following up the Goat River.
tree_site_notes: The further you go up the valley the bigger the tree keep getting.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow signage to Cabin Trail. Venturing off trail onto a game trail overlooking Hunter Bowl.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a hollow core.

access_notes: Starting on highway 6, take the turn off at Upper Passmore for the Valhalla Wilderness Park. Cross the bridge over the Slocan river and continue straight. After about 3 kms it will turn into Little Slocan FSR. Follow Little Slocan FSR for 12 kms until you reach the turnoff for Russel Creek FSR. Follow Russel Creek FSR and stop between KM 20 and 21. Hike east up the steep slope about 100m to the tree.
tree_site_notes: This tree's DHB is a highside measurement. Tupa, is grandmother in Sinixt. Epic cedar growing on a 35 degree local slope on top of a 1-2m wide boulder. Cascading, waterfall like branches on the lower side of the tree which are truly spectacular. Large buttresses stabilize the tree, and has below averTupa, is grandmother in Sinixt. Epic cedar growing on a 35 degree local slope on top of a 1-2m wide boulder. Cascading, waterfall like branches on the lower side of the tree which are truly spectacular. Large buttresses stabilize the tree, and has below average height. Forks into 3 stems about 2/3 up the tree. Truly unique forest as mature engelmann spruce and western hemlock surround the tree.
