Aspect is NW. The area is full of significant cedars, this tree is at the edge of a proposed cut block. Surrounding area is lush for such a steep slope and a thin topsoil layer.age height. Forks into 3 stems about 2/3 up the tree. Truly unique forest as mature engelmann spruce and western hemlock surround the tree. Aspect is NW. The area is full of significant cedars, this tree is at the edge of a proposed cut block. Surrounding area is lush for such a steep slope and a thin topsoil layer.

access_notes: The Gorby Trail is accessed from Mount Fernie Park Road off of  Highway 3. Drive to parking lot past campground, trailhead with aluminum bridge crossing Lizard Creek. Follow signage to Magic Grove.
tree_site_notes: The “Magic Grove” has some of the finest cedars in the Fernie area. The big tree is joined by some other enormous beauties, all clustered together to make a sheltered setting.

access_notes: Island Lake Access Road then follow creek downstream
tree_site_notes: Spired top.

access_notes: Located across creek from boardwalk when heading up from parking lot.
Difficult bushwhack from Lizard Creek Trail
tree_site_notes: Grove of substantial sized cedars on southeast facing slope

access_notes: Difficult bushwhack from Lizard Creek Trail
tree_site_notes: Grove of substantial sized cedars on southeast facing slope. Tree has a dead spire top.

access_notes: Starting on highway 6, take the turn off at Upper Passmore for the Valhalla Wilderness Park. Cross the bridge over the Slocan river and continue straight. After about 3 kms it will turn into Little Slocan FSR. Follow Little Slocan FSR for 12 kms until you reach the turnoff for Russel Creek FSR. Follow Russel Creek FSR and stop between KM 20 and 21. Hike east up the steep slope about 30m to the tree.
tree_site_notes: The highside DBH for this tree is 2.62 m. Unique, pillar like cedar tree growing on a NW facing slope with a 30 degree angle. The tree is very compact and straight with basically no buttresses. The tree has multiple tops and branches stick out notably. In an area with 7 cedars of significance including a close tree with 8.0m of diameter. This tree is in a cut block and is scheduled to be harvested.

access_notes: From Revelstoke take Highway 1 West.  At the junction 500m from west end of Revelstoke, turn north. Travel 6.5 km to Frisby FSR. Follow Frisby FSR North for 20k and take the west spur.  Go up the spur for 3.2 km. Walk 100m downhill off of the road, cross the small creek to where the tree stands.
tree_site_notes: The tree has a fairly uniform trunk with slight twist all the way to the top, is leaning approximately 4 degrees and has a turreted top.  The canopy is healthy with some low branches and heavy lichen load.  There is an animal nest partway up the tree, with a big hollow and marks at the opening, possibly a porcupine.  The tree is next to small creek, surrounded by medium density devils club. It is located in an old growth grove containing numerous big western redcedars and hemlocks. The tree is in a flat section of grove near the creek, just down from the logging road. The forest is highly productive forest with evidence of ungulate and bear activity.

access_notes: Accessed from Highway 1 east of Sicamous, the Yard Creek P.P. Campground in Malakwa is well signed. The Eagle River Nature Park is located on the north side of the highway, and has a great little trail through some impressive forest.
tree_site_notes: The Cedar Sister is located in the 3rd grove along the trail, and is a beautiful tree. Nestled in amongst some other sisters, her bark shines, and her long limbs seep down for embraces.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow signage to Cabin Trail. Venturing off trail onto a game trail overlooking Hunter Bowl.
tree_site_notes: Slippery debris at base.

access_notes: Starting on highway 6, take the turn off at Upper Passmore for the Valhalla Wilderness Park. Cross the bridge over the Slocan river and continue straight. After about 3 kms it will turn into Little Slocan FSR. Follow Little Slocan FSR for 12 kms until you reach the turnoff for Russel Creek FSR. Follow Russel Creek FSR and stop between KM 20 and 21. Hike west down the slope about 30m to the tree.
tree_site_notes: The highside DBH for this tree is 2.44 m.  Largest tree in grove of at least 16 cedars of significance, including 5 or 6 that are over 2m in diameter. There are also two sets of 3 twin cedars that are gorgeous. The tree is on a slope of about 20 degrees and NW aspect. There is a low gnarled branch about 7m up the tree. The tree has light lichen load moderate flagging and the under story consists of vine maple, pacific yew and devils club. This tree is on the edge of a cut block, but is not in the block.

access_notes: The Rail Trail leads out from the Island Lake lodge 1st parking lot. Follow trail until it comes into a meadow area. The tree is located to your left towards Lizard Creek.
tree_site_notes: The three upper trunks of this tree appear to have originated from one bole, creating its significant girth.

access_notes: Boat access only traveling west across Revelstoke Lake. Good launch point at Carnes Creek Recreation Site accessed via Hwy 23 north of Revelstoke. Tree is located approximately 2 to 2.5 km up a flagging marked trail . Trail is accessed from a small flagged drainage approx 500 m north of the mouth of Frisby Creek. Accessing area through Frisby Creek not recommended.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in lush area near creek in flattish area and moist depression. Tree has large hollow crack that runs 50% the length of the tree and has ferns and moss growing out of it. Split at top and one leader broken. Small burls around base. The tree is located in a spectacular contiguous old growth area in the Frisby Creek drainage that has not been significantly impacted by logging. There has been some shake bolting and selective logging lower in the valley. The valley is towered over by steep slopes and the tree is on a bench situated above a lower bench along Frisby Creek and below steep slopes leading into the alpine. Moist and lush area. Lots of Devil's club and moss, abundant mushrooms. Lots of moose activity and bear dens in the area.

access_notes: Follow the Sugar Lake FSR for 40 + km’s until reaching Shuswap Falls Creek spur. The Ecological Reserve is on the opposite (river) side of the road. The tree is located on the flat benched area near the river.
tree_site_notes: A primeval setting, that appears ver coastal. The big limby tree has its own signature look with branches extending to touch the ground creating a sheltered cone at its base.

access_notes: Highway 16 on opposite side of the road from Ancient Forest parking lot and across from gated rock quarry to the west.
Either descend from Red Tree Road at Fernie Alpine Resort, or enter from Gorby Trail at Mount Fernie Provincial Park. Tree is the valley between Snake andVerboten Ridge
tree_site_notes: In a productive drainage where many Englemann spruce join the company of the cedars. Tree height includes a 9 m dead top.

access_notes: Located along boardwalk in the park, right beside the trail.

Minor amount of blowdown, regen close to Hwy but forest floor and canopy open up before rocky outcrop uphill. Unknown cultural history.  Area has potential Culturally Modified Trees, and has been previously surveyed for Timber and most likely Ecotyping.  Very old flagging found throughout, near potential CMTs and large timber stands.  Multiple human-made "test" holes found throughout the forest, as well as a potentially "stripped" Cedar tree.  Area was part of a 2008 push by local organizations to introduce an investigation by the Forestry Board (Dome Creek area) as to the impact of logging in ICH stands in the Robson Valley "Funnel" and as a result an extensive Old Growth Management Area Plan was introduced.  This "island" is an "Ancient" area (as B.C.Forestmap.com age class) which was left out of OGMA areas, deemed fragmented due to previous logging operations. Area is known for Caribou.  SARA listed species found within and above (previously documented on inaturalist) the "island" such as Nephroma occultum (Cryptic paw) and potential for Smokers Lung (Lobaria retigera) due to noted sites nearby.  Beautiful highway site, tree is visible from the road.  In summertime the area will be abundant with Devils Club.  Easy to get to and a magnificent little nook and a pleasant day hike area.
tree_site_notes: From Prince George Drive East on Hwy 16 to Dome Creek Rd. East of The Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park and Protected Area. *12.5 km After the Dome Creek Rd. Hwy Intersection (Joe Boo's Mobile Eatery) there is a small turnaround and garbage disposal location on the North Side of Hwy. This is a Good Parking Spot. If you pass Walker Creek FSR you have gone too far.* Tree is located on the South (SSW) side of Hwy, roughly 80-100 m from the parking area and 40-60 m from the brushed road edge. Hikers must climb up the steep ditch embankment and into the forest, minor elevation gain after entry into Mature Stand Area. System of very large Trees and Alli's Hollow are along a small plateau between the Hwy and a Rocky Ridge above, leading to a Silviculture regen area.

access_notes: From Revelstoke drive 108 kn north on Hwy 23. Turn east on Goldstream FSR. Between km 20-21 look for small south spur. . Walk south up 450 m. Tree is 100 m upslope travelling SE.
tree_site_notes: Trees has a forked stem approx 1/3 way up. The area is a lush, north facing, moderately inclined lower slope although where the tree is is relatively flat. There is lots of Devils club and larger shrubs. The grove and slope on which this tree is situated has many other trees (rough estimate of 10-15) in the 7-7.5 m circumference range. This grove is in a cutblock slated for imminent logging and is one of the few unlogged areas on the lower slopes of the Goldstream FSR.

access_notes: The trailhead for the Lazy Lizard is located at Island Lake Lodge’s 1st parking lot. The tree is about 4 km up the trail.
tree_site_notes: There are many large cedars that stud this trail. The sampled tree is off to the side aways, and is quite obscured by its very long branches that extend right into the surrounding alder and devil’s club.

access_notes: Heading west from Golden, the Big Bend Highway heads north from Highway 1 at Donald. The tree is on the west side of the gravel forest service road at approximately 23 km, and is approximately 45 m into the forest from the road.  The tree can be seen from the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree assessed to be in healthy condittion.  Has a forked top.  Surrounding features and wildlife while taking measurements included the following:  Sunny side of tree has Devil's Club. Tree has mosses and lichens growing on trunk, and yew growing around tree base.  Trunk is hollow in places (potential for wildlife use), with lots of bark fissures (e.g., bat roost habitat). Bird species present during site visit: Pileated Woodpecker, Pine Sisken, Red Crossbill, Golden-crowned Kinglet, White-winged Crossbill, Brown Creeper. Mammals: Red Squirrel

access_notes: Sensitive area - exact location is hidden.

The paved Mica Creek highway travels for 100 km north of Revelstoke. Downie Creek is one of the major drainages that connect to Revelstoke Lake (see Columbia River). The tree is located a few km up the Bigmouth Creek FSR, where it forks down to BMX bridge.
tree_site_notes: With active logging going on all around you, and recently logged blocks visible in every direction, it is amazing this grove of trees is still standing. Luckily, and perhaps because of riparian setback requirements this grove of big trees is nestled in beside Bigmouth Creek.

access_notes: Follow signage from Slocan City to Valhalla Provincial Park, turn right on Bannock Burn FSR, stay right at first wye, note signage to Gimli Peak Trail. Some fine cedars located all along Bannock Creek.
In the forest below the Island Lake access road. Growing right between 2 creeks, so has a root uptake advantage.
Kokanee Creek Rd access to Old Growth Trail (signed at Highway 3A). Tree is on opposite side of the creek as the trail.
The Big Bend Highway heads north from Highway 1 at Donald. The Giant Cedars Rec. Site is on the left side of the gravel road, and is well signed.
tree_site_notes: Located in the Help Creek floodplain the “Giant Cedars” line the trail through this very wet site. The sampled tree had its roots extending right into the creek.

access_notes: The Wap FSR extends from Three Valley Gap to Lumby. A spur referred to as Bottoms Rd. accesses this beautiful setting, where a plentiful grove of big cedars and hemlocks reside in a large seepage area above the lakes.
tree_site_notes: A luxuriant green surrounds you as you enter into this very boggy site, where big trees are nurtured by just the right stuff.

access_notes: Tree is located in the Duncan/Lardeau Flats Conservation Area.  Where the Duncan and Lardeau River converge at the north end of Kootenay Lake the delta flats provide an important habitat for: well everything. Access is at a signed, small gated pull-out just to the south of Meadow Creek.
tree_site_notes: The long branches of this tree hide its magnificence. Due to the open space afforded, this tree has taken full advantage of its surroundings, or lack thereof.

access_notes: Difficult bushwhack from Lizard Creek Trail
tree_site_notes: Grove of substantial sized cedars on southeast facing slope

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: Taking the time to grow lichen on your bark is a cooperative effort. This epiphyte and big cedar have done a good job, and the crop shows.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead. This tree is located in a cedar studded opening once you have bushwhacked up past where the old logging was done early in the 1900’s
tree_site_notes: Mother of Pearl, as the name implies, is  a significantly larger tree amongst the other meagre giants.

access_notes: Located on the west side of the trail looking down towards an unnamed drainage.
tree_site_notes: Easy access.

access_notes: The paved Mica Creek highway travels for 100 km north of Revelstoke. Downie Creek is one of the major drainages that connect to Revelstoke Lake (see Columbia River). The tree is visible from the highway just before the Downie Creek bridge.
tree_site_notes: With a highway on one side, a logging road on the other, this grove is pinched in just above the Downie River escarpment. A very jungly approach is required to access from the highway. From the logging spur above is much easier, as I discover on my exit.

access_notes: Old Growth Trail - Cedar Valley.  Drive up Mount Fernie Park Rd from Highway #3 to trailhead parking lot. Tree is located between the trail and the Island Lake Road.
tree_site_notes: Tree height does not include a dead 4m spire at the top.

access_notes: Driving north on the Trout Lake Highway (gravel) from Meadow Creek, a small settlement of Poplar Creek is reached. At Rapid Creek, a well signed trailhead is positioned to direct you to the trail.
tree_site_notes: Standing in the expansive floodplain of the Lardeau River this huge tree is the first one to greet you when you enter the forest.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow trail past Cabin Ridge junction. Descend down towards Lizard Creek.
tree_site_notes: An area providing perfect conditions for nurturing giant cedars.

access_notes: Located beside the hydro transmission right of way clearing that crosses over the Elk River just upstream of where Morrissey Creek ties into the river.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a heavy lean and thickly covered in Gold Dust lichen.  Old Yeller is located in a wonderful setting amongst many very large cedars, cottonwoods, and the Jeffy Dougy fir.

access_notes: From Revelstoke take Highway 1 West.  At the junction 500m from west end of Revelstoke, turn north. Travel 6.5 km to Frisby FSR. Follow Frisby FSR North for 20k and take the west spur.  Go up the spur for 14 km. Walk 370m downhill off of the road,  initially through the 20 year old clearcut.
tree_site_notes: Slight split at base on S side and small hollow on N side. Located in Cedar/Hemlock grove with 15+ western red cedar @1-2.25 m DBH western red cedar.  Slightly turreted with one side of canopy quite defoliated.  High productivity, moisture collecting flat area near creek, devil's club, western yew, wild ginger, ferns on overall E facing moderate mid slope. Tree is at base of moderate slope coming into the flat area. Within planned cutblock boundary and OGMA.

access_notes: From Revelstoke drive 108 kn north on Hwy 23. Turn east on Goldstream FSR. Between km 31 and 32 on Goldsteam FSR stop before creek crossing. Tree is located approximately 200 meters from the road walking north.
tree_site_notes: Tree is a fairly solid and uniform diameter column with only a light flair and a full canopy. It is located in a beautiful valley bottom grove along the south side of the Goldstream River. The tree was one of the largest we found valley bottom up the Goldstream FSR. The grove is located at the confluence of a smaller stream entering into the river, contains wetland areas and shows evidence of annual flooding at high water.This grove is one of the bigger intact groves along the base of the valley. Most significant sized trees in this grove are in the 1.75 to 2 meter dbh range. The vegetation in the area is fairly lush with a good layer of Devils Club, however with sandy soil and areas that show evidence of frequent high water there are patches of more limited undergrowth. There is a fairly clear trail that runs from the Goldstream FSR to the tree and shows evidence of being used by both elk and people. A muddy, wetland area directly south of the tree shows evidence of being a well used elk bed.

access_notes: This trees is 100m from BCBT #1177.  The directions to 1177 are: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1, as you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the now closed Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the very overgrown spur follows the drainage to where the road is obstructed by a small landslide. We had to back down from here, so best to just park at the junction and walk up to the tree. It is only about 850 m until this massive tree shows up on the left side of the road. You can’t miss it!
tree_site_notes: Healthy tree with several sappling western hemlocks growing near base and other plant, lichen, and moss life visible on tree surface, located beside large western hemlock (circ. breast height 2.92m) and large Engleman spruce (BCBT # 1378), within grove of large, old trees and giant Devil's Club.  Bark has lots of gaps and spaces for bats and various species.

access_notes: Heading west from Creston on Highway 3 a parking lot on the right, just before the Summit Creek bridge is the starting point.
tree_site_notes: The Kootenay River has flooded these lowlands repeatedly over the lifespan of these big cedars that now languish in the well maintained grasses of a once established campground. The tree is estimated to be over 800 years.

access_notes: In the forest below the Island Lake access road
Travel Akokalyx FSR to 12.5 km then turn south on Crawford FSR. 1.5 km on south side of road at small pullout. walk in 20 m.
tree_site_notes: Straight very slightly slanted tree with some twisted branch turreting midway up. Flat area to gently S facing sloped area 50 m from Akokalyx river. Very lush with large Devil's Club. Small remnant grove (<1 hectare) between fsr and river. Road less than 20 m away. Largest cedar in a grove of 8 other significant western red cedar (above 1.5 m) within 50m including a set of twins over 2m dbh each.

access_notes: Island Lake Access Road then follow creek downstream
Island Lake Access Road then follow creek downstream

From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1.  As you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the spur road is overgrown and not safe to drive a regular vehicle, so it's best to park at the junction and walk up to the areas of big trees. It is only about 850 m up the spur road until one of the massive tree shows up on the left side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree assessed to be in healthy condition. Tree splits into two trunks about 10m up the base of the tree. The tree stands on a gentle slope. The tree is located in an old growth Interior Cedar Hemlock ecosystem.  Plentiful fungi, ferns, and Devil's Club in the surrounding area, along with several other big trees.

access_notes: Old Growth Trail - Cedar Valley.  Drive up Mount Fernie Park Rd from Highway #3 to trailhead parking lot. Tree is located between the trail and the Island Lake Road.
From Highway 3, when travelling west from Creston over Kootenay Pass, a parking area on the left just before the avalanche road closure gate is the trailhead.
tree_site_notes: The tree in Ralph’s Grove is just one of many amazing trees nestled in the sheltered hollow of Summit Creek. This tree stands out, as it is definitely the largest cedar that is visible from the trail.

access_notes: An abandoned trail leads down below the lodge, through heavy windfall, and devil's club
Old Growth Trail - Cedar Valley.  Drive up Mount Fernie Park Rd from Highway #3 to trailhead parking lot. Tree is located between the trail and the Island Lake Road.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a dead top.

access_notes: Drive north from Rossland on Highway 3B to Biathlon Trailhead. Mxi?p Xewílh (Cedar Trail) begins on opposite side of highway.

Driving Directions:From Bull River, travel north on the Wardner Fort Steele Road. Turn east on Bull River Road. In 8.5km the road intersects with Bull River FSR. Turn left (northeast) on Bull River FSR. The trailhead is approximately 10km from this junction, on the left, at a pullout just past the Dibble Cr bridge.  The trail follows a deactivated road for about 3km.  Then steeper single track for 1km to a tributary and the old growth cedar stands starting at about 1260m elev. along the east side of the creek.  The measured cedar is at about 5km, above the trail, just before the first slide path.
tree_site_notes: The measured tree is touching another large cedar at the base.  Both trees have forked stems at 3-5m.  The fork on the measured tree is dead.  This patch of trees contains several cedars in the 150-170cm range. This cedar old growth is, for now, fed by Dibble Glacier and is quite unique in the East Kootenay area.

access_notes: Sensitive area - exact location is hidden.
Island Lake Access Road then follow creek downstream
Follow Gorby Trail in Mount Fernie Provincial Park, turn right onto Verboten Trail, climb steeply into upper reaches of trail.
tree_site_notes: In impressive cedar grove dotted with many very large western larch

access_notes: From Valemount, drive south towards Blue River for 46 km. Take exit to Gosnell Road, then turn left onto North Thompson FSR. In winter, a snowmobile is required to access the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree has an old broken top. Healthy otherwise. There is flagging in the area which could indicate a riparian management area, or future logging. The site is a riparian zone right beside a small creek with devils club, hybrid spruce and hemlock. ICH BEC zone.

access_notes: An abandoned trail leads down below the lodge, through heavy windfall, and devil's club
Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow trail past Cabin Ridge junction. Descend down towards Lizard Creek.
tree_site_notes: An area providing perfect conditions for nurturing giant cedars.

access_notes: Turn off Highway #3 onto Mount Fernie Park Road. Drive to Old Growth Trail parking lot, follow trail past Cabin Ridge junction. Descend down towards Lizard Creek.
tree_site_notes: An area providing perfect conditions for nurturing giant cedars.

access_notes: Island Lake Access Road then follow creek downstream

From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1.  As you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the spur road is overgrown and not safe to drive a regular vehicle, so it's best to park at the junction and walk up to the areas of big trees. It is only about 850 m up the spur road until one of the massive tree shows up on the left side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree assessed to be in healthy condition. Tree is located on a steep slope. The tree is located in an old growth Interior Cedar Hemlock ecosystem. Devil's Club was abundant in the surrounding area. Several other big trees nearby, lots of rattlesnake plantain. Top 6-8 meters of tree is bare with no branches, like a pointy spire. Potential caribou scat found at base of tree.

access_notes: Sensitive area - exact location is hidden.

Driving from Kimberley, take the St. Mary's Lake Rd, which eventually turns into the St. Mary's River Rd after the lake is passed. Continue following the St. Mary's River Rd past the Redding Creek Rd. The tree is about 150m before Pyramid Creek on the North side of the road. The tall candelabra top of the tree should be noticeable, along with 3 others in close proximity.
tree_site_notes: Dead candelabra top. No noticeable damage to the tree, but it is leaning slightly.

access_notes: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1.  As you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the spur road is overgrown and not safe to drive a regular vehicle, so it's best to park at the junction and walk up to the areas of big trees. It is only about 850 m up the spur road until one of the massive tree shows up on the left side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree assessed to be in healthy condition. Tree is split into two about 7-9m up the tree trunk, and looks like one of the trunks that split off broke off some years ago. The tree is located in an old growth Interior Cedar Hemlock ecosystem, about 20m N of river edge. Several other big trees nearby, largely red osier dogwood, fern species, alder, and horsetail. Recent claw marks seen on the bark.

access_notes: Turn from Highway 16 onto Walker Creek FSR. After crossing bridge over the Fraser River turn right onto POB FSR - Grove begins at approx. 8 km.
Drive to end of road at Clearwater Lake. Trailhead is at the very last campground and is not very well marked.
Drive south from Fernie on Cokato Road. Turn left onto Thompson Road, follow to end, then walk down beside lagoon chainlink fence into forest.
tree_site_notes: Some 1 m plus diameter cedars are aged in the 250 year old range.

access_notes: Drive uphill (south) from Nelson on Highway 3B, look for a turn off to the right. Follow the steep and rough road  approx. 14 km along Giveout Creek FSR. Look for signage for the Farily High Trail, walk uphill to join onto Very High Trail.
tree_site_notes: OGMA in any otherwise heavily harvested timber supply area. Tree has a lean.

access_notes: The trail is accessed from the 2nd Island Lake parking lot in summer. Follow the Old Growth Trail to the Cabin Ridge junction (signed). Trail descends down to Lizard Creek, where a sometimes tenuous crossing is required. This big Cedar is just up the trail aways, but not right beside the trail.
tree_site_notes: Located right beside the trail, with a big burl overhanging you as you pass by, it is difficult to miss. The added Grizzly handle is because this game trail is the grizzly bears path when it traverses from Hunter Bowl to Cabin Bowl.

access_notes: Orca Road is an old skid trail that traverses at the base of the Lizard Range. A bridge crossing Lizard Creek, just upstream of the sawdust pile meadow in Cedar Valley is the trailhead. This tree is located on the downside of the road about 750 m after crossing the creek.
tree_site_notes: The Whale is a massive beast. With its wall of wood confronting you in the dark ocean of this forest. It gets its name from the Orca Rock peak whose fin sticks out of the sea of powder above, and is visible on the many horizons of the Lizard Range.

access_notes:
From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak.                  the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak. 

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.

Hike down the trail almost to the end. To get to the tree requires about 30m of bushwacking from the trail.
tree_site_notes: Found in a wet ancient forest in the ICH BEC zone, this tree was the second largest in the grove. Surrounded by devils club and ferns.

access_notes:
From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak.                  the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak. 

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.

Hike down the trail almost to the end. To get to the tree requires about 20m of bushwacking from the trail.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in ICH BEC zone in wet ancient forest. Devils club and ferns surround tree. This is the largest tree in the grove on a bench above the river.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone. The tree is healthy with abundant "wolf-tree" (downward sweeping) branches in the lower canopy. The broken top is consistent with nearly all the old trees on this site.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone. The tree is healthy with abundant "wolf-tree" (downward sweeping) branches in the lower canopy. The broken top is consistent with nearly all the old trees on this site.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone. The west side of the trunk is decaying with the bark flaking off near the ground.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone.

access_notes: Drive east 110 km (ca. 1 hour) from Prince George to the Ancient Forest/Chun T'oh Whudujut Provincial Park trail parking lot (marking with highway pullout signs). From the Ancient Forest trail pullout drive west 5 km to the entry site for the Ministry of Transport quarry, found on the south side of the road (look for locked gate on access road).  Park on the roadside or on the edge of the quarry pull-off and hike up the old Driscoll Ridge trail. The trail is heavily overgrown with Devil's Club and alder, watch for the red trail markers on trees (the old trail route also shows on most GPS map apps).  If the lower quarry site is active access on the old Driscoll Ridge trail is not allowed.
tree_site_notes: The stand is located on level mid-slope bench on the north face of Driscoll Ridge. Trees are growing on a wet site with ground vegetation dominated by Devil's Club, located in the ICHvk2 biogeoclimatic zone.  The tree has a noticeable line of burls ca 2 m off the ground extending across the north side of the tree.

access_notes: From Valemount, drive south towards Blue River for 46 km. Take exit to Gosnell Road, then turn left onto North Thompson FSR. In winter, a snowmobile is required to access the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy. Largest in grove of cedars.

access_notes: From Golden BC drive west 45 km on TransCanada Highway 1.  As you start to climb up from the Columbia River bridge crossing, keep an eye to the right for a sign that says Kinbasket Lake Resort, turn off of the highway here. The rough gravel road (Columbia West FSR) descends steeply down to where the Resort is situated at the Beaver River bridge crossing. Set your odometer to “0” here. Drive 58.7 km to where the Smith Creek drainage crosses the road. At this switchback, the spur road is overgrown and not safe to drive a regular vehicle, so it's best to park at the junction and walk up to the areas of big trees. It is only about 850 m up the spur road until one of the massive tree shows up on the left side of the road.
tree_site_notes: Tree assessed to be in healthy condition. Tree is leaning at an angle and the base of the trunk is on a moderate slope. The tree trunk is covered in mosses and lichens.  A burl is located on the SE side.  The tree is located in an old growth Interior Cedar Hemlock ecosystem.  Plentiful fungi and Devil's Club in the surrounding area.

access_notes: Drive 7 km north on Inland Lake Rd. (see provincial park signage) from Haslam St in Powell River.
tree_site_notes: Tree could easily be mistaken for a Sitka if not for the littering of large cones on the ground.

access_notes: NE of Lillooet River/Job Creek. Several hundred metres west of unnamed waterfall.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. River valley. CWHms1.

access_notes: In Bowser at the junction of Highway 19A and McCaul Road. Drive 2.4Km up McColl Rd to the Cable Trail pullout. Walk 730 east along the Cable Trail. Tree is situated adjacent to the trail on the left.
tree_site_notes: Tree is healthy, growing in a fairly wet site. It has western redcedar adjoining the stem. The tree is named 70s Cable Guy as it growing on the Cable Trail and all three nominators are retired foresters in their 70th year of life!

access_notes: NE of Lillooet River/Job Creek.
tree_site_notes: Healthy. River valley, ridge. CWHms1

access_notes: Tahsis Highway
tree_site_notes: 175 yrs old; seemed to be an isolated representation of this species at this location.

access_notes: Crossley Rd - Bowser
tree_site_notes: Double top.

access_notes: Boat access only. Drive up the Nahatlatch River and park near the first lake (Frances Lake). Paddle to a flat of land on the opposite side of the lake and hike to the tree, as per coordinates.
2.5 km WSW of Victoria Peak.
tree_site_notes: Healthy with broken top. MHmm1.

access_notes: Tree is visible from Risa Main at the edge of a cutblock. It stands well proud of the surrounding forest. Park at the creek crossing and hike down the old growth.
tree_site_notes: Tree is on an open slope near the edge of a cutblock but is very healthy and vigourous, standing much taller than the surrounding stand. The surrounding forest is a very species rich assemblage of montane and subalpine species, with predominantly blueberry shrub layer.

This white pine stands proud of the surrounding forest, composed almost entirely of late-successional redcedar, hemlock, and amabilis fir. It is notable not only for its size but its extreme rarity in the landscape. This tree, along with a couple scattered Doug-firs, suggests that a relatively powerful disturbance hit this particular stand within the last few hundred years, opening up the forest floor to pioneer species. The size and crown structure of this single remaining pine suggests that it is quite old for the species.

access_notes: Tree is visible from Highway 4, in a small retention patch of an area that has been cleared for development. Pull over at the barricaded entrace to the new road and hike up to the tree.
tree_site_notes: Tree is in a small leave patch with a rocky outcropping to the east and a new elevated road grade to the west. Not in excellent health, but hopefully will survive the land use change around it. Tree is sunk down into roadbuilding debris that makes it difficult to measure DBH. Poor to moderate site productivity based on the few shrubs around.

access_notes: Tree is about 6 km upstream from the mouth of the Wolf River on the SE bank.
tree_site_notes: Healthy.
MHmm1 05

access_notes: The Sugar Lake FSR heads out of Cherryville extending along the lake, past Monashee Provincial Park to the east, passes the Upper Shuswap River Ecological Reserve (42 km marker), then comes to a junction of the Blanket FSR to the right. Turn onto Blanket FSR. The road climbs up above Greenbush Lake, and the tree is just below the road after the  first switchback.
tree_site_notes: This tree stands out amongst the surrounding forest. Both the height, and shadowy girth are very impressive. The tree had a blue "O" spray painted on the trunk. This mark indicated that I was not the first person to visit this tree. The follow up search revealed that a forester with Tolko had marked this tree 12 years earlier.  LiDar imagery provided by Tolko (available if requested) showed this tree poking out of the data.

access_notes: Located adjacent to a clearcut on the Upper Boards Creek FSR. Visible from landing.
tree_site_notes: 4 m dead top spire

access_notes: Approximately 35km on the East Canoe FSR.  East of Valemount, turn left into a small unmarked road and follow it nearly to the end 3.75km, will need to hike or use ATV for the last 0.5km.
tree_site_notes: Several large and old forks, one mostly dead top, a large scar at the north side with exposed decaying wood and loose bark, south facing slope, 20%, ICHmm-01, leave tree in a recently logged cutblock.

access_notes: The trail access turn-off from Highway #3B is 13.8 km. towards Nancy Greene / Strawberry Summit from the Rossland, Washington Street / Highway junction. A post mounted solar panel on your right is your indicator to begin slowing down, where the Murphy Creek FSR is next on your right. A large timber frame sign, lets you know you are in the right location. Following the road a short distance, take the right turn at the fork where after about 500 m. through a recent approx. 20 year old cutblock, is the trailhead parking area.
tree_site_notes: Very healthy looking tree, with evidence of a strong cone crop being dispersed around the trees base. No signs of dead/blister rust affected trees in the vicinity. This small reserve is basically surrounded by logging blocks.

access_notes: From Revelstoke take Highway 1 West.  At the junction 500m from west end of Revelstoke, turn north. Travel 6.5 km to Frisby FSR. Follow Frisby FSR North for 20k and take the west spur.  Go up the spur for 14 km. Walk 400m downhill off of the road,  initially through the 20 year old clearcut.
tree_site_notes: Tree is slanted approx 5%. Split top high up with one side of canopy very limited. Located in Cedar/Hemlock grove with 20+ 1-2.5 m DBH western red cedar. High productivity, moisture collecting flat area near creek, devil's club, western yew, wild ginger, ferns on overall E facing moderate mid slope. Just within planned cutblock boundary.

access_notes: Headwaters of the Shuswap River.
tree_site_notes: Healthy, dead top. ICHvk1

access_notes: Follow the signage from Nakusp to the Kuskanax Creek Hot Springs. From the parking lot a well signed trail to the creek and then a left at the wye to Kimbol Lake . Climbing up past the old hot springs source to a rest bench, the western white pine is on the slope down towards the creek, and visible from the bench.
tree_site_notes: Western white pines, with their towering trunks, special elongated cones, and soft needles, I would describe as a friendly tree. This particular tree is no different. Special in every way.

access_notes: Larch Hills Nordic area is accessed from the Grandview Bench Road, and then follow signage up gravel roads for 8 km to the day lodge. A further 5 km up the Larch Hills FSR, and you will come to the White Pine Walk. A nice loop through some boggy ground with a great selection of big trees to ogle over. The big western white pine is a short distance in on this trail.
tree_site_notes: When you see a western white pine of this magnitude it goes off the Richter scale. Towering straight up into the forest canopy, this tree is winning the reach for the light game.

access_notes: Cai Creek ATV Trail from Highway 3 east of Castlegar.
Cai Creek ATV Trail from Highway 3 east of Castlegar.
tree_site_notes: Tree has a broken top

access_notes:
From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak.                  the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow instructions for "Goat River Canyon Trail" on Trailpeak. 

The trail is accessed by an old road on the south side of Highway 16, 1/2km before the Goat River bridge and rest area. The old road is easily missed by those driving on Highway 16, because of the steep drop it takes off the highway. If you do not have a 4-WD vehicle, it is best to park at the Goat River rest area and walk west on the south side of Highway 16 to spot the rough access road. If you drive down the old road, there is a small clearing a short ways down with room to park.The hike initially follows the old road. You will cross a rough wooden bridge over a creek. Shortly afterwards, you will reach a fork in the road where the right side is very overgrown. Take the left fork. A short distance after this, there is a second fork in the road, where an ATV trail continues to the right and the left side appears less worn-in. At this second fork, follow the left (less worn-in) side. After a minute or so, take the trail on the left leading away from the old road and into the forest (it should be flagged). From here, the trail is easy to follow. You will stay on the plateau before crossing a stream and descending towards the canyon. After the stream is where the very old trees are located.GPS Coordinates:- Old road off Highway 16: 53.4924063, -120.6176087- Goat River Canyon (trail end point, for reference, to ensure one is hiking in the correct direction): 53.4772961, -120.6406700.

Hike down the trail almost to the end. To get to the tree requires about 150m of bushwacking from the trail.
tree_site_notes: Given this tree's geographic location, low elevation, and indentifiable features (see photos of cones), it is most likely a white spruce (Picea glauca). Engelmann spruce is found at higher elevations in this region though hybridization is possible. This tree is found on a slope just above a wet area containing large western red cedars in the Interior Cedar Hemlock BEC zone. The tree is healthy with no broken top or obvious signs of rot. Aspect is roughly south though I forgot to take a reading. Surrounding vegetation includes Ribes, devil's club, queen's cup, western hemlock, and western red-cedar.

access_notes: From Crescent Spur, drive south on Loos Road towards Highway 16. Turn left on Highway 16 and drive southeast for 8.9 km towards the Goat River bridge. Just before the highway bridge over the Goat River, park on the left (north) side of the highway at the Goat River Rest Area. From the rest area, follow the National Hiking Trail / Lower Goat River Trail - Crescent Spur Section up and away from the river. There is a large brown sign marking the start of the trail. Hike up the trail for about 500m until you reach the flat bench above the river. The tree is almost immediately on the left side of the trail after reaching the bench.
tree_site_notes: Given this tree's geographic location, low elevation, and indentifiable features (see photos of cones), it is most likely a white spruce (Picea glauca). Engelmann spruce is found at higher elevations in this region though hybridization is possible. This tree is found on a bench above the Goat River containing western red cedars and western hemlock in the Interior Cedar Hemlock BEC zone. The tree is healthy with no broken top or obvious signs of rot. Surrounding vegetation includes Ribes, devil's club, queen's cup, western hemlock, and western red-cedar.

access_notes: West fork of Lakes Creek, Stein River valley. Two day cross country hike from end of Kwoiek Creek logging roads, or long day cross country hike from Stein Vally trail at upper cable crossing.
tree_site_notes: Westnorthwest aspect, 40-45% slope, midslope, straight (upper mesoslope, convex). Alpine tundra.

access_notes: From Sphinx Bay on Garibaldi Lake, hike south to hanging valley NNW of Guard Mountain. Tree is on knoll at lower end of valley.
tree_site_notes: Crest of knoll, straight site surface, wind and frost exposure. MHmm2.

access_notes:
The site can be accessed by driving east on Highway #3 from the Highway #43 traffic lights in Sparwood for 11km. to the Coal Mountain /Michel Creek Road. This paved road continues for 22.6 km. to the Coal Mountain mine gate, where the Flathead FSR to the right leads to the next right turn-off at 4.4 km.. A new logging road and bridge have been built crossing Michel Creek, where you can either begin walking here, or continue on a very rough road for 800 m. to the trailhead. The unmarked old road on the west side of the landing is your route. After hiking for 2.5 km. you will come to an intersection. The left trail/road leads to Barnes Lake, while the right road climbs steeply up to Elliot Lake. If heading to Barnes Lake the trail continues for an additional 1.3 km. following along a beautiful alpine meadow, to where you will arrive at the south campsite.
The Whitebark Pine that was sampled, is located just beside the campsite.
tree_site_notes: Many dead standing whitebark pines in this vicinity. Likely blister rust casualties. The remaining live trees appear to be somewhat healthy. Cores from tree were solid to the center. Trees estimated age is 350 years old. +/- 50 yrs.

access_notes: This tree was located near Crystal Lake in North Tweedsmuir Provincial Park. To access the site requires a 1 hour float plane ride from Burns Lake BC, followed by a 1 hour power boat trip to the north end of Tesla lake. This site required a 1 km hike from the shore of the lake.
tree_site_notes: This whitebark pine was living and had no signs of blister rust, ips, blue stain fungus or mountain pine beetle present. It was a single stem and dominant in the canopy with 5-6 other whitebark pine trees in good health. A bear was using the base of one of the trees as a wallow and a squirrel midden were also present in this dominant cohort. It was situated in a productive toe slope near a riparian area in a cool and moist site with strong coastal influences. Four increment cores were taken with a haglof borer to determine the age of the tree. The 24 inch increment borer was not long enough to obtain the exact age of the tree. The minimum age of the tree (as determined through tree ring measurements of the four samples) is 459 years (1561-2020). Pith estimates could not be used to estimate the location of the centre of the tree as no ring curvature was present. The absence of ring curvature, DBH of the tree, and calculation of years to reach coring height suggest that this tree is between 600-800 years in age. The tree is estimated to be 20m tall with a basal DBH of 0.9m.

access_notes: Between White R. and Adam R., north of Tlowils Lake; south of Sayward.
tree_site_notes: Old tree with a dead top.  Tree is growing out of an old snag making it impossible to get an accurate measurement at 1.37m from the ground. Dbh is estimated at 3.69, but the more representative measure is 3.26 taken at 1.8m from the ground at midslope.

access_notes: 1 km NE of Lyon Lake. From Halfmoon Bay at Hwy 101, take logging road north to 1 km N of Lyon Lake. Hike east, past small lake in basin at 3050', over 3300' shoulder. Descend east slope to about 3100', angling slightly left. Tree is near edge of clearcut at about 3100'. Tree #2 - at about 3000' on east slope.
tree_site_notes: Midslope, toe mesoslope, aspect east. CWHvm2, montane.

access_notes: Tree is located above Road M31, Memekay River. Access is off Memekay-Salmon hookup. MacMillan Bloedel Menzies Bay Division.
tree_site_notes: This one of the largest known yellow-cedars.  Straight cylindrical bole, single stem, ‘stovepipe form,’ large burl on up slope side of base of trunk.  Mid-slope on mountainside, CWHmm1, montane.

access_notes: White River "A Branch" (A600).
tree_site_notes: Broken, dead top. Tree is leaning ~15, 110 east. Located 10 m from edge of Wildlife Tree patch.

access_notes: Head of west branch of Bigtree Creek. Follow Venus Main to head of west branch of Bigtree Creek. Tree is above and east of the end of Road V20 at 810 m elevation.
tree_site_notes:
Tree has a large burl at the base, and appears to be two stems that fused together at an early age.  In 1991 the double stem, ring count age = 789 years in 36.5 cm core, 80 years in outer 1.2 cm: estimated total age = 1500-2000 years.    Hole in base of trunk, and rotten wood sample taken at 4 m from centre of tree for Carbon 14 dating. 

Mid-slope on southern aspect mountainside. Near upper edge of clearcut; possible windthrow risk. CWHmm2, montane.

access_notes: Drove South and West on Port Main 9km from Port Clements.  Merged with QC mainline at 9km and continued South to 29 km.  Entered Canyon Main and continued East for 2km and Turned South on Drill Main.  Drove South to merger with OCM-19 and folowed South and then East for approximately 7.5 km and parked at the North edge of cutblock labelled  HG492251.  (The cutblock and road are part of Mosaic Forest Management private land holdings but there is no restrictions or gates deterring recreational access.)  From Parking spot walked East at 91 degree for 670 meters to tree.  There is also a 2m + dbh yellow cedar just upslope.
tree_site_notes: Live tree, Broken or broomed off top.  Some burls typical of YC.  Edge of the CWHwh1 and CWHwh2 BEC zones in the Skidegate Plateau of Haida Gwaii. Mid to upper slope. Slope was 25% to 30%. SMR 4 and SNR C.  Aspect 210 degree.
CWHvm2 10

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Good health. Broken top. Active bear den

access_notes: Follow Baden Powell Trail from Cypress Bowl downhill ski area towards Hollyburn Mountain. Climb rough trail east of Cypress Creek tributary to junction with old Strachan Trail. Tree is approximately 30 m ESE of junction.
tree_site_notes: A huge, hulking, but broken tree.  A 63 cm increment core taken in 1992 revealed 498 annual growth rings.  Mountain hemlock-Amabilis fir-Twisted stalk site association. West aspect, 30% slope, mid-slope bench, concave (toe mesoslope). MHmm1,montane.

access_notes: Labyrithine and poorly signed forest roads. Do not recommend attempting to locate without a georeferenced map of forest roads. Turn off from Hwy 19 onto Adam Main. Continue onto AR103A. Turn right on M2262. Turn left onto M2260. Turn left onto M2000. Turn right on M2460. Turn right onto M2462A. Turn left on M2462A1 and follow to end. Tree is obvious just into the timber.
tree_site_notes: Massive, ancient cypress with a gnarly broken top. In a stand of unifrm younger amabilis and hemlock, clearly the only tree standing after windthrow ~80-100 years ago. Little understory. Unclear if there has been massive amount of sedimentation on the upslope side or excavation on the downslope side, but the lower side of the tree is approximately 3-4m below the upper side. Lower side is deeply excavated. Recent hemlock blowndown onto the stem. Very near forest edge.

access_notes: One km NE of Lyon Lake. From Halfmoon Bay at Hwy 101, take logging road north to 1 km N of Lyon Lake. Hike east, past small lake in basin at 3050', over 3300' shoulder. Descend east slope to about 3100', angling slightly left. Tree is near edge of clearcut at about 3100'. Tree #2 - at about 3000' on east slope.
tree_site_notes: Midslope, toe mesoslope, aspect east. CWHvm2, montane.  Unable to relocate during revisit in 1998 by R. Van Pelt. Found in 2024 by M. Bailey, DBH and crown measurements had not changed, unable to measure height.

access_notes: Fromme Ridge in Lynn Headwaters Regional Park.
On the west fork of Kowus Creek.  A 4-5 day cross-country hike from Clayoquot Sound or Buttle Lake.
tree_site_notes: South aspect, approximately 75% slope, middle slope (macro), upper slope (meso), convex. Other large (1.5-2 m DBH) specimens in vicinity. MHmm1, montane.

access_notes: Access is a steep climb up from Marion Creek FSR through old growth (approximately one hour climb) on very steep and broken terrain.
tree_site_notes: CWHvm2

access_notes: Follow Lynn Headwaters Trail to Norvan Creek, then hike up Norvan Creek Trail. Tree is above trail, east of large avalanche chute below "The Needles" at approximately 700 m elevation.
tree_site_notes: Lower mesoslope, toe macroslope, aspect northwest. CWHvm2, montane.

access_notes: Access is a steep climb up from Marion Creek FSR through old growth (approximately one hour climb) on very steep and broken terrain.
tree_site_notes: CWHvm2.  When first measured in 2008 by Hans Roemer, this tree was the tallest on record at 60.5m. The top has since broken.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Good health. Broken top
CWHvm2 04

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Good health. Broken top

access_notes: West side of Cypress Parkway near cross-country ski area turn-off.
tree_site_notes: This is one of largest known yellow-cedars.  One meter increment core taken in 1986 has 1,110 annual rings, total age ±1,200 years (core at Forintek Canada Corp.).  Road fill was found against the trunk.  Aspect WSW, slope approx. 75% middle slope, mid-macro slope, upper mesoslope, Hm-Ba-twisted stalk site association, CWHvm2, montane.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Good health. Active bear den

access_notes: Drive west from Campbell River on Gold River Highway. Continue south along Western Mine Road down Buttle Lake. Turn left on Jim Mitchell Lake Road. Hike up Bedwell Lake Trail.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Fair health. Shatterd top. Several live large lateral limbs. Elevation 761m

access_notes: Take Hiway 4 west from Port Alberni. Drive approximately 80km to the Maggie Lake FSR. Turn left and follow Maggie FSR for 11km to Macoah Villagfe turn-off. Keep left on Maggie FSR and drive another 4km to the end of Maggie FSR. Keep left and you are now on Toquaht FSR. Drive 9km to the junction with Lucky FSR. Turn right onto Lucky FSR and drive 2.5km to the junction with Black Peaks FSR. Keep left and follow Lucky FSR for another 2.4km. You will pass two lakes on your right. The second (and larger lake is Kite Lake). Once past Kite Lake, you will come to a major junction. Keep right and continue along Lucky FSR for another 1.4km. there will be a deactivated and brushed in spur road on your right. This is the start of teh rough trail up to Block F004C4DT. Hike up the spur for 700m to a very overgorwn junction. Keep to the left and hike a further 450 m. You will come across some yellow flagging that indicates a rough trail up to F004C4DT. The trail heads upslope from the spur road and is heavy going through an advanced plantation for approximately 150m. Once you reach the Old-growth it is easy but steep hiking. From the end of the flagged trail, continue up slope heading directly south for approximately 170m until you reach the upper falling boundary. The Amabilis fir (5 trees) will be visible both ahead of you and slightly to the right. To reach Cypress, continue angling upslope in a southeasterly direction along the base of the steep rock outcops. You will find C4DT-002 after hiking/climbing for 350m. Tree C4DT is approximately 145m above the first Cypress. Follow the rock bluff uphill (keeping the gully to your left). C4DT-001 is approximately 150m upslope and is situated on a rock knob in a nice open area of timber.
tree_site_notes: C4DT-001 is located in CWHvm2(09) on a steep (60%) mid-slope with a northeast aspect. The tree is growing on a small rocky knoll surrounded by medium colluvium.

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld
tree_site_notes: Good health. Situated on steam edge

access_notes: Sensitive ecosystem - exact location withheld

tree_site_notes: C4DT-002 is located in the CWHvm2(01)situated on a small bench situated mid-slope and adjacent to a deep gully system. Slope has a NE aspect.

access_notes: Drive west from Campbell River on Gold River Highway. Continue south along Western Mine Road down Buttle Lake. Turn left on Jim Mitchell Lake Road. Hike up Bedwell Lake Trail.

4x4 with good clearance required!  From Halfmoon Bay head east towards Trout Lake Road. Head north up Trout Lake Road. Around 5.5km, turn east (right) on Carlson Mainline towards Carlson Lake. At around 1.5km turn east (right) and head up an old, washed out road between 2 cut blocks. Follow this road for about 1.3km until you reach a fork. Take the road on the left that heads north up towards Spipiyus Provincial Park. Stay on this road for about 4.5km before reaching a 4 way. Turn right (east) and consider parking before the next cross ditch between the 2 small lakes. Enter the forest on the other side of this cross ditch. The tree is up on a little raised area with a small slope down to another small lake on the east side of it.
tree_site_notes: This tree is in excellent condition, other than having lost much of its upper crown quite some time ago. I remain convinced that this region warrants thorough exploration, as we were able to view other trees of similar size in this grove. Not far from this specimen are the remnants of the largest cedar we found, easily over 2.00 metres in diameter, I estimated. It’s not unusual for yellow cedars such as these to be at least 1000 years old, and some are much older. Wildlife values for this area are exceptionally high, and the forest is regularly frequented by elk and black bear.
